title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: speaker
text:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If everyone thinks you're worthless, then maybe you need to find new people to hang out with.Seriously, the social context in which a person lives is a big influence in self-esteem.Otherwise, you can go round and round trying to understand why you're not worthless, then go back to the same crowd and be knocked down again.There are many inspirational messages you can find in social media.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Maybe read some of the ones which state that no person is worthless, and that everyone has a good purpose to their life.Also, since our culture is so saturated with the belief that if someone doesn't feel good about themselves that this is somehow terrible.Bad feelings are part of living.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: They are the motivation to remove ourselves from situations and relationships which do us more harm than good.Bad feelings do feel terrible.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Your feeling of worthlessness may be good in the sense of motivating you to find out that you are much better than your feelings today.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?

text:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Therapy is essential for those that are feeling depressed and worthless.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: When I work with those that are experiencing concerns related to feeling of depression and issues with self esteem.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I generally work with my client to help build coping skills to reduce level of depression and to assist with strengthening  self esteem, by guiding my client with CBT practices.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: CBT helps with gaining a better awareness of how your thought process influences your belief system, and how your beliefs impact your actions and the outcome of your behaviors.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: This process isn’t easy but it helps teach an individual that we don’t always have control over what happens in our lives but we can control how we interpret, feel, and behave.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: CBT is good for individuals dealing with depression, anxiety, toxic relationships, stress, self esteem, codependency, etc.

author: listener
text: I first want to let you know that you are not alone in your feelings and there is always someone there to help.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: You can always change your feelings and change your way of thinking by being open to trying to change.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: You can always make yourself available to learning new things or volunteering so that you can make a purpose for yourself.

author: listener
text: You are exhibiting some specific traits of a particular temperament type.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Seek out a counselor who provides NCCA temperament therapy and discover the joy of being you -- God loves you as you are!

author: listener
text: It sounds like you may be putting yourself last.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: You wrote that you want to fix your issues but never get around to it.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I wonder how you are spending your mental and physical energy.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Are you spending time taking care of and doing for others?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I also wonder where the thoughts and feelings of being worthless are coming from - are you around people who treat you poorly or are hurtful?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Or do you feel it is more of a worry you have but aren't really sure how others feel?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: It may be helpful to talk to someone about your feelings - a counselor perhaps - to clarify your feelings and move forward from se that are hurting you.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?

text:

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you may be struggling with depression.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Depression can make you feel overwhelmed and paralyzed to change.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I would suggest that you connect with a provider who can help you get to the root of where the worthlessness is coming from and help you develop a plan for recovery.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: In the meantime, small steps can go a long way.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Self-care interventions such as journaling your feelings, mindfulness meditation, and regular exercise are all helpful to reconnecting with the present moment and gaining internal motivation.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Focusing on one day at a time and bringing your thoughts back to the present can also be beneficial.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: There is hope!

text:

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I'm glad you are interested in changing your feelings of worthlessness.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Visiting your doctor is a great first step to address your lack of sleep.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: First, you want to make sure that you are physically healthy and that there isn't a physical condition causing your problem with sleep.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Changing your feelings is something that is difficult to do, especially on your own.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Make sure that you have someone you can trust and you can talk to about how you feel.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: This can be a friend or a family member.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If you find that there isn't anyone you would feel comfortable talking to about this issue, find a therapist close to you who can help.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: One activity that people have found helpful in feeling better about themselves is keeping a gratitude journal.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: You can do this by journaling daily about the things that you are grateful for.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: There is no right or wrong way of doing this, as long as you focus your journal entries on the things you are grateful for in life.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: speaker
text:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Oftentimes we can change our feelings about ourselves by building a better relationship with ourself.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: It sounds like there is a very critical aspect of your self that is alive and taking over.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Sometimes when we are stuck it is because a part of ourselves, a way that perhaps we learned to cope with difficult situations earlier in our lives, has decided to run the show.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Like a highly critical part that may actually be desperately attempting to protect us from a past hurt.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Slowing down and even forming a relationship with this critical internal part will help you get some space from it.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: When we can begin to observe parts of ourselves, be curious about them, get to know them like a new friend, then we have room for other ways of being.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Beginning therapy could be a great way to change this feeling of worthlessness.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Beginning to build a better relationship and understanding of yourself will deeply influence the relationships around you.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: This first step may feel hard, to reach out to someone, and it could be the beginning step to a path of radically shifting your relationship with yourself and others in your life.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: speaker
text:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Feelings of worthlessness often originate  from what you learned about yourself when you were young.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Improving your self esteem needs focus on that original message from parents, teachers or siblings that may be suppressed.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Most of us need help to uncover the "lie" because you were born valuable!

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: speaker
text:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.
   How can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: The feeling of being worthless is caused by your inside being not matching your outside result.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Your comparison to others and you thinking you need to be someone other than who you are.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: You are not worthless.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: No one is worthless.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: You need to find your worth and not let yourself talk yourself out of the good you find in yourself.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I hope these words resonate with you and that you start looking for your worth even if it’s as simple as I am able to get out of bed and call someone and make a joke.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: speaker
text:
I'm going through some things with my feelings and myself. I barely sleep and I do nothing but think about how I'm worthless and how I shouldn't be here.
   I've never tried or contemplated suicide. I've always wanted to fix my issues, but I never get around to it.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Hi there, I'm sorry you're feeling this way.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Let me see if I can guide you in the right direction.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Often when I talk to my clients about feelings of worthlessness we start with a little bit of self-exploration.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: We start with noticing.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Start to notice when these feelings come up for you.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text:
Is there a particular time
of day, a specific person who brings it out, a phrase you hear?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text:
Just
start to notice.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Usually it's tied to something but it may take a while to figure out what that something/someone is.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Try to be patient.Next we start to explore.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: When did these feelings start?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Where do you think they come from?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Is there something - a statement - perhaps that repeats in your head over and over again?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If so, whose voice is it?

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: These are difficult questions, and just a few of them, so take your time answering them.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: (We usually do it over a few sessions.)

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: It might even be helpful to write them down somewhere.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If you have a journal that would be a great place as research has shown that our brain works differently when we put pen to paper versus typing on a computer.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Now comes the good news.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Our brains are able to rewire themselves.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: This allows us to change habits we don't want as well as statements we say to ourselves that are no longer serving us.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: The next step is to select an ally.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Someone who is or has been in your corner, someone who is always rooting for you.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If you don't have someone like that, that's ok - a lot of us don't - you can just make someone up.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Close your eyes and try to describe that person in great detail from the way they look to the way they act to the way they sound.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Now, pick a phrase you would like that person to say to you whenever you start to think that you're worthless.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Something that will help you feel better about yourself - a characteristic, a skill, a great joke you tell, a physical attribute.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: This also takes time and may involve you asking for help from someone who knows you.Once you have all of that together - the noticing, answers from where these feelings and statement(s) come from, your ally, your new statement, you can try to put it altogether.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: When the feelings come up, notice what is bringing them up and then call upon your ally to try to change the statement in your head from the self-defeating one to the more positive, uplifting one.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: I hope this was helpful.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: Again, I do this with my clients over quite a few weeks, if not months, and I am there with them the whole time.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: It is quite an involved process and can bring up a lot of very difficult feeling/memories.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If at any point you find it too hard to go at alone, please seek help.

title: Can I change my feeling of being worthless to everyone?
author: listener
text: If you take anything away from this reply, know that there is help out there and that it is possible to change the way you feel.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: speaker
text:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: You have been through so much and it sounds like you have a lot of things that have complied over the years.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Regardless of the struggles you have been through, you do not have too many issues for counseling.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Many times when someone starts out their counseling and healing journey, there are multiple things they would like to address and work on.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: If you decide to start counseling, you and your therapist can decide collaboratively what you would like to process and work on first.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Be sure to express to your counselor if any of the above experiences you've been through is causing a lot of distress , as many times the first things addressed are the ones that are presently affecting your life or you emotionally.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Often times when we experience negative situations in our life , but do not address them, they bottle up inside us and can manifest in other ways, such as depression or even physical symptoms like IBS or neck pain.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Counseling can give these bottled up emotions and situations a release.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Given the situation you shared, not only do I not think that you have too many issues for counseling, but believe that you will be a great candidate and can get a lot from it.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?

   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?

author: listener
text: This is a great question!

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: I personally don't believe that any client could ever have too many issues for counseling.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: In fact, that type of thinking may be stopping you from seeking counseling, so it may be hindering you from getting the help you need.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: In fact, all of what you described points to the importance of you seeking help in order to cope with the many challenges in your life.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: If you seek counseling, it will be important for you to understand that you may need to remain in counseling for a sustained period of time in order to work through each of these issues.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: All of these issues won't be able to be solved right away or in a brief period of time.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Counseling will take commitment and hard work, but it is possible for you to recover and heal from all of the issues you described.Many clients come into counseling with numerous issues rather than just one particular thing.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Most of the time, the issues relate to and exacerbate each other.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: We call these "comorbid" conditions, which means that two or more mental health problems exist at one time.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: A lot of the times, when you start to work on one issue, the other issues get better as a result.I encourage you to find a professional therapist that can help you learn how to cope with all of the mental health difficulties that you described.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: You deserve the help just as much as anyone else.

text: Sometimes, working on  one issue helps to bring other issues to light in the context of your main problem.

title: How do I find out the cause of my depression and anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I have been feeling more and more down for over a month. I have started having trouble sleeping due to panic attacks, but they are almost never triggered by something that I know of.

title: How do I find out the cause of my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: It could be really helpful to see a counselor/therapist about your increasing depression/panic symptoms.

title: How do I find out the cause of my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Finding out the cause of depression/anxiety isn't always as straightforward as it seems, since both issues tend to become patterns we engage in rather than solely related to a specific trigger/reason.

title: How do I find out the cause of my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: For example, if I am feeling down about a particular circumstance in my life, then I start seeing life through this lens of feeling down, and typically I'll start to see a lot more that I get down about, and it can really build very quickly on itself.

title: How do I find out the cause of my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Same with anxiety.

title: How do I find out the cause of my depression and anxiety?

title: How can I get my husband to listen to my needs and talk to me?
author: speaker
text:
I tried telling my husband I was depressed, and he ignored me. He said "you're always sad or depressed." And he picked up his phone and ignored me. I said, "Please don't exaggerate, that isn't true." And he said, "Whatever babe. You just want to be sad."
   How can I get through to him so he will take me seriously?

title: How can I get my husband to listen to my needs and talk to me?
author: listener
text: Oh dear.From what you write, your husband doesn't have any interest to know about you and your sad feelings.Stay clear in understanding that you already did your part by asking him to listen and care about the way you feel.In this example, he told you he doesn't care.Its up to him to open his mind and heart to you.Depending on how motivated to continue asking him to hear you, try until you feel satisfied that you've given him enough chances to know who you are.

title: How can I get my husband to listen to my needs and talk to me?
author: listener
text: At a certain number of tries at this, you'll either have success or not.Just don't try forever because doing so will increase your depressed feelings.

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: speaker
text: It's not entirely true to say I enjoy being sad, but I always find a way to feel that way. I listen to sad music, read tragic stories, and, in a twisted way, like how bad it makes me feel. I focus on negative aspects of my life even if they aren't legitimate or I just make it seem negative.

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are noticing that you are drawn towards sad and negative content and it's hard to understand why.

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: listener
text: This may sound counter-intuitive, but sometimes we do things that on the surface may look problematic (or even cause us some real problems) because it serves us in some unseen way.

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: listener
text: A simple example would be somebody who is addicted to a substance; their addiction may be causing serious problems in their life, and they may even know it, but the addiction serves them by helping them to avoid painful feelings that they anticipate having if they quit using.

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: listener
text: Now I am not saying that what you describe is an addiction, it is just a really illustrative example of the unseen benefit.One thing I would be wondering about is what is the unseen benefit of seeking out sad and negative content?

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: listener
text: I'd also be wondering what your relationship is to other feelings.

title: Why do I crave depression?
author: listener
text: These are things you may benefit from exploring with a competent therapist.

title: How do I get back on my feet while going through a bad divorce?
author: speaker
text: I am going through a divorce. He is extremely angry. He refuses to physically assist me with our teenager daughter. I have no extended family support. Often times, I feel overwhelmed, tired, and joyless. I feel out of control, sad and depressed on a daily basis. I am just going through the motions of life every day. I am in my mid-50s. I have almost 29 years on my job. How can I handle this?

title: How do I get back on my feet while going through a bad divorce?
author: listener
text: You are in the midst of a really hard time and it sounds like you have no help at all.

title: How do I get back on my feet while going through a bad divorce?
author: listener
text: Search out a local support group through community counseling type centers.

title: How do I get back on my feet while going through a bad divorce?
author: listener
text: If you can't find a group, at least get in to see a therapist who can help you manage stress and upset better.

title: How do I get back on my feet while going through a bad divorce?
author: listener
text: Your sadness, depression and out-of-control feelings don't mean there is something wrong with you - they just mean that your circumstances are too big for your current resources to handle, so get some help.

title: How do I get back on my feet while going through a bad divorce?
author: listener
text: Take care of YOU and you'll be able to get through this.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: speaker
text: I just don't know what I want in life anymore. I'm can't figure out what it is that is keeping me distracted and unfocused. I can't put things into perspective at all. I'm just stuck, and I'm disappointed with my lack of accomplishments.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: If you are a people-pleaser type or a natural caretaker, you can slowly "lose yourself" over time if you are always tending to the needs of others and neglecting yourself.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: If this sounds like a familiar pattern for you, this may have happened without you even realizing it if you were raised in a family where you had to pick up the slack alot.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Maybe your parents were addicts or they might have even just worked all the time and you learned to "take care of everything" because that is what you had to do to help the family run smoothly.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Over time, a person who grows up in this type of environment learns that you put the needs of others before your own.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: You might also be stuck in these types of patterns in intimate relationships as well; if you completely give yourself over to your significant other and you don't create a life for yourself with your own interests and supportive friends, you are at risk of losing what is unique and amazing about you.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: If you grew up in a family where you learned this role out of survival or because it was needed to take care of your family, it's easy to re-create this in adult relationships.In both scenarios, if there is no awareness that this "self sacrifice at the expense of others" is going on, your identity is shaped around being a caretaker/enabler/people-pleaser and down the road it can lead to depression, low self esteem, and a confused sense of self.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Basically, you spend so much time helping other people that you don't make time for yourself or create a life of fulfillment.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Before you realize it, you have been living a life for others instead of yourself and you have no idea who YOU are.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Supporting loved ones and friends is important and certainly admirable, but if you are always that person that rescues, those that rely on you begin to take advantage of you and they will suck you dry if you let them.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: In conclusion, learning to set boundaries with those in your life that are too needy becomes a really important part of the process when you begin to recognize that you are unhappy and unfulfilled in life.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you may be at that crossroads right now.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Take one small step at at a time.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Identify the worst offenders in your life that suck time and energy, and limit your contact and/or set some strong boundaries with those people so you can refocus and do some soul-searching.

title: How can I find myself again?
author: listener
text: Meanwhile, engage in pleasurable activities with people you enjoy being with, get yourself outside in the fresh air, get some good sleep, and eat some nourishing food!

title: How can I find myself again?

text: Sometimes we are so focused on something we haven't achieved yet or on comparing ourselves to others that we lose touch with what we actually want and need.

title: Is wishing I wasn't born a sign of something deeper?
author: speaker
text: I'm not suicidal and wouldn't take my own life, but sometimes, I've wished for an accident to occur and take it. I feel like I just shouldn't be here and wish I wouldn't have been born so I didn't have to go through life. For me, it's a chore, but I don't know if that's normal or a sign of something.

title: Is wishing I wasn't born a sign of something deeper?
author: listener
text: Sounds like a sign of great unhappiness, or sadness, or insecurity.The real way you'll find out what this feeling is about is to ask yourself your own question.

title: Is wishing I wasn't born a sign of something deeper?

text: Inside you are the only one who will feel when you discover the true answer to your question.Everyone feels some amount of discontent in their lives once in a while.

title: Is wishing I wasn't born a sign of something deeper?
author: listener
text: Its normal to not feel entirely happy all the time.Try to accept your unhappiness as motivation to learn more about who you are, what you like, whom you like.Study yourself bc this way you increase the chance to find a road which feels right and happy.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: If you've had any experience with addicts at all, then I'm sure you've heard the term "enabler".

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: A lot of the times, when people think they're "helping", they're actually enabling the addict to continue their self-destructive behavior.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Tough love and clear boundaries are needed in a lot of situations, but especially with addictions.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Family and friends are often the biggest contributing factor to someone choosing to use/drink, continuing to do so, or relapsing back into it.You said she recently quit.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: You said she is depressed.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: She wants to move.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: When a person receives counseling for addictions, they are encouraged to make changes like this.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: They need to break the habit, and this means removing people from their lives at times.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: It means moving to new locations.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Anything that may trigger a relapse needs to be identified and removed.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Not only that, but the addict needs to do a lot of personal reflection to figure out WHY they use/drink in the first place, and not only break the physical addiction to it, but deal with whatever is the root cause that led them to use in the first place.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: She may need some time alone to figure out who she is as a person, time to make some decisions for herself and do what she needs to do to be healthy.Don't pressure her to stay.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Let her have the freedom to do what she needs to do.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: If she stays, the decision needs to be hers and hers alone.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: It doesn't need to be made under pressure.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: That will only lead to resentment.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Support her, but don't try to change her or make her do anything, especially for selfish reasons.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Let her go.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: It sounds like she needs some time to focus on herself right now.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: It wouldn't be a bad idea for you to do the same.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: speaker
text: My girlfriend just quit drinking and she became really depressed. She told me that she wants to move. What can I do to help her? I want her to stay.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: I would say talk to her about her depression.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: The best thing you can do is let her know that you are there for her as a support system.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: I would encourage her to talk more if it helps and encourage her to get move involved in doing activities she likes to do.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Also, getting connected in a community of people is important to help with feeling depressed.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Encourage her to speak with a therapist or counselor to address her depression as she has made a major change in her life by deciding to stop drinking.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: She may believe moving is the best to help with this.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: You can share with her that you want her to stay and express to her how you feel.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Ultimately, you will have to respect her boundaries and the decision she chooses to make.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: She may want to move and this may be what she feels is best for her life.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: If she does choose to move that will be her decision.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: It sounds like she is trying to do what is going to make her happy.

title: How can I help my girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Maybe staying in the city she is currently in is causing her more feelings of sadness.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager. My dad has been jail for the last five years. It's tough, but my mom really tries to give a normal life to my two sisters, my brother, and I. I feel like I took upon a parent role when I'm the second youngest, and I'm not stable. My mother and sisters say I'm overdramatic. I’m just so hurt, and I keep breaking down.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: listener
text: Each person handles themselves differently in any situation.Since you are willing to speak about how you feel, keep looking for blogs and forums on whatever topics you feel most describe your current circumstance.Your mother and sister, even though they are family seem to prefer the opposite method to yours.Find your own path of supportive other people and possibly a therapist.This way you’ll have understanding and validation which your mom and sister don’t want to give you right now.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager. My dad has been jail for the last five years. It's tough, but my mom really tries to give a normal life to my two sisters, my brother, and I. I feel like I took upon a parent role when I'm the second youngest, and I'm not stable. My mother and sisters say I'm overdramatic. I’m just so hurt, and I keep breaking down.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you have a lot of weight on your shoulders.I'm not sure what you mean when you say you're not stable and you are breaking down.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: listener
text: If you are crying because you're sad, that is okay.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: listener
text: If you are crying a lot or having trouble eating or sleeping, that's different than just crying sometimes because you are sad.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: listener
text: It may be helpful to talk with a local mental health professional in your area.

title: Is it normal to take a parent role and feel so hurt and broken as a teenager?
author: listener
text: They can help you to figure out what you could do differently to have the role in your family that you would like while also supporting yourself and what you want.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my mid 20s with a husband and children. I love my family, but I feel like I've lost my identity, and I don't know who I am other than a mom and wife. At times, all I can think is what I gave up and how I feel unhappy and trapped, but I know I'd feel like worse without them. I loathe myself at times. I have an amazing life, so why can't I just enjoy it?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Being a parent can be all-consuming.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: And there are more societal pressures on mothers to be everything to their children and families.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: In that effort to be everything (cook, housekeeper, planner, social organizer, teacher, etc) it can be easy to forget about being you.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: We can certainly acknowledge that becoming a mother likely means giving up or sacrificing parts of yourself for motherhood.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: There are parts of becoming a mother that can be wonderful and magical, and parts of it that can be just flat out hard.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: I think it is very important however, for all parents to ask for what they need and to carve out the time to nurture their individuality.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: This may not only be supportive to you, but it sets a great example for your kids about how to advocate for their needs, and teach them about the depth and interests of their mother.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my mid 20s with a husband and children. I love my family, but I feel like I've lost my identity, and I don't know who I am other than a mom and wife. At times, all I can think is what I gave up and how I feel unhappy and trapped, but I know I'd feel like worse without them. I loathe myself at times. I have an amazing life, so why can't I just enjoy it?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: It is not easy being a wife and mother.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: You have shifted roles in your life.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: You went from having a career to focusing on your family.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Transitioning can be hard, especially when we feel we gave something up that we really wanted.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: I want to acknowledge you for wanting to be the best wife and mother you can.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: I think it is great that you are self-aware and want to work on this.Feeling "unhappy and trapped" may also mean that you are  believing these negative thoughts are absolutely true.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: We have lots and lots of thoughts throughout the day.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Sometimes we pay a lot of attention to some and some we ignore.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Right now these thoughts are getting a lot of your attention and perhaps you are thinking because you are thinking them they are true.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Is it really true that you trapped?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: You also said that you have an amazing life.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: It doesn't sound like you are only having negative thoughts.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: You have some positive ones, too.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: However, you are giving a lot of weight to the negative thoughts, more weight than the positive ones.I also wonder if you are struggling with the fact that you are even having this thought.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: One thing that can be helpful is to recognize that you are having a thought, that it is a negative thought, that thinking it does not make it true, and to let it go.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: This is the basis for mindfulness work that can be really helpful.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: It is a great place for you to start so you can balance out your thoughts and emotions.Best of luck to you!

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my mid 20s with a husband and children. I love my family, but I feel like I've lost my identity, and I don't know who I am other than a mom and wife. At times, all I can think is what I gave up and how I feel unhappy and trapped, but I know I'd feel like worse without them. I loathe myself at times. I have an amazing life, so why can't I just enjoy it?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: It sound like there are some parts of your life that you really enjoy it and also some things that you wish were different.You say you feel like nothing more than a wife and mom, so I wonder if you could make a list of what else you are (friend, daughter, etc.).

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: I also wonder if you could list your positive attributes or skills.I don't know what you gave up, but I wonder if there is some way that you could spend an hour or so a week working on things that you like and/or spending some time with what you did before you had children.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: For example, if you're missing a certain part of your career, maybe you could work with your husband to come up with a plan where you could do whenever that is for one day a week.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: There are often a lot of small changes that can lead you in that direction.Of course, that is assuming that you want to continue being involved with what you were doing before.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: If not, what else do you want to do?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: What is it that makes you feel happy?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: What do you look forward to?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Remember that looking forward to having an hour or two where you can do something for yourself does not mean that you are not a good mother or wife.

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: These ideas can coexist.Can you talk with your husband about how you are feeling?

title: Why do I feel like I'm nothing more than a wife and mom?
author: listener
text: Do you have trust for one another with feelings such as these?

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I have been dealing with depression and anxiety for a number of years. I have been on medication, but lately my depression has felt worse. Can counseling help?

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Certainly counselling can help.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: however, there is a caveat, namely, you will need the right counsellor with the right approach.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: This leads to two questions: 1) What are the identifiers for the right counsellor, and 2) What is the right approach?1) What are the identifiers for the right counsellor?

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: The right counsellor will almost certainly have a lot of experience.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: He or she will have done a lot personal work and have an ongoing practice of inner work both on their own and with the support of an experienced therapist.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: This person will be viewing you as a human being with challenges, not as a diagnostic category.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: He or she will be willing to work with you over an extended period of time and have experience doing such work.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Further they will be well versed in approaches that are responsive to you in the moment and overall.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: The in-depth work will be collaborativel designed in an ongoing way that is responsive to you, the moment, your overall life experience, and their in-the-moment experience.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: It goes without saying that you will subjectively evaluate the felt sense of connection with this person and the feeling that they are invested in their work with you, value you as a human being, and value the connection.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: As well, it is crucial that you feel this connection and that your therapist 'gets you.'

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: 2) What is the right approach?

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text:
As Carl Jung stated, "When the doctor sits down with the patient he (or
she) must drop all theories and learn the theory of this person."

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: The approach must include a bond between you and your therapist that is in a continuous process of development, attention to pre-verbal imprinting, development of awareness ability, ongoing development of the ability to attend to and stay with inner experience, development of a process orientation, attention to egoic structures that were seeded from the earliest days in the service of perceptions of threats to needs being met, identification of current egoic states and work with these inner selves and their relationship with each other to facilitate movement from developmental points of arrest, increased ability to access and contain non-ordinary states of consciousness, attending to what is, and working with this in the service of moving towards optimal human development.depression is generally experienced as the system shutting down.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: anxiety is a signal that something is wrong.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: anxiety is not the problem.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: it is a sign that there is a problem.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: the core of these issues is a lack of inner security that is the outcome of insufficient bonding.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: the work of psychotherapy is to establish an environment and relationship that will facilitate work with the bonding ruptures and re-initiation of the developmental process that stopped at an early stage.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: My initial response:  consider a more comprehensive MH assessment to determine other factors.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Blood work is helpful.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?

text: Review what hadn't helped.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I have been dealing with depression and anxiety for a number of years. I have been on medication, but lately my depression has felt worse. Can counseling help?

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: From whom do you get anti-depressants?This person should be talking with you to know whether the pills are helping or not.Trust your own instinct that the pills aren't helping you.Pills work differently for everyone and not all people feel better from them.It is also possible the particular pills have lost their effectiveness because after around six to eight months, this usually happens.Try to understand what is depressing you.

title: Is there anything I can do about my depression and anxiety?
author: listener
text: This is slow work since you may have many theories.Just by addressing your own emotional needs and life structure in a caring and respectful way, may improve your mood so that you'll feel less depressed.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: speaker
text: There are many people willing to lovingly provide me with a home. I have food, clothes, and a university education, but I never feel like I belong. Even when I have a good time with people who are supposed to be close, I feel like I'm just out with friends and I never go home.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: For some people, having a sense of belonging takes some time.You mentioned that you have an education and some basic daily needs.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: I wonder if you may be able to look at your relationship with yourself and what makes you feel happy, safe, and having a sense of accomplishment.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: If you have those feelings, I wonder how you define trust and who you trust.You say you have a good time with people who are "supposed to be close," so I wonder what keeps them from feeling close.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: I have also wondering if you have been emotionally hurt in the past, and if so, you may have some protective defenses that you use (maybe on purpose, maybe not) to protect yourself from being hurt again.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: Remember that this idea comes in degrees where you can be more perfect in certain situations and a little less in others.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: Being emotionally protected is on a spectrum or continuum, where you can make an infinite amount of adjustments or changes with different people and situations.I also wonder what it is that you want in your "home," and how you define it.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: Consider giving yourself permission to think about how you would define your perfect home in a world where there were no realistic restrictions (such as money or location).

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: After you have that, consider what parts of that you can have.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: Perhaps there is a small part that you could make a reality within a week or so.Thank you for reaching out.

title: Why do I feel like I don't belong anywhere?
author: listener
text: If this continues to be difficult for you, consider seeing a local mental health professional so you can discuss some more specific details.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: speaker
text: I am a teenager. I have been experiencing major episodes of depression (if that's even what it is) for several years. It’s always getting worse. I have been having panic attacks, feeling like I can't control my fears, and I can't even bring myself to care if I live or die anymore. The problem is that I don't know who to ask for help. When I try to talk to my parents, I freeze completely and can't do anything but make a joke because never once in my life have we talked about our feelings.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: I understand that talking about our feelings can be awkward and using jokes is a way to relieve that awkwardness, but there is a right or wrong way to talk about your feelings.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: The important part is to recognize that you need help addressing those feelings and reaching out, which you are doing already.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: Having small conversations with your family is helpful, you can explain to them that you have been experiencing emotional discomfort and would like to talk to them about it.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: Since you been experiencing anxiety, panic attacks, and have thought about dying,  It is VERY important that you ask them to help you make an appointment with a mental health professional.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: Those symptoms indicate that your body is having a hard time managing intense feelings and it will be helpful if you understand why they occur and how to cope with them.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: You may contact your school counselor or you may schedule an appointment with a local therapist.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: You may contact the Texas Crisis Hotline 800-989-6884 where you can talk or chat with mental health professionals or schedule a teletherapy session.

title: How do I talk about my feelings of depression, and to who do I talk to?
author: listener
text: The National Crisis Hotline is also available for calling and texting 1-800-273-8255.I am a Licensed Professional Counselor in Texas, currently providing services in West Houston.
