title: How can I stop feeling empty?
author: speaker
text: I feel lazy and numb. I have no interest in things.

title: How can I stop feeling empty?
author: listener
text: Maybe right now it is time for you to rest before the next wave of new activity comes along.To have "no interest" may mean you are already so saturated with recent situations and their meaning that you are naturally withdrawing in order to regain your energy.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: speaker
text: I'm currently struggling with diagnosed depression, anxiety, and Misophonia. Also, I am 99% sure I have Borderline Personality Disorder and Avoidant Personality Disorder. I read the DSM-IV, taken college psychology, etc. I know it in my heart I have them. Is self-diagnosing okay with the right research?

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Self-diagnosing is something that we all do about one health issue or another.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Taking a guess about what may or may not be happening to us is completely normal, however the actual clinical diagnoses of a mental health disorder requires a licensed mental health professional.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Here are a few reasons for this: 1.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Making a clinical diagnosis often requires other things besides matching up the symptoms of a disorder.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: To come to a diagnoses for any of the things you mentioned, a counselor would consult the DSM, but they may also use some type of screening tool, assessment or scale.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Many disorders have similarities and it requires someone with training to tease out the differences in the symptoms.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Our judgement is sometimes off when it comes to assessing ourselves.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: We really can't be objective.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Something as serious as determining a diagnosis really needs to be done by someone who has that objectivity.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: In addition, once you know your diagnosis, treating it usually requires help from a professional.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Sometimes the symptoms of a mental health disorder makes self-diagnoses impossible, in and of itself.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: For example, someone could be having hallucinations or delusions and not realize it.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: That would clearly make it impossible for them to diagnose themselves.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: There a many examples where something like this could happen with different mental health disorders.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: There are other reasons, but these are three important ones.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Now, does this mean that you are wrong about your diagnosis?

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Maybe not.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: You may be correct.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: But, it is important to get this confirmed by a professional mental health clinician.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: If a disorder is then found, you can begin to talk about treatment.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Hope this was helpful.

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCC

title: My family can't stand me
author: speaker
text: I am the problem. I make my family argue because of me. My mom has even said it. It's constantly like this. I cause problems. I am worthless. I can't stop crying. Sometimes I have to cry myself to sleep. I can't even leave my room because my family can't stand me.

title: My family can't stand me
author: listener
text: I am so very sorry for how pressured and sad you feel right now.Definitely all family members have an effect on the other ones.From what you write, your family members are not considering the effect their negative comments have on you.Also, keep in mind that each person is responsible for deciding to argue or find a different way to discuss a problem.

title: My family can't stand me
author: listener
text: You are not in control of the other people in your family.More likely they take the easy way out and blame you for what they don't want to know about themselves.Stay aware that the family's decision to target you doesn't mean that you are doing something wrong.

title: My family can't stand me
author: listener
text: Certainly your existence is not wrong, which is the degree to which the unfairness seems to have spread.What to do about it is read about family systems to see more explanations on how you are being unfairly treated.Also stay in touch with friends bc these are the people who value and respect you.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I'm very depressed. How do I find someone to talk to?

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: You have already taken the brave first step of making the decision to heal from it and find a professional that will help you do so.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: There are lots of different options nowadays for therapists, as you can see them online or in an office.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: My biggest tip for you is to use Psychology Today or Counsel Chat to find a therapist.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Enter in your zip code and you will find many different therapists you can talk to .

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Be sure to find someone that you most resonate with and ask them any questions you may have.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Many  times, therapists will provide free consultations and this can be a great opportunity to see if you are a good fit.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I'm very depressed. How do I find someone to talk to?

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: The first step, which you've taken, is actually wanting to talk to someone.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: It's a great sign that you are seeking to reach out for help.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: And there are therapists everywhere (there are even therapists online, so you don't have to be that close to them or their office.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: )There are several sites that I refer people to to begin the process of looking for a therapist.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: I usually have them start with psychologytoday.com.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Once there (there is a therapist directory), you can narrow choices down by ages that they work with, insurance they accept, depression as an issue they focus in, etc.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: You can also narrow down by therapist's modality, but that can get complicated if you aren't too familiar with the various theoretical approaches.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: It's important that you find someone that you feel understands your situation.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: That might mean that they identify an issue you are having in their profile, or on their professional website.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: But, you should try to meet a couple of different therapists if you aren't quite sure.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: It can be challenging that first session, but your best (note, not "THE best") therapist will help you feel comfortable (or as comfortable as possible, given therapy can be uncomfortable especially at first) and understood from the get-go.I have found that asking friends or family for names and recommendations Is also a common way to find a therapist, because it can come from a trusted referral source.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: But remember that we are all different, so what works for one might not always be a good fit.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: And again, it could take a couple of first sessions with different therapists to know if someone is a good fit (sometimes, it can take a few sessions.)

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: And if there is no one around that can give a name or two, then searching online is quite common and can yield positive results.And try not to give up!

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Finding a therapist is not easy, but finding a good one for you is extremely rewarding.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I'm very depressed. How do I find someone to talk to?

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Hi,Reaching out here is a great start!

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: I recommend looking for somebody in your area that works with people experiencing depression.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: After you've chosen somebody to try, feel free to call them for a consultation!

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: A lot of counselors and therapists offer free consultations, and remember that your counselor is working for you, so make sure they are a good fit!

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: I hope this has been of some help.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I'm very depressed. How do I find someone to talk to?

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Hang in there!

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Feeling depressed sucks but talking with someone can really help - so its awesome that you're already trying to figure out how to find that person.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Tons of good suggestions already but to add my two cents - you can find therapists in your area and read a little bit about them to find someone you like the sound of via this website, and also via www.psychologytoday.com; if you have health insurance your insurer might be able to make recommendations as to therapists covered by your plan, or if you happen to be in school, the school itself should be able to connect you with either their own counselor or a center that they recommend nearby.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Finding someone can take a few calls or a bit of research so if you need some immediate support, or find yourself having thoughts of hurting yourself, you can also call the great folks who run the Suicide crisis line https://suicidepreventionlifeline.org - they are great in moments of crisis.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I'm very depressed. How do I find someone to talk to?

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: Great that you realize talking with a professional counselor about how you feel, would be helpful!If you'd like a very fast response by phone, then google "depression hotline" for where you live.

title: I'm very depressed?
author: listener
text: And, if you have a specific topic which upsets you then google around with this topic to see if there are services specific to your interest.If you've got time to invest in looking for the best fit therapist for yourself, then google "therapy' or "therapist".There will be many, many names which come up.I know I sound like I work for google only it is the easiest way to find lots of information.I send you good luck!

title: My family says I have depression
author: speaker
text:
I'm in my late teens and live with my dad. The only time I go out is for my college classes. Sometimes when I see my friends I want to talk with them, but sometimes I won't want to talk to them for days or even weeks.    Sometimes I feel i'm not worth knowing or i'm never going to do anything right.
   Are they right, am I depressed?

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Although some people managing depression feel sad or "down",  it is a possible to have depression without an obvious sad mood.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Many people indicate that they feel numb or flat.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: People managing depression often have low motivation.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: They may stay in bed for long periods of time and only get up for absolutely necessary activities.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: People with depression may also feel inappropriate guilt or shame.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: If you have been experiencing the symptoms you described for more than two weeks, I recommend that you see a counselor to get a more in-depth evaluation.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: The symptoms you are experiencing are typical of depression, and with a bit of support, you could regain energy and improved self-esteem.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: The stigma surrounding mental health can make a diagnosis or a label of depression seem scary.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: The important thing to remember is that mental health disorders are as important as and as treatable physical health disorders.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Hang in there.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Healing is possible!

title: My family says I have depression
author: speaker
text:
I'm in my late teens and live with my dad. The only time I go out is for my college classes. Sometimes when I see my friends I want to talk with them, but sometimes I won't want to talk to them for days or even weeks.    Sometimes I feel i'm not worth knowing or i'm never going to do anything right.
   Are they right, am I depressed?

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: The answer to the question of whether or not you're depressed, is less meaningful than what you are doing to feel strong and secure in your life.Otherwise, people shortcut themselves to go deeper in understanding who they are and what they'd like to do with their lives, and accept "depression" as though it is their new name.What you write sounds like classic depression.What to do about this feeling is to get closer to yourself in an accepting way.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Assume that what you do in daily living is somehow necessary.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Unless you are doing immoral or illegal actions to other people, to accept your own wishes as truth will open you to appreciate why you do what you do.Make believe you're interesting and find out more about who you are, if you have trouble to start with thinking of yourself as worth understanding.The more you appreciate who you are and your unique strengths, vulnerabilities and fears, the more these will dissolve by what seems on their own.In fact they will disappear bc you are believing in yourself and your ways.Good luck!

title: My family says I have depression
author: speaker
text:
I'm in my late teens and live with my dad. The only time I go out is for my college classes. Sometimes when I see my friends I want to talk with them, but sometimes I won't want to talk to them for days or even weeks.    Sometimes I feel i'm not worth knowing or i'm never going to do anything right.
   Are they right, am I depressed?

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: I'm alway wary of assigning a term to a feeling, as often that term becomes more important than the feeling itself.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: From the very little that you have written, it is clear that you are going through something that has made you extremely low, affected your self-esteem and motivation, limits your enjoyment of formerly pleasurable activities and affects your feelings of self-worth.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: All of these are aspects of being depressed, though you can be depressed and still not have "depression".

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Counseling is definitely a place where you can go and sort out why you have had such a sudden a drastic change to your mood.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Sometimes our mood can be effected by changes in our routine, losses or significant disappointments.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Talking with someone will not only help you to better understand why you are feeling this way, but they will also help you to ground yourself and learn strategies and tools to help you to manage your mood and strategize for the future.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: I do hope that you will reach out.

title: My family says I have depression
author: listener
text: Feeling alone can be harmful over long periods of time, as it can stop us from seeking out the support we need.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: speaker
text:
She has trouble falling and staying asleep and she's always either extremely hungry or not hungry at all. She also gets angry and feels like crying really easily for no reason. She says she is always "kind of down."
   Is this depression? What can I do to help her?

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Sounds like signs of someone who is depressed.Since the person in question is your friend, offer your friendship to listen to any situations or feelings she has about herself and the way her life is going.Depressed people are often lonely people and feel as though no one around them cares or notices them.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Your willingness to be available to her may lift her spirits.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Feeling loved goes a long way to dissolving depressed feelings.Also, if in the beginning when you offer to talk, there is a high chance she'll be defensive and turn down your offer.Try again on another day and then another day.When people feel depressed they usually shut down.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: So you may need a few or several tries before your friend accepts your offer to show her you care about how she is doing.Also, watch for signs within yourself that your friends' depression is not sinking your emotions.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Depressed people are draining to be around because they often see and talk about only the negatives and drawbacks of situations.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: speaker
text: I just feel sad all the time and I don't like anyone in my family. I feel like they're trying to control me and won't let me grow.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: Hello,While one can be sad from time to time, feeling sad "all the time" could be a sign of depression.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: If you feel sad on most days, it is worthwhile speaking to a psychologist to determine whether you suffer clinical depression.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: Feeling sadness is a normal response to loss, whether you lose a family, friend, job, or something you deem important in your life.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: However, feeling sadness all the time is a signal that you are not happy about something in your life.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: If it is related to your family and often relationship with family members could affect our self-esteem and self-worth, then perhaps it is worthwhile exploring what you find unhappy about your relationship with your family.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: Is it that you do not feel heard, supported or loved?

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: Is it that you feel disrespected, disregarded or feel unimportant?

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: These are just a few examples of common issues that people report that contribute to their depression.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: To help you to uncover your reasons for your sadness or depression and to cope with them in a healthier and more constructive way, it may be helpful to contact a therapist who could support you with this process.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: You do not have to deal with it alone.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: Dr. Virginia Chow, Montreal Psychologist.

title: Why do I feel sad all the time?
author: listener
text: For more information about depression, please consult my website at www.PsychologyResource.ca

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: speaker
text: I can't seem to feel any emotion except anxiety, not even for myself.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: Empathy usually falls on a spectrum, meaning that some people show more than others.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: Empathy is the ability to look at the world through someone else's eyes or "walk a mile in their shoes."

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: There could be some people in your life for whom empathy is easier to feel and those for whom you have no idea what they are experiencing.Empathy is not usually categorized as an emotion, but as something related to emotions.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: For example, you could have empathy about someone's anxiety.I'm not sure whether you are also referring to the idea that you don't have sympathy for yourself or others.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: That's a different concept, but also involves different degrees.When you say you don't have emotion except anxiety, I wonder if you are saying that you have anxiety all the time and it may be covering up other emotions?

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: If you are experiencing a lot of anxiety, try to look at what it connects to and find something that changes your focus for a few minutes.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: This could be any number of activities, such as watching TV, cooking, reading a book, or many other options.If you are feeling as if you are just going through the motions and not having a lot of emotions about anything, if it's just been a few days, it may just be related to a current stress that will lessen in a few days.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: If it has been quite a while, consider tracking your mood and looking at when you do notice changes in your emotions.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: There may be some variations that you are not aware of.If you continue to feel anxious and as if you don't have as many emotions as you would like, consider talking with your primary care physician or a local therapist.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: speaker
text: I can't seem to feel any emotion except anxiety, not even for myself.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text:
Empathy is the ability
to tap into our own experience to help us connect with others in order to be
aware of how they are experiencing life.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text: It is a skill that we learn with practice and refine as we become mature.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text:
If you are feeling anxious, maybe you are able to understand better others who
are going trough anxiety.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text:
But I wonder
if instead of feeling empathy, you may just want to find ways to reduce your
anxiety.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?
author: listener
text:
A good idea is to be very aware
of your anxiety triggers, and once you identify them explore other ways you
could react.

title: is it normal not to feel empathy?

¿Sera normal que no sienta empatía?Parece que no puedo experimentar ninguna otra emoción que

Empatía es la habilidad de usar tus propias

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: speaker
text: I know I need to deal with my depression. But I don't know how and I don't want to tell anyone.    How can I deal with depression without telling anyone?

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: Love yourself more and treat yourself kindly, with empathy and compassion.Usually when people feel depressed they also feel lonely and isolated.

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: Since at this time you wouldn't want to tell anyone about the way you feel, which includes the possibility that a few of the ones whom you tell would offer you emotional support, give this to yourself.Also consider to make a goal of eventually telling someone whom you are reasonably sure would understand and empathize, about your depression.This will help alleviate the sense of shame, unworthiness and pervasive guilt which often comes along with depression.Sending you good luck!

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: speaker
text: I know I need to deal with my depression. But I don't know how and I don't want to tell anyone.    How can I deal with depression without telling anyone?

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: It can be really tough to tell someone - anyone - that you're feeling depressed.

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: But finding that supportive person that you can share with is a big part of the battle with depression.

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: Depression thrives on being secret, it seems to grow the more we isolate ourselves and hide it away so I'm with Laura Cassidy, when she suggests finding that professional support person so you can start fighting back against your depression.

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: If that feels like too big a step right now, maybe check out a book or two...

title: How can I deal with my depression?
author: listener
text: I'm a big fan of a book called 'Feeling Good' by Dr. David Burns if you want some practical thoughts on tackling depression and on 'Radical Acceptance' by Tara Brach if you prefer something a little more spiritual.

title: Can i learn to be happy alone?
author: speaker
text: I'm dealing with an illness that will never go away and I feel like my life will never change for the better. I feel alone and that i have no one.    How can I overcome this pain and learn to be happy alone?

title: Can i learn to be happy alone?
author: listener
text: Is it possible that even though your illness is chronic, that it goes through phases in which you are more comfortable and that it requires less focus from you than at other times?I think the idea of having a lifelong illness is frustrating and can be depressing to think about.

title: Can i learn to be happy alone?
author: listener
text: Thoughts are not necessarily the truth of what will actually happen though.Illness makes negative situations look worse so be sure you are concentrating on specific areas of your life and not just assuming they will work out badly because you are ill.One way to be happy alone is to love and appreciate, nurture and be kind to yourself.This frame of mind may generate new answers to find ways of being among other people too.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: speaker
text: How do I make myself happy without the people who made me happy? Now that they’re gone, I feel sad. It’s been two months now but I seem to be unable to stay okay and independent.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: So, someone made you happy but is no longer around?

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: I am sure that feels devastating.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: As a counselor I usually have to ponder this kind of thought because it lends itself to suggesting that happiness comes from the external, rather than the internal side of a person's life.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Happiness is formed within ourselves.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: All the external trappings of happiness are usually quite fleeting, and temporary.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Even relationships fo not last forever.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: If we get to a place where we are reliant and dependent on those around us to create happiness in our lives, then we lose the opportunities for us to do it ourselves.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: We are entirely capable of finding ways to be happy.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Sometimes this entails working out issues that are holding us back from reaching a place of peace, or resolution to a specific problem.What I would offer to you, is to find ways in which you can develop happiness for yourself.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: What do you like about your life as it is right now?

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: What can you do to create change in your life to increase your happiness?

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: These kinds of questions can be valuable to you as you seek out ways to make happiness an internal rather than an external event.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Mourning the loss of a social connection (in whatever way that occurred), is part of the grieving process, but it is not permanent.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: It is a path to healing and moving forward.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: From this, you can seek out new sources of happiness.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: I encourage you to remember that happiness is independent of the external experience you have in the world.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Happiness is an expression of the internal feelings, so that will be the source or the font of positive emotion from which you really draw.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: If you are lacking in happiness, then it becomes important to examine why that is, and what you can do about it to promote self-care.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: Seeking out a professional counselor can also be a good option as you move through the grief/loss process and examine the reasons happiness is not in greater supply.I wish you happiness for every day of your life.Best wishes.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: speaker
text: How do I make myself happy without the people who made me happy? Now that they’re gone, I feel sad. It’s been two months now but I seem to be unable to stay okay and independent.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you have been feeling pretty down, since the loss of a relationship, and you're wondering how to be happy by yourself.

title: How do I make myself happy without someone who made me happy?

title: How can I get people to listen?
author: speaker
text:
I've never been able to talk with my parents. My parents are in their sixties while I am a teenager. I love both of them but not their personalities. I feel that they do not take me seriously whenever I talk about a serious event in my life. If my dad doesn’t believe me, then my mom goes along with my dad and acts like she doesn’t believe me either. I’m a pansexual, but I can’t trust my own parents.

But they don't always try to help me with mine, when I really need them. I feel as if my childhood has been taken from me. I feel as if I have no one whom I can trust.

title: I need help coping with depression as a result of stress
author: speaker
text: My depression has been reoccurring for a long time. It all started when I was being bullied in high school. In ninth grade, my principal told me I needed to stay home for a couple days to protect myself while she spoke to my classmates. I needed professional help for my stress because I was having crying spells from the stress of going to school and confronting my classmates. After that, I was fine for a couple of years. I entered my first year of college in a really tough program with high demands of expected work. I believe my depression re-booted from there with the stress. I began to cut myself because a friend of mine at the time told me how she used to do the same and it used to feel good for her. Obviously, that wasn't the right choice. I regret ever doing that, seeing as even though I'm not self-harming anymore, I always look back at that time whenever I feel very stressed. I have a big problem with handling problems in life. Whenever a problem arises, I get stressed and I feel hopeless, as if it's not going to get better. I get way too stressed from my problems, which leads to overreacting a lot (especially when talking to others), which then leads to depression. I have a hard time coping with stress because I know that if I could handle it easily then I wouldn't be sad all the time, and I would say and do the right thing instead of overreacting to my loved ones.

title: I need help coping with depression as a result of stress

title: I need help coping with depression as a result of stress

title: I need help coping with depression as a result of stress

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
author: listener
text: Feelings like anger, shame, guilt and fear are frequent; while, wanting to avoid, minimize and become distant from the person are parts of the defense mechanism to attempt a quick resolution.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
author: listener
text: Once you understand and overcome those feelings you may be in a better position to help your husband; who may be experiencing some negative feelings as well.First, it is important to have a safety plan in place, which includes removing harming objects from the home, knowing who to call if there’s a new attempt (either 9-1-1, or nearby treatment center), have a professional expert who monitors you and your husband’s progress, either a Counselor or mental health provider could help you manage negative feelings and identify ways to handle triggering situations.Once the safety plan is in place,  make him feel supported and not judged, saying open ended statements, like: “I am glad that you are here, please let me know what I can do to help you through this process”.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: speaker
text: I no longer carry expressions on my face, and my emotions are decreasing the more I have fights with my fiancée.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: Sometimes repressing anger can lead to depression and block all kinds of other emotions too.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: I would wonder about your experience with anger and if you've ever been discouraged from expressing anger.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: I would also wonder if you feel like you have space to express yourself in your relationship or if you feel like you really aren't being heard.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: It's hard to feel cared for and connected to someone else when you don't feel accepted by them.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: speaker
text: I no longer carry expressions on my face, and my emotions are decreasing the more I have fights with my fiancée.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: Sometimes when we fight a lot with our partner, it becomes more uncomfortable to share emotions because it feels like it will lead to another flight or disagreement.You could try having a conversation when you're not fighting and starting it out by saying that you would like to discuss something important to you and see if your fiancée is open to that.Something else is that you could have an agreement that if one of you is having a really strong emotions in a difficult conversation and would like to break from the conversation, you could agree (ahead of time) that you'll say that you would like a "timeout" and will come back to discuss the issue in a certain amount of time (usually about an hour) and then try to resume the discussion.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: The reason this can work is it can give you a chance to calm down and then still go back to the discussion rather than not talking about it again.

title: How can you get back to my old self?
author: listener
text: This only works if both of you agree to that before something starts, though.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: speaker
text: I'm depressed. I have been for years. I hide it from everyone because I'm scared of the reactions I'll get. Last time I tried telling my parents, it was a huge argument about me being too young to be depressed (I’m a legal adult), calling me ungrateful, and telling me that if I can't handle things now, it's only going to get worse in the future (which is turning out to be true). It's exhausting pretending to be okay, and I don't know how much longer I can try. I'm just really tired, and sadly, I can't afford the help I need on my own.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: Hi Georgia, There's a really good lesson here.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: People tell us things, and we tend to think that's the truth...but it's not!

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: I'll do some translating for you..."You're so ungrateful" means "I need you to be successful and happy in order for me to feel I'm a good parent".

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: "You're too young to be depressed" means "I don't want to deal with your mental health issues right now.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: I'll pretend it's not happening so I don't have to face my fear and shame".

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: "It's only going to get worse" just means "I don't know how to support you beyond scaring you into wanting to at least fake happiness for my sake".Your parents are being unsupportive, not because you're not suffering, but because this is all they're capable of right now.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: They are not where you will find the support you need, so keep looking for it in other places.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: It's out there.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: If might be an aunt or a friend, or a friend's aunt.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: It might be a therapist or a bus driver or your family doctor.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: Keep looking for someone who will hear you.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: I hope you don't ever give up.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: speaker
text: I'm depressed. I have been for years. I hide it from everyone because I'm scared of the reactions I'll get. Last time I tried telling my parents, it was a huge argument about me being too young to be depressed (I’m a legal adult), calling me ungrateful, and telling me that if I can't handle things now, it's only going to get worse in the future (which is turning out to be true). It's exhausting pretending to be okay, and I don't know how much longer I can try. I'm just really tired, and sadly, I can't afford the help I need on my own.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: Don't think that you can't afford the help you need on your own.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: There are several counselors that see people on a sliding scale that can be as low as $5 (based on your income).

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: Find a center that is non-profit, they have great counselors as well.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you know what you are experiencing and know that you need someone to talk to, someone that is willing to listen.

title: How do I tell my parents that I'm depressed and need help?
author: listener
text: Your parents may not understand what your are feeling right now and that is not totally abnormal.I would encourage you to seek help immediately so you can live the best live you can...which is not being depressed.

title: What can I do about my depression and anxiety after trying so many things?
author: speaker
text: I have terrible anxiety and depression. I've tried various therapists and pills, but nothing's helped.

title: What can I do about my depression and anxiety after trying so many things?
author: listener
text: Is it possible you simply didn't mix well with the particular therapists with whom you've worked?

title: What can I do about my depression and anxiety after trying so many things?
author: listener
text: If this is possible, interview a therapist before  starting therapy.

title: What can I do about my depression and anxiety after trying so many things?
author: listener
text: Then you will be choosing a therapist who feels compatible with your way of seeing yourself and your life.Also, therapy isn't for everyone.Read about the different healing modalities and see if one of these speaks to your interest in feeling better.What matters most is finding among all the legitimate healing methods, what you believe will be effective.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my early 20s. I've worked since two months after I turned 18. I have “plans.” I could become an electrician, or I could operate heavy machinery. I have goals, but I do nothing to try to meet them because I don't feel I can. I just want a better life for my fiancée and the kids than I did.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: For starters, commend yourself for being committed to working.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: You have no idea what is going to happen in the next second, so focusing on thinking you will never have a good career or amount to anything financially is creating a fictitious story.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Remind yourself of that every time the thought pops up.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: The false belief that nothing good will happen is sucking out energy you can use on pursuing your career dreams.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Next, do you know what you need to do to become an electrician or heavy machinery operator?

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: If not, find out.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Then, set up a realistic schedule for yourself to accomplish the steps.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: As you accomplish each step, see your progress.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Notice that you are moving closer to your goal.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Every day remind yourself why you are pursuing this career.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: In fact, write it down and tape it on your bathroom mirror.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: When you start to feel discouraged, remember your goal and remind yourself that you have no idea if you'll make it or not but you are going to give it everything you have to find out.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Anything worth pursuing is going to take a lot of persistence and hard work.

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: Stay with it!

title: Why do I feel like I will never have a good career/amount to anything financially?
author: listener
text: You and your family are worth it!

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: speaker
text: He said he would try and he never did. It's been nine months, and this is making me worse. Today, he said I have to respect whatever decision he makes. Is that true? Am I supposed to respect the decision to leave because he can't handle what I'm going through and leaves me here crying and worried every night? He's constantly changing his mind on if he wants to work it out.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: I'm sorry for the hurt you're feeling from your husband's decision.Keep in mind that if one partner does not want to be in a relationship and remains in it, then both people will be unhappy, dissatisfied and feel stressed.Imagine being in a relationship that you'd rather leave.All the negative feelings and resentment of being with someone whom you'd rather be without, would not leave very much energy to satisfy your partner.I'm glad you realize that you feel depressed.Depression is a mood that can change once you understand what is causing it.Depression is an area that very often therapists help their patients understand, and emotionally support and encourage them during the course this takes.For now, concentrate on decreasing the tension in your life.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: Your husband's indecision may very well be adding to your stress.Only he can make up his own mind.As hard as this may be, all you really can do is take care of how you feel so that you will feel better.From what you write, your husband is too unsure to offer you the love and care you'd like from him.Learning to love oneself is always worthwhile.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: At this stage in your marriage, now sounds like an ideal opportunity for you to teach yourself self-love.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: speaker
text: He said he would try and he never did. It's been nine months, and this is making me worse. Today, he said I have to respect whatever decision he makes. Is that true? Am I supposed to respect the decision to leave because he can't handle what I'm going through and leaves me here crying and worried every night? He's constantly changing his mind on if he wants to work it out.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: The fact that you mention that he is "constantly changing his mind on if he wants to work it out," suggests that Discernment Counseling might be a really good fit for you both.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: Discernment counseling is a protocol for partners where one or both aren't certain they want to remain in the relationship.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: It's a brief (1-5 sessions) and intentionally focused on helping partners talk through (primarily individually) their reasons for and against staying in the relationship - as well as confront their own contributions that lead to the relationship crisis.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: It's aimed at helping the couple reach a clear understanding of which path they are going to take, not asking anyone to change just yet, so it can be a lot less intimidating and more to the point than couples therapy.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: You can look to find a local therapist providing this service here.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: That said, I agree with other respondents that if he is deciding to leave, seeking out support for yourself would be incredibly helpful.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: You may need to accept his decision, but you can certainly feel whatever emotions you have.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: You are allowed to feel exactly how you feel, and it's likely you'll be sad, or angry or hurt or disappointed or scared, or any combination of any/all of those.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: Having someone there who can validate those emotions and help you to process the grief that naturally comes with the end of a relationship can be a huge help in finding a place of healing and regaining a sense of self, a sense of hope.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression
author: listener
text: Although the marriage vows say in sickness and health, each person has the right to choose to stay or to leave, depending on their ability to cope and handle marriage challenges.

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression

title: My husband wants a divorce after I was diagnosed with severe depression

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: speaker
text: I'm in my late 50s. I never loved or have been loved. I need deeper help than is offered in my small town, but I cannot leave this town because of agoraphobia. I find myself losing hope more and more. My brain barely works anymore, and my memory so small, I forget in a moment. I serve no purpose. I'm incapable of work or anything of value, and I never have been. I’m a complete waste of time and resources, and yet I keep trying. Why? Why does God insist that I continue to exist? I’m not suicidal, just tired.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Hi Oak Harbor,My heart goes out to you.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Sometimes when I'm working with a client who experiences depression or anxiety, I ask them for a glimpse into their worst moments in their minds.

text: "What are the worst thoughts that run through your head?".

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Often they struggle, perhaps out of shame; maybe they don't want me to know their worst thoughts.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: But I can help them better if I do know, because then we have a place to work from.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually

text: You are feeling hopeless and worthless, and your thoughts support these intense emotions.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually

text: I don't know you, but I strongly believe that you have someone in your life who, if they heard your thoughts, would say "That's not true.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: I believe that there are people who would see your value clearly, even if in small things.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: What evidence might God...who sees all..have of your worth?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: What hint might God give you about your purpose?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: You suffer from severe anxiety, and the agoraphobia works together with fear; they're a tag team.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Fear tells you perhaps that people will reject you (or something equally bad), and then agoraphobia steps in and traps you and uses as evidence the fact that no one seems to be reaching out to you to convince you that you have no worth.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Do you see their plan?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Make her scared... keep her here alone...convince her it's hopeless.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: They both try to convince you that they are your only friends, except they're lying to you.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: They only want power over you.You forget your worth.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: You forget that we all have worth.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: No one is a waste.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: I believe all God's creatures have worth, and that we're here to use our gifts to improve the world, and to remind each other of our value.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: There are people out there needing your support as much as you need theirs.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Can you find them?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: My guess is you've been alone and isolated for a very long time and it's impossible for you to see your worth in this situation.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: We need mirrors to see our worth and other people are our mirrors.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: We see our value in their eyes.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Do you remember the first time you questioned your worth?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: What was happening that you blamed yourself for?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Can you speak to that child and tell her (or him) that whatever's happening isn't her fault?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: It's that child who cannot see her own worth, probably because someone treated her as though she had none.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: That's only a story though; not the truth.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Can you find another thread of a story?

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Who might tell a story of your worth?Oak Harbor, I believe that there is help closer than you think.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually
author: listener
text: Fear wants you to believe it's hopeless.

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually

title: I'm a mess physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: speaker
text: Both of my parents committed suicide together, and I was the one who found them. I suffer from overwhelming depression, which is having an extreme effect on me and my husband’s sex lives. He does not understand at all and is always making me feel so uncomfortable about sex.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: First, I want to tell you how sorry I am for the experience you had with your parents.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: That is a grief and trauma that is certainly hard to imagine.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: Trauma and grief can affect us in many ways, and certainly deeply personal things like our sex lives.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: It may be difficult for others to make the connection, but it is there.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: So, for example, if stress and trauma make you feel like you are not interested in sex, a partner may take it as a personal rejection rather than response to stress, trauma or grief.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: If your husband will agree to it, couple's counseling may be your best bet.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: A counselor can help you with your communication and may be able to provide some education to your husband about trauma and how it can have an impact on intimacy.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: If he doesn't agree to go, it may be worth it to go on your own.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: You still have a lot you are dealing with yourself.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: And sometimes our personally therapy can influence others, so it may be a good idea.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: It is important to remember that even though you are married you have the right to make decisions about your body, and that includes when you want to have sex with it.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: I hope this is helpful, and some of my colleagues may have ideas, also.

title: My husband makes me uncomfortable about sex
author: listener
text: Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I stress over everything. If I don't have enough "quality time" with my boyfriend, I start to feel resentment towards him. He has three children, and they are great kids, but I find we don't have much time together. I break down easily and find myself depressed.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: Everyone has some level of anxiety - it's what helps us respond to stressors in our lives and clues us into the fact that we need to respond to something going on.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: However, if you're feeling overwhelmed by racing thoughts, feeling like you spend a lot of energy worrying about something specific or even pretty much anything at all, and you're starting to find that it's getting in your way when it comes to living your life the way you want, then I'd suggest seeing a counselor or therapist for an assessment for anxiety.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: Your other concerns, though, seem pretty "normal" for someone who is in a relationship with a partner who has children.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: As a married stepmother, I've been there, and as a therapist, I can tell you that the boundaries and communication skills you have in your relationships need to be healthy for you to feel healthy.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: Finding some support from a group of others whose partners have children might be really helpful - being able to hear from others that you aren't alone in feeling like this can really lighten the load, and they might have some good ideas for handling certain situations.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: Another option is to find a counselor or therapist who has experience working with step/blended family dynamics - because even if you're not officially married, those dynamics come into play whenever there are kids from another relationship involved.

title: Do I have anxiety?
author: listener
text: You may even consider couples counseling so that both of you can learn to talk about your relationship needs and concerns in a way that will encourage connection and strengthen your sense of partnership.

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

text: I have been falling into a deep depression where I can no function during the day and night. The only time I am at peace is when I’m asleep. If I am with friends, family, at work, and mainly alone, I cannot think straight. I no longer feel like myself.

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

text: This may be a starting point for you.

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

text: It is common to go through a stage of adjustment after a breakup, which may include depression symptoms.

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

title: How can I take care of my depression from a breakup?

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: speaker
text: I am pretty sure I have depression and anxiety. I also have voices in my head. I have problems sleeping too. I've already been diagnosed with attention-deficit disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder. I have self-harmed in the last and used to be suicidal. How do I tell them this and ask for therapy?

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: listener
text: If you have already been diagnosed with attention-deficit disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder, can you go back to the people who diagnosed you with those things?It may be that your parents would be open to you talking with someone because it sounds like you have done this in the past.

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: listener
text: I don't know whether you have a specific reason that you are thinking they may have some hesitation, but if you are comfortable saying that you would really like to talk to someone because you are feeling sad or anxious (or whichever of your concerns you feel comfortable revealing to them), that may be a way to start the process.

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: listener
text: As for how you tell them about the fact that you have harmed yourself in the past and used to be suicidal, a therapist may be able to work together with you to discuss the best way to tell them about that.I'm not sure if you have told anyone about what you have been experiencing, but if you have some support there, perhaps they would be able to give you feedback about ways to talk with your parents as well.You mentioned that sometimes you hear voices.

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: listener
text: This can happen for a variety of reasons, but if the voices that you hear are giving you directions and you feel as though you might follow them, that would be a time to ask for immediate help, before you follow through with what they are telling you, perhaps by calling 800-273-8255.

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: listener
text: They may be able to connect you with local resources and they can definitely talk with you in the moment that you call.

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: speaker
text: I am pretty sure I have depression and anxiety. I also have voices in my head. I have problems sleeping too. I've already been diagnosed with attention-deficit disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder. I have self-harmed in the last and used to be suicidal. How do I tell them this and ask for therapy?

title: How do I tell my parents that I think I have some mental problems?
author: listener
text: What stops you now from telling your parents the way you are feeling?Do you imagine asking them for therapy would be a surprise for them?If they're paying attention to you at all, then I imagine they'd feel relief to know you're aware of having some feelings within yourself of a problem.If you believe they'd have a negative reaction to you asking for help, this may very well be part of why you are having problems in the first place.What reaction did your parents have when you were diagnosed with the other conditions?I'd separate their willingness to help you from your sense of needing help.If they do not want to help with finding a therapist for you, then start by looking for services available for people in your age group whose parents also do not wish to be involved in their child's emotional and psychological health.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: speaker
text: I'm not the same anymore, I don't know how to get back to who I am. I'm sad and confused and angry and tired. I don't sleep well.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: Being tired can really affect almost everyone's ability to work through things that make them sad, confused, or angry, among other emotions.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: If you're having difficulty sleeping, try to get into a habit of going to bed and waking up close to the same time every day.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: Also consider only using the bed for sleeping so your brain knows that it's time to sleep when you are in bed.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: If you are not sleeping while you are in bed, consider getting up and reading a book or doing something to make you tired before going back to bed.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: Hopefully you'll be able to establish a pattern.Sometimes sadness and other emotions make sleeping very difficult as well.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: Try keeping track of your moods to see what is leading up to the changes.If you're still struggling, consider talking with a therapist about the specifics and/or maybe talking with your primary care physician.

title: How do I stop feeling so awful?
author: listener
text: There are natural sleep remedies that he or she may recommend for you.

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?
author: listener
text: There are an infinite number of possibilities here.

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

text: You included a lot of things that you don't have.

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

text: I don't know how old your child or children is/are, but perhaps going back to work is something that can happen in the future.I wonder if you may consider who you have in your life who can support you.

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?

title: How can I be happy as a stay-at-home mom?
author: listener
text: For example, if your children are sleeping for about two hours, maybe 30 minutes of that could be reserved for you and the rest could be for cleaning or other things you need to do.

title: How do I balance school and life?
