title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: This could be a parent, a friend, someone at school, a coworker, or any number of other people.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: speaker
text: I stopped for a while, but I’ve started doing it again. It’s like an addiction. The more I try to stop, the more I want to do it. I’ve tried doing some of the stuff they say to do like draw, but it doesn’t work.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: I've heard people say that they cut themselves as a way to feel relief from different emotions.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: You're also right that when you try to focus on just not cutting, it becomes more difficult because it's what you are focused on.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: While that is still something to work on, it may also be helpful to find something else you can do instead.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: You said drawing doesn't work for you.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: Sometimes more physical activities, such as doing a few jumping jacks, can be helpful.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: If you don't exercise, it might be something to talk with your doctor about first.The more you can learn about what makes you want to cut, the easier it will be to find out what you could do to change that.

title: How can I resist the urge to cut?
author: listener
text: Try talking to somebody about what you are feeling in addition to the urge to cut.

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: speaker
text: I used to be the funny guy of the group—the class clown, if you will. I used to laugh uncontrollably all the time and be able to be social without it feeling awkward. Now I can't laugh at all, and I'm dead inside.

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: listener
text: If you look back to when you feel as though you were the "funny guy," I wonder what is different now?

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: listener
text: It may be that responsibilities have changed or any number of other things.I don't know whether you're also saying that you feel sad or if you're saying that you feel as though you don't have any big changes in your feelings.A lot of us tend to be really busy, and sometimes we over schedule ourselves to the point that we don't have time to have positive time for ourselves.

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: listener
text: Sometimes even if we are spending time with friends, we're thinking about work and all of the other things we need to do.I wonder if it feels awkward when you're with friends that you trust in an environment that you are used to.

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: listener
text: Maybe if that is more comfortable for you, it can be a stepping stone to focusing on how you feel better in those moments.It sounds as if you may have had an experience (or more than one) where you felt misunderstood or criticized and now reacting to people feels awkward.

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: listener
text: If so, try going back to people you trust.

title: Why can't I laugh anymore?
author: listener
text: Who do you have support from?

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: speaker
text: I'm starting to think that I might have depression. The thing is though, I'm not exactly sad. I can joke with my friends and stuff, but I've stopped caring about my work, and I've been starting to think that life is pointless. I really have no clue if I need help, or if I'm just tired or something.

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: It is possible that you have depression, but you could also be experiencing some other changes that mean that you have feelings of being sad without actually being depressed.

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: Your statement makes it sound like you've stopped caring about your work, but you're still going to work and doing your work.

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: It almost sounds like you are dissatisfied with your work.

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: Do you like what you do?

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: When you said that life is pointless, what makes it that way?

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: What is keeping you going?

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: Is there something you can do each day that you can find meaning in?You mentioned that you are not sure if you need help or are just tired.

title: Is it possible that I have depression?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you could certainly benefit from talking with someone about more specifics.I'm curious about how long you have felt this way and if you are aware of anything that is contributing to it.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: speaker
text: I've been feeling worthless, unaccomplished, and so frustrated. I want to break things, hit myself, run away, kick, scream, and cry. I just want to be happy and outgoing again. I want to be able to take care of my daughter and live comfortably.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Philadelphia, there is help out there.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: For your daughter's sake, start somewhere.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Feelings are only that; your worst fears about who you are are only based on a few moments that haven't gone well.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Depression is so treatable, but you have to seek treatment from a professional.Here's a quick exercise for you to do that can show you how therapy might work... fear is telling you the worst possible story of your life, right?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: So... if there was an opposite story...the very best story that someone could tell about you and your life...what would that be?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Who would be telling it?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Someone who loves you?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Someone who was around you when you were that outgoing person?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Someone who's been watching your life from the start?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: God?

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Write that best story.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: I dare you to give it as much credibility as the worst one.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: Therapy is often about helping people reject their "worst stories".

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: I invite you to start exploring with a qualified therapist whatever barriers stand between you and your best life.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener
text: I hope you reach out soon.

title: How do I get rid of depression?
author: listener

title: Is my depression sabotaging my job search?
author: speaker
text: I keep feeling paralyzed and unsure during interviews. Previous jobs have fired me for lack of performance, and five employers have rejected me after extensive personality tests and interviews. I'm afraid of continuing because my depression is getting worse. I'm already humiliated working for temp agencies and doubt my self-worth as a provider for my family.

title: Is my depression sabotaging my job search?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are feeling pretty overwhelmed and stuck between wanting to improve your work situation and worrying that you won't be able to.

title: Is my depression sabotaging my job search?
author: listener
text: It is possible that the paralysis, uncertainty, and self-doubt that you describe are contributing to your difficulty in getting  and maintaining a satisfying job as employers generally like to see that a potential employee is confident and can think on his or her feet.

title: Is my depression sabotaging my job search?
author: listener
text: With a competent therapist, you may be able to get more understanding of the roots of these feelings and learn how to move forward in your search for a better work life in a way that leaves you feeling confident and capable.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: speaker
text: I feel like I am not at a good state of mind. I'm very unsettled in my soul. I'm not happy with myself or the decisions I make, which makes me not happy with anyone else. I feel like a failure most of my days. I don't feel like I'm good at anything anymore. I feel like less of a person.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: It seems like you may be experiencing depression symptoms, they could be the triggered by unexpected life changes, or building up throughout time.The important part is that you have identified them and wanting to change them.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: The first step is to establish a self-care routine that will help you to feel centered and motivated: go for walks, or make any physical activity that you enjoy ( be kind to yourself, anything helps at this point), eat balanced, add whole grains and fibers to your diet, make a point to rest at night and avoid naps, practice a hobby that you love, or look for a new one that you are curious about.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: You mentioned that you feel unsettled in your soul: explore your spirituality, meditate about what makes your soul at peace, and find ways to practice that or surround yourself by those activities.If you find it difficult to begin, talk to your therapist to identify roadblocks and ways to find motivation.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Suicidal and homicidal thoughts are common but serious depression symptoms, discuss them with your therapist, contact your doctor or psychiatrist, and call 9-1-1 if its and emergency.Once you feel stable, you can focus on exploring the source of the problem and see if you need to make changes or learn coping skills that will help you manage it.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: It will also be a good time to explore your spirituality and your purpose in life, that may help you to feel better with yourself and then happier around others.¿Cómo puedo volver a ser la persona que realmente soy?Siento que mi mente no está bien.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: My espíritu está intranquilo.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: No me siento feliz con las decisiones que tomo, lo cual me hace infeliz con los demás.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Me siento como un fracaso la mayoría del tiempo.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Siento que ya no soy bueno para nada.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Siento que soy menos que los demás.Al parecer estas experimentando síntomas de depresión, la cual puede ser causada por cambios recientes en tu vida o estarse acumulando a través del tiempo.Lo importante en este momento es que tú reconoces los síntomas y estas buscando cambiar la situación.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: El primer paso sería trabajar en restablecer una rutina de cuidado personal que te ayude a sentirte emocionalmente estable y motivado: Sal a caminar o hacer alguna actividad física(ten compasión contigo mismo, cualquier cosa funciona para comenzar), comienza a comer balanceado, especialmente granos y fibras integrales, , procura descansar en las noches y evita las siestas, y practica algún tipo de actividad que hayas disfrutado en el pasado o que te de curiosidad.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Mencionaste que tu espíritu esta intranquilo, explora tu espiritualidad, y que te ayudaría a encontrar la paz, busca la manera de hacer esa práctica una rutina.Si te cuesta mucho trabajo iniciar estas actividades, será bueno buscar a un consejero para que te ayude a identificar formas de estar motivado o obstáculos que te estén deteniendo.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Es común tener pensamientos que atentan en contra de tu vida o la de otros, discútelos con tu terapeuta, con tu medico primario o psiquiatra, y llama al 9-1-1 si es una emergencia.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: Ya que consigas estabilidad, puedes comenzar a trabajar o explorar la causa del problema y ver si hay cambios mayores que debes hacer o destrezas que debes aprender para manejar el mismo.

title: How can I get back to being the person I truly am?
author: listener
text: También es un buen momento para explorar tu espiritualidad mas profundamente y tu propósito en la vida, cuando encontramos un propósito y como ejercerlo, tendemos a ser más felices con nosotros mismos y con los demás.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: speaker
text: I am not sure if I am depressed. I don't know how to bring it up to my parents, and that makes me miserable.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: You are not alone, many people fear opening up to family members about the topic of depression or mental illness.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: There are many different reason why some may fear telling their parents.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: The most common thoughts I hear in my office are: " My parents won't understand me", I may cause more problems to the family", "I am worried that something bad may happen if I tell them".

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: If possible express your current concerns and worries to your parents.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: You can start the conversation with your parents by saying "I have not been feeling like myself lately, and I may want to see a counselor".

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: I think you are doing the right thing by going on this website and asking for help.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: Just a helpful tip: positive self-talk can be beneficial before having difficult conversations with others.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: For example, tell yourself something positive before talking to your parents such as "I feel confident in myself, and I am doing this to overcome my fear of talking to my parents" can help to decrease the anxiety you are feeling leading up to the conversation.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: I would recommend if you are feeling depressed or down it would be beneficial to seek counseling to understand your current thoughts and behaviors.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: Best of luck and hope you decide to start counseling.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: speaker
text: I am not sure if I am depressed. I don't know how to bring it up to my parents, and that makes me miserable.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: I am so sorry you are struggling!

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: I do think it's a good idea to share your feelings with your parents and perhaps get some help connecting with a counselor or therapist if you feel that might help.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: There are lots of ways to tell them, depending on your relationship.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: Maybe saying "I wanted to tell you guys something.. sometimes I worry that I might be depressed."

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: Or, some folks will write a letter, or even send a text.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: The most important thing is that you tell someone you trust so you don't feel so miserable.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: I hope this helps.

title: How can I bring up my possible depression to my parents?
author: listener
text: Best of luck.

title: Why do I feel so lonely when I have friends and attention?
author: speaker
text: I live a normal life. I have tons of friends and family, but I feel lonely.

title: Why do I feel so lonely when I have friends and attention?
author: listener
text: This may be happening because you and the others are not connected to each other on a level which reaches your emotions.Loneliness may show the absence of feeling a variety of emotions when you are among others.How many friends you have doesn't affect whether you and someone else feel emotionally engaged with one another.Consider if you feel like concentrating your friendship on more intensively sharing your feelings with a few of your friends.This may lead to fewer friends who are also more meaningful to you and your feeling a decrease of loneliness.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I started having anxiety three months ago. I'm new to having anxiety, and it's making me depressed.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: I agree with Cory.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) does seem to help a lot of people who struggle with anxiety.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: It's not the only type of therapy that can help, but it seems to help people in a way that is more natural and realistic.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: As Cory mentioned, anxiety is something that is part of life, so therapies that indicate we can get rid of it are questionable.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: Our natural inclination when we have anxiety is to STOP any and all things that may cause it or provoke it.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: We do this because we think it will help, but it actually doesn't.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: Anxiety usually has us rehashing the past or rehearsing the future while ignoring the present.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: ACT helps folks who have those kinds of tendencies.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: Be well..Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I started having anxiety three months ago. I'm new to having anxiety, and it's making me depressed.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: As a past sufferer of anxiety myself, I have learned that it is a natural part of life, it is a natural part of us, the longer we try to run from it the more it entangles us in its clutches, if we deny certain parts of ourselves we will become depressed or even oppressed, the only way to deal with anxiety is to embrace it and accept it, and in fighting the fight without fighting we will eventually win, I would encourage you to look into Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, your answer I think lies in that area of research.

title: How can I control my anxiety?
author: listener
text: Hope this helps,C

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: speaker
text: I have a lot on my mind, but all I want to do is stay locked in my room and not socialize with anyone. Why do I feel so alone?

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: There is a difference in someone agreeing to try something and agreeing to continue to do it.

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: Have you ever been willing to try something and then decided you did not like it?

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: A type of food?

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: A sport?

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: A new restaurant?

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: A type of dance?

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: So this does not mean that things have changed between you.

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: It does mean that the two of you may need to spend some time to find out what you both like.

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: Instead of looking at it as a rejection, look at it as a challenge, an adventure that the two of you can go on as explorers together.

title: Why have I been feeling empty lately?
author: listener
text: Some couples have even found it helpful to each write down ten things they would like the other person to try and then each person can pick three things from the other person's list to add into their life together when they chose to over the next few weeks.

title: How can I deal with my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: speaker
text: I feel angry, anxious, and depressed. The PTSD I suffer is from a past relationship.

title: How can I deal with my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: If the symptoms are to the extent that they are affecting your ability to function, you may want to consider seeking treatment.

title: How can I deal with my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: PTSD, anxiety, and depression all typically respond well to treatment if provided by a trained clinician.

title: How can I deal with my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Common types of treatment for PTSD that you may want to look into include Cognitive Processing Therapy or EMDR.

title: How can I deal with my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: The nice things about Cognitive Processing Therapy is that it is time limited and only lasts 17 sessions typically.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: speaker
text: I've had posttraumatic stress disorder for years without my parents ever finding out. I want to overcome it, but it’s so vivid, it’s like it’s happening again. I'm scared and paranoid. I have depression, which I have been struggling with since a young age.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: What is the reason you wouldn't want your parents to know you are trying to find your way through PTSD?Would they believe that you've been traumatized?And, do you feel that your parents had a hand in creating your trauma?There is no need to tell your parents you have PTSD unless you feel that doing so will help you.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Maybe you intuitively realize that they don't want to understand or know about this.How did you come to the conclusion that you have PTSD?If you are working with a therapist, and a minor, then  the laws of your State dictate what information your parents can ask your therapist about you.If you are a grown person and working with a therapist,  you have complete legally protected privacy of what you talk about with your therapist.In any case, a good starting point is to know exactly your own reason for wishing to keep your psychological situation hidden from your parents.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: speaker
text: I've had posttraumatic stress disorder for years without my parents ever finding out. I want to overcome it, but it’s so vivid, it’s like it’s happening again. I'm scared and paranoid. I have depression, which I have been struggling with since a young age.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a very complex issue.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: It is the root cause of many other issues including depression, anxiety and anger to name a few.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Re-experiencing the event is a telltale symptom of PTSD.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: One of the best things you can do for yourself is to find someone who specializes in this area to help you work through the symptoms associated with this disorder as well as directly addressing the event/events that initially caused the symptoms.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: There are various treatment methods available to helping professionals that are successful in treating this disorder.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: In the meantime there is a book called "The Body Keeps the Score", it is informative and may be helpful for you on your journey.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: It is my hope that you are not dealing with this alone.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Best wishes!

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: speaker
text: I've had posttraumatic stress disorder for years without my parents ever finding out. I want to overcome it, but it’s so vivid, it’s like it’s happening again. I'm scared and paranoid. I have depression, which I have been struggling with since a young age.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, ptsd is not something that can be cured.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Ptsd can be managed through therapy.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Mindfulness can assist in redirecting thoughts and gaining further control over paranoia.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Therapy is confidential and there are different ways you can obtain treatment.

title: How can I get over my posttraumatic stress disorder without my parents knowing about it?
author: listener
text: Mental health professional have availability to provide therapy online,  on the phone or in person.

title: How can I love myself?
author: speaker
text: I was anxious to go to middle school. I was afraid of what people might say about me, so when school started, I wasn't acting like myself. I was quiet, which I'm usually not. I didn't talk to anybody and didn't have any friends. Then a few years later, my grandma died. I really became depressed and stop going to school for a little. I hated myself and still do. I just need help. I need someone to care for me. I need someone to show that they care.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: I agree; you need more care and support.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: No one deserves to feel alone, or like they hate themselves.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: We're all wonderful, imperfect, complicated people and we're at our best when we're all helping each other.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: I'm glad you wrote this question, because a lot of people have this feeling sometimes.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: I can tell that you're smart, because you seem to sense that the two things you wrote about are connected...you "not being yourself", and then how you felt when your grandma died.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: When Grandma died, you needed and deserved extra love and support, but the people around you didn't seem to give it to you, maybe.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: My hunch is that they wanted to, but that they didn't know how much you needed it, or what you needed exactly.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: The older you get, the more you will have to take charge of letting people know what you need.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: Maybe this is one of the suckier parts of being mature, but that's how it works.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: When you started middle school, it sounds like you changed; you got more quiet, right?

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: That must have felt weird, to not be acting like yourself.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: It sounds like fear tricked you into thinking people wouldn't like you.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: Fear can be silly.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: So then, fear got you to not show yourself, and when we don't show ourselves, people can't see who we are; they don't know us as well and then they don't know what we need and they can't care for us as well either.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: Fear of not being liked isolated you from the people who love you.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: It does that to a lot of us.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: So, where you're at right now is because of what fear did to you, and also because when Grandma died you were already isolated so people couldn't see your pain and know that you needed support.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: There's a simple solution, but you'd have to be brave enough to look fear in the face and say "Get off my back!".

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: "You're not helping me by telling me lies."

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: Can you be brave enough to go back to your old, louder, self?

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: If you talk to the people closest to you...tell them what you think and how you feel, then they'll be able to give you the care that you want and deserve.

title: How can I love myself?
author: listener
text: I wish you well as you try this!

title: How do I cope with bad thoughts?
author: speaker
text: People have been calling me names, and I have had enough of it. I cannot stand it anymore I'm done. I have told someone this, and that is why I am writing this. The thoughts are awful.

title: How do I cope with bad thoughts?
author: listener
text: It's sounds like you are feeling pretty overwhelmed with intrusive thoughts and are feeling very criticized by others as well.

title: How do I cope with bad thoughts?
author: listener
text: I think it is great that you are reaching out and I can tell that you want this to change.

title: How do I cope with bad thoughts?
author: listener
text: Working with a competent therapist may be a good option for getting some more clarity about what is going on, developing ways to cope, and eventually getting relief from these overwhelming experiences.

title: How can I feel so empty even though I'm only in my early teens?
author: speaker
text: My life is completely normal, yet I feel empty inside. I feel as if I already know why I'm alive: to reproduce and die.

title: How can I feel so empty even though I'm only in my early teens?
author: listener
text: Are there any times or moments in which you feel other than "empty"?

title: How can I feel so empty even though I'm only in my early teens?
author: listener
text: Start with knowing the context of when you feel something other than empty.If there is no recent example, then in your mind, go back in time to think of when you felt something other than empty.

title: How can I feel so empty even though I'm only in my early teens?
author: listener
text: Recall what you liked about this time, whether you were by yourself or with others, what type of activity you were involved at the time of non-emptiness.How did you come to your conclusion that your life purpose is to reproduce and die?

title: How can I feel so empty even though I'm only in my early teens?
author: listener
text: If this is what your parents, siblings and extended family believe, it is possible that you have a broader view of yourself and haven't yet uncovered a way of defining your own philosophy of living.Give yourself the time to browse around online, or in person social meet ups, on your interests.

title: How can I feel so empty even though I'm only in my early teens?
author: listener
text: It is possible you will discover entire new areas of life and ways of considering life, that are brand new to you and which connect to your true self.This is one way of respecting your individuality, which of itself, may decrease your sense of emptiness.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: speaker
text: I'm almost never happy. Half of the time, I don't feel anything. I find it easy to make myself feel nothing. I know I push people away because it’s easier. I just want answers. I'm sick of feeling this way. It’s ruining my relationships with people.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Maybe you have depression.The name of your condition matters much less than the descriptions you wrote of how you feel.Since you've observed how you sometimes interact with people and realize you aren't happy with the result, you've a very solid starting point for reflecting on your deeper wishes in relating to others.Start with asking reasons of yourself about the puzzling aspects of how you're engaging with others.Theorizing as to "why" you feel that pushing people away is "easier", and easier than what?Googling the keywords of how you feel, may open a starting point for ideas on knowing yourself and what you wish for.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: speaker
text: I'm almost never happy. Half of the time, I don't feel anything. I find it easy to make myself feel nothing. I know I push people away because it’s easier. I just want answers. I'm sick of feeling this way. It’s ruining my relationships with people.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Hi Loyal, This is a common question.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: I suggest that you not diagnose yourself (only a physician can do that), but the symptoms you mention are certainly common signs of depression; rarely happy, emotional numbness, hopelessness, isolation.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Depression is very common.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Research suggests that one in three people may experience it in their lifetime and at any one point, ten percent of adults may be experiencing it.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Most therapists are very good at spotting the signs and treating accordingly, although only a physician can prescribe medication.The great news is that depression is treatable.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Some people experiencing depression may benefit from medication (often to lift the heaviness of the illness enough so that one can focus on psychotherapy), and therapies such as cognitive behavioural therapy and behavioural activation therapy have demonstrated a clear ability to reduce symptoms of depression.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Even if medication helps, seeing a therapist to look at the roots of your depression and to build coping skills is very important.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: A qualified therapist will help you look at the barriers to happiness in your specific case and suggest a course of treatment.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: You are not alone, and you don't have to suffer.

title: How do I know if I have depression?
author: listener
text: Keep asking questions and you will find your answers!

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are in a terrible place. Part of me wants to fix it, but then I'm caught up with not knowing how and not being able to communicate my feelings to him because he always feels I'm blaming him. Sometimes I am because the feelings of distrust are so strong. I feel they must be coming from something he's doing, but sometimes I know I'm being irrational. Still, that doesn't stop the anxiety. The other half of the time, I just want to walk away, but I feel like that will only be a temporary fix.

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: listener
text: You may be pressuring yourself to be the one person who fixes the relationship.

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: listener
text: This is impossible because the relationship belongs to both of you.Has he told you whether he feels about himself that how he interacts with you, is contributing to problems in the couple?Is he willing to understand what you're asking of him, without shutting down with whatever he is feeling when he feels blamed?Your feelings of distrust are the natural outcome of not being properly heard and understood.

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: listener
text: He's not willing to listen to you, so of course you're frustrated and this frustration comes out in all sorts of uneasy feelings.Willingness to hear each other in a non-defensive way, sometimes requires a couples therapist's assistance.Ask your husband if he's willing to understand, not judge you.

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: listener
text: Be willing yourself to do the same.If after trying and getting nowhere, you'll know when to stop trying on your own as a couple and to find a specifically trained couples therapists.Warning, not all therapists are trained to do couples therapy.

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: listener
text: Ask the therapist if they've had specialized training in couples therapy.Otherwise, having a referee type therapy session of, "what do you think", "what do you think?

title: I think I have anxiety and depression. It has manifested an extreme distrust for others
author: listener
text: ", isn't going to do anything except frustrate both of you further.Good luck!

title: I have voices in my head
author: speaker
text: They don't go away, and I feel like I'm going crazy. Does that ever stop? Can it be a symptom of medication?

title: I have voices in my head
author: listener
text: This can certainly be a side effect of some medications.

title: I have voices in my head
author: listener
text: If the voices are so powerful that you can not sleep or they are constantly present, you shouldn't wait any time, but go and see your doctor straight away.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: speaker
text: A girl and I were madly in love. We dated for over a year and were even talking about marriage and future plans together. She moved away for school, and we attempted a long distance relationship. We eventually broke up. It's been a year now, and I still haven't lost my feelings for her. I still love her the same way I did. I've suffered from depression ever since the breakup and have been unable to connect with anyone else. It's damaging me and my life.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Hi Boise, I'm sorry that you've lost this love.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: The fact that you were planning marriage and a future tells me that you meant something very special to each other at that time.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: It's different now...you're not together anymore, but you can't accept this, right?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Good for you for identifying that this situation is damaging your life.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: You've been grieving for longer than you were together.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Oh, but really you've not been grieving...you're stuck still loving her instead of moving forward.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Unrequited love is a recipe for eternal heartache.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Let's look at some possible blocks to moving forward.It could be that there's something unfinished for you.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Maybe you felt hurt and you didn't have the chance to say so, or you felt you hurt her and you didn't have the chance to make it right.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Maybe there's a burning question you need to ask or something else you need to say.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Maybe you want to tell her you've never stopped loving her, and see if she feels the same way.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: If this is the case, you have two choices, right?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: You can reach out and say what you need to say, or you can stop ruminating on that question and let it go.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: If you reach out, there's no guarantee it will go well or that she'll even respond.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Maybe write her a letter and don't send it (or send it...it might be worth the risk).

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Use the next paragraph to help you decide.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Do you know how she feels?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: How did it end?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Did she end it?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Was it ended just because of the distance, or are there more differences between you that didn't work?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Sometimes people are so in love that they can't clearly see that the other person isn't in love with them anymore.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Use the information you have about what she wants for her life...can you honour what she says she needs?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: If she's asked for distance, you would do well to honour that.A key to moving forward: look at your thoughts and where they're getting stuck.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Write it down.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: What bad thing can happen if you let it go?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Or "If I move forward, that will mean..."  Keep going...what would be the worst part of that?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: This kind of exploring can help you identify your stuck place.It is possible that you've turned this ending into some kind of negative meaning about you or your future.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: As in "If this person doesn't love me, then I'm unlovable", or "No one will ever love me as much as she did".

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: So your need to cling to her in your heart is your way of rejecting that negative message about yourself or the future.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Can you find another way to reject that message?

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: Try saying these things to yourself:I know she loved me.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: There is evidence of that.I was a good partner.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: There is evidence of that.It's part of life to fall in love and then have to move forward...I can do this and learn from it.Many people like me...that's how I know I'm lovable.It's normal to feel sad.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: I'm grieving a lost love.I want to move forward and not stare in the rearview mirror.I know more love awaits me if I can get fear out of the way.If this person loved me, others can too, (but not if I'm clinging to some old memory)These are the kinds of things a therapist would explore with you.

title: I'm depressed and unable to connect with people after my breakup
author: listener
text: I wish you well!

title: What can I do if I need to talk to someone but I have no money?
author: speaker
text: I am broke, but I am sure I have been depressed for the past couple of years. I have always had anxiety. I just need someone to talk to right now. I don't have any friends or family I can talk to. I'm on the verge of just giving up.

title: What can I do if I need to talk to someone but I have no money?
author: listener
text: Good question.

title: What can I do if I need to talk to someone but I have no money?
author: listener
text: There are resources out there - people to talk to.

title: What can I do if I need to talk to someone but I have no money?
author: listener
text: I'd try going to this link and calling the free 24/7 hotline: http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/

title: I'm depressed because my mother kicked me out after having a child
author: speaker
text: I just had a newborn. When I brought him home, my mom told me to leave. Now I'm in a women's home. I don't see my boyfriend that often because he works. The women's place is helping me find an apartment so I can go back to work and get child care.

title: I'm depressed because my mother kicked me out after having a child
author: listener
text: Congrats on the birth of your son!Was your mom's request for you to leave her house, one which she asked awhile ago or was this her greeting when you walked in the door?My question is whether your mom had some changed circumstance in her life, whether she and you discussed living arrangements prior to your son's birth, or whether nothing was talked about, you assumed you'd be living with her, she assumed you wouldn't, and the two of you didn't speak to one another about any of this.Depending on the answers, there may be clues as to handling future expectations of others, especially your mom.From what you write, the women's home is supportive of your basic daily living needs.

title: I'm depressed because my mother kicked me out after having a child
author: listener
text: It is good news that the people who run this home know and offer community resources.In your interactions with the staff of the women's home, ask all the questions necessary so you'll have a clear understanding of the apartment lease, anything at all that is on your mind about becoming employed and finding childcare.The point is to have all the major steps you're about to start, addressed.This way, you'll be minimizing the possibility of any sudden bad news by the women's home, told to you.Sending lots of good luck!

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: speaker
text: I have experienced cycles of depression for the past four years, and it hits me harder every time it comes back. This past time, it was extremely debilitating, so I went on Wellbutrin. I could feel the effects of the medicine after the first week. A month and a half later, I decided that my depression was being caused by my own unwillingness to move forward and address my behaviors and thoughts that were keeping me in a place of despair. I became worried that the medicine was making me complacent and prohibiting me from working out what I needed to in my life to bring back true fulfillment. I stopped taking it a month ago and feel okay; a lot of the anxiety it was paired with has gone away. However, I still don't feel my sense of self has been completely regained, and I have days where I feel a zombie-like haze of having no interests or the ability to fully concentrate on anything. Is it better to continue letting time and good habits work out the remaining depression or should I go back on the medicine?

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: listener
text: Deciding whether or not psychiatric medicine is a good option can be complicated, as you have noticed, and only a person who is licensed to prescribe can give you medical advice regarding medications.

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: listener
text: While there is sometimes relief from symptoms from medication, as you have pointed out, there are often negative side effects as well.

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: listener
text: While I can't give you advice on whether or not to continue medication, I would urge you to take an inventory of the positive and negative effects that you have noticed and educate yourself as much as possible about the short and long-term costs and benefits of psychiatric medication.

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: listener
text: If you can find a doctor, psychiatrist, or ARNP who is competent in mental health, it may also benefit you to consult with them.One thing that I am wondering about is, what is your support system like, in regards to your fight against depression?

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: listener
text: Are you seeing a therapist or attending any therapeutic or supportive group?

title: Should I go back on my medicine?
author: listener
text: While there are many things that one can do on their own to work through challenges such as depression, psychotherapy has been shown time and again in research to be highly effective and sometimes having a relationship with a caring, competent professional who understands depression and ways of helping can make a huge difference.

title: I always feel depressed
author: speaker
text: I think about death all the time because I feel so alone. I want someone to love and someone to love me.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: Feeling alone and/or isolated is almost always associated with being depressed.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: As humans, we need connection and interaction with others in order to feel satisfied.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: Given that you are frequently thinking about death, I highly recommend that you see a mental health professional as soon as possible to help assess your immediate needs and address any underlying issues that may be contributing to your feelings of loneliness and depression.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: The good news is that with proper, consistent treatment and commitment to change, things can really turn around for you.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: A therapist can work with you on building enjoyable activities into your daily routine, change maladaptive thought patterns that contribute to your sadness, and help with exploring what has gotten you to where you are.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: By learning about where your sadness originates, engaging in preferred activities, and changing your thought patterns, you should begin feeling relief from the burden of depression.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: What will likely result, is further opportunity to find social outlets and an increased ability to connect with others.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: Don't give up.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: Create some short terms goals that you can likely achieve and make your treatment a priority and a focus.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: You have already taken the first step in getting better by writing to this site.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: Keep on this path and believe in yourself.

title: I always feel depressed
author: listener
text: Best of luck to you!

title: I'm overwhelmed and depressed
author: speaker
text: I'm unemployed just relocated. I can't get approved for a place to live because of past mistakes which follow me to this day. I'm depressed and on the verge of loosing my partner because I'm overwhelmed and have trouble functioning on a daily basis. I see no light at the end of this tunnel and need some help. I see no point in this chaos infested joke some call life.

title: I'm overwhelmed and depressed
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are feeling like things are hopeless and out of control and you're not sure what to do about it.

title: I'm overwhelmed and depressed
author: listener
text: If you can find a competent therapist to work with, together you may be able to come up with some strategies for alleviating the overwhelming distress that you are experiencing and gain some insight into what may be contributing to these challenges.

title: I'm overwhelmed and depressed
author: listener
text: Additionally, a therapist may be able to support you in getting back on your feet in regards to work, a place to live, and showing up with your partner in a way that will be more satisfying to you.

title: I'm studying abroad, and I'm depressed
author: speaker
text: I'm supposed to stay here the rest of my academic life, but I've never liked it here, not even before I came. I’ve never felt like I belong, I’ve missed my country every second in the past four months, and I'm just miserable. I'm gaining weight, doing nothing, and crying for hours straight. Is it time to go back home or is it just culture shock?

title: I'm studying abroad, and I'm depressed
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are feeling very unsure and out of place and the prospect of continuing to feel as you do now for the remainder of schooling seems daunting.

title: I'm studying abroad, and I'm depressed
author: listener
text: Without getting to know more about you and your experiences here and at home, it is hard to say what you should do, however, I think exploring these things with a competent therapist may help you to discover the answer.

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: speaker
text: I'm going through a divorce with my wife of three years, who I've known since the 4th grade and been involved with for seven years! We just had a baby seven months ago and never got along with my mother, who I've lived with for years. I am now back with my mother because I have nowhere to go with this divorce looming. I'm heart broken because I fell into a depression, I haven't seen my child in a while, I'm having good and bad dreams, and I feel hated. Can you help? Can you intervene? Can I speak with someone?

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: listener
text: It's hard to accept the end of a marriage when it's not your choice; you feel powerless, abandoned and unwanted.

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: listener
text: Your wife has the right to decide not to be in a marriage with you, and a therapist can help you accept and move through this change that has broken your heart and left you lost.

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: listener
text: You don't indicate why you haven't seen your child, and you may want to consult with a lawyer about the laws in your area and how to gain access to your baby.

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: listener
text: Therapists don't intervene in these ways.

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: listener
text: The marriage may be ending, but your role as a loving father is only beginning.

title: I'm depressed because my wife is divorcing me and I haven't seen my child in a while
author: listener
text: You can focus on giving your child the gift of two parents who respect each other.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I have manic depression and last summer was very very bad. I have recurring nightmares and I avoid anything that will give me a similar feeling as I did that summer.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: A PTSD diagnosis requires an event which occurred at least 6 months prior to the symptoms.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: Depression is a common symptom of PTSD, but depression can come from many other sources as well.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: In the end, diagnoses are systems of behavioral labels.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: If you believe that one label (PTSD) is worse than another (Depression), you are creating a false hierarchy.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: Consider consulting a CBT therapist, such as the fine clinicians listed in AcademyofCT.org.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: You may also want to look at my book, Living Yes, for many ideas about challenging your thinking and improving you mood.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: www.LivingYes.org.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: I hope you feel better soon.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: ~Mark  (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: speaker
text: I have manic depression and last summer was very very bad. I have recurring nightmares and I avoid anything that will give me a similar feeling as I did that summer.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: In general, the answer is no.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: Depression can not not generally cause PTSD.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: Your question does make a lot of sense, though.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: Depression is a common symptom of PTSD.

title: Is it possible to get PTSD from being very depressed?
author: listener
text: A counselor in your area should be able to help you what's going on - either feelings of depression, PTSD, or both.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: speaker
text: My doctor thinks that seeing a psychiatrist will help with my depression and anxiety. Now my anxiety is worse, what do I do? Writing on here has taken every bit of strength I have left.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: Did you take the medication the way the psychiatrist prescribed it?

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: Did you follow up with her/him to report how it was going?

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: Different medications work differently with different people.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: It's not always the first one that helps.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: And some of the medications take some time to have an effect.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: Give the doctor the chance to help you.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: I suggest you find a certified CBT therapist to help you examine your thinking.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
author: listener
text: www.AcademyofCT.org has listings of the finest CBT clinicians.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers

text: In the meantime, do some "anxiety fasting" by taking a few minutes to do something nice for yourself right now.

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers

title: I hate talking to people much less strangers
