title: I get depressed whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. What do I do?
author: speaker
text:
My last relationships have ended horribly. They just up and abandoned me. One of them I have never gotten closure with over it, leaving me emotionally wrecked. I know something's wrong with me but I don't know how to even start trying to better myself.
 I get into these depressed like states whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. I know that I shouldn't act like that because people are genuinely busy, but I feel like they're doing it just because they don't want to be around me.

title: I get depressed whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. What do I do?
author: listener
text: Frequently when working with clients, I utilize the A-B-C model developed by Albert Ellis, the founder of Rational Emotive Behavior Theory.

title: I get depressed whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. What do I do?
author: listener
text: The theory basically states that you can not control an event but you can control your reaction to the emotions associated with said event.

title: I get depressed whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. What do I do?
author: listener
text: For instance here is an example:A (Action or Event): You need to talk to someone and that person is not calling you back.B (Behavior or Response): You begin to tell yourself that this person is too busy for me or I am not important to this person.C (Consequence): You feel depressed.If you look at the model, B has a direct effect on C. The thought is if you change your reaction to A, then C will have a better consequence, such as:A: stays the same.B (this is what you change): This person must be busy, they will call me back when they get a chance or I can call someone else to lean on for support until this person is available.C: Decreased feelings of depression & overall functioning improves.This is just an example but if you actively work to replace the negative thought patterns that effect your behavior, studies show that your overall outlook and mood will improve.

title: I get depressed whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. What do I do?
author: listener
text: If this model resonates with you, I recommend "Feeling better, getting better, staying better" by Alber Ellis.

title: I get depressed whenever anyone I care about is too busy to be with me. What do I do?
author: listener
text: In addition, looking for support groups in your area are a great source of support when you are feeling abandoned or alone.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: speaker
text: I don't know what's wrong with me. At times I can be really happy, excited, I'll talk fast, and I want to do things. But lately I've been staying up way later and sleeping too much. I don't hang out with friends, I don't really have them. I feel nothing, worthless. I want to do nothing, I have no interest in anything.    All I usually do is stay in my room. I want to be happy, I want to be nice. What's wrong with me?

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: I'm sorry to hear that you are feeling as if you're in a slump.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: First of all, nothing is wrong with you.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: Many people report similar symptoms.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: Have you ever talked with a physician regarding your symptoms?

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: Two extreme emotions such as feeling extremely happy and then feeling extremely low for a length of time may indicate a mood disorder.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: I think it would be best to talk with your doctor or a therapist to help pinpoint the issue causing them.It's possible that it could just be certain stressors in your life that are causing the two extremities but you definitely want to rule out any mental health issues.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: If it is in fact mental health related there are many medications or therapy choices that can help.

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: Thanks for reaching out!

title: How do I get over a slump?
author: listener
text: I hope that you will feel back on track soon!

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: speaker
text: I've have lived for sometime with depression but things have gotten a lot better, but why is it so hard to get over anxiety and social isolation?

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: The best way to handle depression and anxiety is with a combination of appropriate medication given to you by a medical doctor, and therapy to help you understand the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that are causing the depression and anxiety in the first place and then to replace these with more positive thoughts and behaviors.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: This is not something that anyone should just “white knuckle” and try to get through on their own with no help.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a technique that has been proven helpful for depression and anxiety.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: This takes a therapist trained in CBT.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: There are some things in life that you cannot change and must learn to accept.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: A lot of people spend time trying to change things that they have no control over.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: This may be the behavior of someone else in your life or it could be a situation that you cannot change, such as the recent death of a loved one, a lost relationship, or an accident or illness which has left you handicapped.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: In cases like this, what can change is your attitude and thoughts about the situation that you now find yourself in.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: One thing that is inevitable about life is that stuff happens and it is not always pleasant.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Some people take these unpleasant occurrences very hard and it throws them into a deep depression.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Other people seem to be able to handle life’s ups and downs and bounce back.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: They do this with having positive coping skills in their life.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Learning new coping skills is something your therapist can help you with.A lot of people are so focused on trying to change the things in their life that they cannot change and are ignoring the things that they can change.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: There are things that you can do.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Here is a quote for you to consider.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: “You are getting almost everything that you are getting based on the choices that you have made.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: You will continue to get the same thing out of life until you make some changes.” Another quote I like is “You will find a way or you will find an excuse.” Don’t ever say that you have no choice.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Everyone has a choice.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: You might not particularly like any of the choices that you are facing, but you do have choices.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Not happy in a relationship?

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: You can leave it.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Hate your job?

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Get a new one.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: If it matters to you, you will find a way.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Don’t sit there complaining about everything but not doing anything different or better.Take care of yourself.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Exercise is very important not only for your physical health, but for your mental health as well.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Eating right and exercising will help you feel better about yourself.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Also, find a meditation that works for you.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: There are progressive muscle relaxation exercises, visual and mental meditations, and many many more.

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: Start making some positive changes in your life today!

title: How do I get over anxiety, depression, and isolation?
author: listener
text: You can do it!

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: speaker
text: I'm in a state of depression right now. Who can I talk to? I've been sick in a lot of pain and crying. Don't know where to turn.

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: listener
text: First of all, if you’re sick and in pain, have you seen your doctor?

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: listener
text: If you have a chronic illness and pain, this can often lead to depression and is very common.

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: listener
text: You’ve taken the first step to dealing with it.

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: listener
text: You can talk to your doctor, even if your depression isn’t related to your health.

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: listener
text: He or she can either look at prescribing you an antidepressant or can refer you to a psychologist or psychiatrist.If that’s not really an option for you, there are also helplines (local or national) or support groups where people dealing with similar issues can talk to each other.

title: How do I deal with depression?
author: listener
text: If you can't find any in your area (newspapers usually publish this information), there are online support groups as well.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: speaker
text: I've been married for 3 years and I have two kids. During my 3-years married, my husband cheated on me twice. The second time really got to me and at my lowest I hurt him back. We aren't communicating as well as I would like. What do I do?

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Hi there.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Thank you reaching out for help.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: It takes a lot of courage for someone that is being abused to reach out for help.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: I want you to know that I am here to help you in any way that I can.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: First and foremost, you did not mention whether or not you had children yourself by this man.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: I’m going to assume there are.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: So, the most important thing right at this moment is asking yourself, if you and your children are safe?

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Is the boyfriend currently living in the home or is he coming and going?

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: If he is coming and going or currently living in the home, my suggestion for you to is to pack a bag for you and your children and go somewhere safe (i.e.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: family members home, friend or a shelter temporarily).

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: I cannot stress this enough.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Although, some people tend to minimize their abusers behavior (i.e.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: they only do it when they are drinking, they only do it when they are mad), it’s those individuals that find themselves or their children in a serious situation.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: So, you can never take abuse (physical or mental) lightly because you never know what is going through that persons mind at that particular time.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: It’s always better to be safe than sorry.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Secondly, it will not be safe, helpful or productive to attempt to talk to the abuser about your relationship.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Abusers often times try and manipulate you into staying by apologizing or attempting to justify their behaviors.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: This is the time you would want to go see a magistrate in order to get a protective order for you and your children.It’s unfortunate that your significant other was involved with another women causing pregnancy; however, that is no longer your concern.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: Your concern at this point is keeping yourself and your children safe.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: I would also suggest counseling for you and your children in order to work through these issues.

title: I'm going through depression right now and my relationship is suffering
author: listener
text: I hope this was helpful and please stay safe and take care of yourself.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: speaker
text:
When I'm in large crowds I get angry and I just can't deal with people. I don't really like other people (I prefer animals) they make me nervous and scared.
   I lay awake at night thinking and having conversations in my head and i almost always end up making myself feel terrible and crying, I have more conversions in my head than I do with actual people.    I don't know what's wrong with me and why I feel this way. What should I do?

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: I think you have a lot of insight into what’s going on - being able to pinpoint the issue you’re facing and describe the responses it evokes.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: It sounds like you may be dealing with social anxiety and it may be beneficial to talk to a professional counselor about this.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: A therapist can help you develop tools (or coping strategies) for dealing with these situations.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: From what you’ve shared, you might benefit from animal assisted therapy.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: Equine therapy is a great approach, or even just working with a therapist who uses animal assisted therapy integrated with a traditional approach to counseling.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: speaker
text:
When I'm in large crowds I get angry and I just can't deal with people. I don't really like other people (I prefer animals) they make me nervous and scared.
   I lay awake at night thinking and having conversations in my head and i almost always end up making myself feel terrible and crying, I have more conversions in my head than I do with actual people.    I don't know what's wrong with me and why I feel this way. What should I do?

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: Reaching out to talk about these issues is an important first step.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: Finding professional services might be recommended if these issues are happening more and more.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: A few things to note...Anger is an important secondary feeling to be aware of- it keeps us safe, allows us to stand up for ourselves or others....but it also harbors a myriad of disadvantages.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: But its secondary.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: It's more necessary to understand the primary emotions behind the anger- worry, confusion, frustration, fear, loneliness, etc...Anxiety has a lot to do with worrying about the future, especially things that we might not be able to control.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: If we focus our worry on negative things- mistakes, failures, or messups then we will inherently tell ourselves negative things about ourselves.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: People tend to dwell on the negatives without embracing, or as t least recognizing, the positives.

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: speaker
text:
When I'm in large crowds I get angry and I just can't deal with people. I don't really like other people (I prefer animals) they make me nervous and scared.
   I lay awake at night thinking and having conversations in my head and i almost always end up making myself feel terrible and crying, I have more conversions in my head than I do with actual people.    I don't know what's wrong with me and why I feel this way. What should I do?

title: I feel really uncomfortable around other people
author: listener
text: Since you're aware of your sensitivity to being among large groups of people, then continue to satisfy this and stay away from crowds as much as reasonably possible.It is also fine to prefer the companionship of animals, as long as it is not to the exclusion of relationships with people.Recognizing this feature about yourself is another example of self-understanding.The only point to consider is the reason you avoid talking with other people.If its because of bad or stressful encounters, betrayals or some type of violation, then having this relationship pattern remain in your mind, may introduce new problems such as loneliness from lack of close friends.What you should do is honestly understand whether you avoid people from fear of being hurt or exploited in some way or because you genuinely prefer solitude.If you have the right combination of people/solitude/animals, then great!If not, then consider the confidential office of a therapist for new understanding of yourself and your social interests.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: speaker
text: Sometimes I can't stop thinking about life after death. I was raised in a religion that teaches that we will live on forever either in hell or in heaven.  When I think of living forever (even if it is in heaven which should be good), I feel overwhelmed. I don't like the thought of living forever and ever and ever. Sometimes I just can't get the thought out of my mind and the thoughts lead to panic and anxiety.  Am I crazy? I don't think these thoughts are normal.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Hi California, What you're experiencing is indeed anxiety; it's very common.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Through research we know a lot of things about how to reduce anxiety.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: I'll get you started and it's a great idea to connect with a therapist who can build on these ideas and get to know you well.It's natural to have random thoughts that unsettle us.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Our brains are complex, wonderful things.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Fearful and anxious thoughts are a part of this picture; their purpose is to prepare us for the future and to help us make sense of the past and learn from it.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: But what happens sometimes is that our alarm systems get out of whack and get set off too easily.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: We often spend TOO MUCH time worrying about things that happened or might happen.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: When these thoughts take away from our enjoyment of life, it becomes a problem.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: So, while fear and anxiety try to protect us, they also seek power and will take any power they can get.In general, fear and anxiety try to tell us one or both of two things: that something is wrong with us, or that something bad will happen (or that something bad will happen because there's something wrong with us).

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: They will use anything they can as evidence to convince you.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: For example... "That person looked at you funny.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: You're strange looking".

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Well there are dozens of possible explanations for the look on that person's face, and it's unlikely it had anything to do with you.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: For you personally, your thoughts are about the afterlife...about living forever.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: What does fear tell you will be uncomfortable about living forever?

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: What would the worst part be?

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: A therapist would help you dig deep to find the core of what you fear.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: It might be that you have no control over who you are or where you go.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: It might be that you fear going to hell because you're "bad".

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Search for that deepest fear.I invite you then to picture that thought as a glass of water on a shelf.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: It's a heavy glass, and if you held it in your hands for a while and stared at it, it would get in the way; you'd be uncomfortable and unable to focus on your life.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: That's what's happening now.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: I suggest that the problem is not so much the thought you're having; we all have random silly thoughts that usually aren't true.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: The problem is how long you're holding it in your hand.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: You could have that thought (pick up that glass) a hundred times a day and, as long as you put it right back on the shelf, it's not a problem.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: The trick is to get it back on that shelf.Right now, you're using distraction to do this.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: You're trying to focus on other things around you, but I think the glass is still in your hand.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: It's not enough; you're looking for more tools to get that glass back on the shelf.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: And the key is in your thoughts.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Once you find out what fear is trying to tell you, then you can "talk back to" fear.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: So, as an example, if fear is saying to you "you have no control over anything", then you can work to accept the pieces you don't have control over, learn to tolerate that feeling, and claim back the pieces you CAN control.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: You CAN control the extent to which you let fear take you over.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: With a therapist you can learn to "refute" fears' ideas.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: You can learn to look for concrete evidence of fear's lies and gain back control over your thoughts.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: I wish you the best!

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: speaker
text: Sometimes I can't stop thinking about life after death. I was raised in a religion that teaches that we will live on forever either in hell or in heaven.  When I think of living forever (even if it is in heaven which should be good), I feel overwhelmed. I don't like the thought of living forever and ever and ever. Sometimes I just can't get the thought out of my mind and the thoughts lead to panic and anxiety.  Am I crazy? I don't think these thoughts are normal.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Your life here matters and being present in it so you feel joy in yourself and your surroundings is important in creating your sense of ease and balance.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: No one can predict, for sure, what happens after death because consciousness transcends boundaries and limits we tend to impose on it.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: That said, if reincarnation exists or if there is a heaven or hell your consciousness of it will most likely be free of discomfort or pain as you experience it now.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Meditating or doing self-hypnosis for anxiety can help alleviate your thoughts and sense of fear and living the a life of kindness and balance will assure that your future will be happy for you regardless of the unknown.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: speaker
text: Sometimes I can't stop thinking about life after death. I was raised in a religion that teaches that we will live on forever either in hell or in heaven.  When I think of living forever (even if it is in heaven which should be good), I feel overwhelmed. I don't like the thought of living forever and ever and ever. Sometimes I just can't get the thought out of my mind and the thoughts lead to panic and anxiety.  Am I crazy? I don't think these thoughts are normal.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Religious questioning is a complex and often philosophical topic, and these types of questions, especially around heaven, hell, and an afterlife can bring up a host of difficult & confusing feelings.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: What I want to focus on is the fear & anxiety you seem to be feeling that are deeply connected to your questions.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Scary thoughts, negative thoughts, obsessive thoughts sometimes feel like they're out of control and there is nothing we can do to stop them, but I want to offer two techniques that might assist with your panic & anxiety.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: The first step in working with scary or negative thoughts is to acknowledge that they are just thoughts and we can choose to follow the scary thought streams or work with cutting them off or ignoring them.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: I also realize that might seem really hard to do, but here's a good way to think about the brain and how thought patterns work.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Thoughts arise in the mind all the time, our brain is a thought machine.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Many thoughts drift by like clouds and we don't pay any attention while other thoughts arise and they trigger us in a particulate way, i.e., scary, angry, happy, sad, and when those thoughts arise we can chose to pay more attention to the thought which can lead us down that particular thought stream that will lead to fear and anxiety.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: So, how do we work or stop those scary thought streams?

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: One new skill to implement comes from the work of Rick Hansen, he wrote the book Buddha's Brain," he teaches that we need to give more energy and attention to the positive thoughts or positive memories we hold in our mind and pay less attention to the negative thoughts.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Hansen asks us to imagine the brain this way, the brain is like Velcro with negative thoughts and like teflon when it comes to positive thoughts.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: There are reasons that our brain works this way, but I don't have time to go into all of that in this response.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: So, it's just important to remember we have to work at positive thinking, actually pausing throughout the day to focus on positive feelings and memories,  this will help the mind reinforce positive thought streams and help reduce negative thought streams over time.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: If a scary thought arises try to replace it with a happy experience for at least a couple of moments, and see if that helps reduce the negative charge connected with that scary thought.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: I would also suggest when you're having the thoughts about death take a moment to notice how you're breathing.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Often when we are feeling anxiety we are doing shallowing chest breathing rather than taking in a full, deep breath or what is called belly breathing.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: If you take a moment to focus on your breathing and allow a couple of full breaths, bringing in the breath so the belly rises and then the belly natural falls as you exhale, just noticing the breath and practicing breathing can slow down the anxiety cycle as it begins.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: speaker
text: Sometimes I can't stop thinking about life after death. I was raised in a religion that teaches that we will live on forever either in hell or in heaven.  When I think of living forever (even if it is in heaven which should be good), I feel overwhelmed. I don't like the thought of living forever and ever and ever. Sometimes I just can't get the thought out of my mind and the thoughts lead to panic and anxiety.  Am I crazy? I don't think these thoughts are normal.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Many people generate intense anxiety with obsessive thinking.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: While the nature of your obsession about the afterlife and eternity appear very powerful and unique to you, the pattern of obsessing about one thing/area is common.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: I suggest that you consider counseling to help you with your anxiety.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: If you are so inclined, there are also medications which may bring relief.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: Obviously, I can't diagnose you from one paragraph, so it would be wise to visit an experienced mental health professional (either a counselor or an MD in your area) to help you with disengaging from your self-destructive thoughts.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: CBT, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, is a very effective counseling approach for obsessive thinking.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: If you'd like a see a top notch CBT therapist, visit www.AcademyofCT.org.

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: And of course I suggest you pick up my book, LIVING YES, A HANDBOOK FOR BEING HUMAN, which includes CBT concepts and many more tools which will help with obsession and anxiety.As for believing yourself "insane" (or "crazy") this is not a mental health term but a legal one (or a slang).

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: So as long as you don't commit a crime, no professional can legitimately call you insane or crazy!Take it slow!

title: Thoughts of afterlife causes anxiety
author: listener
text: ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

title: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
author: speaker
text: I've been like this ever since I was in school; back then I transferred to another school. Now I'm thinking about changing my job.

title: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
author: listener
text: There's a quote I love that says, "Wherever you go, there you are" and the book by the same name by Jon Kabat-Zinn may be very helpful for you.

title: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
author: listener
text: The thing about changing things up when they get tough is that they often aren't the things that need changing.

title: I keep on changing my life when things get tough
author: listener
text: The awesome (and challenging) thing about it is that when you work on the internal aspects that may need attention, you can learn to find a sense of centeredness that comes with practicing mindfulness and asking yourself who you really are and want to be.

title: I keep on changing my life when things get tough

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I have anxieties about everyday stressors, i.e. finances, work, relationships, kids, and maintaining a household.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Something to remember about anxiety is that it's a useful and necessary response to stressors, and we all have a level of anxiety that falls somewhere on the spectrum from very slight to very overwhelming.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Anxiety is our brain's way of prompting us to deal with the stress in our lives by getting us geared up for action.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Some helpful ways of managing anxiety are actually very simple.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: The first I'd recommend is a calm breathing technique - breathe in for 4-5 seconds, and then out for 7-8 seconds.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Try to repeat this for 3-5 minutes.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Another suggestion is to pay closer attention in the moments you feel the physical symptoms of anxiety and see if you can describe - without judging - the sensations to yourself.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Try to be very specific, such as "my palms are feeling very sweaty, and I can feel the slight tightness and fluttering in my belly of the butterflies."

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Then try to sit with these sensations without deciding if they are good or bad - just experiencing them as intentionally as possible.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: Combining the calm breathing with this technique can also be very helpful.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: If you feel that these techniques don't help and your anxiety about everyday stressors are inhibiting you from being able to engage in life the way you want to, then I'd highly recommend going for an assessment or even just consultation with a professional.

title: What are the best ways to reduce anxiety?
author: listener
text: This professional can help you determine if therapy/counseling would be helpful for you to develop additional skills for managing those interfering anxiety symptoms.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: speaker
text: I'm dealing with imposter syndrome in graduate school. I know that by all accounts I am a phenomenal graduate student, and that I am well-published. I am well liked by students and faculty alike. And yet I cannot shake the feeling that I'm going to be found out as a fraud.    How can I get over this feeling?

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are on the right track.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Recognizing these nagging thoughts of self- doubt as "imposter syndrome" is a huge step in the right direction.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?

text: From what you have written here, it appears that you are able to challenge your own thoughts and provide yourself with evidence that counteracts the imposter syndrome.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Continuing to remind yourself of what you have accomplished and looking at the facts at hand can help diminish doubt.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Remember, many successful people battled imposter syndrome on the way to the top (and still manage it).

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: It might be helpful to read some of their stories so that you don't feel alone.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: "The Cut" has a great article on "25 Famous Women on Imposter-Syndrome and Self-Doubt".

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Business Insider has a great article about men and the imposter syndrome too.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Remember, if you jumped through all of the hoops to get into school and get published-- you belong.

author: listener

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: speaker
text: I'm dealing with imposter syndrome in graduate school. I know that by all accounts I am a phenomenal graduate student, and that I am well-published. title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: I'm sorry you're feeling this way.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: You've probably read articles already about impostor syndrome, but still didn't get the answers you were looking for; you probably know that lots of people feel this way, that it happens to lots of successful people in professional settings.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Not helping, right?Think about people who succeed at big tasks: an Olympic athlete has a defined goal that they need to meet: cross the finish line, say, faster than anyone else.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: That success is remarked upon, and - until someone does the event better than they did - they are 'the best.'

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: Grad school, however, is not so great at discrete goals and celebrations of success.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: You got a good grade on an assignment, but what about the next one?

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: You and 6 other people in your class probably got the same grade, so does that make you a success or average?

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: It falls to you, then, to identify ways you are sure you've succeeded.

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: If your grades and peer admiration aren't hallmarks of success enough, perhaps pull your measuring tool inward: measure your achievements against your own progress- ie: I got a 93 on my last assignment, I got a 97 this time!

title: How do I get over "imposter syndrome"?
author: listener
text: You might find those feelings fading soon~

title: I don't want to keep going back and forth between my parents' houses
author: speaker

title: How can I wake up without having an anxiety attack?
author: speaker
text: I have these dreams of men, and they always seem to try to hurt me. It's gotten so bad that I first wake at 4:30, then 4:45, and finally stay awake by 6:00. I'm always the last one to fall asleep and the first to wake. I hate falling asleep. The longest I've went without sleep is three days.

title: How can I wake up without having an anxiety attack?
author: listener
text: The good news about your dreams is that your fears are right at the surface of your mind so you can study them and release some of the harm from the terrifying experiences you had which created these bad memories in the first place.The bad news is the feelings themselves are sickening.Probably a therapist would be very helpful for guiding you to unfold these uneasy feelings and their source.This type of deep work is easier with emotional support from someone.

title: How can I wake up without having an anxiety attack?
author: listener

title: How do I cope with separation anxiety while boyfriend is out of town?
author: speaker
text:
I have been with my boyfriend for more than a year. He recently got a new job and travels a lot. I’m not used to him being gone all the time. I feel as though he has forgotten about me because he does not talk with me as much and doesn’t keep me up to date on everything that he does throughout the day, which he used to.
 I feel lost, sad and unwanted. This is really a tough new challenge. I just want to break up with him, but I love him so much. I don’t know why he is acting this way lately. I believe I have separation anxiety. Is there anything that I can do to help me cope with this while he is out of town?

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?
author: speaker
text: I panicked over a minor parking lot mistake. It was totally my fault, but due to another insurance issue, I left a note with an illegible phone number. Guilty over this, I got an envelope containing several hundred dollars. Unfortunately, by the time I returned, the other driver had seen my ersatz note and drove away. Since I cannot make this up to that individual, how do I atone for my cowardly act? I have been trying to do random acts of kindness in hopes that karma will somehow even out.

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?
author: listener
text: From your writing, you have already atoned for what you describe as "cowardly".Recognizing your action and trying to directly correct it, realizing your action was improper and demonstrating the willingness to take right action, are all examples of making things right.Since the actual driver is unavailable to consult as to their wishes on what they expect and feel would correct the matter, you did the next best thing and considered the situation from the driver point of view.

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?
author: speaker
text: I panicked over a minor parking lot mistake. It was totally my fault, but due to another insurance issue, I left a note with an illegible phone number. Guilty over this, I got an envelope containing several hundred dollars. Unfortunately, by the time I returned, the other driver had seen my ersatz note and drove away. Since I cannot make this up to that individual, how do I atone for my cowardly act? I have been trying to do random acts of kindness in hopes that karma will somehow even out.

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?
author: listener

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?

title: How can I atone for being cowardly?
