title: How can I deal with this anxiety that keeps me up all night?
author: speaker
text: I've been having horrible anxiety for the last week. I can't sleep. I get a sense of doom, and it's hard to breathe. I feel like nothing I do makes it better.

title: How can I deal with this anxiety that keeps me up all night?
author: listener
text: Anxiety is usually a sign of a current problem to which familiar emotional patterns of feeling similarly upset, attach themselves.Try to understand more about who you are, what you like, feel uneasy about, especially your deeper emotions of being emotionally harmed or injured by meaningful people.Anxiety is best addressed indirectly by understanding and kindly accepting previous hurt and fears from long ago.Once you feel at ease with dynamics of past situations then the current anxiety will decrease.

title: How can I deal with this anxiety that keeps me up all night?
author: listener
text: This is because you will have adjusted and found new ways of handling otherwise frightening and overwhelming interactions and involvements with others.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: speaker
text:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Its understandable to have anxiety when transitioning to a new job/career or any other major life change.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Doing some mindfulness activities such as deep breathing exercises, grounding, or mindfulness meditation can help center and calm yourself in moments of anxiety when being away from your family.It may also be helpful to make a list of your concerns or fears about being away from your family.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: What are you afraid will happen while you are away?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Once you've identified those fears you can challenge them and determine whether they are based on fact or your emotions.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: speaker
text:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Hi, It is really good that you are working so hard to take care of your family.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Anxiety can be so challenging, especially when new challenges have come up.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: It would be good to work through some of these issues you are experiencing, and examine your self care and support processes.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: speaker
text:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Anxiety or panic attacks can be very frightening.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Here are a few "tools" you can use that will help in the short term:  Keeping your mind occupied by listening to books on tape may help;  Counting backwards from 100 in 7's; Naming cities that begin with each letter of the alphabet; Keeping some ice or an ice pack in a cooler beside you, which you may take out and hold in your hand or to your face; Soothing self-talk such as "This is uncomfortable, but I can handle it" or "I've been through this before and can make it through again".

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: I recommend that you seek out a Therapist to help you with some long-term solutions to the anxiety.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Additionally, learning to breathe into the abdomen and practicing this daily is another long-term solution.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Yoga and meditation would be great!

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: speaker
text:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: First of all, congratulations on your new role!

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Transitions can be challenging, and it sounds like you are experiencing a lot of change.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: This would be difficult for many people, and it seems that you have an added layer of challenge.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: I recommend visiting a therapist to determine the root cause of your anxiety and working to unravel those causes piece by piece.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: I know seeing a therapist can be challenging when traveling, and online counseling could be a good solution.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: In the meantime, here are a few of my favorite anxiety stopping strategies.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Grounding Exercises: When you feel your anxiety increasing, take a deep breath and begin things in your room (or where ever you are) that have things in common.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: For example, name all of the blue things that you can see.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: You can also do non-visual grounding exercises like naming all of the hte sports teams you can think of or all of the state capitals.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: This will get your mind off of your anxiety and connect you to space.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: The pretzel: This is a seated pose that will stop any anxiety attack in its tracks.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Start in a seated position and cross your dominate leg over your nondominant leg.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Then, stretch your arms out in front of you with the back of your hands facing one another.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Cross your arms in front of each other so that your palms are touching.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Flip your arms into your body.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: You will end with your elbows by your side and your hands crossed under your chin.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Close your eyes and take long breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: This calming pose will help you get through even the toughest of panic episodes.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Bilateral stimulation and visualization: Start in a seated position with your hands placed on your knees.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Tap each knee in an alternating pattern.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Close your eyes and begin visualizing a peaceful setting.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: The combination of bilateral stimulation and visualization will help calm your body and mind.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: I could go on and on, but these techniques should get you started.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: These techniques should help you manage anxiety in a pinch.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Best of luck!

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: speaker
text:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: It is ok to have anxiety.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Please don't be anxious about being anxious.If you feel anxiety coming over you, then pull off the road to a safe place.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Concentrate on centering yourself and to breath slowly.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Take some sips of water.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Sit still.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: The anxiety should pass in about twenty minutes.If it does not pass, then continue calming yourself until you feel safe enough to drive to your hotel.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: You can always explain to your supervisor that you were taking care of a medical problem, because anxiety is a medical problem.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: speaker
text:
I just took a job that requires me to travel far away from home. My family and I really need this job.
   People keep telling me I have "anxiety" and I'm terrified of having an anxiety attack on the road. This is all new to me. What can I do?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Anxiety often occurs when big or unexpected changes come to our lives, like having new jobs, relocating, or assuming new roles.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Notice if your anxiety feels like excitement, concerns, or fear.It seems like you are excited about your new job, but worried because OTHERS are telling you that you have anxiety.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Let's notice how other‘s input is affecting your thoughts and maybe causing more anxiety that you may really have.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: If you are indeed experiencing anxiety, that does not mean that you will have panic attacks.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: But if you are experiencing panic attacks, or suffer them at some point, you could learn how to reduce them either with therapy or medication.You can learn how to process it depending what triggers it and channel it, in a useful way.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: For example, you could plan a schedule around your new job and be meticulous about it because you are worried about how your new job may affect your routine, or, you could feel overwhelmed with your schedule, focus on the feeling, but not do anything about it.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Notice the difference?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: The key is in recognizing if you are anxious about something that you can change or have control over it, and take action if you do, and recognizing when you cannot control things and be OK with not being in control.I teach clients how to use meditation and cognitive reframing techniques to help calm anxiety symptoms.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: If you are interested in engaging in counseling or teletherapy you may contact me at 787-466-5478.I wish you success on your new journey!Estoy preocupada por mi nuevo trabajoLa gente me dice que tengo ansiedad y estoy aterrorizada de tener un ataque de pánico en la carretera.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Esto es nuevo par a mí.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: ¿Que puedo hacer?La ansiedad ocurre comúnmente cuando llegan cambios grandes o inesperados en nuestras vidas, como tener un nuevo empleo, mudarse o asumir nuevos roles.Al parecer estás emocionada por tu nuevo trabajo, pero preocupada por que OTROS te dicen que tienes ansiedad.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Notemos como la opinión de otros esta influenciando tus pensamientos y tal vez te puede estar causando más ansiedad de lo que realmente tienes.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Si realmente estas pasando por un periodo de ansiedad, no es necesario que vayas a experimentar ataques de pánico.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Pero si ya los haz experimentado puedes utilizar terapia o medicamentos para controlarlos.Nota si tu ansiedad se siente emocionante, preocupada o temerosa.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Puedes aprender a procesar estos sentimientos dependiendo que pensamiento los causen y canalizar la ansiedad de manera productiva.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Por ejemplo: te puedes enfocar en organizar una agenda porque te preocupa como tu nuevo empleo afectara tu rutina diaria.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: O te puedes sentir agobio respecto a cómo tu trabajo afecta tu rutina, y no hace nada más que preocuparte constantemente.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: ¿Notas la diferencia?

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: La clave está en saber cuándo te preocupas  por algo que puedes cambiar, y tomar acción; vs. cuando te preocupas  por algo que no puedes cambiar y aceptar que no lo puedes cambiar.Le enseño a mis pacientes a  usar técnicas de meditación y re enfoque cognitivo para manejar síntomas de ansiedad  y desorden de pánico.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: Si te interesa una cita de consejería o tele-terapia me puedes contactar al 787-466-5478.

title: I'm worried about my new job
author: listener
text: ¡Mucho éxito en tu nueva jornada!

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: speaker
text:
I recently broke up with my boyfriend After being together for over 4 years. I truly believe I did the right thing, but omehow being single now has made me very needy and unsure of myself.
    I am seeing someone casually and I am losing my mind with anxiety about how he feels about me and this need for validation.
   How can I learn to be content and at peace with myself regardless of my career, relationship status, etc?

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: What you are experiencing is entirely reasonable for someone that is still trying to adjust to a new life and also leave behind a long term relationship.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you lost touch with who you were as a person and need to start exploring that side of you again.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Spend time doing things that you have been putting off, or did not do because you were involved.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Take the time to become one with yourself before you get into another serious relationship.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Regaining self-confidence on yourself will help you with all other areas of life.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: It is time to make you a priority and to start focusing on your mental and physical well being.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Get connected with your community and find things you would want to do that give you purpose and lift you.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Before too long you will be in your way to being content and in total control of your mind and at peace.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Best of luck.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Mirella~

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: speaker
text:
I recently broke up with my boyfriend After being together for over 4 years. I truly believe I did the right thing, but omehow being single now has made me very needy and unsure of myself.
    I am seeing someone casually and I am losing my mind with anxiety about how he feels about me and this need for validation.
   How can I learn to be content and at peace with myself regardless of my career, relationship status, etc?

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: A break up, even one that you initiated, may deserve some time and space to allow it to be complete.There's a few ideas I'll throw out there and you can choose if they stick.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: One is to re-invest in the friendships you have by setting up regular coffee get-togethers for example.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Two, get out in nature.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: It's hard to ignore how grand and patient nature is, and it sometimes takes the pressure off what we should be and instead allows us to be.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: And the last one I'll throw out there is to invest your time and energy in a project or achievement you've wanted to do for a while, but that perhaps you didn't have the time to.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Something related to a hobby such as sports or music, or related to your career.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Something that is 'for' you.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Life knocks us off balance at times, and that's ok.  Self-questioning during these times can be a healthy endeavor.

title: How can I learn to be content and at peace?
author: listener
text: Should you follow any of the advice on this website, continue to be kind to yourself about what you're feeling, and curious about why you're feeling that way.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager, and while I’ve never been to any kind of therapist, I noticed I experience several anxiety symptoms. I frequently find myself not going out and following my parent around the house. I can't go into stores (grocery stores specifically) on my own, and when I do, I have to be on the phone with my dad the whole time. I also forget things a lot.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: With the way you described your anxiety, it sounds like you have different types of anxiety.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: I'm not sure whether you have anxiety of public places, large crowds, being alone  (sometimes called separation anxiety), or some combination thereof.One thing that would be helpful would be to track your anxiety and see how anxious you are (on a scale of 1 to 10) in different situations.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: Also, if you know what leads up to your anxiety, it would be good to know this as well so you can look for patterns.As for forgetting things, you could be anxious because you are forgetting things or you could be forgetting things because you are anxious.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: When you are having anxiety, certain parts of your brain are overactive because you are in a kind of protective mode.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: It's also possible that forgetting things and anxiety are not related.Something else to try would be to notice where you feel your anxiety in your body and put your hand there is a way of giving yourself comfort.Another thing about anxiety is that having anxiety can lead to more worry about having more anxiety.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: One thing that helps for some people is to go to the regular primary care doctor to make sure that there are no physical problems (just for the regular physical) so they know that there are no physical problems and that the anxiety will lessen in a few minutes.Also, if you are able to notice your feet on the floor or your hips in the chair, this is helping you to be mindful of your body and connecting you to your surroundings.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: During this in combination with naming your emotions can be soothing as well.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: For example, in the grocery store, if you are feeling anxious, you could say to yourself "I'm anxious right now and I'm okay" while gently shifting your weight from one foot to the other.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: No one around you would notice what you were doing and the motion may be soothing to you.Anxiety can have a lot of different causes and things that trigger it.

title: Is there anything I can do to make my anxiety go away?
author: listener
text: If it is difficult for you to work it out on your own (which is very common), consider talking with a local therapist so you can have more specific ideas.Also consider making a list of people who you trust and what it is about them that makes you feel comfortable.

title: I have difficulty with communication
author: speaker
text: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?

title: I have difficulty with communication
author: listener
text: Have you tried rehearsing to yourself or a trusted friend what you will present to the class?

title: I have difficulty with communication
author: listener
text: The more confident you feel in a safe space, the more chance there will be of making the same presentation to a larger group.Giving presentations is not necessarily a difficulty with communication.

title: I have difficulty with communication
author: listener
text: It has more to do with performance than expressing yourself clearly.Practice, practice, and practice, until you see yourself improve in how you present.Also, keep in mind that whatever anxiety you may feel about making a mistake, the audience is almost alway much more forgiving than the person who feels anxious.Anxiety heightens fear, so whatever concerns you have, check if they are growing from anxiety instead of a realistic assessment of your abilities or audience receptivity.Good luck!

title: I have difficulty with communication
author: speaker
text: I am a really shy person. I'm currently in a graduate program which requires lots of presentations, but they always make me feel stressed out and less confident. How can I get more confident?

title: I have difficulty with communication
author: listener
text: I can offer you hypnosis for confidence in presentations, via Skype, if you're in Cali.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: People do cry in therapy sometimes, but it's not at all necessary to cry in order for most kinds of therapy to be helpful.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: When you start counseling you don't yet know your counselor very well, so it's normal to keep your feelings in check until you feel comfortable and a bit more relaxed with your counselor and with the situation.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, though, there are emotions that have been waiting and waiting to finally find someone who will listen with a kind ear.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: If you feel safe right away in the situation with your counselor, you might just cry in spite of your fears about it.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Your therapist is used to people expressing how they feel and will keep strict confidentiality, so even though it's embarrassing, finally experiencing someone truly listening with empathy and kindness may just be worth it.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's okay too to let your counselor know right at the beginning that you're kind of freaked out about getting too emotional in front of another person.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It is not uncommon to be a bit nervous meeting your therapist (or another person) for the first time.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Your therapist understands that calling and getting an appointment was a big step for you and will do their best to put you at ease.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Providing a safe environment for our clients includes not judging them and being comfortable with the information and emotions that they share with us.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It is ok to cry and to trust that the therapist will honor this as part of your process.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It is is absolutely normal to cry in therapy.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: I can understand wanting to keep everything together and put your best foot forward with everyone you come into contact with, but it can be such a powerful experience to cry with somebody that can hear you and accept you.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's so brave of you to go and share yourself with your counselor!

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: I hope you will keep being brave as you begin healing.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Lots of people do cry in session, but your therapist won't be uneasy with this.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Crying is a natural response and it also releases toxins, so some might say it's necessary!

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Remember that you can be in charge of what you talk about in your session and if there's something that feels too uncomfortable, just say, "I'm not ready to talk about that."

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Your counselor wants  you to feel at ease and will probably not push you right away to a very uncomfortable place.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: As you get to know your therapist, you will feel more relaxed and even not worry so much about how you appear to them.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's normal to be anxious going into a new situation especially when you might not feel in control of uncomfortable emotions.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Don't give up, go and put your best effort in!

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Hope that helps, Allison

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Many people cry during their therapy sessions.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Actually most people cry in their therapist's office.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: I tell my clients that it's safe to cry in my office and crying isn't a sign of weakness.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's a normal human response to pain.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: People actually do more harm to themselves by trying not to cry than by crying.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Crying is very cleansing and an important part of the healing process for many people.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Please do not worry about crying.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: People cry, laugh, rage, rant, and talk during counseling sessions.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Part of the therapy process is to look at your feelings, and to feel what you are actually feeling (instead of what you think you should feel).

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: So if you need to cry, that's ok.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: If you feel embarrassed because you cried, or if you feel anxious that you might cry, well those feelings are ok as well.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Your counselor can help you manage your feelings so that you can attain your goals, and your counseling session is the perfect place for that.

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: speaker
text: I'm a male in my early 20s. Lately, my paranoia about being around kids is causing me too breathe heavy and sweat a lot. I then start to act weird because I'm trying to fight my paranoia. This leads to people starring at me because they don't know that I'm suffering from panic attacks and paranoia. They just notice me acting scared around kids and they think I'm a threat because of it.    I'm not a pervert or predator. I would never hurt a kid. I like kids and don't know why I'm so scared to be around them.    I don't understand why I feel like this. Am I a bad person? How do I make this stop?

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: listener
text: In our practice, many people we see have unwanted thoughts of doing harm to children - physically or sexually.

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: listener
text: As you said, these are intrusive and unwanted thoughts - not genuine desires to harm them.

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: listener
text: This is a form of OCD we often call Harm or Pedophilic OCD.

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: listener
text: What you are describing here as "paranoia" sounds similar to this, and is so demoralizing because you are dealing both with the distress of these unwanted thoughts and feelings, as well as the fear and uncertainty about your own character as a good person.If this is really what is going on (further assessment by the right professional would determine this), the current gold standard approach to addressing OCD is Exposure with Response Prevention - in this case, confronting the feared situations, thoughts or images on purpose, rather than avoiding them, until they lose the fear and shame associated with them.

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: speaker
text: I'm a male in my early 20s. Lately, my paranoia about being around kids is causing me too breathe heavy and sweat a lot. I then start to act weird because I'm trying to fight my paranoia. This leads to people starring at me because they don't know that I'm suffering from panic attacks and paranoia. They just notice me acting scared around kids and they think I'm a threat because of it.    I'm not a pervert or predator. I would never hurt a kid. I like kids and don't know why I'm so scared to be around them.    I don't understand why I feel like this. Am I a bad person? How do I make this stop?

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: listener
text: Your question is written in a very sincere tone.

title: When I'm around children I get this intense feeling of paranoia and fear
author: listener
text: This, together with the fact of searching for self-understanding, sound more like someone who is unsure and puzzled, not someone who is "bad".What was your own childhood like?The sensations you describe feeling sometimes occur in people who are reminded of very deep hurts from during their own childhood.Is it possible what you're feeling is from being reminded of great distress you lived through when you were at a similar age as the kids around whom you feel this sudden and great paranoia and fear?

title: Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
author: speaker
text: I've known him for about six years. We've dated off and on. I hadn't seen him in close to three years but recently started seeing him again. I really want this to last this time. I stayed the night. Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?

title: Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
author: listener
text: It is possible your question reflects some insecurity about whether or not either or you would like this relationship to continue.Otherwise, the answer to your question would appear naturally.

title: Do I text, call, or make contact first, the same day of the morning I left his house?
author: listener
text: If you genuinely feel close enough to this person to sleep with him, then who texts whom first, wouldn't really matter too much.Try to understand within yourself whether you feel truly interested in this person as much as you would like to feel toward someone.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: speaker
text:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: There's a lot of layers there to your situation, and I'm focusing on two layers that may be contributing to your feelings of discomfort around others.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: One layer is the daunting news that your son has autism.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Many parents can feel overwhelmed and distraught with this diagnosis.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: The vast array of treatments available is daunting in and of itself at times to wrap one's head around.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Taking time to reflect or seek out therapy regarding how this diagnosis has impacted you may be helpful.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Some parents feel their individual identity gets lost in the diagnosis because they have dropped everything to help their child, and others may experience guilt.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: If either of these or other feelings come to the forefront for you, it may be worth working through them with a therapist.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: A support group list is available through www.autismspeaks.org and may help connect you with others raising children with autism.A second layer is the abusive relationship you were involved in.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: The trauma you experienced in this relationship may have a very meaningful impact on your ability to trust and to be intimate with others.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Engaging with a therapist can help facilitate the healing process, as well as paving the way for more comfortable and trusting relationships.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: speaker
text:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: It might be helpful to have a good understanding of the "why" in terms of feeling nervous around people, or the difficulty in developing more comfort.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: If your discomfort is somehow related to your son's diagnosis or your lack of employment, or an abusive relationship you were in and maybe embarrassed about, that is important to understand, and get clarity around.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: When we can understand on a deep level what is happening for us (i.e., where does fear come into this, and what's it about) we can give ourselves empathy.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Everyone struggles in some aspect, so to not necessarily think of yourself as pathological is a first step.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Sometimes being around people can trigger an anxiety related to being "good enough" that goes back a ways in our history.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: If any of the above is true, it would need acknowledgement and care from you, as opposed to shaming that experience (in the hopes it would just go away), because this experience is very real for you.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: speaker
text:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: I'd wonder first if you were still in the same home and neighborhood where you raised your son and experienced the abuse?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: In many ways, we react to our environments - and if you're still surrounded by neighbors who didn't reach out when they heard your ex yelling or offer assistance and resources when your son acted differently than his peers, it might make sense that you're more timid around folks.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: It might also be worth thinking about where your bar is set: do you want to be as comfortable around people as you were before your recent circumstances?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Or find your new normal, and connect only with people who raise you up and bolster your self-esteem?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: You have the right to be both cautious (if you're still surrounded by the same folks and environment) and discerning - only connecting with people who will be supportive.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: All the best~

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: speaker
text:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: It sounds like you have taken on a caretaker role for a while as well as experienced some pretty severe interpersonal trauma.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: It makes sense that you would feel nervous around people.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Working through the trauma of an abusive relationship in itself can be a difficult process.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: And then to add on the caretaker part can make things even more difficult.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: First off, you may want to seek support to work through what you have experienced.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Many cities offer support with survivors of domestic violence and there is a hotline to help with this 888-724-7240 as well as online resources.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Processing the isolation of this relationship as well as working with your son can help to overcome the anxiety related to others.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Accessing autism support networks may be of support as well.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: Other parents that will understand your experiences are a good and tend to be safer place to start in attempting to connect to others.Very importantly, go slow and be kind to yourself as you begin to adapt to a new life of allowing others to care for you as you so clearly have for others.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: speaker
text:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: I would look at  getting engaged with a support network of individuals who may also have autistic children.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: They will understand some of the things that you are experiencing at home and you may also find someone who feels that same way as you.

title: I want to feel more comfortable around people
author: listener
text: If you have not sought professional counseling for the abusive relationship I would seek out a therapist who can help you process through it so you do not repeat similar choices in your next relationship.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: These types of symptoms can be very disruptive to life!

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Anxiety often presents in two key ways:  1) physical symptoms such as: racing heart rate, sweaty palms, dry mouth, shaking or trembling or nausea - often these physical sypmtoms are categorized as a Panic Attack.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: 2) mentally anxiety presents itself as worry.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Worry that spirals out of control, worry that dirsupts your life and concentration.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Worry that keeps from being present in your life.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Anxiety when it begins to spiral out of control either with disruptive mental or physical symptoms, needs to be addressed formally.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: I urge you to see a counselor and/or a psychiatrist soon to begin to address these issues.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Good Luck, Sitka Stueve, LSCSW

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Feelings of anxiety can be scary and sometimes we're not aware of the triggers that lead up to moments of anxiety, i. e., heart racing, sweaty palms, sweating, shortness of breath.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: It's important to realize that in moments of anxiety our body & mind are experiencing a reaction from our primal or reptilian brain that is signaling the flight or fight response within us, which kicks the hypothalamus into action flooding our body with chemicals, like adrenaline or cortisol.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: So, one way to work with anxiety is to find out what the triggers are that lead to anxiety, such as fear, stress.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: negative thought patterns, not enough food or sleep.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Keeping a daily journal can help you track the patterns and triggers and once you identify the triggers you can ameliorate them by learning new skills & techniques and by reducing stress and getting enough sleep.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: One quick way to reduce anxiety is by taking deeper breathes, sometimes this is called belly breathing.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: When you breath in make sure your belly rises and expands and as you breath out the belly deflates.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Many of us do shallow breathing up in our chest which does not allow for a full breath, and getting a full breath is so important as a tool to help relax us in times of stress & anxiety .

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Though I don't know for sure, it sounds like anxiety to me.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: I think it would be helpful if you work with a therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: First, be aware that each end every one of us has anxiety at some point.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: That certainly seems to fit what you're describing here, but that doesn't mean you have an anxiety disorder, necessarily.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: That's where there is a difference.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Anyone who has a hard time with public speaking or feels uncomfortable in large crowds, for example, is experiencing anxiety.It sounds like it would be helpful to look at the differences between the days when you are more comfortable on the days that you are not.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: If you notice your anxiety is keeping you from doing things that you need or want to do, it may be helpful to talk with and mental health professional.I wonder also whether your appetite and sleeping patterns are the same or similar to how they were before you experienced this anxiety, when your anxiety started, and whether you feel more comfortable when someone you trust is there with you.If you have an idea of times or situations in which you feel anxious, consider carrying a small smooth rock or another object that makes you feel calm and centered.

title: Do I have some type of anxiety?
author: listener
text: Perhaps you can keep it in your pocket and remember specific comfortable times while you have it in your hand.

title: How can I get over my fear of public embarrassment?
author: speaker
text: A lot of times, I avoid situations where I am to meet new people because I have a fear of embarrassing myself. I often avoid large groups of people, like parties, because I think they all constantly judge me.

title: How can I get over my fear of public embarrassment?
author: listener
text: Why not accept and tolerate that you naturally are a shy person who doesn't like large groups?This is not necessarily something to get over if it is part of who you are.People have the capacity to judge others regardless of whether the group is large or small.If you aren't afraid of being judged in small groups then study the factors which allow you to feel safe in small groups.

title: How can I get over my fear of public embarrassment?
author: listener
text: Possibly you can generalize your findings to large group venues.If you try the and aren't successful, then likely you simply aren't naturally someone who cares for large group settings.Not everything a person doesn't like is a symptom of something is wrong w the person!

title: How do I handle my extreme paranoia?
author: speaker
text: I'm just an extremely paranoid person. I constantly feel as though I am in some sort of danger, like as though I live in a horror movie with no resolution. It worsens at night. It gets to the point I'm scared in my own home more so than anything. I have no access to the help I need so I'm desperate.

title: How do I handle my extreme paranoia?
author: listener
text: One approach is to be more accepting of yourself as someone who has fears.It is much easier to manage a problem when you're not fighting yourself for having a problem.Once you are willing to accept this quality within yourself you may start to feel a little more relaxed about handling the fears when they arise.One answer is to examine the facts about the fears.

title: How do I handle my extreme paranoia?
author: listener
text: Ask yourself fact based questions as to how you would handle the worse case scenario of your fears.Feeling prepared, whether or not the circumstance is highly unlikely to happen, may increase your peace of mind with living the great fears within your mind.

title: Why am I scared to touch a girl?
author: speaker
text: I don't know if I'm normal. I'm really scared to touch a girl. I'm a young adult and a virgin. My fiancée and I want to have sex soon, and this might mess everything up because she wants a baby soon as well.

title: Why am I scared to touch a girl?
author: listener
text: Your question is a good one!The best way to decrease the fear would be to talk with your fiancee about it.

title: Why am I scared to touch a girl?
author: listener
text: Eventually she'll find out, and better to talk about it when there is less pressure than to be in the midst of a situation which frightens you.Also, she may feel similar to you, who knows?Discussing a topic which relates directly to your relationship is a good way to increase emotional intimacy.

title: Why am I scared to touch a girl?
author: listener
text: And emotional intimacy has a lot to do with feeling at ease with physical intimacy.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: speaker
text: I am a peaceful person, but I often find myself having thoughts about killing people. Eventhough I like the thoughts at the time, they make me cry. Why do I feel like this?

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Clearly this is something that has you very concerned.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Sometimes thoughts are just thoughts, and they are pretty harmless.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Many people have thoughts of killing someone, but they would never actually do it.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: They really don't even want to do it, they are just having a thought.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Other times, thoughts are a sign of something more serious, and we should receive help when they start to worry us.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: I would recommend meeting with a counselor to discuss these thoughts.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: It is usually a safe environment where you can get advice with little judgement.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Now, If you begin to start thinking about killing someone specific and making a plan to do it in reality- you should call for help immediately.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: By help, I mean 9-11, or a family member or friend.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: You would want to get help before doing something to harm yourself and others.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Again, none of this is to judge, but rather to encourage you to get the help you're seeking.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Either way, when we become concerned about some aspect of our behavior, seeking counseling is usually a good choice.

title: Why do I find pleasure in thinking about killing?
author: listener
text: Be well, Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCC

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: speaker
text: I shake and have panic attacks.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: One of the first things I would suggest is to see if you can keep track of what is leading you to feel anxious.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: If you shake all the time, consider talking with your primary care physician.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: Sometimes that can be a hormonal imbalance or another chemical imbalance (such as thyroid).One of the most difficult things about anxiety is that having anxiety (particularly panic attacks) can lead to anxiety about having more panic attacks.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: Also remember that panic attacks are typically part of your brain's protective response to what it considers to be some sort of threat.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: You may have heard of the fight or flight response.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: When you have an anxiety attack, your body is preparing you to react to something that isn't actually a threat, so it's almost as if you're fight or flight response is overactive.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: Here is an image that may be helpful: http://psychology.tools/fight-or-flight-response.htmlThere are many different things you can do.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: You can practice breathing, mindfulness, meditation, or yoga techniques.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: If you decide to try some breathing techniques, try breathing in for a count of five, holding for a count of five, breathing out for a count of five, and repeating five times.Also remember that it is easier to learn these techniques when you're not having a panic attack.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: At that point, it can be really difficult to use methods to not panic.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: Also remember that panic attacks typically last 5 to 10 minutes.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: Using techniques to slow your breathing or become focused on the room around you is probably most helpful when you first start to feel anxious.Here are some other techniques that may help to decrease anxiety: http://psychcentral.com/lib/9-ways-to-reduce-anxiety-right-here-right-now/As you figure out what is leading up to your anxiety, also consider asking yourself what is making that certain issue a big concern for you.

title: How can I be less stressed out?
author: listener
text: Another important question could be when you have felt that way before.

title: Overcoming fears
author: speaker
text: I have a fear of something and I want to face that fear to overcome it, but I don't know how. What can I do?

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Fears are not that difficult to deal with, first you need to train yourself to relax using some relaxation strategy, once you are able to employ that in your daily life, you then need to start facing your fear, for instance I'll use an example of a man who has a fear of driving over a bridge.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: We would build a hierarchy of fears, that is a list of fears ranging from least to most, for example the man may want to start by looking at a picture of a bridge while employing his relation technique, then he may want to see a real bridge from a distance while employing that same relaxation technique, then moving closer to the bridge, then maybe standing on a bridge, all the while moving closer to his fear while relaxing, until you come to most fearful proposition which is crossing that bridge, or you can also engage in flooding which is for example, if you were scared of an elevator, go into an elevator until you are not panicking anymore, in the movie Batman Begins, Bruce Wayne who has a great fear of bats, goes into this cave and allows himself to be surrounded by bats until he is no longer fearful of them.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Secondly, look at your fears, do they even need to be worked on, some fears are healthy, for example if i was a therapist in New York City and someone came to me and said "I'm scared of snakes", I would probably say that is OK because there are very little snakes left in ManhattanHope that helps C

title: Overcoming fears
author: speaker
text: I have a fear of something and I want to face that fear to overcome it, but I don't know how. What can I do?

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Your fear may have deeper roots within your sense of who you are, than you realize.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Fears are sometimes irrational so that logic doesn't get rid of them.Think about whether you felt secure and confident as a child.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Also, did any major bad events happen to you with other people or situations when you were growing up?Often these overwhelming situations of childhood stay with us as fears of situations in our adult lives.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: If the root of the problem w the fear is from long ago, then probably a therapist who can ask you questions which help you remember upsetting childhood circumstances, may help you to dissolve the current fear.Another possibility is CBT, cognitive behavior therapy which teaches people short term mantras to do something which is safe, say being a passenger in a commercial airplane, which feels frightening to a person.CBT is short term and results are limited to specific fears.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: It is a much quicker approach than self-understanding.

title: Overcoming fears
author: speaker
text: I have a fear of something and I want to face that fear to overcome it, but I don't know how. What can I do?

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Biologically, fear is designed to protect us from harm.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Fear is not always a bad thing, and in fact can be quite healthy and appropriate depending on the situation.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: A phobia, however, is different.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: You used the term "fear" rather than "phobia".

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: A phobia is an irrational fear - meaning it is not rational for you to fear that thing.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: If your situation is a phobia, exposure therapy can help.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: This consists of gradually exposing yourself a little at a time to the thing you are afraid of.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Some people with phobias find that the irrational fear interferes with their life and they do need to overcome it.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Someone who is afraid to drive over bridges may go to great lengths to avoid routes that have bridges.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: People who are afraid of elevators may always use the stairs instead, which may not always be feasible.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: If overcoming a phobia will improve the quality of your life, then by all means, seek professional help to overcome it.Everyone has fears, or things that make them nervous.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Public speaking, asking a person out, fear of failure.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Examine what your fear is and try to determine the reason for the fear.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: When you can get to the root cause of the fear, you can deal with that issue.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: A lot of times, it is a self-esteem issue.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: You may be able to peel back the layers of the fear and find out what's causing it and deal with the real issue.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Some fears are caused by trauma.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Someone with PTSD is going to have an exaggerated fear response and will find themselves being kicked into "fight or flight" mode over things that someone without the trauma experience wouldn't notice or react to.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: In cases like this, exposure therapy would be the wrong approach and could actually make things worse.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: If there is a possibility that a past trauma is the cause of your fear, I strongly urge you to seek a therapist - not just any therapist, but one who is trained to work with trauma and abuse victims.

title: Overcoming fears
author: speaker
text: I have a fear of something and I want to face that fear to overcome it, but I don't know how. What can I do?

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Overcoming fears is something that everyone struggles with at one time or another.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Sometimes we come across something that scares us, we push through it and suddenly we aren't afraid anymore.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: But sometimes it can seem like our fears just take over and we cannot overcome them.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: There are some options:1.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: You can go to a counselor and receive some type of treatment.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: What kind of treatment would depend on the type of fears you are experiencing.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: For example, if you have a general phobia about something, they may use various techniques to help you manage it.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: There are different websites and even some self-help books that you can use to try to overcome your fears.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: When it comes to overcoming certain fears or phobias, exposure therapy well-studied and proven to work.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: A therapist would help you with this, but some websites give instructions for how to do it yourself.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: I am not sure how well it works when you try it by yourself, but here is a link to a website that does offer some tools.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: http://psychology.tools/anxiety.htmlSome colleagues may offer you some other types of advice.

title: Overcoming fears
author: listener
text: Be well.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPCC, NCC

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: speaker
text: I don't remember when the voices in my head started, but I remember Hearing them when I was little.    I know it's not normal to hear voices that aren't your own. I fight the voices and I want them to stop. They've been here so long and I want them gone. How can I make the voices stop?

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: How is your life going overall?Since you hear voices since you were young I wonder whether you mean the thoughts each of us has about what to do, our opinions, including self-criticism and praise.I try to understand how severe a problem these voices are if you've managed to get to a point in life of awareness about the voices.Usually when mental health people hear about voices the immediate thought is you need drugs bc you are psychotic.Since this is going on for a number of years, I wonder if the problem is something different.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: speaker
text: I don't remember when the voices in my head started, but I remember Hearing them when I was little.    I know it's not normal to hear voices that aren't your own. I fight the voices and I want them to stop. They've been here so long and I want them gone. How can I make the voices stop?

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: You are right.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: It is not normal to hear voices that aren't your own but the fact is some people do.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: In my experience, medication seem to help.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: It is also important to understand when you hear voices the most - meaning it is important to understand what the triggers are.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: It is also important to understand when the voices are the least - meaning what helps you deal with the voices better.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: My clients have reported that their triggers are being in social gathering or around strangers or for some even the TV.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Trying to identify your triggers is helpful for some people.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Clients have also reported that listening to music, watching TV, being with friend or family helps them deal with their voices.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Every individual is different and you need to figure out what works for you and what triggers your voices.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: My suggestion is to see a therapist / health care provider and then go from there.I hope this helps.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: speaker
text: I don't remember when the voices in my head started, but I remember Hearing them when I was little.    I know it's not normal to hear voices that aren't your own. I fight the voices and I want them to stop. They've been here so long and I want them gone. How can I make the voices stop?

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: First, let me express my support and compassion for what you're going through.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Hearing voices can be incredibly difficult and can feel like you can't get a moment's peace, even in the privacy of your own mind.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: And not everyone will necessarily understand what you're dealing with, so I imagine you may also be feeling isolated or somehow different.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Atta girl/boy on reaching out for help!

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Many people find benefit to taking medications, such as risperdal, seroquel, and so on.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: These should be prescribed by a nurse practitioner or psychiatrist -- I do not recommend a primary care doctor venture into this area, as a general rule.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Discuss the options thoroughly and insist on a good rapport with your prescriber, if you decide to go this route.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Some people are having results with a talk-therapist to develop coping strategies.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: There is a new and somewhat less conventional approach to challenging voices with a professional to assist you, rather than to suppress the voices, which medication will do.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: There is peer-run organization and a general approach that attempts to live with voices in a different way.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: You can read about it in Living With Voices by Marius Romme.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: I have heard interviews but have not read the book(s) and can't speak to its efficacy.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: No matter what steps you decide to try, managing your stress, sleep, exercise, healthy food is essential -- in other words, just the daily care and feeding of yourself should be included in all of your efforts and bears surprising benefits to your brain and emotional health.

title: How can I make the voices stop?
author: listener
text: Best wishes to you,Karen Keys, LMHC, CASAC

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: speaker
text: I've hit my head on walls and floors ever since I was young. I sometimes still do it but I don't exactly know why,    I have anxiety and I had a rough childhood but now I'll start to hit my head and sometimes not realize it but I don't know how to stop or even why I'm doing it.    How can I help myself to change my behavior?

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: I have to wonder from a behavioral perspective if what you are doing is useful for you.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: In other words, does it serve a purpose in some way when you find yourself doing it.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Yes, this could well be an expression of anxiety, or maybe some type of coping skill you have developed over the years to deal with stressful situations.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Yet it sounds like you have developed a sort of knee-jerk behavioral conditioning that causes you to do this behavior during specific (or perhaps even non-specific) circumstances.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Do you think it is a self-soothing behavior?

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Do you feel good after you have done it?

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: The behavior itself is likely causing some form of slow physical damage, so I would recommend you have yourself checked by a doctor, to rule out any injury.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: If none exists, this obviously doesn't excuse the behavior, it just says that for the moment luck is on your side.When we do any behavior of any kind, it is good to ask if what we are doing has merit or value.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Is the behavior helping us to solve our problem, or is it merely creating yet another problem by doing the behavior in the first place.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: In the same way that a person might drink excessively because they are stressed and need to cope with some unresolved issue, when they are done drinking the original problem will still likely be there, but now they are intoxicated.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: No closer to solving the issue.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: When we deal with things like anxiety or depression, we need to do things that work on dealing with the symptoms, but also get to the root issue that created those feelings and find effective solutions.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: So the things we do to cope with life events need to not be ones that cause us harm, but rather support us as we move forward and work to deal with what life throws at us.Sometimes seeking support from a friend or a counselor is a good idea.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Being given the opportunity to express your feelings about what is going on around you and getting feedback and insight from others is much more effective than actions of self-harm, wouldn't you agree?

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: So I would encourage you to find a counselor or a trusted friend who can help you find positive behaviors you can take to deal with your feelings, as you also work to find the answers to the day to day issues of living a life filled with promise and opportunity.Reach out if you need help...there will likely be a hand there waiting for you.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: speaker
text: I've hit my head on walls and floors ever since I was young. I sometimes still do it but I don't exactly know why,    I have anxiety and I had a rough childhood but now I'll start to hit my head and sometimes not realize it but I don't know how to stop or even why I'm doing it.    How can I help myself to change my behavior?

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: The best way to handle anxiety of this level is with a combination of appropriate medication given to you by a medical doctor, and therapy to help you understand the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that are causing the anxiety.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: This is not something that anyone should just “white knuckle” and try to get through on their own with no help.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a technique that has been proven helpful for depression and anxiety.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: This takes a therapist trained in CBT.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: You will learn to recognize when and why you perform the behavior of hitting your head, help you deal with the underlying cause of this, and replace the behavior with a more positive behavior.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: You'll learn coping skills.You mention having a rough childhood.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Anyone who has experienced trauma like this, especially long-term ongoing trauma from abuse of any kind, definitely does not need "exposure therapy", which is what is recommended for phobias.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: You need a therapist trained specifically in trauma informed therapy.You are on the right path by recognizing there is an issue and what it is.

title: How can I help myself and change my behavior?
author: listener
text: Good luck with your healing journey!

title: How do I open things up with a therapist without fearing judgment and condescension?

title: How do I open things up with a therapist without fearing judgment and condescension?

title: How do I open things up with a therapist without fearing judgment and condescension?
author: listener

title: How do I open things up with a therapist without fearing judgment and condescension?
author: listener

title: How do I open things up with a therapist without fearing judgment and condescension?

author: listener

author: listener

author: listener
