title: How do I open things up with a therapist without fearing judgment and condescension?

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: speaker
text: Why am I so afraid of it? I don't understand.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Your fear is somewhat reasonable.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: No one wants to be raped and I imagine everyone is afraid of what being raped would feel like.Do you mean that this fear is on your mind more often than you would like?If this is the case, then try understanding the reason behind your fear.Is it because you personally know or know of someone who was raped?

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: One general direction of what would help is to regain confidence in your decisions of keeping yourself safe.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: The more you trust yourself to avoid social situations with lots of drinking, isolated physical surroundings, and being in isolated locations with someone with whom you're not very familiar, probably your fear will decrease.The other general direction to understand is if in your family history, people have been violated severely, either emotionally, mentally, or physically.In families in which people have suffered severe violations of themselves, often the emotional patterning of expecting to be hurt by others, plants itself very deeply and transmits to the younger generation.Its possible then, that you are suffering from fears established in other family members who have not yet been able to fully understand and accept their own suffering.The good news is that individual therapy, with a credentialed and licensed therapist, is ideal for a safe place to open and clear this type of emotional burden.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: speaker
text: Why am I so afraid of it? I don't understand.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Why are you afraid of rape?

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Because it is a problem in the United States!

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: The National Sexual Violence Resource Center reports that one in five women (0r 20%) will be raped (http://www.nsvrc.org/sites/default/files/publications_nsvrc_factsheet_media-packet_statistics-about-sexual-violence_0.pdf) and that 80% of women know their assailant.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Given these statistics, it is perfectly logical to be afraid.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: However, there are things you can do to reduce the risk of rape, such as being aware of your surroundings, and limiting the use of drugs or alcohol.The Enhanced Access, Knowledge, Act program for college-aged women has been shown to reduce the risk of rape by more than 50%.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: (http://www.blueprintsprograms.com/factsheet/eaaa-enhanced-assess-acknowledge-act-sexual-assault-resistance-education) You may want to see if a program like this is available in your area.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Another great app for when you need to walk somewhere alone, is the Companion App (http://www.companionapp.io).

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Friends or family can track your progress from one point to another via the GPS in your phone.In addition, talking with a counselor about your fears would also be a good idea.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Sometimes fears are rational and reasonable.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: Sometimes they are over-reactions and unreasonable.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: When then are over-reactions and unreasonable, they can have a negative impact on your life.

title: How can I be less afraid of rape?
author: listener
text: In this case, a counselor could help you understand why your fears are unreasonable, and how you can stop them from negatively impacting your life.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?

text: I never feel like myself. I can’t even think straight anymore. I start stuttering and I can’t remember anything. I always get nervous and usually talk myself down but recently end up fighting with, what feels like, someone else. I don’t know why I feel this way, but I hate it.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Hi Houston, Okay, something's definitely going on, right?

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: My gut is to start with your family physician, because you have some physical symptoms.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: speaker
text: I never feel like myself. I can’t even think straight anymore. I start stuttering and I can’t remember anything. I always get nervous and usually talk myself down but recently end up fighting with, what feels like, someone else. I don’t know why I feel this way, but I hate it.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: What you are describing sounds like it may be a form of dissociation.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Dissociation is our mind's way of disconnecting us from aspects of our experience in an attempt to protect us in overwhelming situations.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: It also sounds like you are noticing anxiety in certain situations.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: In working with a competent therapist, you may be able to gain insight into these experiences, learn skills for coping with anxiety and reconnecting with yourself, and alleviate these symptoms over time.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: speaker
text: I never feel like myself. I can’t even think straight anymore. I start stuttering and I can’t remember anything. I always get nervous and usually talk myself down but recently end up fighting with, what feels like, someone else. I don’t know why I feel this way, but I hate it.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Hello,I am wondering if you might be experiencing some form of dissociation.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: People who dissociate might feel like the world around them is unreal and unfamiliar, or that they are not really in their bodies and that they are observing themselves from outside of their bodies.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Dissociation can also mean that there are parts of you that have "split off" and sometimes parts are can feel like they are at odds with each other or are locked in conflict.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Sometimes dissociation happens after someone experiences a trauma.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Therapy can help you to understand what is going on and help you to integrate your experiences and ultimately heal.I am a therapist in Houston who specializes in dissociation.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: On my website I have information specific to dissociation that might be helpful to you.

title: Why do I feel like I’m watching my life from a window?
author: listener
text: Sarah

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: speaker
text: I’ve been on 0.5 mg of Xanax twice a day for the past month. It hasn't been helping me at all, but when I take 1 mg during a big anxiety attack, it calms me down. I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Do you think you're abusing xanax?It is a highly addictive drug so maybe one reason you feel compelled to take more is bc you already are addicted.Drugs don't do anything helpful in solving life's problems.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Once the effect wears off, the stressful situation is once again waiting for you to address it.Think over your reason for not directly asking your psychologist about upping your dose.Also, do you ever talk about your life problems with this psychologist or only your need for drugs?

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: The more gradual path to a better life is to not need drugs in the first place.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: This consists of your willingness to face the matters that are creating such terrible feelings inside you.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?

I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Staying on the lower dose may give you more room to learn strategies for coping with your anxiety.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Medications are so helpful, and needed at times, but it's also important to have a variety of tools you use to manage your responses to stress.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: If you are not already seeing a therapist, consider finding one who can help you learn some effective strategies, like replacing self-defeating thoughts with ones that work better for you, or mindfulness, relaxation, or other tools to keep your anxiety in the manageable range!

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?

I was wondering how I can ask my psychologist to up the dose to 1 mg twice a day without her thinking I'm abusing them. I just have very big anxiety attacks. Should I stay on the 0.5mg and deal with the attacks or should I ask to up the dose? I'm afraid she will take me off them and put me on something else.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: In general, Xanax is very short-acting.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: You mentioned that you are afraid that your medical provider will take you off of the Xanax and put you on something else.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: If the Xanax is not working well for you, I wonder if something else may work better.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Also, sometimes there are medications that you can take in addition to Xanax.In addition to talking with your medical provider about changing the medication, try to track your levels of anxiety on a scale of 1 to 10 throughout the day so you can get a pattern of what is happening.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Also consider writing down what is happening before you have anxiety attacks.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: This may help your medical provider know what medication may be helpful to you or what changes could be made.As far as how to discuss this with your medical provider, I would suggest mentioning the symptom changes you are having (anxiety attacks that are not helped with 0.5mg of Xanax) and ask what they would suggest that might help.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: If your medical provider suggests taking you off of the Xanax, I would recommend talking about the reasons why you would prefer to stay on the Xanax and what your concerns are about coming off of it.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: You could also ask whether anything could be combined with Xanax.There are also many other anxiety medications.

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: I have seen lots of people that take more than one medication to lessen anxiety that they are having.I would also consider talking with a therapist (unless the person who is prescribing a medication is also doing therapy with you).

title: How can I talk to my psychologist about upping my dose of Xanax?
author: listener
text: Getting more information about your anxiety and how it is affecting you may be greatly helpful to you.

title: Why do I always feel anxious?
author: speaker
text: It's especially bad at night time. I am scared of sleeping alone.

title: Why do I always feel anxious?
author: listener
text: Being able to know you feel anxiety and write about it, is the first step to addressing and handling it!Generally, anxiety is deep fear of not being able to handle what comes up in life.

title: Why do I always feel anxious?
author: listener
text: Somehow the person was insufficiently nurtured and so felt  insecure when very young.Usually the person had to fend on at least a psychological and emotional level for themselves before reaching an age when doing so would have been reasonable.Their inner feeling of overwhelmed from when very young, hasn't faced the reality that the grown person is now capable, even if this takes some practice.

title: Why do I always feel anxious?
author: listener
text: Try asking yourself what you are afraid of and theorize how you would handle these situations as a grown person.Also, sometimes anxiety comes from feeling lonely.

title: Why do I always feel anxious?
author: listener
text: This loneliness is reminiscent of the loneliness that the grown person now, felt when being left to take care of situations as a child which were too difficult and complex for any child to address.

title: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
author: speaker
text: I am on the track and softball team. My school is small, so I play all four sports it offers. I feel obligated to do track because I'm not a horrible runner, and my dad wants me to. The catch is is that the days before a track meet and the morning of, I get sick and cry.

title: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
author: listener
text: Does anyone notice that you get sick and cry on track meet days?Have you told anyone?From what you write, as much as you would like to please your school and dad, something within you doesn't quite want to fully follow through.Step one in life always is to know what you want and what your limits are.

title: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
author: listener
text: It already is difficult to avoid listening to your body.Try understanding what is difficult in telling your father that you'd like doing as he wishes, only are not able to do so because you are emotionally and physically distraught on the days you have track.After finishing the season for this year with your school's track team, then expect to concentrate on taking care of your own need to not do track.Hopefully your father will understand and care about your problem.

title: What should I do about my stress before track meets?
author: listener
text: If he does not and track is more important than your well being, then you have a different problem entirely.

title: How can I stop worrying much?

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: Thinking about what others think of us is a natural tendency.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: Human beings are social creatures and rely on feedback from the outside world of people, places, and things to let us know more about ourselves.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: We also have an inner voice, dialogue, conscience, etc.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: that helps us to determine the path for us.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: Often, when someone is worried about the external feedback, and focuses on this as the sole source of information, it can create a dependency that can become problematic.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: Balance is key to so many things in life.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: Your own voice is powerful and has strength to provide you the enjoyment you seek.

title: How can I stop worrying much?
author: listener
text: Don't discount it and rely only on the voices of others.

title: Why is it so hard for me to talk publicly?

title: Why is it so hard for me to talk publicly?

title: Why is it so hard for me to talk publicly?
author: listener

title: How can I avoid becoming wrapped up in family issues and control my anxiety about them?

title: How can I avoid becoming wrapped up in family issues and control my anxiety about them?

text: I do not like to assume so I will direct you to information regarding families dealing with enmeshment and triangulation.

title: How can I avoid becoming wrapped up in family issues and control my anxiety about them?
author: listener
text: Enmeshment is the concept of diffused boundaries in families and other personal relationships.

title: How can I avoid becoming wrapped up in family issues and control my anxiety about them?
author: listener
text: Triangulation is two individuals relaying information to a third party what cannot be said directly to each other.

title: How can I avoid becoming wrapped up in family issues and control my anxiety about them?

text: From someone who has dealt with both these issues on a personal level, being informed about family dynamics is beneficial and can help you develop healthy boundaries for yourself within your family structure.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: speaker
text: Whenever I have to speak in public or be in big crowds, I freak out. I get light-headed, sweaty, and I have trouble breathing.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
Basically, your response is the fight, flight or freeze reaction
which is hard wired into the human nervous system, specifically, the autonomic nervous system (called the autonomic response).

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
This system
is responsible for regulating the heart, digestion, respiratory rate
as well as other aspects which match the symptoms you describe.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
It is largely an unconscious function, but
with training it can be managed such as a public speaking course in which you
prepare and even have some exposure to smaller experiences to help you prepare
and cope for larger presentations.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
One of the greatest applications of
addressing this response is the NASA program which exposes the astronauts to situations
they will encounter while in space which will trigger the response so that when
it does happen (not if but when) that they are able to move through the
challenge with success.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
You can learn
more about his by going to TED Talks “What I learned about going blind in space” It is
a truly inspiring look at what you are experiencing as well as how to deal with
it.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
With that being said, finding a program
like a Dale Carnegie Public Speaking program can help.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text:
Working with a counselor who can help you
utilize visualization of an upcoming speech has been shown to help and you can
always talk to your doctor to see what options might be available there as
well.

title: Why am I so anxious in social situations?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?
author: speaker
text: Recently, I had a close call after delivering my second child (blood clot followed by internal bleeding and several blood transfusions). It was a close call. I have never really had anxiety in the past, but I find now that it consumes my every day and night. With two beautiful children to raise, I am most terrified of not being able to raise and protect them.

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

text: Hi Meriden, it's natural that after a serious scare like that you would have some anxiety and fear.

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

text: This fear is helpful to some extent, because it will assist you in taking care of yourself and not taking unnecessary risks with your health.

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

title: How do I get over my fears of dying?

text: I wish you well.

title: Why am I not as comfortable around my boyfriend anymore?
author: listener
text: Very often, just being told the person has a "condition" makes them feel fragile and less capable than they actually are.Anxiety and panic attacks do mean that there is a great deal of emotion and situation needing to be addressed.It is the normal sign of having to address many or deep matters.

title: Why am I not as comfortable around my boyfriend anymore?
author: listener
text: Be patient and give yourself time to learn the details of your relationship and whatever the career particulars are that are bothering you.

title: Why am I not as comfortable around my boyfriend anymore?
author: listener
text: You're apparently self-aware since you're the one describing your own problematic situations.

title: Why am I not as comfortable around my boyfriend anymore?
author: listener
text: Keep the label of being "disordered", aside.

title: Why am I not as comfortable around my boyfriend anymore?
author: listener
text: Psychiatry labels do more good for psychiatrists than they do for people who are trying to live their lives.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: speaker
text: My toddler defies everything I say and doesn’t see me as authoritative, so she says no about everything. I'd like to hear some ways I can work on not needing to feel so much in control all the time.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Hi Biddeford,This is a super goal.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Feeling powerless is something parents are wise to get used to; there's a creature in the home whose job it is to find and use their power in the family and in the world.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Of course your toddler defies you, and that's healthy.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: I worry more about the overly compliant ones.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: She is wanting to know what the rules are, and all you have to do is show her clearly where the lines are.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: I'll give you some tips.First, remind yourself that it's her job to learn what the rules are, and where her power is.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Don't be so surprised when she wants it her way.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: If we go through our days being ready and prepared for these beautiful creatures to have minds of their own, we're less caught off guard when it happens.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Avoid situations that invite power struggles.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Any time you tell your daughter "do this now", you set up a power struggle.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: The good thing is that she's young enough you can pick her up; now is the time to teach her that mom's (or dad's) word means something.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: So, if you say "let's get you dressed", then be prepared to pick her up right away and show her that when you say something will happen, you can make it happen.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: And I'm talking about gently picking her up here...not roughly.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Pick your battles; only give instructions when you have the power to make it happen.Give her choices, so she can see her power.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Instead of opening her drawer and asking what she wants to wear, give her two choices.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Here's an example...she's on the ipad and you say ipad time is over.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: She says "no".

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: You can say "ipad time is over.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: If you put it down, you can play later.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: If I have to take it away, you don't play it later."

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: The choice is hers.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Then follow through.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: "When...then" statements are really helpful.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Your child asks for something.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Instead of saying no, try "as soon as the toys are picked up, we can have a snack".

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: You're simply a pleasant parent who wants the same thing they do...but they have to earn it.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Staying calm yourself is the key, because then at least you will feel in control of yourself, which is the ultimate goal.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Use self-talk to calm yourself.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Remind yourself her behaviour is normal and healthy.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Breathe through a moment in which you would have reacted, and it will be over by the time the breath is done.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: You can give yourself time to think before you make parenting decisions.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Time is a useful tool not enough parents use.

title: How can I be less anxious when dealing with my toddler?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: How can I deal with flashbacks of trauma?
author: speaker
text: I was violently raped by another women who was my friend of 13 years. I’m having bad flashbacks. I’m scared to sleep because I see it in my dreams. I don't leave the house because I have panic attacks.

title: How can I deal with flashbacks of trauma?
author: listener
text: I'm sorry for your suffering.There are therapy programs which help people to gradually feel more at ease so that daily living does not feel so frightening.Once you feel stronger and more secure from such a behavioral program, you'll be able to sleep more peacefully and leave the house whenever necessary to do your regular life.Then, you will be able to open and clear the deep emotional hurt that always occurs from being violated by a trusted friend.Sending good wishes in your work!

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: speaker
text:
I have lately been having lots of anxiety and self-loathing about the fact that I am a young adult virgin girl who has never had a boyfriend before. It seems like everyone my age has already had boyfriends by now or are not virgins anymore, and I just had my first kiss five months ago. I’m worried that, at this rate, I won’t have a boyfriend for a very long time. The problem is that I want to lose my virginity to my first boyfriend who cares about me, but at the same time, I don't want to be waiting forever in order to experience sex. I have already given in to bad temptations by hooking up with random strangers on social media sites and having oral sex with them. Luckily, they were nice guys, but none of them wanted a relationship with me. I feel dirty by doing this, but I feel pressured to do this things in order to seem normal.
   Most people are surprised when they find out that I am a virgin or never had a boyfriend because people think I am really good looking. I am tall, I play lots of sports, and I get excellent grades in school. I am in my first year of university right now, and no guys have approached me to go out on a date or showed any interest. It bothers me. Most of the people in my family have been in relationships at my age already. I feel like I will be single forever sometimes.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Hi Winters, I'm so glad you wrote, because I think there are a lot of young women experiencing the exact same thing.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: You feel self-loathing for both being a virgin, and for being sexually active.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Young women have always gotten crazy mixed messages about what they're supposed to be.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: They feel pressure to be pure, and they also feel pressure to be the vixen and please men sexually.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: But you can't be both, so you can't ever win if you buy into all that horse manure (excuse my language).

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: This current hook-up culture puts added pressure on girls to expect nothing more than random sexual encounters that leave you feeling empty and used; perhaps desirable in that moment but mostly worthless.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: The stupid part is that research tells us that young men are also impacted negatively by this cultural norm that values sex and not relationship; they feel guilt, and loneliness.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: I urge you to talk to other girls and women about your feelings.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: My hope and prayer is that they will echo my words here.Your value and power cannot ever be found in whether a man wants you, whether you turn his eye, or how he treats you.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Your sexuality is a beautiful part of who you are, and it is to be celebrated.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: I love that you want to celebrate it with someone who cares.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Who you are is so very much more than your sexuality.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: You sound like you have a lot of things going for you.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Try to see all of those things when you think of yourself.There are many more virgins out there, and many are afraid, like you, that they don't fit in.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: We are all different, and you don't have to be anything but who you want to be; who you are.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: You don't have to have any kind of sex until you're ready, and that makes you brave and smart, not weird.You're tall and beautiful, and guys may be intimidated by that.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: It may take time for you to meet the right guy, but he's out there.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: The question is: How do you want to spend your time until he crosses your path?

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: I hope you talk to someone soon and find out that your feelings are normal.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: I wish you the best.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: speaker
text:
I have lately been having lots of anxiety and self-loathing about the fact that I am a young adult virgin girl who has never had a boyfriend before. It seems like everyone my age has already had boyfriends by now or are not virgins anymore, and I just had my first kiss five months ago. I’m worried that, at this rate, I won’t have a boyfriend for a very long time. The problem is that I want to lose my virginity to my first boyfriend who cares about me, but at the same time, I don't want to be waiting forever in order to experience sex. I have already given in to bad temptations by hooking up with random strangers on social media sites and having oral sex with them. Luckily, they were nice guys, but none of them wanted a relationship with me. I feel dirty by doing this, but I feel pressured to do this things in order to seem normal.
   Most people are surprised when they find out that I am a virgin or never had a boyfriend because people think I am really good looking. I am tall, I play lots of sports, and I get excellent grades in school. I am in my first year of university right now, and no guys have approached me to go out on a date or showed any interest. It bothers me. Most of the people in my family have been in relationships at my age already. I feel like I will be single forever sometimes.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: I think that every person who has been single for any extended period of time has felt the same worries - myself included.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Since relationships are so important to us we fear not having them and being single.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: It is similar to fearing that we won't ever get a good job when we have been out of work for awhile or fearing that we won't be healthy when we have been sick.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: We fear these things because they are so important - not because these fears are realistic or true!

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: There is immense pressure put on young single people from peers and media to conform to ideas of what is normal and to meet expectations in terms of sexual experience, dating, etc.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: While some people may judge an adult who is a virgin - others will respect your choices and feel even more attracted to you because of your choices.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Experimenting with sex, so long as you are being safe and respectful is also completely okay and normal.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Since expectations vary and we can't be happy if we are always comparing ourselves to other people, we need to ultimately trust that being who we are and building a loving relationship with ourselves is the key to meeting someone who will cherish us for all the ways that we are special and unique, virgin or not.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: When we are able to really accept ourselves and trust in our loveableness (not a real word but you get what I mean!)

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: then meeting someone special is simply a matter of time and effort - putting ourselves out in the world in situations where we are likely to meet other single people looking for relationships.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: When you are most afraid of being alone - remember that this fear is simply a reminder of how much you value relationships.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Use that passion about wanting relationships to build the best relationship you can with yourself and then one day soon some lucky person will stumble into your life and benefit immensely from your passion and your ability to be authentically who you are rather than pretending to be "normal" or whatever that is anyway.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Hope this helps!

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: It is very hard to want a loving relationship, and either see or imagine all around you, the great times other couples are having.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Extra hard is that other people's comments may start giving you the sense that you are letting them down to not have a relationship!All the fantasies that develop from viewing Facebook photos and imagining everyone or most people in ideal relationships, just augments any frustration of not being part of this group.Your post sounds like you're being true to yourself and honoring who you are really, by developing clear standards of what you'd expect from a relationship.For the longterm, whatever develops in your relationship life, you will always be able to look back and know you had self-integrity.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: By being your natural self, you're being attractive.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Probably very unlikely that a young woman who would like a relationship, will never have one.Maybe the young men in your school are not yet emotionally mature enough to know how to see and appreciate you.Even though it may be hard, have patience with bringing in someone who is good for you.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: And, continue your keen insight of yourself because it is guiding you to be the best in all areas of living.Sending good luck in all areas!

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: I think one of the first questions that springs to mind for me is, "what's the rush?"

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Just because other people in your circle have had experiences that you are still warming up to does not mean that there's something wrong or something to be ashamed of.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: If anything, I want to commend you on the self-respect you have in wanting to wait and share this most intimate of experiences with someone that will feel the same way about it.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: One of the most common distortions in our thinking is when we try to directly compare ourselves to others; while these people and even those in your family share a level of closeness to you they are not exactly like you - they don't see or feel things in the exact same way as you nor do they share the exact same perspective.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: It's important to be making choices for you and for your own desires and life goals.

title: I'm worried that I will be single forever
author: listener
text: Once you stop comparing your happiness, you may find that you are already experiencing it and allow more of your guard to fall down.

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: speaker
text: For my whole life, I’ve been very unconfident, insecure, and self-questioning. I'm super quiet because I'm scared of what people will think of me. I avoid all social situations as it causes me great anxiety. It is how both of my parents have always been, and I feel like I'm doomed to that life also. It makes it super hard for me at work as the other employees try to use me and walk all over me because I’m too nice. It causes me depression and brings me down. I’m in my early twenties, and I really need to create a better life for myself. I've been like this for so long, so how do I change?

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: listener
text: One of the greatest ways that we can promote ourselves s by learning how to assert ourselves.

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: listener
text: Despite what most people think of when they hear the word assertive, assertive communication is one of the best ways to manage interpersonal conflict as well as maintain personal boundaries.

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: listener
text: Once we become comfortable with acknowledging our boundaries, there is usually a follow-up whereby we realize that we have the right to those boundaries.

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: listener
text: In effect, assertiveness communication becomes it's own self-motivating force in managing positive self-esteem.

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: listener
text: You may want to invest in a workbook that can help you to develop these skills on your own, or work directly with a therapist to develop them in a safe situation.

title: How do I become more confident and face social situations?
author: listener
text: One of the Workbooks that I have found to be very helpful is, "The Assertiveness Workbook: How to Express your Ideas and Stand Up for Yourself at Work and in Relationships" by Randy J Paterson.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: speaker
text: I have a lot of issues going on right now. First of all, I have a lot of trouble sleeping at times, while other nights I sleep too much and still feel quite tired. I’m also noticing increased irritability and experiencing anxiety attacks that last for hours. Is there something wrong with me and if so what should I do?

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: It sounds as if you may be experiencing a bout of anxiety and/or depression.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: Sleeping difficulties, irritability and anxiety attacks all are correlated with these mood disorders.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: And it’s actually quite common for someone to deal encounter this during their lifetime.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: Also, keep in mind that just because you are experiencing this now does not mean that you will be dealing with it the rest of your life.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: Many times, it can be a single episode and if treatment is received, you can help prevent any recurrent episodes.However, you may want to first talk with your primary physician to rule out any medical issues that could be causing these problems.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: There may be a reason for the sudden onset of these symptoms that can be addressed quickly.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: On the other hand, if it is determined that you are experiencing anxiety and/or depression without a medical reason, there are two methods that are very helpful in your treatment:#1 Talk therapy with a certified therapistHe/She will be able to address the concerns you’re experiencing and discovering if there is an underlying issue that may be causing it.#2 MedicationThere are many medications that can assist you with the feelings that you are experiencing.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: Your doctor will be able to help you find the right one that works for you.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: If one doesn’t work, keep trying.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: There are many different options to address your specific needs.Also, a combination of these two options is extremely beneficial!Thank you for your question.

title: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
author: listener
text: I sincerely hope that you feel better soon!

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: speaker
text: I feel that I need to end my present relationship. He lives three hours away and likes the reassurance of having someone to talk to multiple times per day and seeing me once or twice a month. I want someone who is more present and more of a life companion. Lately, he has had a very busy work schedule and I have only seen him a few times in the last 6 weeks. I told him that I can't continue in this way because I constantly feel frustrated and angry and that he is not making the relationship enough of a priority. I also feel it is keeping me from possibly finding the relationship I want. We have been together 7 years. The problem is that I panic and experience anxiety and depression thinking of him with someone else and then thinking I will never meet someone I like. We have gone through this cycle already 4-5 times and I feel it is unhealthy to stay in it, but my aversion to the anxiety and depression I experience upon separation always leads me to reconcile.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: It sounds like you have some insight into the cycle that you describe with your current relationship and at the same time you are still feeling stuck.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: It also sounds like the distressing feelings that you experience, when you imagine what will happen for you and your current partner, are pretty overwhelming.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: A competent therapist may be able to help you work through these difficult thoughts and feelings and find a resolution to this cycle that will feel right to you.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: speaker
text: I feel that I need to end my present relationship. He lives three hours away and likes the reassurance of having someone to talk to multiple times per day and seeing me once or twice a month. I want someone who is more present and more of a life companion. Lately, he has had a very busy work schedule and I have only seen him a few times in the last 6 weeks. I told him that I can't continue in this way because I constantly feel frustrated and angry and that he is not making the relationship enough of a priority. I also feel it is keeping me from possibly finding the relationship I want. We have been together 7 years. The problem is that I panic and experience anxiety and depression thinking of him with someone else and then thinking I will never meet someone I like. We have gone through this cycle already 4-5 times and I feel it is unhealthy to stay in it, but my aversion to the anxiety and depression I experience upon separation always leads me to reconcile.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: Sounds like your panic is less about loosing the relationship you are in (which by the way doesn't sound like it's meeting YOUR need for connection) and more about being alone.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: Being with him is serving you, even if the relationship is less than ideal, from being alone.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: Being alone can be scary.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: You'd have to face yourself.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: You'd have to learn to love and care for and cherish yourself.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: All important skills and tasks in maturing and growing up, but scary none the less.

title: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things
author: listener
text: What if...What if you gave yourself permission to be in a relationship with YOU?

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager, and I struggle with going out and talking to people. I feel awful about leaving home. I know I can't afford a therapist so I don't know what my problem is, but I think I might have social anxiety.

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: listener
text: If you are noticing that anxiety tends to be triggered around interactions with others, then you may have social anxiety.

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: listener
text: Working with a therapist, you may be able to gain insight into the nature of the anxiety, develop tools for coping with it, and take steps that may alleviate it over time, so that you can enjoy your interactions with others.

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: listener
text: If you are short on money, there still may be options for you to be able to see a therapist.

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: listener
text: Check with your insurance provider about your behavioral health coverage.

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: listener
text: If you have medicaid/apple care, there are some private practice therapists who accept this form of insurance, as well as community clinics which do.

title: How do I know if I have social anxiety?
author: listener
text: If you are not insured, some therapists and clinics will work on a sliding fee scale, and accept either low fee or may even work with you pro-bono (for free).

title: I always feel the need to tell people everything
author: speaker
text: Whenever I don't tell my friends or anyone what I did or stuff that's not really important, I feel terrible, like there’s a hole in my stomach. It only goes away when I hurt myself.

title: I always feel the need to tell people everything
author: listener
text: Sorry to hear of your situation.Possibly you are overlooking that your own Self is someone worth talking to as well.None of us are ever really alone because we are always with ourselves.Self-talk is a major part of what guides our decisions and how we make sense of relationships and situations.

title: I always feel the need to tell people everything
author: listener
text: Even after telling people the stories or activities, hearing their comments, it is always within ourselves that we decide if the way we were received by these others, the comments we heard back, feel right and accurate to our lives.I hope the feeling of a hole in your stomach would decrease by enjoying your Self.

title: I always feel the need to tell people everything
author: listener
text: I am guessing that hurting yourself makes the stomach hole feel less bad because the physical pain you create in yourself distracts you from feeling it.Enjoying your Self by talking kindly, loving, and having inner dialogue may very well decrease the feeling of a hole, altogether.Sending lots of good luck!

title: I am fearful of social situations and avoiding people all together

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: speaker
text: Whenever I leave my girlfriend I get panic attacks. I'm taking medications to control them, but I'm thinking of moving in with her since I get so anxious.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener
text: I’m sorry to hear that you are currently experiencing panic attacks.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener
text: I hope that the medication you have been prescribed has provided you with some relief.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, I don’t feel that moving in with your girlfriend would alleviate your anxiety.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Although you may feel very anxious about leaving her, your body is reacting to this stressful event in your life in an unhealthy manner.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener
text: You may be able to render this particular situation but it’s likely that you may experience another panic attack when an additional stressful event arises.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Therefore, it is essential that you address the reason for why you are experiencing panic attacks in the first place followed by practicing coping mechanisms in the case that one would arise in the future.Talk therapy has shown to be effective with those affected by anxiety along with breathing exercises and yoga.

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener

title: I'm experiencing panic attacks when I'm physically separated from my girlfriend
author: listener

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: speaker
text: I had a head injury a few years ago and my mind races all the time. I have trouble sleeping and have a lot of anxiety. Every medicine I have been on my body rejects; I get sick to my stomach and get blisters in my mouth. How can I calm my self down? I'm a wreck.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: You didn't say what or how many medications you've tried.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: Certain anxiety medications can make you feel nauseous, but I haven't heard of any that cause mouth blisters, so there may be some other underlying medical issue there.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: I would definitely talk to your primary care physician and whoever has prescribed the medication as well as a neurologist if you've suffered a severe head injury.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: There are so many medications available for anxiety or insomnia or even depression that there may be others with lesser side effects.But beyond that, have you tried any other treatments such as deep breathing or meditation?

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: Meditation can be very effective, but it takes practice and you don't have to sit cross-legged for hours chanting "Ohm" to meditate.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: It's about focusing on your breath, rather than all the thoughts that are racing through your head.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: And when they do take your mind off your breath, simply refocus (and refocus and refocus).

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: Like I said, it takes practice, so don't give up.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: You can find many sites offering different ways to meditate, so look around and see what works best for you.

title: Can I control anxiety without medication?
author: listener
text: Like medication, you just have to find the one that works best and that might take some experimentation.I hope this helps and best of luck to you.

title: Should I feel guilty if my adult daughter cannot afford to go on a family vacation?
author: speaker

title: Should I feel guilty if my adult daughter cannot afford to go on a family vacation?

title: I get verbally abused everyday by my parents in front of my child and I cannot take it anymore
author: speaker
text:
I'm being verbally abused on a daily basis by my parents in front of my child. I feel like I’m trapped and I have no escape. I feel like I have to listen to the horrible things they say and just take all of it.

title: I get verbally abused everyday by my parents in front of my child and I cannot take it anymore

title: I get verbally abused everyday by my parents in front of my child and I cannot take it anymore

text: Saying this over and over to yourself as you are listening to your parents will help you to tune out some of their words but it will also start to build more positive neural connections and start to wire your brain to build and/or strengthen your self esteem.

title: If my kids come back from their dad's and act like they are afraid they will get hit, should I be worried about him abusing them?

title: My fiancé's ex-husband shows up unannounced
author: speaker
text: he just walks in the house whenever he wants to see his kids. My fiancé tells me it makes her angry and doesn't like it, but she seems afraid to say anything to him about it for some reason. Is it okay for him to do this?

title: My fiancé's ex-husband shows up unannounced
author: listener
text: The kids are actually her Property, and he does have a claim to them as he wishes;The house is yours, I presume;So require that if he wishes to see his Property, it be done off of your Property;And, that as long as it remains your Property, you have jurisdiction over all those, therein;Require compensation for visits, and send him a bill;When he doesn't pay, send to the local sheriff, go to small claims court, and win a judgment against him for non-payment;I wonder how that might work out... act as man :)

author: listener
text: Do you know the reason your fiancé puts up with the ex's behavior?If not, then ask her.The answer could be anything, from some agreement the two of them made either formally or informally before you came into her life, to residual sense of obligation she feels toward him as a parent, or that she genuinely does fear his physical or verbal anger if she disagrees with what he wants.Facts are the best starting point to know how to handle a situation.There is no blanket rule and certainly no law which prohibits what he's doing.

title: My fiancé's ex-husband shows up unannounced

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: speaker
text: My daughter seemed to be developing at a normal rate until about the age of 10. She then started to act younger than she is.    Now she only wants to play with younger kids and she doesn't act her age. I don't know why this is happening. Is this normal?

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Hello.It sounds like you are really concerned about your daughter because you have noticed a significant change in her behavior .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: It's really a great first step that you are reaching out to get some ideas about what might be going on .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: You are clearly an observant and hands on  mom who wants to be sure that her daughter is ok.This is a tough question to answer without more information .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: With that said , I have found that "under stress people regress."

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: In other words , many people , children and adults alike , often regress and behave differently - as if they were younger than their actual age - when under stress .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Therefore , my first question would be : has anything been happening recently that is causing your daughter stress ?

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: This could be anything from conflict at home , recent changes such as moving , divorce , a loss of some kind , switching schools , or losing a friend or friends .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Additionally , sometimes if children are feeling bullied or left out by same age peers , they may gravitate toward younger playmates as a way to boost their social confidence .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: I would suggest that you think about what stressors / changes may have occurred recently.

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: You may also want to check in with her teacher (s) to see if they have noticed any changes in your daughter's behavior at school .I also think that you can have a conversation with your daughter in order to see if you can get a sense about whether or not something has been bothering her.

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Something as simple as " I have noticed that you aren't spending time with the friends you used to hang out with ; it seems like you have been playing with a lot of younger kids lately .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Am I right about that ? "

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: and then if she says yes you might ask a few questions such as : "did something happen with your friends that  is making you not want to be with them?"

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: "Has something been bothering you lately ?

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Are you feeling upset or worried ? "

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: If she denies that there is anything wrong you might even say " I know that sometimes when I feel stressed or worried , I tend to act a little differently - sometimes I withdraw from my regular group of friends , or I get cranky and feel less like myself .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: I wonder if something like that is happening with you ?"

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: If you are really concerned and not getting any answers from her and / or her teachers , perhaps you can consult with a therapist to discuss your concerns further and decide if it might  help for your daughter to talk to a therapist a few times , or at the very least you can get more specific tips from a therapist about how to approach this issue with your daughter more effectively .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: The more detail you can provide about what you have noticed with your daughter , including any changes or new stressors ,  any possible patterns to this behavior , if school has become more difficult socially and or academically , the more a therapist can guide you about how best to handle your concerns and talk with your daughter in a way that is helpful to her.

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: I believe that this may just be a phase and it seems to me to be well within the normal range of children's behavior.

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: I do, though, think that you will feel more assured about this  if you can get to the bottom of what's going on .

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: speaker
text: My daughter seemed to be developing at a normal rate until about the age of 10. She then started to act younger than she is.    Now she only wants to play with younger kids and she doesn't act her age. I don't know why this is happening. Is this normal?

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Good for you to know your daughter's friendship circles and to notice when these have changed.While friendships are key relationships, they are not the only indicator of someone not developing normally.Is your observation and opinion that your daughter isn't normal based on other factors or just this one?If this is the only factor then start with reflecting on what circumstances may be influencing your daughter to socialize with younger kids.Has she ben ostracized or bullied by her peers and may be retreating to avoid further emotional hurt?Is she keeping up with her school work?Sometimes kids who feel overwhelmed by schoolwork will regress into conditions in which they feel more success and control.Are there family circumstances such as the death of someone with whom your daughter felt close?

title: My daughter isn't acting her age
author: listener
text: Or, is there a new younger sibling in the family or a younger sibling who due to their own circumstance receives more attention than your daughter may wish for herself.Once you've reflected on which areas may be affecting your daughter, gently ask her some questions about her comfort with what you theorize may be the source of the problem.Its also possible that offering her your extra time and interest may increase her sense of self so that she feels secure enough to increase her social time with her age group.

title: How should I handle the child I had with my ex-wife?
author: speaker
text: My ex-wife married and used me to have a child. She now uses that child as a pawn. I know my child misses me, but I need to move on and not live in the past. How do I do this? Do I see my child as much as possible or very little? Is it more confusing for the child?

title: How should I handle the child I had with my ex-wife?
author: listener
text: You can "move on and not live in the past" in the context of your ex-relationship, but that does not mean moving on from your child.

title: How should I handle the child I had with my ex-wife?
author: listener
text: "Moving on" then would involve accepting the end of the relationship and developing a civil relationship with your ex-partner as far as is possible for the sake of your child's development.Generally, it's good for a functional (non-abusive) parent to spend time with his/her child, but only insofar as that doesn't cause your child unnecessary stress.

title: How should I handle the child I had with my ex-wife?
author: listener
text: That requires the two adults to act like adults with each other for the sake of their child.What's confusing for children is seeing their parents act uncivilly or manipulatively.

title: How should I handle the child I had with my ex-wife?
author: listener
text: Children also do well with routines so regular dependable visitation is preferable to random visitation or, worse, not following through on commitments.But if one person is exploiting their child to harm their ex-partner, then visiting your child in that context may be stressful to him/her (depending on what you mean by using your child as a pawn).

title: How should I handle the child I had with my ex-wife?
author: listener

author: listener
text: What are the ways your ex-wife uses your child as a pawn?This answer determines the best ways to handle particular situations.Basically, distinguish that your father relationship to your child lasts has great meaning for your child and as the adult, the responsibility for managing this relationship falls on you.Your relationship to your ex wife took place between two adults and therefore you are only responsible for your own actions to repair the damage done to you.From what you write, you already have a plan in progress to do this by separating yourself as much as possible from contact with the ex.In a way the challenge of keeping active as a parent while also distancing and clearing your emotions of the hurt and betrayal done to you, will establish both a solid relationship with your child and grow more acceptance and self-forgiveness of having been taken advantage of and tricked.

title: How can I help my son succeed in life when he refuses it?
author: speaker
text: When my son was a teenager, we sent him to live with his dad because of the constant disrespectful attitude. A week after he graduated, his dad made him leave because of the same issues. All four parents tried to talk to him, and he just refuses help all around. He is now living with his grandparents. He had a job, and took steps to get his license and an insured vehicle. I thought he was heading down the right road, and then he tells me he quit his job because he didn’t like it. I just don’t know what to do.

title: How can I help my son succeed in life when he refuses it?
author: listener
text: Probably the best way to be supportive of your son is to tell him what bothers you about the way he's handling himself.If you'd like him to work with your suggestions then before you make critical comments be sure to validate his strong points and to recognize his natural talents.People are much more likely to take advice if the person feels the criticism is spoken by someone who respects them and isn't only critical of them.Offer your availability to talk with him if you genuinely feel available to speak with him in a non-judgmental way.

title: How can I help my son succeed in life when he refuses it?

author: listener
text: For example, if he is willing to talk to you about what he does on a daily basis and/or what he would like to be doing, you may be able to get a sense of what he finds difficult and find some resources to help.I might ask things like this (just as examples):Can we talk for a few minutes about some things that I would like to learn more about?I'm just looking to learn more about what has been happening for you recently and I'm not trying to make you do anything.I know you said you quit your job because you didn't like it.

title: How can I help my son succeed in life when he refuses it?
author: listener
text: Could you tell me more about what you liked and what you didn't like?Do you see yourself doing the same kind of job in the future?What is it that makes you happy or what is it that you look forward to doing?Can you think of anything that I can do to be of support to you?If he is interested, you may be able to connect him with an area community college to learn more about possible job opportunities.With the way that I wrote the questions above, it probably sounds like it's relatively easy.
