text: As a parent, we want to force them to do what we think is "the right thing" but trying to do that only results in frustrations for everyone involved.

title: I don't know how to communicate with my adult daughter
author: listener
text: Whether the issue is a hair color, a tattoo, a lifestyle choice, a job, or choosing not to work or take care of their health, or doing drugs, or drinking - the choice is theirs and theirs alone and so are the consequences of those choices.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: speaker
text: My son stole my debit card and lied about it. It's not the first time he has lied. I don't know what to do anymore. I don't know if I should punish him or make him do something. I've tried talking to him and asking if anything was wrong. I have grounded him, but nothing works. What should I do?

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: A lot depends on the age of your child, but given that it was a mis-used debit card, I am going to guess he's a teen?

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Assuming that, there are a couple of important things to keep in mind...1.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: That he lied about the misuse indicates he knows he was in the wrong.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: That's a dreadful feeling - getting caught out- and an impulsive lie may have popped out of his mouth before he thought it through (after all a debit spend is pretty easy to track).

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Once he lied he stuck with the lie.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Somewhere along the line, even though he knew that you knew he wasn't telling the truth, he stuck with his story.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: And as you said, it's not the first time he lied.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Now it looks like a habit has formed.Going forward, when there is a dishonest act of any kind, it's essential that you set it up so your son can be truthful.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Simply put, do not ask questions.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: If you know for certain that he has, for example, misused your debit card, say so.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Asking "did you" invites him to get creative with denial; asking "why did you" implies that, with a good enough reason, he might not be in hot water with you.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Instead, say what is:  "I see this charge on my debit card and realize you used it without my permission".

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: (You can only do this if you know for sure it was him but it sounds like you do).

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: If he meets with denial, stay calm, restate that you are aware this happened.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Then deliver consequences that match the transgression (he has to return the item if it's returnable or find a way to pay you back for the charge as well as any fees incurred in using it).

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Make it harder to find your card because he isn't that great at curbing the impulse to use it yet.And most importantly, once the consequence is delivered you have to let it go.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Continuing to bring it up won't benefit him, but it does have the potential to make him more sneaky.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: Every time he asks respectfully to use it, whether you allow him to or not, be sure to praise him for asking nicely.

title: I don't know what to do about my son's lying
author: listener
text: "Catch" him doing it right as often as possible.Hang in there - this isn't super unusual behavior but it isn't acceptable, so address it but don't let yourself get too wound up about it.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: speaker
text: I'm concerned about My 12 year old daughter.    About a month or two ago she started walking on her toes, as well as coloring and writing very messy. This all happened very suddenly. She has never walked on her tiptoes and has always colored and written very neatly.    Is this something I should be concerned abou? Any advice will help.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: listener
text: It is great that you are noticing these changes with your daughter.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: listener
text: I can’t offer advice without knowing much more about your particular situation but some things to think about:Has something else happen recently that has been stressful, upsetting?Is your daughter trying to communicate something to you and if so what might that be?Have you discussed these recent changes with her?

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: listener
text: (Without being too serious or accusatory)There is so much changing for her (and you) now-communication and connection are crucial.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: listener
text: I hope you both can talk to a supportive person about all these changes.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: speaker
text: I'm concerned about My 12 year old daughter.    About a month or two ago she started walking on her toes, as well as coloring and writing very messy. This all happened very suddenly. She has never walked on her tiptoes and has always colored and written very neatly.    Is this something I should be concerned abou? Any advice will help.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: listener
text: Have you asked your daughter why she's doing the behaviors you describe?Often the best way to find out why someone does something is to simply ask them their reason.Her answer will give you some guidance as to next possible steps.If she's pretending to be a fantasy figure or trying to find out how being taller feels, or walking on high heels or some other image then knowing this rules out that she has some unbearable pain in her arch which may require more practical answers such as new shoes or even indicate a medical problem.Ask if she's noticed any change in the way she walks.

title: I'm concerned about my 12 year old daughter
author: listener
text: Maybe she doesn't know she's doing this and maybe she feels embarrassed to tell you she's doing something a bit odd.Since usually 12 year olds don't color, is it new that she started coloring?Maybe given the fact of messy handwriting, she's in a phase of pretending or reflecting on good times as a young child.Then this becomes the topic of examination.Does she feel insecure about being on the cusp of adolescence?Some of these questions can be asked directly and some are for you to first decide based on what you know of your daughter, which questions and what direction to take in understanding your daughter's motivation.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: speaker
text: I have three children. The oldest is nine and not my biological child. The middle child is three and the youngest is one. I have a great relationship with the oldest two children but I haven't developed the same level of attatchment to the youngest child. I rarely want her around and look forward to her nap times. Is this normal?

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: This is a common response parents can have.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: There are many reasons for attachment disruption.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: But attachment is  important for the child as well as your long term relationship with them.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: I would want to know more about the history of the child and any stressors you have gone through during the child's lifetime.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: Often if there is stress parents will not have the time or energy to attach well to the child.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: Sometimes the energy of the child and the parent are mismatched as well.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: But whatever is at the core this is something that can be addressed in counseling.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: The earlier the better because adult relationships are based on parental relationships we had as children.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener
text: Therapy can start at age 3 to address these types of issues.

title: Is it normal to dislike one child?
author: listener

title: Is it ok ayto talk with my grown children about spending time with their children?
author: speaker
text: I was a single mom most of their growing up life and have guilt about trying to work three jobs and being gone a lot. My children are successful with their own business's, have lots of nanny and cleaning help, but I just feel they have such a great opportunity to spend it with their kids.

title: Is it ok ayto talk with my grown children about spending time with their children?
author: listener
text: You seem to have been a very positive influence in your kids' lives.They may have worked so hard because they understood how difficult and tiring your life was as a single mom.I feel you are seeing your kids' lives through the measurement of how much toil was in your life as a single mom.In other words, what you see your kids overlooking or not appreciating, may remind you of your wishes during the many years you raised your kids.If it helps you and is possible, then maybe you could spend more of your own time tougher with your grandkids.

title: Is it ok ayto talk with my grown children about spending time with their children?
author: listener
text: This may give some reward for the many years you spent working to support your kids and had no choice in the amount of time you had with your kids.As far as your kids relationship to their kids, it is now their turn to raise them as they wish, within ethical boundaries of course.Depending on the topics you and your kids talk about, consider to bring up your concern as to whether they feel their kids, your grandkids, are missing anything due to the limited time they have with the parents.

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?
author: speaker
text: My dad is always, and I mean always, cussing and screaming at me for no reason at all. He makes me feel stupid. He also compares me to my other siblings in a negative way and demeans me. Is this abuse?

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?
author: listener
text: Oh my goodness, my heart goes out to you!!

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?
author: listener

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?
author: listener
text: Healthy Place offers us some great examples of emotional abuse which certainly fit the criteria of what you describe:Yelling or swearing Name calling or insults; mocking.Threats and intimidation.Ignoring or excluding.Isolating.Humiliating.Denial of the abuse and blaming of the victim.And abuse survivor and author, Kellie Jo Holly, offers some other great examples of verbal abuse:Emotionally Abusive StatementsYou’re so cute when you try to concentrate!

text: Look at you trying to think.I can’t believe I love a stupid jerk.Aw, come on, can’t you take a joke?Sexually Abusive StatementsYou should know how to please me by now.I hoped you were less experienced.Stop acting like a whore.Financially Abusive StatementsYou are going to nickel and dime me to death!In what world does buying that make sense?Fine.

title: Is screaming and cussing at your child considered emotional abuse?

text: You handle your finances.

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: speaker
text:
My daughter was overly tired and throwing a fit at her grandparent's house. She wanted to come home at midnight and cried screamed said she said she hated her grandma and that she wanted to kill herself!
    We also have a new baby in the house i didn't know if this would contribute to this. How should I approach this?

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: You wrote a very full family context w many directions to examine.Do you know or can you find out what the grandma and your daughter were doing in the evening of the screaming episode?Is it possible the grandma abuses your daughter, or tells her scary stories, watches scary movies.

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: These are only suggestions of some problem between grandma and your daughter.Also, ask your daughter directly why she wants to kill herself and what' killing herself" means.

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: Seven year olds don't have a concept of death being a forever condition.

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: Seven year olds don't have a sense of future meaning besides liking/disliking them.

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: Maybe the new baby is a factor.

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: Do you feel this is a factor?

title: What do I do if my 7 year old says she want to kill herself?
author: listener
text: Trust your intuition to tell you if your daughter is resentful of your new baby.Even if she is, I doubt a seven year old has the capacity to connect current unhappiness with the intention of a future action, including suicide.

title: What are the long term effects of losing one's adopted mother?
author: speaker
text: The birth mother attempted suicide several times while pregnant. The adopted mother was terminally ill upon adopting the baby and died when the child was just over one year old. The adopted father then remarried to a physically, psychologically, and emotionally abusive woman. The child was placed in foster care at 11 years old.    What might be the long term effects on an adult with this childhood history?

title: What are the long term effects of losing one's adopted mother?
author: listener
text: The true answer is, "no one can really say with certainty".The variables are the way this child absorbs and adjusts to these significant changes in their life.

title: What are the long term effects of losing one's adopted mother?
author: listener
text: All anyone can do is guess at this point and there's no good reason to guess.The only general certainty is that the adult whom this child becomes will have had a profound encounter with the biggest types of human losses a child can go through.Some people become great teachers, therapists and philosophers who have this background.

title: What are the long term effects of losing one's adopted mother?
author: listener
text: Some give up on life and hide away from others.The best anyone could do who knows this child is to offer love bc this is the greatest guarantee to show there are good people on this earth.

author: listener
text: The second thing is to keep in mind that their controlling behavior is most likely not about based your behavior.

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: listener
text: Controlling parents are often driven by their concept of what will keep their children safe and happy.

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: listener
text: Unfortunately this is not always accurate but keep in mind it is not a personal attack.

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: listener
text: There are ways you can deal with controlling parents – and most of them require creating a plan of action.Examples of action plans:Decide in advance how you’ll calmly and rationally respond to your parents when you feel they’re trying to control youArrange to phone a friend or trusted adult when you feel like you’re losing controlTalk in person to an adult you trust.

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: listener
text: There aren’t any quick tips on how to deal with parents who want to control you; you need to find strategies that are geared to your specific family situation.

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: listener
text: Get specific coping tips from books about family dynamics, such as:Toxic Parents: Overcoming Their Hurtful Legacy and Reclaiming Your Life by Susan ForwardCutting Loose: An Adult's Guide to Coming to Terms with Your Parents by Howard HalpernA counselor can be a good resource and provide support and guidance about issues addressing normal growth and development during periods of transition.

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: speaker
text:
I am in my early 20s and I still live with my parents because I can't afford to live alone.
   My mother says that if I live under her roof I have to follow her rules. She is trying to control my life. What should I do?

title: My mother is trying to control my life and I don't know what to do
author: listener
text: You're among many millennials who live with their parents due to financial reasons.Does your mother mean rules pertaining to the way your family household organizes its daily or does she mean something else?Every household needs rules as responsibilities to keep the house clean, who does the grocery shopping, the way costs are distributed for this and all the other carrying charges  and tasks of maintaining the house in decent order, as well as respecting the privacy and noise level requests of others who live in the home.This set of responsibilities applies whenever more than one person lives with another person.Have you tried simply telling your mom that you're willing to be a responsible household member and that you prefer to keep the details of the way you live the rest of your life, to yourself?This would show respect to your mom and start the discussion as to the areas of your life you feel deserve privacy and how you would like to handle when your right to run your own life overlaps with any household duties.

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: speaker
text: I want to live with my mom. My dad gets angry and makes me feel like everything is my fault. I still talk to my mom although My dad tells me that I'm no allowed to. I'm scared I will make the wrong decision and that my dad will hate me.    How do I tell him that I want to live with my mom?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: Yes, from what you wrote, your dad doesn't accept responsibility for the way he feels and blames you for his feelings.I'm glad you recognize he's handling himself less as a grown person and more like a young child.I also understand your hurt and frustration that your father handles himself in a way which shows for now that he is unwilling to respect your wishes.Your decision is not surprising since most people wouldn't want to live with a parent who shows little interest to respect their kids' decisions.In terms of how to tell him your choice, do this in simple and most basic information terms.

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: "I've decided for now to live w mom".I suggest to not offer reasons to him bc he doesn't seem interested in hearing them.

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: Giving him reasons would likely trigger him to rebut them.If he asks questions, answer them as simply as possible.If and when you feel he is more willing to understand and know you, then you'd feel more free to have genuine dialogue with him.Right now he doesn't seem very ready to handle this.

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: speaker
text: I want to live with my mom. My dad gets angry and makes me feel like everything is my fault. I still talk to my mom although My dad tells me that I'm no allowed to. I'm scared I will make the wrong decision and that my dad will hate me.    How do I tell him that I want to live with my mom?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: There is a lot of information that needs to be filled in first.

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: So what the custody arrangement?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: Does your dad have full custody?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: Is the custody shared?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: What does your mom think about the situation?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: Is she willing to go to bat for you?What is your age?

title: How do I tell one parent I want to live with the other one?
author: listener
text: Usually you have the right to choose based on age requirements set by the state.Legally you can't be kept away from your mom unless there is some legal complications that prevent it.Is your father abusive and should you seek protection?Many details need to be filled in.You can seek counseling without your parents approving or knowing, depending on your age.Find counseling through school or local agencies.You have rights and one of those is the right to choose.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: speaker
text: I told her that if daddy dies, we will never see him again. She started crying because I wouldn't make her daddy die.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: listener
text: Children often have a difficult time expressing emotions accurately.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: listener
text: It is also very likely that your daughter does not understand  the permanence of death.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: listener
text: Having said that, she is using some very specific ideas here and I would recommend contacting a local mental health professional with some experience working with children.I would also wonder where she is getting this idea.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: listener
text: Sometimes children hear things on TV or from an adult and we are not even aware of how much they are remembering.It may be helpful to teach her things that she can do when she is angry, like say that she is mad because she cannot have the toy that she is asking for.I'm curious as to how long it is that she stays mad like this and whether she talks to her dad after she is no longer angry.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: listener
text: Does she say the same sorts of things about you?It may also be helpful for you to work with a mental health professional (possibly the same one who is working with your daughter) so that you can have some support with this as well.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: speaker
text: I told her that if daddy dies, we will never see him again. She started crying because I wouldn't make her daddy die.

title: My toddler wants her daddy to die when she's mad at him
author: listener
text: Toddlers don't have the intellectual capacity to conceptualize.Better to find out why she wants daddy to die than explain the future consequences of death to your toddler.A person must be around 9, possibly 8 years old before absorbing the potential effects of an action taken in present time.Pretty much your toddler demonstrated to you here age appropriate and limited understanding of the loss of a parent, by crying that you weren't able to magically make her father disappear.Also, please pay attention and form your own opinions as to the reasons why your toddler would wish her father's death.She may be pointing out that the father behaves in frightening or harmful ways towards her.

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?
author: speaker
text: My husband’s ex-wife married a man who was charged with seven felony counts of pandering involving a minor. He, by his own admission, is addicted to child pornography. My step-daughters are now all teenagers. They do not know. My husband’s ex-wife has kept this information from my step-daughters. The step-father has had issues regarding his pornography addiction recently. The ex-wife minimizes it by saying that he has "repented." It is a constant strain on my husband, knowing that his girls are living with a man who is addicted to child pornography. My own therapist believes the girls should be told. The ex-wife says her therapist says the opposite.

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?
author: listener
text: If the daughters are old & mature enough to understand substance abuse.

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?
author: listener
text: They should be told for their own empowerment.

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?
author: listener
text: KNOWLEDGE is their power of safety and protection.

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?

title: Should my step-daughters be told that their step-father has a child pornography addiction?

title: My daughter won't stop stealing and lying
author: speaker
text: Her father and I have been dealing with this problem for quite some time now. She is an adolescent, and the problem is mostly food. She is now overweight, and we just don't know what to do anymore. She can be disrespectful and doesn't listen to or respect what we say.

title: My daughter won't stop stealing and lying
author: listener
text: I would be curious about there potentially being some emotional or physical trauma in your daughter's history that she is struggling with.

title: My daughter won't stop stealing and lying
author: listener
text: Physical trauma is usually easier to identify, but emotional trauma can be feeling a lack of emotional connection in her important relationships, having experienced bullying, or some other emotional injury.

title: My daughter won't stop stealing and lying
author: listener
text: The fact that there are some defiance symptoms going on suggests that she might be in need of a safe place to process what she's going through, and the potential issue with control or meeting emotional needs with food is also concerning.

title: My daughter won't stop stealing and lying
author: listener
text: I would recommend looking for a therapist/counselor who works with children/adolescents in the area of addressing trauma for an assessment.

title: My daughter won't stop stealing and lying
author: listener
text: They may be able to ask the right questions to see whether trauma is truly the issue.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: speaker
text: He is an adolescent. He has peed his pant multiple times over the last few years, all at times when he is too wrapped up in a video game or video. We have taken away games and videos for long periods of time as punishment, but after a few months of having then back, he pees his pants again.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: From a behavioral standpoint you should refrain from punishing your son.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: Instead of utilizing punishment when he wets himself provide contingencies prior to any accidents.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: Sit down with your son and discuss the importance of utilizing the bathroom and responsibilities and inform him that if he chooses to wet his pants that his video games will not be available for use for him the next day(or your designated realistic time frame).

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: This way if an accident occurs, no heated words have to be exchanged because you have already laid the ground work.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: Also allow him to clean up himself.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: Gather cleaning supplies and and oversee cleaning operations without ridicule or negative feedback.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: Since you have stated that you have an adolescent who is experiencing enuresis, you may want to check with your PCP and a licensed professional for underlying diagnosis that can be treated.

title: How should we punish our son for peeing his pants because of laziness?
author: listener
text: You can also call a local behavioral analyst.

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: speaker
text: Is this something I should be worried about? Should I do something about it?

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: I recommend asking your son about the reasons he chooses to play alone at recess.

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: If he is happy on his own and you know he has some friends, I would not be very concerned.

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: However, there may be bullying going on at school.

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: In the case of bullying, it may be a situation where you as his parent will need to step in.

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: speaker
text: Is this something I should be worried about? Should I do something about it?

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: Humans are social creatures so this can be an alarming thing for a parent to deal with, just like adults children are not the same and some children are more social than others, if he plays alone at recess (all the time) it would worry myself as well, however recess is only one domain of life, does he have friends outside of school or daycare?

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: Does he socialize in other situations or is it just at recess where this occurs?

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: If this is a global problem occurring at other social times it may be indicative of something deeper going on, if perhaps it is occurring "just during recess" it could be something else altogether.

title: My son plays alone at recess
author: listener
text: I would request reports from all teachers and caregivers concerning socialization and make a choice on whether or not to evaluate further.Hope this helps,C

title: How can I improve my relationship with my daughter?
author: speaker
text: Me and my adult daughter just do not get along. She's very belittling to me when I don't agree with her. It's almost like she scolds me. We get into all out war. She's said I don't support her in what she does and that I've never loved her. She calls me horrible names, and she pushes my buttons to the point I call her names.

title: How can I improve my relationship with my daughter?
author: listener
text: As frustrating and probably hurtful as your daughter's comments sound, there's also a message in them about how she genuinely feels.To some degree, your daughter and you may both feel similarly misunderstood by the other.Developing ways of listening and talking to one another to better understand how you each feel, would probably help a lot.One major point to be aware, is that the mother/daughter relationship dynamic, because it is strong, may slow the new dynamic of relating as two adults.Watch for your own tendency to expect your daughter to consider you as a parenting authority, instead of considering her as a grown person.The same is true of your daughter.

title: How can I improve my relationship with my daughter?
author: listener
text: She may need to remind herself to talk to you as the adult she is.Her needs from you are real, they just need to be spoken to you in an adult way.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: speaker
text: We are the legal guardianship of our grandson. He has been acting out, and he wants to talk to his mom that has not talked to him since before last year. How are we to handle this?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Hi Boone, This depends a lot on his age and the situation.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: The younger the child is, in general, the more I would see this as your decision, not his.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: A child of any age should be listened to carefully about these matters, but just because a child has unresolved issues about a parent doesn't necessarily mean that having contact is a good solution.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Some questions... Was the parent harmful to the child?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Is the parent likely to be harmful to the child?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: How likely is it to be a positive experience?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Do you have any contact with the parent?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: You may want to speak with the parent first to determine whether they are in a stable enough place to allow this to happen.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: I would start by asking the child more about what is on his mind.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: What does he want to get out of a visit with the parent?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Is it to see them and know the parent is okay, to get an apology, to apologize for a perceived hurt, to have regular contact, to find out if they are loved...?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: What does he hope mom or dad might do or say in the visit?

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: There are many possible goals this child might have in mind.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: This will give you a sense of what's missing for the child; what need are they trying to fill.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Once you know the need, try to determine the likelihood of that need being met successfully through contact.Once you determine the risk of the child's need not being met, then you decide whether it makes sense.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: The older the child, the more able they are to determine this with you or for themselves.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: There are other options than a face-to-face.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: He can write to his mom or dad, text or email.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: It's likely that the child is looking for a sense that he is loved, wanted, worth some effort.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: When a child is separated from a parent, they tend to blame themselves.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: Whether he sees the parent or not, he will need extra love, attention and support than a child who has two loving, present parents.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: I wish him the best and I'm grateful for the love and support you continue to give your grandson.

title: Our grandson wants to talk to his estranged mom
author: listener
text: You're very special!

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: speaker
text: I am divorced and happily remarried. Our blended family of children are in their 20s. My youngest, age 20, continues to call me crazy and favors her dad. He was abusive to me, and I left with injuries. He never wanted kids, and I did. He paid child support only through forced wage earners. Now my daughters favor him after all the sacrifices I made for them the past 15 years as a single mom. I don’t deny them a relationship with their dad, but to be called crazy and then watch them hang out with him hurts me to the very core. I’m not sure how to handle this.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Hi Arkansas, Your situation sounds like a case of parental alienation.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Your ex-partner unfortunately has the power to say things to your children that poison their relationship with you.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: It's a form of woman abuse and child abuse.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: He's likely doing this to hurt you and have power over you, and he's not considering how it's affecting the kids.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: I've seen this happen in many families; parents who once had a strong loving relationship with their children suddenly feel abandoned in favor of the other parent.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: In some cases, children actually stop having contact with one parent, who is left bewildered and powerless.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: It's your ex's job to support your relationship with your kids, not try to destroy it.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: While you can't change his behaviours, and I think you know that, there are things you can do for yourself and your kids.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: For your children, you can refuse to enter into the war he's setting up.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: He's trying to provoke you into acting "crazy", but you don't have to fall for this.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: If you run around screaming "he's lying!

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: ", it only makes you look more 'crazy'.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Try to stay calm, and don't put their dad down to them, no matter how tempting it is.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: One day, they may be ready to hear the truth of your relationship with their father, but wait until they ask.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Trust that they have their own experience of their dad, and trust that he doesn't have the power to destroy their love for you.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Children, in the long term, lose respect for parents who denigrate the other parent.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: They see who their dad is already, I'd bet, but they don't know how to cope with that.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: If he's the only one fighting a war, you're helping them feel less trapped in a parental conflict.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Don't engage on his level.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Don't blame your children completely.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Although I have to say that for them to call you names like crazy is not acceptable and you don't need to tolerate that disrespect, try to deal with this behaviour without bringing their dad into it.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: They are acting out their father's agenda, likely because they instinctively see his weakness.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Children often support the weaker parent, rather than abandon them.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: You get the worst because they trust your love.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: But you can still have boundaries.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Letting them abuse you isn't the answer, but have compassion for their position.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: This picture isn't their fault, but as adults, they can be held accountable for their choices.Reassure yourself that you are the mom you know you are.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: You don't need them to gush all over you in order to know that you made sacrifices.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Hold onto the likelihood that some day, they will come back and be grateful.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: It may take a while, you can't rush it, but they will see you for who you are.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Your power is in giving them a consistently calm, generous, connected, supportive mom who refuses to play games or be walked on.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: I'd recommend trying to connect with other parents who experience this phenomenon, or a therapist who can reinforce these goals and help keep you grounded.

title: My daughter calls me crazy, and I’m not sure how to handle that
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: speaker
text: We live with my ex-partner’s sister and her husband. We have been there for five years now. They are Hispanic and talk to my daughter in their language. Sometimes they overstep their balance between aunt and uncle and reach into my role as a parent. They neglect to see this. I do, and it reflects in my child's behavior. She sees them as stable but is upset that her dad isn't here, and my intuition tells me she blames me to a degree because she doesn't know about his alcohol addictions.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: Hi New York, I'm happy to hear that your daughter doesn't know about her dad's addictions.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: Although you don't say how old she is, and I imagine that at some point in her life she will be ready to know the truth, I trust your instinct that now is not the time.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: Your ability to have clear boundaries about what is adult conversation and what is suitable for a child to know are really important here, and I can tell you're being appropriately protective and a thoughtful parent.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: As much as this helps your daughter, I sense that you also know you can't take away the emotional pain that comes from having an absent parent.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: Children tend to blame themselves for a parent's absence.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: These children need extra love and support wherever they can get it.You say that you feel like there is a wedge between you and your daughter.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: I understand that having your ex partner's relatives in the same home would make it uncomfortable at times.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: It is very important to establish boundaries; only you should parent your daughter, but it's also natural for people to want to assist you.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: Let's trust that their intentions are good, if there is no evidence to the contrary.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: As much as they support you, they also  have emotional ties to your daughter's father.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: While there is potential for discomfort in this complex situation, there are also many positive factors here that I invite you to see.I don't know what your culture is, but for your daughter to have the opportunity to preserve her father's heritage language and a relationship with his family are potentially wonderful additions to her life.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: In general, the more adults around loving and supporting a child, the better.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: It could be that you are feeling threatened by small moments where there appears to be a special connection between your daughter and her father's family.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: Nothing anyone else does can take your daughter's love from you.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: My hope for you is that you can feel so secure in your own position as loving mother that you will not feel intimidated by other positive connections your daughter has.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: They are potentially wonderful connections, and she deserves your support in maintaining those relationships if they don't harm her.I suggest that the most important alliances to work on here are between you and your ex's family.

title: I feel like there is a wedge between my daughter and I
author: listener
text: If you could all give your daughter the gift of a healthy, united supportive and loving safety net for her...that's the best outcome of all.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: speaker
text: My daughter didn't see her biological father for the last three years. She doesn’t want to see him because she remember really bad things from him such as domestic violence and child abuse. The visitation is with supervision, but she refuses to see him. Is it better to take my daughter to the therapist and try to see him after the therapy?

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: Has the father or the visitation supervisor contacted you regarding why your daughter hasn't shown up for the past three years' worth of supervised visitation?Or is the supervised visitation a new development for the bio dad and your daughter?If no one is pressuring or expecting your daughter to show up, no one has even asked where she is, why she isn't present, then I don't see any reason for you to offer more effort by your daughter, than the father is willing to make for seeing her.If your daughter is willing to talk with a therapist, then let her find out first hand if the sessions seem useful or not.The one move I'd avoid is to force your daughter to go to a therapist since growing up in a household in which child abuse took place, being forced may remind her of her own feelings from this past, of feeling no one heard or cared about the way she wanted to be treated.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: speaker
text: My daughter didn't see her biological father for the last three years. She doesn’t want to see him because she remember really bad things from him such as domestic violence and child abuse. The visitation is with supervision, but she refuses to see him. Is it better to take my daughter to the therapist and try to see him after the therapy?

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: Hi Dillon,I'm from Canada, so I don't know the laws in your state.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: It depends on that a good deal, perhaps.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: In my opinion, a child should never be forced into a situation where they feel unsafe, even if it is "supervised".

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: If the child is old enough to make a strong statement about not wanting to see a parent, then this should be honoured.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, the laws don't always uphold a parent's right to do what is best for their child.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: I recommend you see a lawyer, who will advise you about how to proceed without putting yourself at risk of breaching custody agreements.If you feel your daughter can benefit from therapy, that is a separate question.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: Or is she already in therapy?

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: A family therapist will typically meet with you alone first, in order to determine if therapy is a wise move for your child.

title: Should I take my daughter to therapy?
author: listener
text: It isn't always appropriate.

title: I can't leave my negative environment without leaving behind my fiancé
author: speaker
text: My fiancé and I have been in a relationship for two years. We have an infant son. My fiancé also has a child from a previous relationship. We do not live together. I live with my mother currently while I get on my feet, and he's living with some friends. My mother and I have an awful relationship that is completely unbearable most of the time. We cannot even stand to be around one another while living in the same house. She has made it clear that she wants me gone. Recently, I was talking to my father who lives in a different state. My father and I have always had a good relationship. I explained to him the situation I am in with my mother, and he said he would like for me, my fiancé, and our son to come live with him and his wife. I would really love to go. I do not want my son to be in this environment with constant arguing and negativity any longer. There is nowhere else for me to stay while remaining in this state. The problem is my fiancé is refusing to move away with me because he does not want to leave behind his other child. He and his child's mother have a horrible relationship, and she would absolutely not be willing to let him visit if we moved away. I believe I would be doing what is best for my child by moving away, but I do not want to leave without my fiancé. I have already explained the situation to him, and he will not give in. Do I continue to stay in this negative environment with my child and keep our family together? Do I move away with my child and have my relationship end? I do not want to take him out of either of his kids’ lives. What do I do?

title: I can't leave my negative environment without leaving behind my fiancé
author: listener
text: Hi Bethlehem,You have a big decision to make.

title: I can't leave my negative environment without leaving behind my fiancé
author: listener
text: I appreciate your fiancé's need to stay close to his child and be a stand-up dad, and I am glad that you know your son needs an emotionally safe place.I'm a bit confused, because the obvious answer seems to be that you and your fiancé would get your own place together.

title: I can't leave my negative environment without leaving behind my fiancé
author: listener
text: I get that you want your dad to take care of all of you, but maybe it's time to take responsibility for your own future and start building it independently of either parent.

title: I can't leave my negative environment without leaving behind my fiancé
author: listener
text: I say that without knowing how old you are, but if you have a child and a two year relationship, you basically have declared your independence anyway.

title: I can't leave my negative environment without leaving behind my fiancé
author: listener
text: I wish you the best.

title: My child urinated in his mother's drink
author: speaker
text: Just wondering if this is a deviant act, and if I should be concerned for him. He isn’t quite 10.

title: My child urinated in his mother's drink
author: listener
text: Well it's certainly unusual, and potentially could be cause for alarm.

title: My child urinated in his mother's drink
author: listener
text: It's a passive aggressive act if done intentionally, so I would wonder if this child is trying to say something.I think without any context, however, or sense of whether there are other signs of disturbance, it's impossible to say what's going on.

title: My child urinated in his mother's drink
author: listener
text: If there are other signs of distress or very unusual behaviours, you might bring the child to someone who can assess him properly.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend has a child he gets every other weekend. He goes to see her twice a week or more. Every time she leaves, he gets into these funks like when his mom died. When she’s here, she’s disrespectful, and his answer is “Well, I don’t know what to tell you.” She swears and talks back, and he laughs. He and her mom have been apart for three years, and he blames her behavior on that and her being so young. We never have adult time when she’s not here. She’s the "golden child," and he won’t listen to anyone.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Hi Lockport, Building a relationship when there are already children involved is very tricky.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: You don't tell us whether you live together or not.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: If you do, your position is perhaps more difficult, because his daughter's behaviours affect you; you live in the home.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: A bottom line for me is you don't tell someone else how to parent.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: That's for your boyfriend to decide.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: When he's there, he's the parent, and he makes the decisions about how she is disciplined (or not).

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Even if you have good ideas or you completely disagree, or you think you see something that he's not seeing, it's simply not for you to interfere there.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: It sounds like your boyfriend is struggling emotionally and needs support.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: He has had a lot of losses in his life and maybe every time his daughter leaves he feels powerless and abandoned.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Do you talk about these things?

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Can you find that line of supporting him but not telling him what to do?Although I suggest you leave the parenting to him, what you can do is tell him what you see, offer suggestions if he's open to it, and talk about the ways in which the situation affects you.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: It makes sense to say "I see you struggling and I don't know how to help", "I've noticed that you seem afraid to discipline her.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Are you aware that it's coming across this way?

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Do you need help?

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: ", or "I feel sad and frustrated when we don't spend any time alone together."

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: You sound a bit resentful of his daughter.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Is it possible that your real struggle is about whether you're ready to be in a relationship with a man whose priority is his child?You have a voice, and it's great to offer support and ideas and let him know how you feel.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Ultimately, however, you are wise to accept this man as who he is and accept the situation for what it is, and make your own decision about whether you want to be a part of it.

title: Should I leave my boyfriend?
author: listener

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: speaker
text: For the last year, my adolescent son and daughter have been driving me nuts with fighting. I'm at my wits end. How can I get them to stop and get along?

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: That is a good question.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately there is no generic answer with this one.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: Kids fight for different reasons - wanting attention, wanting respect, feeling jealous, wanting space and to be left alone, or a whole bunch of other reasons.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: Regardless of the underlying motivations for fighting, most conflicts result from misunderstandings and assumptions about the motivations of others and one of the best ways to start figuring out what is going on is to sit them down and have some conversations with them.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: These conversations should be centred on getting a better understanding of why they are angry with each other and really understanding them.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: It is important that they each know that you are committed to understanding their experience rather than simply sitting them down and lecturing them about what they are doing wrong.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: The more they are able to understand each other and feel understood the more likely they will be cooperative and considerate of each other.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: One exercise for doing this that can be very helpful is "active listening" where one person speaks and the other person reflects back what they heard the other person say and then checks for understanding.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: This is hard to do but it often illuminates where the misunderstandings and assumptions are.

title: How can I help my kids get along?
author: listener
text: If this doesn't work it may be time to get a family therapist or counsellor involved who can help facilitate dialogue and resolve conflict.

title: My parents aren't letting my boyfriend and I talk or see each other while I'm pregnant
author: speaker
text:
I’m a senior high school student. I’m also five months pregnant. I got pregnant by my boyfriend of three years. My parents don’t want us to communicate with each other. He can’t even come to visit my gynecologist. My mom goes to attend all of my doctor’s appointments. She’s supportive of me. I wish, though, that my boyfriend was next to me and be able to see his daughter on a sonogram, at the very least. My family does not understand that he deserves that much. I cry all the time because I feel lost and hopeless.
 I need guidance and I believe that you can give it to me. Am I wrong for wanting him around? Are they right for keeping him away from the appointments and not letting us communicate with each other even though we are the parents? I do everything that they ask of me. I just want him to be around. When I ask my parents to let him be here, they call me a selfish person. Please help me.

title: My parents aren't letting my boyfriend and I talk or see each other while I'm pregnant
author: listener
text: You're not wrong for wanting to be with your boyfriend of three years who is also the biological father of your child.Do your parents object to you and your boyfriend continuing to see each other in person?

title: My parents aren't letting my boyfriend and I talk or see each other while I'm pregnant
author: listener
text: Or, do they object only to electronic communication and don't want him involved in his child's life?

title: My parents aren't letting my boyfriend and I talk or see each other while I'm pregnant
author: listener
text: Ask your parents what their reason is for forbidding you to communicate with your boyfriend.

title: My parents aren't letting my boyfriend and I talk or see each other while I'm pregnant
author: listener
text: Ask them also to understand your point of view.Now is also a good time for you and your boyfriend to plan whether and where you will live as a family and how to financially and emotionally support one another once your baby is born.Your mom and dad are definitely making fatherhood difficult for your boyfriend and motherhood stressful for you.Consider bringing up the topic during your next obgyn visit.

title: My parents aren't letting my boyfriend and I talk or see each other while I'm pregnant
author: listener
text: Your doctor may ask your mom to explain her reasons and address these.Look online for women's resources to see if there are clinics or agencies that would help you advocate for your position in this matter.Good luck with the remainder of your pregnancy, labor and delivery!

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: speaker
text: What makes my step child, an 8 year old boy, choke my daughter, a 6 year old girl? This has been going on for 4 years. The boy tells my daughter not to tell on him. He knows it's wrong; we have did time out, spanking, taking away toys, and sitting on the wall. I am afraid for my daughters safety!

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: I can see why you are alarmed.

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: That is a scary situation for a parent.

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: Do you know if the child has been evaluated by a mental health professional?

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: Early treatment is often the key.

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: A professional will be able to help the child learn how to control their anger and mend the troublesome actions into more appropriate responses.

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: Have you addressed your concerns with the child's other parent?

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: There could be contributing factors in his life that could be causing these issues (exposure to violence, sexual/physical abuse, drug use, stressful events in his life, etc.).

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: It is important that these factors are identified so that they can either be eliminated and/or reduced.

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: I wouldn't hesitate to have him evaluated (if he hasn't been already) and to ensure that he is getting the help that he needs whether it be medication and/or therapy.

title: How do I stop my step child from hurting my biological child?
author: listener
text: Until then, I would make sure that he is always supervised under an adult's care.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: speaker
text: My grandma had a stroke and passed away recently. I lost my home and job. I'm looking but haven't found a job. I've been binge watching television and binge eating.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Wow, you got hit with some serious stuff all at once.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Work, relationships, and housing/security are major needs for us and to lose all that at once has got to affect you.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: When things go wrong, it is natural for us to look for blame----and the easiest person for us to blame is ourselves.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Put that with grief and you've got a recipe for feeling awful.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: We can start feeling so low as to want to check out with things like food, and TV as you described.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: It can take time for us to move to self-forgiveness, and self-kindness in order to start moving forward again.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: I wonder what you can do right now to improve your situation?

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: I also wonder if you may be willing to seek counseling to help you work through some of this, to help with your perspective, and to assist in your grieving process.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Just reading these 3 sentences, I get the sense of you being a nice person.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: I hope you can show that kind of kindness to yourself in your healing.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: speaker
text: My grandma had a stroke and passed away recently. I lost my home and job. I'm looking but haven't found a job. I've been binge watching television and binge eating.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Please practice being kind to yourself!!

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: You lost your grandmother, your home and your job!

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Huge changes have just taken place and it would be challenging for anyone to be unfazed.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: And having said that, you wrote that you have been looking for a job, so that tells me that you have most definitely not failed yourself.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Try taking it one day at a time.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: I encourage you to recognize (and even accept) that you're going through a particularly difficult time and that everything is temporary.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: When we are in something, it's difficult sometimes to see the light at the end of the tunnel.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Maybe you could allow yourself the grief that you are feeling, be in the tunnel, and trust that you will come through the tunnel to the other side.

title: I feel like I failed myself
author: listener
text: Be gentle and loving to yourself.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: speaker
text: I feel like I hate myself physically and emotionally sometimes. How can I start accepting myself and be more confident?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: You've already taken the first step.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: You want to not hate yourself.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Self-acceptance is hard!

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: And it's on a spectrum.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: On one side we have self-hate, on the other extreme; self-love.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: And then, there is all this stuff in the middle.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: It kind of looks like thisAnd working toward self-love often means moving around through all these.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Becoming aware of your emotions, exploring the parts of you you that easier and harder to accept, self-kindness, self-forgiveness, self-compassion and ultimately self-love.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: It is a recovery process and has to be an active thing each day.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Meeting with a counselor can give you a partner in that process.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Your counselor can also help you to recognize pieces that may be more difficult to see from your eyes as they have an outside view.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: And with self-acceptance, confidence comes naturally although you may need to practice behaviors that show assertiveness, confidence and boundaries that protect you.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Wishing you the absolute best with this!

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: speaker
text: I feel like I hate myself physically and emotionally sometimes. How can I start accepting myself and be more confident?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Self-doubt and self-hatred are such common and unpleasant experiences and really worth  understanding!

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Therapy with the right person can really help.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: When in your life do you feel the most confident?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: What gets in the way of you accepting and loving yourself (big question!).

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: You can and will uncover that confident self!

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: speaker
text: I feel like I hate myself physically and emotionally sometimes. How can I start accepting myself and be more confident?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Self love and self acceptance is something that many of my clients struggle with, so I can assure you that you are not alone.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: We are bombarded by media and advertisements everyday that try to sell us things to make us somehow better, thus leading us to believe that we are not enough.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, I believe that low self esteem is a social epidemic.On a more personal level, do you have any sense of what types of messages you have received in your life that have led to these self defeating thoughts?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: For example, did a parent or another loved one criticize you or put you down often?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Were you bulled in school?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Has a romantic partner emotionally abused you?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Usually, there are factors such as these which insidiously lead to low self esteem and self loathing.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Once you can identify some of the factors that lead to your self hatred, you can make a decision to not let these things from your past have such power over you any more.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: You learn to take control of how you feel about yourself, rather than letting others dictate that for you.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: I do think it is possible to heal from self hatred.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: It doesn't happen over night, and it takes time and effort.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: It is about re-training your brain to focus on your strengths rather than on your weaknesses.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: None of us are ever going to be perfect, and if we look for a flaw we are bound to find one (or two, or three...).

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Try keeping a self esteem journal.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Every night, write down three things that you were proud of that day about yourself.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Try reciting positive affirmations every day (such as "I am lovable and beautiful just the way that I am today"), to re-program your mind into thinking highly of yourself, rather than poorly.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: speaker
text: I feel like I hate myself physically and emotionally sometimes. How can I start accepting myself and be more confident?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: The most important word here is "sometimes."

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: I know it is quite painful, and I can imagine that at times this pain doesn't feel like it will subside.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: But it sounds like it is not all the time, which means we can easily say that this "hate myself" experience is one part of you.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: There are many other parts, if you give them some space to also "speak up," that will offer you more positive regard, trust me on that.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Generally speaking, we just don't know how to listen to those parts, because......it is the "I hate myself" part that is our inner critic.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: And often, our inner critic has developed a lot of strength throughout our life because of how we've depended on it for certain things.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: Sounds crazy, but in actuality, some of the most "successful" people, in work mainly, are those that have strong inner critics.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: They use these critics to motivate themselves, but with people, and in relationships, and in our relationship with ourselves, it completely backfires, because relationships are far more dynamic processes than "doing well at work.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: "So, try to acknowledge that the inner critic is one part of you, that you've learned to give a lot of space to.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener
text: But, if you sit with even a remotely positive feeling you have, it can also be given the space to speak up and grow, just like the critic has over time.

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: speaker
text: I feel like I hate myself physically and emotionally sometimes. How can I start accepting myself and be more confident?

title: I Sometimes I feel like I hate myself
author: listener

title: How do I handle being wanted in a relationship when I'm used to feeling unwanted?
author: speaker
text: I've always thought that there wasn't much good out there for me. Now that things are actually going well, it kind of scares me. I spent most of my life feeling unwanted and figured I would be alone. I recently met a great woman who seems to really like me, and I don't know how to process this. It's bothering both of us.

title: How do I handle being wanted in a relationship when I'm used to feeling unwanted?
