title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: speaker
text: I'm a male in my 20s. My girlfriend is in her late 30s. She's great. She's funny and smart, she has a big heart, and we have an excellent sex life. She recently moved in with me partially because she wanted to and partially because she had no place to go. We fight a lot. It’s mostly my fault, I must admit. She doesn't like my insecurity and lack of trust I have for her. I have trust issues. Also, I can't fathom why a woman like her is with me, so I'm always dreading when a better dude will come along. I don't think she's happy. She's very submissive and she loves me very much, but also the fact that she has nowhere to go must be influencing her decision to stay. I love her so much, but my jealousy is not likely to diminish. I never believed in the whole "If you love them, let them go," but I do now. I really want her to be happy. Should I end it with her? She has no place to go so I feel like I can’t break up with her. I’m literally trapped.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: listener
text: It sounds like there are assumptions being made regarding how she feels about you and why she is with you.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: listener
text: I would not suggest breaking up with her without first attempting to resolve your own issues.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: listener
text: You may not only regret your decision, but might find that the exact same problem arises in future relationships.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: listener
text: I would recommend seeing a therapist who can help you figure out what is at the root of all of this.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: listener
text: By learning about your own insecurities and where they come from, you can expect to discover new ways of responding and relating to others, which will likely impact your relationship in a positive manner.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?

I don't think she's happy. She's very submissive and she loves me very much, but also the fact that she has nowhere to go must be influencing her decision to stay. I love her so much, but my jealousy is not likely to diminish. I never believed in the whole "If you love them, let them go," but I do now. I really want her to be happy. Should I end it with her? She has no place to go so I feel like I can’t break up with her. I’m literally trapped.

title: Should I break up with my live-in girlfriend?
author: listener
text: Are you possibly mixing up an impulse to nurture and protect someone, such as by offering housing, and your own need to feel loved and appreciated as a romantic partner?Maybe your feeling of jealousy is really your awareness of a reasonable need to be loved by a partner.Even though you are quite detailed in your description of your partner, one piece which is missing, is whether you feel you are loved by her.Maybe too, what she considers your insecurity, is really her unwillgness to love you.It's always easier to put distance between two people by insulting them.I hope this gives you a few new ways to look at your situation.A few therapy sessions, either by yourself or together w your gf, would give you more chance to know more deeply what it is you are facing.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: speaker
text: I feel as though I'm suffering severe abandonment issues stemming from childhood. I convince myself I'm not worthy of happiness, and I’m always afraid I'm doing something wrong. It's as if I create little scenarios in my mind, and I start to believe them.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: This is an understandable response to early childhood trauma and loss.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: Oftentimes when we have overwhelming or difficult experiences as a child including poor caregiving, the ways we managed and the feelings we had then show up in our lives as adults.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: Especially when we get close to someone, it mirrors our early experiences with caregivers in early life.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: So....our body, nervous system, and emotions respond in the same way.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: They feel as if what we experienced when we were little is happening now and they go into full force to manage and protect us.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: Sometimes the ways that happens can feel pretty bad and we can stuck in these loops of old beliefs about ourselves.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues
author: listener
text: Therapy is a great way to interrupt these patterns, process the early experiences, and be able to be in the present with your current relationships.

title: My relationship is suffering from severe abandonment issues

text: It is very possible to shift this cycle and also have meaningful healing from the experiences that caused so much hurt and distress from childhood.

title: How do I save my marriage?
author: speaker
text: What am I doing wrong? My wife and I are fighting all the time. What can I do? We don't agree on anything and she usually jumps to conclusions, which are usually wrong on how I feel. She is very family-oriented while all of my family left me on my butt, abused, ignored and messed up with me mentally. I'm not a family-oriented person. I only have two people in my life - my best friend and my wife.    My mother forced my father out of my life so I do not know who he really is. We've gotten in contact but he just makes comments on how much I look like her when in fact I look more like him. This makes me mad because I don't want to look like my mother. I hate her. All that she did was bring me down and make me homeless, which she was successful at. I need guidance in my life. I don't want to lose my wife but we need to have a space because we usually hit each other and it's not healthy. I'm dying to make our relationship healthy. I've never wanted anything more than this. Please help me. I need your advice.

title: How do I save my marriage?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: How do I save my marriage?
author: listener
text: It sounds to me like you are carrying an enormous amount of emotional weight, and maybe even an equally enormous amount of guilt and feelings of failure about your marriage.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: speaker
text: I am becoming a Water Safety Instructor but I didn't have enough for a proper swimsuit. I was told by a boy in class that my top was displaying everything. I was very embarrassed.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: First I think we have to acknowledge that you are doing something amazing.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: You are putting yourself out there and becoming a Water Safety Instructor.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: We often times will focus on the negative and forget about the positive.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?

text: Next, you had an incident where someone pointed something out which may have caused embarrassment.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: Whether or not it was malicious on his part I think the important thing to focus on is what is called "Common Humanity".

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: Common Humanity is one of the three elements of self-compassion.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: Common humanity essentially recognizes that suffering and personal inadequacy is part of the shared human experience.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: While you may have had this embarrassing moment at this time, that boy may have had an embarrassing moment another day.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: We all have embarrassing moments.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?
author: listener
text: When we recognize that we do not suffer in isolation then we are able to move past that suffering.

title: How do you overcome an embarrassing mistake and forgive yourself?

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: speaker
text: I always feel the need to impress people, whether it's my family, the people at school, or just random people. I know that no matter what I do or how I change, there will always be some people who hate me. Why do I feel this way?

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: listener
text: It is normal to seek other’s attention and noticing that some people would not be interested.

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: listener
text: After all, we belong to a social environment where we constantly receive other’s feedback, which at times validates us, makes feel important and useful, like we belong; but also at times makes us feel isolated, different and neglected, which we could interpret as hate.The key is to be aware of what you think about what people think of you.

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: listener
text: Got it?

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: listener
text: This part can be tricky at times, because, what others think about us does not really affect us, what really affects us is what we decide to believe, internalize, and make our reality.

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: listener
text: For example, I could choose to ignore a person’s comment about me, or I could decide to focus on it all day, analyze why they said that and what have I done to them to get to that conclusion.

title: How can I care less about what people think?

title: How can I care less about what people think?
author: listener
text: It is also helpful to talk to your counselor about how you process feedback and validation so you learn to balance your positive traits from negatives and how that affects your relationships and self-esteem.¿Cómo me puede importar menos lo que la gente piensa?Siempre siento la necesidad de impresionar a otros, ya sea mi familia, la gente de la escuela o extraños.

title: How can I care less about what people think?

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: speaker

author: listener

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, it is unlikely that we can give you some words of wisdom that will make it all go away.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: However, I will give you some ideas and hopefully this will help.One of the things that we know about guilt is that it doesn't usually do much to help us in the long-run.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: People may make changes for a short-term period of time because they feel guilty about something they did, but usually they will go back to their old behaviors if they don't have something else to help them change permanently, such as a new skill.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: So, guilt doesn't necessarily help us.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: In fact, as I write this someone out there is eating an entire key lime pie because they feel guilty about falling off their diet.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Someone may be drinking alcohol because they feel guilty about drinking alcohol.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: For whatever reason, this is just a common thing that we do.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Now accountability is different than guilt.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Accountability can actually be constructive.

title: How can I forgive myself?

text: When you hold yourself accountable you can admit that you have done something wrong.

title: How can I forgive myself?

text: That it hurt others and you deeply regret it.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: That you are prepared to take steps to make sure it doesn't happen again.

title: How can I forgive myself?

text: That you have done what you can to make amends, if necessary.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: That you are sorry.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: And then you move on.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Well, for one thing, it doesn't usually help the people who you hurt.

title: How can I forgive myself?
author: listener
text: In fact, someone's guilty behavior may serve to remind the people who were hurt, over and over again, about what happened.

title: How can I forgive myself?

title: How can I forgive myself?

text: Also, guilt can lead us to behave in ways that may even hurt people more.

title: How can I forgive myself?

I teach this important bit of wisdom to my clients when they need to apologize

title: How can I forgive myself?

responsibility (no excuses, no explanation, no defensiveness: “It was all my
fault.”)Step
Three: Ask what you can do to repair the damage.Step Three is the one many of us didn’t learn growing up.

title: Why do I feel like everyone hates me?
author: speaker
text: I constantly feel like everyone is up against me and trying their best to shut me down. It's ruining my mood and even my whole self. I have trouble sleeping, and I keep having sleep paralysis while dreaming of others mocking and judging me.

title: Why do I feel like everyone hates me?
author: listener
text: The problem you describe sounds very wearing on your spirit.Are there particular reasons for why you feel everyone hates you?Have you been in a clash of ideas or opinions and feel yourself in the minority viewpoint?Or does your sense of being shut out start within your own mind, as though you anticipate that others will not like what you say?If actual conversations are leading you to feel left out, then evaluate whether to bring up certain points to the other person.Or, you may also decide that the relationships in which you feel shut out, are no longer worthwhile ones for you.If the problem is hesitating to interact because you imagine others will reject you, then maybe you can coach yourself into trying a small step toward introducing yourself and your thoughts to others.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: speaker
text: I feel like I'm trying to convince myself that I'm okay when I'm not. I'm always blocking out the bad things and forgetting. I also feel like nobody cares for me and they never will. I feel truly alone.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: listener
text: I'm glad you're aware of how you honestly feel.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: listener
text: Knowing one's personal truth is always the first step in finding what is necessary to be and develop.Reflect a little more on the type of care you'd like in your life.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: listener
text: "Care" means anything from checking in on someone to deep, intimate connection between two people.Knowing your own definition of "care" is the first step to know what is necessary for you to recognize what you'd like attracting.It is much easier to attract what we'd like if we are clear on what this is.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: speaker
text: I feel like I'm trying to convince myself that I'm okay when I'm not. I'm always blocking out the bad things and forgetting. I also feel like nobody cares for me and they never will. I feel truly alone.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?

text: As social creatures, we humans all long for deep human connection.

text: To know that we belong and are part of something larger.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: listener
text: You are not alone in feeling alone.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: listener
text: While it can take time to build deep relationships there are moments in each day where we have the opportunity to interact with other people who may also feel lonely and scared and want to be seen and acknowledged.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?

text: I wonder what it might be like for you if you took on an experiment of trying to really see the people around you and make little attempts to acknowledge and connect with them - fellow humans on this journey of life.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?

text: A "good morning" at the bus stop or really looking at the person who you buy your groceries from or thanking or complimenting someone for something that you notice and appreciate.

title: Am I going to be alone forever?
author: listener
text: While this is not a substitute for close relationships these moments of real connection with the people who we share our communities with can go a long way to realizing that we are not as alone as we may have thought.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: speaker
text: I have been in a relationship with my boyfriend for about six years now. In the past, our relationship was difficult and frustrating. We argued a lot, and due to that, there was a lot of tension between us. We stayed together because we love each other and wanted to make it work. I used to party a lot, and several times I got into situations where I would end up kissing someone else. These situations were never more than just kissing. I have come clean about these situations with my boyfriend, and he decided to forgive and move forward with me. I love him so much and want to work things out too, but I'm having a difficult time understanding how he can forgive me. I can't seem to forgive myself. I'm overwhelmed with feelings of guilt and unworthiness.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: So wonderful to have a boyfriend who is able to understand and forgive you.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Does he see someone who like other humans makes mistakes?

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Does he see someone who despite hurtful choices is a good person committed to being a loving respectful partner?

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: The compassion and understanding that we can often extend to others can be difficult to extend to ourselves.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: We often hold very unrealistic and perfectionist expectations for ourselves which may even lead to our poor choices in the first place - as a ways of letting off steam or rebelling against our high standards.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Regardless of the reasons, we all make mistakes and imperfection does not make someone less loveable - it just makes them human.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: If your boyfriend is able to start clean with you, there must be a reason.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Can you help him to feel loved and safe in the relationship?

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener
text: Can you allow yourself to be imperfect and afraid and still worthy of love and acceptance.

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener

title: How can my boyfriend forgive me when I can't forgive myself?
author: listener

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my late 20s, and I've never had a boyfriend or even been on a date. I have no friends. I hate Facebook because everyone else has kids and a great husband and great paying jobs. I work in retail, and I can't find a job. I have an Associate degree. No one is not giving me a chance, and I'm getting upset and frustrated. I feel worthless and feel like everyone hates me. I feel like a failure, and I still live with my Dad. It's very embarrassing!

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: In case knowing this helps you, there are many more people in similar circumstance as you than you may realize.Similar to you, they are not on FB for the reasons you list.

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: Plus, no one wants to go on FB and tell the world they don't have a fantastic life.

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: Everyone on FB is happy, even when they're miserable they're happy telling everyone about it.First, yes it is painful to see all around you what appears as joyful living.

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: Please keep in mind that the life you imagine these people have, is not necessarily the true life they are having.

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: I've been a therapist for a long time and have seen repeatedly how people who are married with kids by age 30, start having problems by their mid-thirties.Second, respect your unique identity.

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: For whatever reason, you have more sensitivity, possibly more depth, more complex standards and expectations, of yourself and others.As hard as it may sound or actually be, take time to hear your intuition and what it tells you, you need for your own growth and development.Feeling embarrassed can also be turned into a positive.

title: Why am I so angry and jealous?
author: listener
text: Consider it as motivation for the long term to develop new ways of reaching your goals.I hope this helps!

title: How can I get over my ex-boyfriend cheating on me?
author: speaker
text: It's been almost a year since my ex-boyfriend broke up with me after he cheated on me many times. I had found out about a month before, but I hadn't told him I knew because I didn't want us to break up. I used to have very low self-esteem, and I think it might have to do with my dad being an alcoholic. My father cheated on my mother when I was little. I wonder if this pain has to do with that. My ex-boyfriend and I were only dating for five months, but I still can't get over this betrayal. I'm not sure what to feel to get over it: forgiveness? Hate? He helped me financially after our break up by lending me $3000, so I'm grateful for that. I still hate him for what he did and still want him to like me although we're not even talking anymore. We follow each other on Instagram and that's it. I feel like I still need his validation. This is haunting me day and night. I want to focus on my new relationship and goals, but I keep obsessing over this and keep checking my ex-boyfriend's Instagram and Facebook. I feel so bad and keep having nightmares.

title: How can I get over my ex-boyfriend cheating on me?
author: listener
text: The dilemmas you present are giving you a great chance to understand your true reasons for being in a relationship.Continue developing some points you've written here.That you grew up sensing and/or witnessing your mom's emotional pain from your dad cheating on her, very likely set a standard in your inner self, to expect similar circumstances in your relationship life.This is a natural dynamic which happens for all of us.

title: How can I get over my ex-boyfriend cheating on me?
author: listener
text: What we observe in our growing up households is what we understand as "normal", no matter how bad it actually is.After all, children don't have the ability to separate that what their own parents do, is wrong compared with the rest of our culture.It is natural to long for a relationship.What you have the chance to do now, is distinguish the reasons for your longing.Is it to attach to someone who has hurt you, hasn't shown you any understanding of having hurt you, and whose validation, even if he says validating words, has little meaning because people who validate are not the ones who harm us?If you're able to teach yourself that those who love us do not harm us, and to develop new expectations for yourself of feeling good from how your partner treats you, then you will be showing yourself a road that will benefit you for your entire lifetime.

title: How come I feel ugly?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my early 20s. I’ve been married once, and he cheated on me. Ever since then, I've felt ugly no matter what. I'm engaged, and I still feel ugly. I don't like to take pictures of myself.

title: How come I feel ugly?
author: listener
text: Sounds as though you're taking the blame for the bad actions of your former husband.He did an ugly action, and instead of feeling only your own emotions in response to being cheated on, you are holding his ugly behavior within you and feeling it.Does this sound like a possible explanation of why your feeling of ugliness started after the cheating incident?You may start feeling better by looking within your own heart for the full effects of having been hurt.

title: How come I feel ugly?
author: listener
text: It is possible there is more suffering within you than you've realized until now.As you address all the emotional pain you've lived through, the feeling of ugliness may drop out all of its own.

title: How come I feel ugly?
author: listener
text: Because you'd be focused on you, not on any of the ugliness introduced into your life by your cheating ex husband.

title: I don't trust my boyfriend
author: speaker
text: I found messages between my boyfriend and this girl on social media. He was asking her for naked pictures and then hung out with her once, but nothing happened. I didn’t find out about the messages until last month and that was six months after it happened. I can’t trust him anymore and I'm just wondering if I ever will. He admitted that he wanted to have sex with her but he didn't. He was only talking with her because he thought we were going to have a break up. My heart is completely broken. I feel like I'm in competition with every girl on the planet for my boyfriend’s affection. I'm afraid that he doesn't like me anymore, but without me he's homeless and without a car. I love him so much. It's been tearing me apart. I don't feel pretty anymore though. I don't feel good enough for anyone or anything. I thought I knew him as well as I knew myself. Then all of a sudden my world was flipped upside down. I'm still trying to figure out which way is up.

title: I don't trust my boyfriend
author: listener
text: I'm sorry for so much stress in your relationship life.In what ways does your boyfriend express his commitment and positive feelings about you, to you?From what you write, you feel more aggravation, stress, loneliness and insecurity, than satisfaction by being in this relationship.Does he care that you don't trust him?Very often people stay in relationships from fear of knowing who they really are.

title: I don't trust my boyfriend
author: listener
text: The feeling is of needing a partner in a way that is similar to how a fearful child needs staying nearby a parent.My suggestion is to think over how much your sense of need for a partner, may be preventing you from actually seeing the amount of love and investment in your relationship, your boyfriend actually has.These realizations are sometimes painful and frightening to understand, especially if you grew up in a family that largely ignored or didn't adequately nurture you as a child.A therapist for your Self may be a good investment of time and cost in giving yourself a safe and trustworthy space to think deeply about your best interest.

title: All I can do is cry and hate myself
author: speaker
text: I'm going through a majorly bad divorce and my wife is making things so impossible for me. I need help.

title: All I can do is cry and hate myself
author: listener
text: Crying due to a dissolution of a marriage, is normal.

title: All I can do is cry and hate myself
author: listener
text: Hating yourself may be a sign of extreme sadness, feelings of loss and uncertainty.Do you know why you hate yourself?

title: All I can do is cry and hate myself
author: listener
text: Discovering your reason is the first step in knowing the obstacles and then the additional steps possible, to move from "hate" to "self-love".Divorce signals a loss of familiar life structure and daily routines.

title: All I can do is cry and hate myself
author: listener
text: As with any meaningful loss, crying is part of mourning what is soon to be gone.If you have confidence in your attorney's handling of the legal areas related to the divorce, and the "impossible" you reference is on facing and coming to terms with statements and behaviors from your wife that you never noticed before, then your best choice is to find a therapist whom you feel at ease in talking with, to sort through the emotional upheaval within yourself and your everyday life and world.Divorce is a wonderful time for learning about ones own emotional needs and expectations in relationships since these are the areas currently coming apart.The good news behind losing something that seems valuable, is that new space becomes open to attract what is more suitable for who you are.

title: My ex left without fully explaining but I feel broken and empty
author: speaker
text: About 5 months ago my ex left without fully explaining why. For me it seemed out of the blue. I don't miss her as much as I used to but I just don't trust people anymore, not even my friends who I have known since my childhood not even my family. I'm so terrified of being judged or dismissed. Instead of acting like someone else or putting on a mask of a personality, I've just shut down. I haven't felt that sense of comfort and happiness with myself since everything fell apart. I'm scared to because I don't want it to be taken away from me again. I feel like ever lesson I learn only last a day. I just don't know what to do. I'm working at a place I know I should enjoy. I'm keeping up with my creative passions: working out, eating healthy, etc. I'm doing everything the books say I should do, but I don't feel any different. I just don't know what to do.

title: My ex left without fully explaining but I feel broken and empty
author: listener
text: since you realize your sense of trust was broken, withdrawing from close relationships, makes sense.This may be your Self giving you natural time to recuperate from emotional pain.Also it is your chance to think over how to handle yourself differently in future relationships.Maybe this process requires more time than you'd like.Having patience is very difficult when a person feels hurt.A therapist of your own may be a good idea so you have someone for guidance and to chart your progress w you.This may feel less lonely and help you tolerate the waiting period till you're better

She told me I was attractive, and have a great personality, etc. I really started to feel better about myself by the time I woke up the next morning. Now, though, I can't stop thinking about her, but I leave to go back to college in a few days and I go to school 4 hours away from her. So now I feel constantly depressed because even if I told her how I felt it wouldn't matter. I feel helpless and I don't know what to do.

text: Deciding to end a relationship is a big question that deserves your full care and attention.

title: Should I end it?
author: listener
text: If you're asking the question, then probably you are pretty close to ending your relationship.Make a list of what you don't like and then decide whether you'd like to tell these topics to your boyfriend as a discussion about your relationship.He may have similar feelings and together the two of you may figure out new ways to be loving with each other.If you've presented your needs and no change results, then ask yourself if you can be happy with him, given what you now realize about him and your feelings.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are separated and he doesn't even want to talk to me.    He says he doesn't love me anymore, but I would do anything to get him back. Is there any hope?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: There is always hope.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: So don't give up on hope.However, you knew I would say that, there is a lot work ahead of you.You need to see someone to talk things out.Get some space between you and your husband.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Don't chase and please don't stalk him.Do some deep searching as to why he left and what part you had to cause the split.You can't change him but you are in control of your own change.With the help of a professional counselor you can get help and direction where you need to change.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are separated and he doesn't even want to talk to me.    He says he doesn't love me anymore, but I would do anything to get him back. Is there any hope?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: I believe there's always hope.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: I also believe that you are worthy of respect and love.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: I'm curious if you felt loved, cherished, and respected by your husband during your time together.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Feeling willing to go to any extreme to save the marriage is common, but having to do things that go against your values sets you up to develop a lot of resentment.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you did not want to be separated from your husband, but now that it's happened, you can make the choice to focus on yourself, rediscovering, or discovering for the first time, what you really want out of life.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Taking some time to grieve the loss of your marriage and practice self-care can help in the immediate aftermath.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Are there dreams that you put on a shelf during your marriage that you could reignite?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: By considering the dreams and desires you had at the beginning of your marriage, you might find some direction for what to do next.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are separated and he doesn't even want to talk to me.    He says he doesn't love me anymore, but I would do anything to get him back. Is there any hope?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: I would focus on YOU right now.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: We cannot control him, his actions, his love, or his decisions.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: But we can work on you.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Think about a few things: What do you want?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: What do you love about him?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: What made you two separate?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: What do you think about being in a relationship where your partner does not love you?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Does that seem fair?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: He may want to work things out or he may be done.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: He may be done for a short period of time or be done forever.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: No one can answer that which is why I think you should change the focus.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: If you do get back together, will you still trust him to not leave you?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: What if he does not love you?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: If you never get back together, can you still have a healthy, happy life?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Can you mourn that relationship but also learn from it?I want you to be strong, happy, and healthy with or without him.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: So yes, there is hope for you - with or without him.

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are separated and he doesn't even want to talk to me.    He says he doesn't love me anymore, but I would do anything to get him back. Is there any hope?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Most important is to take care of your feelings regarding that he has left you.From your description  there doesn't seem to be much hope your husband would like to keep the marriage going.Has a long time passed since the two of you separated?

title: How do I get my husband back?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, and really this is very rare, people decide to return to their marriage.If he impulsively decided to leave and now is a short while since he did this, then there is some hope he will decide to stay together.If he's been out of the house for a while and tells you what you wrote, then there is greater chance he's had time to think through to split and will follow through.As painful as it is to hear that someone with whom you'd like to be, doesn't want to be with you, accepting your hurt feelings will eventually let you come to peace with your feelings.To keep hoping against the facts of what he's said to you, only makes your own pain intensify.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: speaker
text: A year ago, the love of my life left me and never looked back. Our son was two months old at the time and it broke my heart. I miss her so much and can't seem to get over being so heartbroken.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: listener
text: Who takes care of your son, is a significant part of getting over your heartbreak.If you made reasonable custody terms re your son then the relationship heartache is much easier to recover from than if your son’s mother vanished from his life, or if the mother wants nothing to do w him.Re the actual relationship, let yourself feel sad and hurt since this is the truth.Usually life gradually fills in new people, including a relationship once you feel strong enough from having endured such sadness and loss.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: speaker
text: A year ago, the love of my life left me and never looked back. Our son was two months old at the time and it broke my heart. I miss her so much and can't seem to get over being so heartbroken.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: listener
text: I recognize that you say you are missing being with the love of your life.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: listener
text: At the same time, I don't understand whether you are able to see your son.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: listener
text: I'm curious as to the relationship dynamic between you and your son's mother.When you say that she "never looked back," I imagine you are conveying that getting back together is not something that she is interested in.I would suggest that you talk with a therapist and your local area so that you have the ability to discuss the loss of this person who you love so much.

title: How do I get over my heartbreak?
author: listener
text: Most people think of grief related to the loss of someone who has died, But it also applies to people who have a significant loss, whether that is a relationship, a job, or any number of other things.In the meantime, try finding something about yourself that you value and can focus on.

title: Should I tell my separated wife that I'm expecting a child with the woman I'm dating?
author: speaker
text: I got married in 2014. I have a two year old son. His mom and I decided to separate due to my infidelities. We've tried to reconcile our differences but it never works out. Since we've been separated, I've dated someone, and we are expecting a baby girl. Is this something I should mention to my wife? The current woman whom I'm dating has been telling me for months to break up with her, but it's hard because I actually love her.

title: Should I tell my separated wife that I'm expecting a child with the woman I'm dating?
author: listener
text: Only tell your former girlfriend who is the mother of your son, what is necessary for her to know as it relates to your son.The mother of your son has every right as a parent to know who is directly involved in her son's life.First figure out how you will handle your current girlfriend's request to end the relationship you have with her.Without knowing whether you are in a relationship or not, is a key piece of information which the mother of your son would likely have interest to know and be entitled to know.Also, love is never enough to keep a marriage working.

title: Should I tell my separated wife that I'm expecting a child with the woman I'm dating?
author: listener
text: Love is a wonderful emotion only managing daily life and family decisions requires commitment to the other person.Reflect within yourself if you are willing to commit to your current girlfriend.

title: Should I tell my separated wife that I'm expecting a child with the woman I'm dating?
author: listener
text: Then you'd have a substantial offer to make to her of your willingness to be together with her.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: speaker
text: Our relationship ended about 7 years ago, but don't know how to let go. How can I get over that person and move on?

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: I think giving yourself the space to realize that this was a significant relationship and it really had an impact on you.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: I think you should honor that relationship and then talk about it to someone.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: The more you try to not think of it, the more you will think of it.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: I think you should instead, say "thank you" to that relationship.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: Thank you for showing you what qualities you like, what you desire.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: Maybe even come up with a list of what that specific relationship did for you.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: After you say "thank you" to that relationship then it may be time to say goodbye.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: You obviously want to get over that person, so figure out why you want to get over them.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: Why did it not work out?

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: What negative parts of the relationship do you keep forgetting to think about.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: Oftentimes, people glamorize the past.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: So for your goodbye part of this phase, I would focus on the negative parts of the relationship.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: You can also work on emotionally saying goodbye to that time in your life.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: You are probably different than you were 7 years ago, and to be honest, they are probably different too.I know it sounds weird.

title: How to get over somebody?
author: listener
text: But I would recommend that you mentally say "thank you" and "goodbye" to that relationship.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: speaker
text:
I know that I need to get past my feelings for this person I fell in love with, but t's so difficult to move on because he showed me feelings I've never felt before.    I feel like I don't want to be without my genuine love for him, but logically, I know I need to be without him. I can't discuss this with anybody in my life because the conditions surrounding our love are considered "wrong" by a lot of people.
   How can I get myself to just move on?

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Well, there is some good news and not-so-good news.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: The good news is that people are capable of moving on from relationships, even if the person showed them a sort of love that they've never felt they've had, or deserved, before.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, even just the fact that this has happened for them can, eventually (see below) lead them to seek out love again, because they now believe they will be able to have that again.So, the not-so-good news though is that one can not "just move on."

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: I'd even venture to say that the pressure you may be putting on yourself to just move on and out of this yucky hole of feelings that you are in is actually too much pressure and adding to the yucky feelings as they are.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Instead, try thinking of getting past these feelings as grieving over the loss of someone (even though someone didn't die, there is still a significant loss you are experiencing) and therefore how essential it is to allow yourself to grieve, to feel whatever feelings (of anger, or sadness, or something else) that you are feeling.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Often, it is really helpful to speak those feelings (I recommend professionals in this case) who can help you feel like you are not pathological for this struggle, and instead that it is completely normal.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Love is a crazy thing, and the feelings can get very confusing.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: But, the last stage of grieving is "acceptance," and it is very challenging to get there if you skip over denial, anger, bargaining, and depression.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: speaker
text:
I know that I need to get past my feelings for this person I fell in love with, but t's so difficult to move on because he showed me feelings I've never felt before.    I feel like I don't want to be without my genuine love for him, but logically, I know I need to be without him. I can't discuss this with anybody in my life because the conditions surrounding our love are considered "wrong" by a lot of people.
   How can I get myself to just move on?

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Love is a deep and nuanced feeling so start to accept that a simple cutting of emotional connection isn't possible.Honor the love you felt for this person.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Acknowledgement of your love feelings will most likely help you find a dignified way to accept them while at the same time slowly developing new ways to live your life in a way which does not include the actual person.Your feelings will always belong to you.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: The newly discovered sense of how love feels will be with you and positively influence all your relationships.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: There is a benefit to feeling loved even if it is not forever in this lifetime.Also, your partner opened your feelings, the feelings which showed in fact already were within you.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: He opened the door and this door belongs to you.I hope you will find ways to appreciate having been loved and to be open that your feelings of being loved are a positive influence in all your relationships.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: speaker
text:
I know that I need to get past my feelings for this person I fell in love with, but t's so difficult to move on because he showed me feelings I've never felt before.    I feel like I don't want to be without my genuine love for him, but logically, I know I need to be without him. I can't discuss this with anybody in my life because the conditions surrounding our love are considered "wrong" by a lot of people.
   How can I get myself to just move on?

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: It's difficult to move on and let go, especially when you've experienced things for the first time with someone, or feelings you've never felt before, as you said.I like the fact that you are looking at your situation "logically".

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Feelings can take time to fade, but you seem to understand, even if it is subconsciously, that it's the feelings he stirred up in you that are keeping you tied to him, not necessarily the person himself.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Realize that you can and will experience those feelings again with another person - the RIGHT person.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Don't hold onto someone who is wrong for you just because of something like this.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: You're wanting those feelings and wanting a relationship - but with him necessarily?

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Or with anybody?

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: You said you don't want to be without your love for him - not you don't want to be without him.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: In fact, you said you know you need to be without him.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Not the person.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Trust me, you will find that again.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Take some time to let this fade.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Don't try to force him or anyone else into a role that is meant for someone else.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Cherish the memories and the experiences you had.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Sounds like it's been a valuable learning and growth experience for you, but you have your own reasons, and I don't know what they are, for thinking this person isn't good for you.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Trust your gut instinct and be glad you've had this relationship.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: Not all are meant to last.

title: How do I get over a person I fell in love with?
author: listener
text: But all shape you into the person you are and will become, and all teach us important lessons.

title: Did I make a mistake breaking up with a guy who said his ex-girlfriend will always be on his mind?
author: speaker
text: He was in love with someone years ago, and he still thinks about her time to time. He said, and I quote, "That relationship is definitely over. I love you, but that girl will always be in my mind." It just didn't feel like he appreciated all the things I've done to make him happy.

title: Did I make a mistake breaking up with a guy who said his ex-girlfriend will always be on his mind?
author: listener
text: Trust your intuition on your conclusion about this guy.He may very well love you, only with the ex so prominent in his mind, it is possible your feeling of not being appreciated now, would multiply if ever the two of you needed to address a delicate topic.Since he is emotionally attached to the former gf, it is very likely he wouldn't be able to fully love you as much as you'd like and are already sensing.

title: Why does my spouse tell me he doesn't want me, but also gets jealous of me?
author: speaker
text: My spouse decided he no longer wanted me six years ago. Things have deteriorated so badly that we have separated but still live in the same house. He says he despises the sight of me, wants to be with other women, and divorce. What I don't understand is that he says constantly that I have no feelings for him and gets absurdly jealous if I speak to another male. Why does he constantly do these behaviors? I might add he has been diagnosed with borderline personality disorder and as a narcissist.

title: Why does my spouse tell me he doesn't want me, but also gets jealous of me?
author: listener
text: What a burden for you!Your husband cannot seem to make up his mind on his viewpoint and doesn't seem to care whether or not you're affected by speaking out of two sides of his mouth.Keep yourself protected emotionally from him.

title: Why does my spouse tell me he doesn't want me, but also gets jealous of me?
author: listener
text: There's no good which can come by arguing with a person who  flips their position.Live as separately as possible from him and stick to roommate type matters such as groceries, bill paying and housecleaning as discussion topics.If he cannot make sense of what he thinks and feels, then certainly you will face similar difficulty trying to do so!

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are separated. He says he needs some time apart. He says he needs to get back the “in love” part of a relationship but doesn’t want to lose me. Should I wait or start over new?

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: It's not uncommon for relationships to go cold over time.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: It is a matter of one or the other becoming complacent.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: If you and your husband have been together for quite some time it's likely that you are very comfortable and familiar with each other.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: While this is a good thing in some ways, it can also become boring and you run the risk of losing that "in love" feeling he is referring to.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: Couples simply become ambivalent.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: For some of the couples I work with in my practice, I find that helping to organize a time apart, which I call a "Therapeutic Separation" can do wonders for the relationship.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: I offer homework to be done during this time.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: Reading, worksheets and individual counseling helps people learn more about themselves and what they desire out of their relationship.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: It often times brings more appreciation for their partners.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: When the pair comes back together, we are able to push the reset button and begin a new chapter that is more fulfilling and exciting than before.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I are separated. He says he needs some time apart. He says he needs to get back the “in love” part of a relationship but doesn’t want to lose me. Should I wait or start over new?

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: That's a tough one.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: Would you and your husband be willing to attend couples counseling during the separation?

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: That would benefit you both.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: If you separate and reconcile, what will have changed other than you having time apart?

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: You will need to gain new skills to enhance and maintain your connection - otherwise you will risk repeating the cycle of disconnect, discontentment and separation.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: Please seek help from a therapist trained in couples work to help the two of you find a way either back to each other or gracefully out of the marriage.

title: Should I move on from my ex-husband?
author: listener
text: Time away will not, by itself, change your relationship into one that can be sustained.

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: speaker
text:
I want a secure relationship with someone that wants to be with me and who will actually put effort into it.
 I seem to gravitate toward unavailable men and those that want intimacy and no relationship. I let men dictate and control me because they accuse me of being controlling. I let men emotionally abuse me and I am at their beck and call.
 I am not comfortable being alone or doing anything by myself. I feel I need the security of someone being around just to survive. I know what I'm doing wrong and I do it anyway just hoping things will change. How do I stop this behavior and thought process?

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: listener
text: You may be interested in reading my most recent post, Intimacy Begins With You.

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: listener
text: In it I offer 7 expert tips to help you get started on a path of self connection and discovery.

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: listener
text: This is important stuff to do in order to work through that stuff that's holding you back from the relationships you desire.

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: listener
text: You may find that it's especially helpful to do this work with the alliance of a skilled individual therapist.

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: speaker
text:
I want a secure relationship with someone that wants to be with me and who will actually put effort into it.
 I seem to gravitate toward unavailable men and those that want intimacy and no relationship. I let men dictate and control me because they accuse me of being controlling. I let men emotionally abuse me and I am at their beck and call.
 I am not comfortable being alone or doing anything by myself. I feel I need the security of someone being around just to survive. I know what I'm doing wrong and I do it anyway just hoping things will change. How do I stop this behavior and thought process?

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: listener
text: Good for you on your keen awareness of your difficulties and your willingness to change!The type of change you'd like to achieve is possible, and since a change in self-confidence and self-love is deep rooted, this comes about gradually and slowly.Keep understanding yourself during your moments of doubt and anxiety.

title: How do I break an unhealthy relationship pattern?
author: listener
text: Its fine to feel terrible and certainly better to know you feel insecure than to act upon the insecurity by being with men who take advantage of you.Everyone needs to feel loved and recognized.Until you attract a partner who will love and appreciate you, develop relationships with co-workers and classmates, neighbors, so that you have some quality of giving and being given by someone.It is a way to nurture yourself and another person until your strength and self-belief grow bigger.

title: Should I give him another chance?
author: speaker
text: After my fiancé cheated on me because of a miscommunication, I pulled myself away from him.    Now he says all he wants is be with me. I'm pushing him away mentally now because he cheated on me again. I make plans with him that I don't keep. I really do love him still and I care about him. Should I give home one more chance?

title: Should I give him another chance?
author: listener
text: People don't cheat bc of miscommunication.

title: Should I give him another chance?
author: listener
text: People cheat bc they feel diminished regard for their partner.You pulling away doesn't explain his behavior.If the two of you still were a couple at the time he cheated on you, then there were many alternatives he cold have taken besides disrespecting you.Try to understand whether you are satisfied and happy in the relationship.

title: Should I give him another chance?
author: listener
text: Your actions sound as though you are not either of these.Whether or not you decide to be together again many depend too on if the trust you had in him is restored.

title: Should I give him another chance?
author: listener
text: Do you feel you can trust him again?If the two of discuss your relationship then if you don't trust him right now and the both of you talk about your dynamics, then tell him about your feelings.Trust is foundational to feeling safe and happy in a relationship.

title: How do I move on?
author: speaker
text: I'm obsessing about a terrible breakup. Everything is a constant reminder. How do I move on?

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Moving on is the right question.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Everyone's different in moving on.

title: How do I move on?

text: First, what can I learn about myself because of this painful time?

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Caring non-judgmental family and friends who listen with the head and heart help a iot.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Other times I need a skillful, caring professional to help me move on.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: You will find a way because you've asked the right question.

title: How do I move on?

text: Dr. Spencer

title: How do I move on?
author: speaker
text: I'm obsessing about a terrible breakup. Everything is a constant reminder. How do I move on?

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Initially, everything is a reminder because there is a trace of that other person present in everything in your life.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: When we lose someone, we're saying goodbye to what we thought our future was going to be.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Accepting that's changed and allowing ourselves to envision a new future is necessary to "move on".

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Start learning something new or try a new activity that you've always wanted to do.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: Find whatever is "good" about being out of the relationship and focus on those things.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: This can be an exciting time of transformation for you.

title: How do I move on?
author: listener
text: As time goes by, you'll add new things in your life that aren't entwined with this relationship and those things will begin to crowd out those things associated with the relationship.

title: How do I move on?

title: How do I move on?

title: How do I move on?

title: How do I move on?

title: How do I move on?
