title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: speaker
text: I was born a girl, but I want to be a boy. Because of my religion I can't tell my family. I know they won't accept me. What do I do?

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
I understand that this must be a difficult time for you with
many adjustments.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
If you feel comfortable enough to ask your parents to see a
Life Coach or a therapist, this may be an excellent place to start.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
You don’t
need to tell them the reason why maybe say that you simply need someone to talk
to for support with school or homework etc.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
The Life Coach or therapist would
be the optimal person to advise you on how to proceed with providing support
and guidance.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
There may be someone at your school whom you could talk to for
confidential support and guidance as well.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
Be confident in the fact that you
are not alone and there are always responsible adults available to guide you
through any difficult process you may experience in life.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
Talking to family
about personal issues can be difficult for anyone, even adults.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text:
I recommend
getting help from a trusted, professional adult before you decide what to do.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: speaker
text: I was born a girl, but I want to be a boy. Because of my religion I can't tell my family. I know they won't accept me. What do I do?

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Chances are your family already knows, they are probably just waiting on confirmation from you to say it.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: A parent knows their child.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: speaker
text: I was born a girl, but I want to be a boy. Because of my religion I can't tell my family. I know they won't accept me. What do I do?

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Spirituality for those in the LGBTQ community can be one of the more difficult roads.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, many unjustly ostracize members of the LGBTQ community away from faith and spirituality.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: I believe that folks can embrace the identity that is genuine to them, and still maintain their spiritual beliefs!

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Briefly, the keys are to first monitor how we allow those in our life to influence our thoughts and emotions.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: We need to create standards and boundaries to protect ourselves.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: We also need to not project the judgment of other people onto our individual spiritual beliefs!

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: There are many ways in which to tackle this effort!

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: speaker
text: I was born a girl, but I want to be a boy. Because of my religion I can't tell my family. I know they won't accept me. What do I do?

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Ultimately, to suppress your natural identity will work against you.However difficult, painful, frightening, it is to tell your family about your discovery about who you are, trying to avoid your own truth will do you harm eventually.One way to make this conversation easier for yourself is to prepare yourself for the outcomes you expect and know will be difficult.Take as much time as you need to accept the potential rejection because this way iff and when it comes you will be better able to handle it.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: speaker
text: I was born a girl, but I want to be a boy. Because of my religion I can't tell my family. I know they won't accept me. What do I do?

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: First of all, I want to say, I am so sorry you are not feeling accepted by your family.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: I know how  isolating and lonely this can be.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: The most important step you can take right now is building a community of supportive people who do accept you.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Creating your own sense of community is very powerful for helping you love yourself.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: If you can find a trans support or LGBTQ support group in your area, I recommend seeking that out right away through your local LGBTQ center or PFLAG.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: If you don’t have access to that, I recommend calling Trans Lifeline US: 877-565-8860 Canada: 877-330-6366 https://www.translifeline.org/.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: You can talk to other trans-identified people anonymously for support, calling them from wherever you feel safe.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: This is a great way to begin to connect with other people who have similar experiences to you.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Next, think of this time in your life as your time to explore your gender identity, just for yourself.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Make room to explore you gender identity in ways that are private and comfortable for you.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Consider reading a book like: https://www.newharbinger.com/queer-and-transgender-resilience-workbook to explore who you are and build resilience.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Also, consider learning about other religions that are accepting of LGBTQ folks for another perspective - there are many out there!

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: Once you feel you have a strong support system outside of your family and a positive sense of self-love (which can take time, be patient, don’t rush it), then you can consider what action steps you want to take with your family.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: If you are still living with your family or financially depend on them, having other supports in place first is very important.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: It’s a very personal choice how you want to navigate your family relationships, talk it through in-depth with a trusted friend, other trans folks, or therapist to help you decide what’s right for you.And remember, there are tons of people out there who will love and accept you.

title: I want to be a boy but I can't because of my religion
author: listener
text: We are rooting for you!In solidarity,-Lindsey

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: speaker
text: My fiancé and I come from a strong Christian background but both went off the "straight and narrow" once before. He is having a hard time accepting my past, especially that I'm not a virgin. He has a hard time in general accepting himself and others.    His insecurities are hurting our relationship. How can I help him let go of my past and decide to live in the present?

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: You are right that his insecurities are at the root of the issue.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: You cannot change that for him.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: He will have to do the work to handle those emotions on his own.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: What you can do is reassure him in whatever ways possible, but always recognizing that you can't "fix" this for him.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: When I work with people who struggle with their partner's past experiences, I always frame it like this:  Everything that you've experienced has resulted in you being the person you are today.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: The person they claim to love.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: If you had not gone through some of those experiences, you would not be in the position you're in now, ready to commit to him and know that you're satisfied with that.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: Just as when bad things happen to us, we have to find a way to appreciate the lessons learned your fiance has to accept that you're the person you are today because of what you have gone through.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: Celebrate that you have moved through that and have landed in this perfect position with him!Hope that helps, Allison

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: speaker
text: My fiancé and I come from a strong Christian background but both went off the "straight and narrow" once before. He is having a hard time accepting my past, especially that I'm not a virgin. He has a hard time in general accepting himself and others.    His insecurities are hurting our relationship. How can I help him let go of my past and decide to live in the present?

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: This suffering and clinging to the past, especially a troubled past or a past that we dont like, may be  amplified due to the Christian framework that may be built into your life.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: I am not averse to religion, i just think that many times it puts unreasonable expectations on us and helps us to form a guilt complex or perhaps even insecurities, we are humans and humans make mistakes.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: you mention the straight and narrow, this is a notion that you must give up on and let go, humans can never travel the straight and narrow for their whole lives there are bounds to be mistakes, we are the most fallible species on the planet and please tell your fiance to have some mercy on himself, he is not perfect.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
Here is a story about clinging on to things you may find useful to mediate on:Once
there lived a village of creatures along the bottom of a great crystal
river.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
The current of the river swept silently over them all -- young and
old, rich and poor, good and evil -- the current going its own way, knowing
only its own crystal self.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
Each creature in its own
manner clung tightly to the twigs and rocks of the river bottom, for clinging
was their way of life, and resisting the current was what each had learned
from birth.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
But one creature said
at last, "I am tired of clinging.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
Though I cannot see it with my eyes,
I trust that the current knows where it is going.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
I shall let go, and let
it take me where it will.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: Clinging, I shall die of boredom."

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
The other creatures laughed
and said, "Fool!

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
Let go, and that current you worship will throw you tumbled
and smashed against the rocks, and you will die quicker than boredom!"

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
But the one heeded them
not, and taking a breath did let go, and at once was tumbled and smashed
by the current across the rocks.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
Yet in time, as the creature
refused to cling again, the current lifted him free from the bottom, and
he was bruised and hurt no more.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
And the creatures downstream,
to whom he was a stranger, cried, "See a miracle!

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
A creature like ourselves,
yet he flies!

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: See the messiah, come to save us all!"

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
And the one carried in
the current said, "I am no more messiah than you.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
The river delights to
lift us free, if only we dare let go.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
Our true work is this voyage, this
adventure."

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
But they cried the more,
"Savior!"

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text:
all the while clinging to the rocks, and when they looked again
he was gone, and they were left alone making legends of a savior.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: speaker
text: My fiancé and I come from a strong Christian background but both went off the "straight and narrow" once before. He is having a hard time accepting my past, especially that I'm not a virgin. He has a hard time in general accepting himself and others.    His insecurities are hurting our relationship. How can I help him let go of my past and decide to live in the present?

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: Sometimes we have difficulty keeping the past in the past.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: The best way to build a great relationship and have a great future, believe it or not, is to be firmly placed in the present.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: That means that when we stay in the moment with our partner and can notice what we are experiencing in the here and now we reap the best benefits of that relationship.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: We notice the good things that are happening in the moment.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: We are reacting to what we are experiencing in the moment, not reacting to a worry about the past.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: We notice, especially, who the person is right now and not who they were in the past.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: We can connect with the things we love about them, too.I think it is great that you want to help him and the choice to stay in the present and move forward in the relationship will mostly be up to him.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: We cannot change another person.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: It sounds like couples counseling might be a great step for you because you can both learn the skills you need to stay in the present and also learn some helpful "active listening" skills so that you can really listen to one another and understand each other.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: Communication skills can really be helpful.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: You can both have the opportunity to hear each other and support each other.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: We cannot change the past, but we can create the future we want.Best of luck to you both!

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: speaker
text: My fiancé and I come from a strong Christian background but both went off the "straight and narrow" once before. He is having a hard time accepting my past, especially that I'm not a virgin. He has a hard time in general accepting himself and others.    His insecurities are hurting our relationship. How can I help him let go of my past and decide to live in the present?

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: One of the sometimes difficult things about being in a relationship is the fact that you can make goals for yourself, but you can't make goals for your partner.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: If your fiancé wants to learn to live more in the present and learn to let go of the past or move in a different direction, you can certainly assist him, but you can't independently make it happen.I wonder if both of you would be willing to have a discussion where he is able to explain to you what he is experiencing and you are able to listen for five, 10, 15 minutes in a way that is not blaming or pointing fingers or asking him to change, but just listening (kind of like an investigative reporter) so you can have more details and ask questions that you may have about what certain things mean, when it feels like to to him when this is discussed, etc.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: At that point, maybe he would willing to listen to your thoughts on the subject as well.Also, if he wants to make a change, it may be helpful to see a therapist who specializes in working with couples.

title: How can I help my fiancé accept and let go of my past?
author: listener
text: Sometimes changes such as these require a great deal of personal awareness and there can be quite a bit of emotions attached, so it is often helpful to have someone there to assist.It may also be nice to have a discussion where you consider what makes you feel valued, appreciated, special, or loved, and also consider what makes your fiancé feel that way.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: speaker
text: Maybe this is a stupid question, but I sometimes don't know what's real or not. If feel at times like everyone's lying. How do I know if God is one of those lies?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: There are an infinite number of ways to look at this.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Spirituality, religion, God, higher power, and many other parts of this discussion mean different things to different people.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: My question for you is what does "real" actually mean to you?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Often, the concept of God has to do with what you believe in.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: If you ask 1000 different people, you'll probably get almost that many different answers.Consider talking with friends or family about this.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: I would suggest, though, that you have the discussion initially with people who you trust and who you feel are willing to listen to your questions and beliefs and perhaps offer an opinion without trying to make you believe as they do.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: You may also consider speaking with a pastor or another religious figure.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: The local Salvation Army may have a link to a religious or spiritual person that leads nondenominational church services.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: There may be able to help you to sort through this if your friends and family do not provide a comfortable environment for you related to this discussion.Just a word of caution.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: In my experience, ideas of religion and spirituality can be lead to very deep discussions with some people who are very strongly connected to what they believe.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Some people do not easily separate their own beliefs from those of others.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: When initiating conversations about this, try first asking whether someone would be comfortable discussing religion or spirituality.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: A second question may be whether it is okay with this person you are talking to if you have different beliefs or opinions.As far as whether God is real or not, consider trusting yourself and what you learn, feel, and believe as you work through this process.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: speaker
text: Maybe this is a stupid question, but I sometimes don't know what's real or not. If feel at times like everyone's lying. How do I know if God is one of those lies?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Thanks for posting.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: This is a significant issue for many people and can make us feel helpless; among other emotions due to the uncertainty.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: You said that, at times, you feel like everyone is lying.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Ask yourself some of these questions.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: What is it that makes you feel so strongly that they are lying?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Where is the concrete evidence that they are lying?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: How could I test my thoughts about this?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: What if things are not what they seem on the surface?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Am I any lesser of a person as a result of this person's behavior or opinion?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Our beliefs about ourselves and the people and our world  and how we interpret information and experiences have a significant effect on how we feel and how we behave.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: It is important to objectively challenge the beliefs that contribute to negative emotions.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: You can start this process by answering some of the above questions.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: We are unfortunately influenced by what and who we associate with.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: As it pertains to if God is a lie; be honest with yourself and question your beliefs that tell you that God is or is not real.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: It may be helpful for you to speak to a preacher or chaplain of some sort and they can help you with a lot of that.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Hope this helps at least a little bit.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: speaker
text: Maybe this is a stupid question, but I sometimes don't know what's real or not. If feel at times like everyone's lying. How do I know if God is one of those lies?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: The way that I see it is that Humans have always been afraid of life and death, historically we have always tried to understand life, we try to organize it, categorize it, explore it, and we've built up this system, our system and societies system around us to help us define what life and (death) is, this system or way is not real but only a perception of our own value judgements, it is, no matter how you try to argue it, a false system of conditioning, humans have a finite mind and a finite mind cannot ever hope to understand an infinite mind of which a god would be.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: God has been developed over time as a security blanket for our child-like selves, the world is a beautifully brutal place and what is more reassuring than a master that will take care of us and show us the way.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: On Earth alone there are thousands of gods and even many more systems of thought, economics, societal structures and so on, it is almost as though it were a supermarket with so many choices, we have more choices in gods than we do flavors of ice cream at Baskin-Robbins, so then I ask you, "which one is real?, and "what is real?"

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: speaker
text: Maybe this is a stupid question, but I sometimes don't know what's real or not. If feel at times like everyone's lying. How do I know if God is one of those lies?

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Your question is actually thoughtful and reflects a true interest to know more about life.No one knows if god is a lie because "god" is a concept in which people either make up their own definition of this concept, or believe one of the concepts of what god is, handed down by religions.All the religions exclude the other god concepts, and expect loyalty to believing in their particular version of "god".Probably god is real in the sense that most people want to believe there is guided purpose to what goes on in life.This is as definite as what we can know about "god".

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: "God" is not a lie because it is not a fact.

title: I'm struggeling with the idea of if God real or not?
author: listener
text: Beliefs aren't provable.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: speaker
text: I'm a Christian teenage girl, and I have lost my virginity. My boyfriend is a Christian teenager too, but things just got out of hand between us in a sexual manner. I planned to abstain from sex but I guess I wasn't clear about this because I was also tempted and led him on. We continued to have sex. Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me? We're so young, but that doesn't stop me from dreaming of a potential future together. I really do feel like he is in my life for an important reason. I'm incredibly happy for I was able to escape from several abusive relationships because of him. I love him very much.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Having sex with your boyfriend is and was a mistake.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Mistakes can be forgiven and you can make amends.But it is not the end of your relationship or God's will for you.Have a serious talk with your guy and get back on track with where you want to be.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Talk to a counselor or your priest/pastor.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Get someone to be your guide and mentor.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Check in with them regularly.Getting back to square one could actually strengthen your relationship.Have a plan for the future where you will not be put into a place of temptation.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Group dates, public places and no alone time where temptations might arise.Forgive yourself and move on.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: speaker
text: I'm a Christian teenage girl, and I have lost my virginity. My boyfriend is a Christian teenager too, but things just got out of hand between us in a sexual manner. I planned to abstain from sex but I guess I wasn't clear about this because I was also tempted and led him on. We continued to have sex. Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me? We're so young, but that doesn't stop me from dreaming of a potential future together. I really do feel like he is in my life for an important reason. I'm incredibly happy for I was able to escape from several abusive relationships because of him. I love him very much.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: I'm not a super religious person...

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: But I can't imagine that if you love him that much and you want him that much, that he wouldn't be the one for you because of something small like that.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: Sex is an act of love and commitment.

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: If you feel that you want to be with this person for the rest of your life, want to marry them, then why should you have to wait until marriage?

title: Does it mean that he isn't the one God planned for me if we had sex as Christians?
author: listener
text: If you truly feel that this is the person you want to be with, then why would you need to wait until marriage if you're just showing commitment to each other?

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: speaker
text:
I'm a young adult woman, and I have trouble finding my true identity being at home. This all started when I had a boyfriend about 10 months ago. My boyfriend and I were dating for a couple months and decided to get in to sexual acts. At the time, I was pretty religious, but I let this happen. I don't know why. I felt kind of guilty but mostly because I know my parents wouldn't like it. My parents are very religious—they're Christians. We did things every time he'd come over to my house. We didn't have anything to do at our house, so we would get tempted to do things when we'd watch movies by ourselves.
   One day, my parents found out I did this stuff with him because my dad read my messages. As soon as my dad found this out, he told my mom. They were both aggravated. They told me he was just a boy that wanted to get inside my pants. They said he wanted me for sex and he's not a Christian. I took their advice and broke up with him. Once we broke up for about a month, I decided to get back together with him a little after school started. My parents found out eventually, and I decided to not listen this time. I would constantly talk to my boyfriend about what they say about him: how's he's not the right one for me, and God totally forbids him. I would kind of try to break up with him, and then eventually I would just never listen to my parents. They're always yelling at me about how I shouldn't date this boy. I felt too old to listen to them. Now I'm kind of just stuck. Is the real me religious? Have I been brainwashed by him? I don't talk to my parents anymore about him, and my parents think I'm deceiving because of it. They threatened me that if I'm still with him, I can't do track and they won't support me. They've also called me slut, and now they called me basically a devil worshipper. They say my boyfriend is taking me away from my parents. I'm actually very happy with him. They also say I'm living a separate life at home than I am at school. They say they want what's best for me and love me because they adopted me.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: What a tough situation you must be in, feeling torn between your parents and someone who is very special to you.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: I would say the first thing you want to do is (if you haven't already), have a calm reciprocal conversation with your parents, telling them how you feel and letting them know what you need from them.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: If communication attempts are unsucessful then you will need to make a decision with how you would like to move forward.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: You, unfortunately, will not be able to change your parent's feelings or opinions but you can agree to disagree on certain matters by keeping them separate from the relationship you have with your parents.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: It always helps to try and see things from another angle.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: You might want to, for example, try and understand your parent's perspectives and let them know you understand that they are upset.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: Validating other's feelings can be very helpful with communicating effectively.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: Are you living with your parents and do they support you?

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: If so, are you willing to give that up should you decide to not follow their rules?

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: Know that there is nothing wrong with being happy with someone or loving somebody so deeply.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: Your feelings and actions certainly do not make you brainwashed or a devil worshipper.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: Not everyone will always approve of the choices we make and sometimes we need to be okay with that.

title: I'm dating a boy that my religious parents don't like, and I'm having trouble finding my identity
author: listener
text: Best of luck to you.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: speaker
text:
There are issues from my past that have me very heavily burdened in my heart. I've been torn for so many years and I need help so I can move on with my life.
   I experienced trauma when I was 8 years old and I did come out about it until I was 40.
   Now I know this is what's holding me back on my happiness. I've met a very loving and caring man but because I'm holding on to these things from my past I’m pushing him away.
   How can I get my life back?

author: listener
text: You already are doing that!

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?

text: You are reaching out (virtually still counts!).

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?

text: You are accepting your past, you are not denying what happened to you, you are talking about the past.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?

text: Do you want to talk to someone?

text: Do you want to write about it?

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: Do you want to pray about it?

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: Do you want to read and research books about trauma?

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: Take some time and think about what you want to do.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: Think about what would work for you and dive in.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: I am a Licensed Professional Counselor, so I am biased - but I really believe that counseling works.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: Having an objective, professional voice that can guide you on this process is so valuable.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener
text: But please choose what makes you feel comfortable - not what everyone else says.

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?
author: listener

title: My past is holding me back from my future. How can I get my life back?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: speaker
text: I was raped a couple months ago, Since then, along with other unfortunately events that have occurred, I have been having trouble feeling emotions. It's almost as if I'm a sociopath lacking any feeling. What can I do to change this?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I'm so sorry you've been hurt.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: It's very normal to stop feeling emotions as a way to protect yourself after experiencing a traumatic event.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: You can think of it as emotional shock-- you experienced something that was so awful that you have numbed yourself (mind and body) as a way to stop the emotional and physical pain of the event.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: It's actually pretty amazing that our selves know how to do this automatically.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: And, I hear you saying that you'd like to get some feeling back now.So here are some ideas for how you can change this:I think it would be a great idea to find an experienced therapist you like and trust and/or a good support group so that you can have some allies as you go through this process.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: You also could try journaling.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: If you're not sure what to write then check out this list of prompts to get you started (it's for teachers, but I really like it).

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: There's also art journaling.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Pinterest has lots of suggestions.Meditation could be useful.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: There are lots of apps available that offer guided meditations.Yoga, tai chi, or chi gong might also help.I have lots of other ideas, but without knowing more about you I'm reluctant to make suggestions that could accidentally make you feel worse.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: IThis protective mechanism of numbing yourself kicked in for a good reason and as you get your feelings back, you may find some pretty challenging reactions coming up.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I guess my final piece of advice to is encourage you to trust yourself and gently go at your own pace in your healing.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I hope this was helpful.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: speaker
text: I was raped a couple months ago, Since then, along with other unfortunately events that have occurred, I have been having trouble feeling emotions. It's almost as if I'm a sociopath lacking any feeling. What can I do to change this?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I don't need to tell you that this is an incredible amount of serious stuff to happen in a short period.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: When we go through a trauma, it is natural for us to shut down as a way to protect ourselves.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: A kind of freeze response.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Think of a possum or a gazelle.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: These animals go so far as to physically freeze in protection.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Our emotions do the same thing sometimes.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: We feel shut down and that can be strange---a kind of disconnection.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: This does not mean that you are sociopath or that your feelings will never come back.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: The amazing thing though is that as time moves forward we naturally heal and emotions come back.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: If you feel stuck, seeking counseling is a way to help accelerate this healing and help you work through and begin healing.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Wishing you the absolute best!

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: speaker
text: I was raped a couple months ago, Since then, along with other unfortunately events that have occurred, I have been having trouble feeling emotions. It's almost as if I'm a sociopath lacking any feeling. What can I do to change this?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I’m sorry to know this happened to you!

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: This is a normal response to traumatic events.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: When we are pushed to the extreme and we are unable to escape, we “freeze” which numbs us from pain but disconnects us from our bodies.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: We oftentimes continue to feel that disconnection until we work through these traumas.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I would suggest working through your traumas with a therapist with methods like EMDR, somatic experiencing, yoga therapy, etc to get your emotions and fullness of life back!

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: speaker
text: I was raped a couple months ago, Since then, along with other unfortunately events that have occurred, I have been having trouble feeling emotions. It's almost as if I'm a sociopath lacking any feeling. What can I do to change this?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I am so sorry this has happened to you!

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I hope you have some people you find emotionally supportive around you!

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: In terms of your question, I understand what you are talking about.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Sometimes when a person experiences a traumatic event, an event called Dissociation occurs.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Dissociation is the brain's way of temporary creating and increasing  "emotional distance" between what is happening and what you are feeling and experiencing.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: This is a kind of natural coping mechanism, and it can occur just prior to, during, and after an event has occurred.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: People describe the feeling as being "numb," or detached from others, their surroundings, and even from their own body.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: All of these descriptions are accurate and they are your brain's attempt to try and keep you safe from emotions that may otherwise overwhelm you.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: This is good, in the short-term, because you are not having to immediately face and cope with the immensely painful feelings associated with your trauma.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: But it is also not-so-good in that it also blocks your ability to feel positive and pleasurable emotions.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: So while your brain is protecting you, it is also preventing feelings you need now more than ever (such as regaining a sense of safety, soothing your hurts, and feeling empowered for your survival).You are not a sociopath, so do not worry about that, but I would strongly recommend that you consider seeing a therapist or other supportive mental health professional to help you work through what is happened.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: There are ways for you to heal from your experience which will help you get back to a place where you can feel safe enough to "feel" again.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: It might be an uncomfortable journey, at times, but you are already hurting and your life is being negatively impacted, now.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Good therapy sometimes is like pulling out a splinter--it may hurt a bit to dig that sucker out, but once it's out, your body can finally start to heal.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: It might seem better (and less painful) to leave it alone, and ignore (avoid) it.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: But you risk INFECTION by your inaction which will be 100 x worse than just digging it out.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Best of luck to you!Learn more about me and my practice at www.EMDRheals.com

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: speaker
text: I was raped a couple months ago, Since then, along with other unfortunately events that have occurred, I have been having trouble feeling emotions. It's almost as if I'm a sociopath lacking any feeling. What can I do to change this?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: You are describing a very legitimate reaction to trauma.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Rape is an aweful experience and I am very sorry that happened to you.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: When horrible things happen, people often react in a way that interferes with the ability to live a normal life and function the way they did in the past.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: This is very common and the goal is to help you manage the stress caused by dealing with negative events and with help you can regain emotional well-being.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: This is especially important if you have had more than one negative thing happen.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Oftentimes, the unconscious reaction is to become numb and avoid all feelings, especially if more than one negative event occurred.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: A big part of what causes people trouble are feelings of guilt.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: We often blame ourselves when bad things happen.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: It is actually difficult to comprehend the concept that we don't always have control of what happens in life.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: In addition, when you mentioned feeling like a sociopath, it sounded like you feel like your reaction is wrong.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: The first thing you can do is realize that your feelings and reactions are o.k., you aren't doing anything wrong, and nothing is wrong with you.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: The next step is to start dealing with the impact of these traumatic experiences.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Identifying your feelings, and knowing the thoughts and beliefs that are behind those emotions can help you regain your sense of happiness.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: Research shows that understanding and expressing those thoughts and feelings can help.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: If doesn't sound like you need to do anything to change yourself, but talking to a counselor can be helpful in managing your reaction to a incredibly traumatic experience.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: I hope this helps you understand your feelings and can get to a place where you enjoy life.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: speaker
text: I was raped a couple months ago, Since then, along with other unfortunately events that have occurred, I have been having trouble feeling emotions. It's almost as if I'm a sociopath lacking any feeling. What can I do to change this?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: First and foremost, be gentle and patient with yourself.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?
author: listener
text: It is normal to feel a range of emotions after a severe trauma including no emotions at all.

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?

title: Is it possible for a person to stop feeling emotions?

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: speaker
text: I have been diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder due to my military experiences. Not a year ago, I had a car accident. Could this experience add more problems?

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: You are right on to recognize that the effects of trauma can be cumulative.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: It is very possible that a car accident could lead to an increase in PTSD symptoms that were related to other traumatic experiences.If you have been deployed to a combat area, you are most likely eligible for free counseling services through the VA Vet Centers.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: The Vet Center clinicians typically have a lot of experience working with military trauma.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Here's a link to a directory of Vet Centers:http://www.va.gov/directory/guide/vetcenter.aspYour service and sacrifice is greatly appreciated.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: speaker
text: I have been diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder due to my military experiences. Not a year ago, I had a car accident. Could this experience add more problems?

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: A car accident can be scary and possibly trigger your symptoms of PTSD.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: It is good that you recognize the possibility of this occurring.Not everyone who experiences a car accident develops PTSD.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: The chances are definitely increased due to your prior diagnosis during military service.Some of the things to be mindful of for yourself include:1.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Feelings of anxiety and increased heart rate when you're faced with reminders of the event.2.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Feeling a little more on edge when you're driving.3.Being more watchful.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: You're more likely to scan your environment for potential sources of threats.4.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Avoidance.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Because of the anxiety that often follows an accident, it's natural that you may want to avoid some situations or experience hesitation at times.If you experience any of these symptoms or feel other symptoms of PTSD it would be advisable to seek help possibly through your local VA Medical Clinic or a private practitioner.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: There are certain modalities such as EMDR that can help with your symptoms.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: speaker
text: I have been diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder due to my military experiences. Not a year ago, I had a car accident. Could this experience add more problems?

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: There are many types of traumas, and they certainly can compound on one another as you experience them.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Without treating the traumas, or incidents where you felt there was a significant risk to your safety or that of others, there can be a cumulative effect.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: What we have learned in the mental health field from studying traumas, is that the body as a whole responds to these stressors in order to keep you safe during the events.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: If the body does not realize that it no longer needs to respond in this way because the event is now over, and then receives a trigger from a new event, it makes sense that the new event could cause additional issues.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Both of these events can be addressed with the help of a Counselor.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: There are many Counselors that specialize in trauma inside and outside of the VA, so shop around if you are able and find someone that you connect with.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: speaker
text: I have been diagnosed with posttraumatic stress disorder due to my military experiences. Not a year ago, I had a car accident. Could this experience add more problems?

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder can occur after any traumatic event where a real and present threat of harm or loss of life to yourself or others is present.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Yes, a car accident could increase PTSD symptoms such as hyper-vigilance, anxiety, nightmares, re-playing the event, etc.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: Depending on the severity of the accident new triggers might exist.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
author: listener
text: This is not to say that you cannot recover.

title: Could a car accident add more problems to my posttraumatic stress disorder?
