title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: speaker
text: I was the one who ended it, and I'm so glad I did. It was the best decision I made in my life. But how do I stop the nightmares and flashbacks? It is creating a wall in my current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Ending an abusive relationship is often very difficult, especially if you were very close initially without the presence of abuse.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: If the abuse included verbal or psychological condemnation, you will often have a negative self-image that you may "know" is not true but often feels very true.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: This negative self-image and fear of being abused again can activate protections in you that were needed at the time you were abused but now create a "wall" in your current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: The fact that you were able to end the relationship and know that you made the right decision is a great acknowledgement that you have solid internal resources to draw upon in healing from the abuse.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Good for you!Nightmares and flashbacks are a strong sign of memories, including associated beliefs, emotions, and physical sensations, that have remained unprocessed and therefore unhealed.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: There are likely reminders (called triggers) of the past abuse that are being activated in your current relationship that are allowing these unhealed memories to come to the surface and affect both your sleep and your waking experiences.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: This is certainly not something you are purposefully doing but is the result of what happened to you.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: However, you likely feel as if you are not in control.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: The goal is protect your current relationship, evaluate your self-image for flaws in beliefs and feelings, and begin working on healing your memories of abuse.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: In many cases, my use of EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing) would be helpful in reducing the emotional strength of your abuse memories, reduce or eliminate triggers, bring healing, and allow you to enjoy being in the present with your current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: I would recommend discussing with your current partner your harmful past experiences, your decision to pursue counseling, and your strong desire to be healthy for your current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: With a good support network in place, healing is very possible.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: speaker
text: I was the one who ended it, and I'm so glad I did. It was the best decision I made in my life. But how do I stop the nightmares and flashbacks? It is creating a wall in my current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: One thing you could try to do on your own is to focus on the partner who is in front of you now.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: If you are able to connect with them via touch or focusing on their tone of voice, that may help to center you.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Tried to stay grounded and/or mindful.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: That is being aware of your position in the room, your feet on the floor, your hands in your lap, or your hips in the chair.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Being mindful of the environment you are currently (for example, noticing what is around you) may be helpful.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Try to use all your senses.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: For example, you could focus on hearing your husband's voice, feeling his hand in yours, being wrapped in your favorite blanket, seeing a comforting photo, using a comforting sense or candle, or tasting an apple that reminds you of times when you have enjoyed yourself in the kitchen.It also sounds like you are having a very specific reaction that could very well be related to trauma.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: I would recommend that you talk with a local mental health professional.Remember, just because it was the best decision of your life, that doesn't mean that what happened to you or in your presence automatically leaves you when you leave the relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Our brain is actually hardwired to remember things that have caused us pain or great emotional distress as a way of protecting us from them happening again.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: This is a very natural response and the reactions you have as far as nightmares and flashbacks are the past coming forward and your brain trying to make sense of it all.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: speaker
text: I was the one who ended it, and I'm so glad I did. It was the best decision I made in my life. But how do I stop the nightmares and flashbacks? It is creating a wall in my current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: EMDR therapy has shown great results for work with PTSD symptoms which are similar to what you described.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: If you are unable to find a local EMDR specialist then I would suggest some meditation and journaling in addition to talk therapy to process your trauma.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Your anxiety response centers int he brain are in hyper vigilance mode and retraining to turn down that response could be helpful for you.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: speaker
text: I was the one who ended it, and I'm so glad I did. It was the best decision I made in my life. But how do I stop the nightmares and flashbacks? It is creating a wall in my current relationship.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Your challenge is called "co-dependency."

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: People seek approval from others in an obsessive way when they are failing to truly accept themselves.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: I encourage you to truly love yourself and know that you have every right to every sensation, emotion, thought, and inspiration that you may have.

title: I have nightmares and flashbacks about a past relationship
author: listener
text: Best of luck on your journey.

title: How do I deal with my trauma?
author: speaker
text: I was a victim of an incident. I've been made fun of and have been beating myself up for it because I don't feel anyone honestly believes me. There are so many other factors I deal with on a daily basis. I ignore my problems when I'm with my friends, but it’s scary when I’m alone.

title: How do I deal with my trauma?
author: listener
text: As you seemed to have learned, the impact will not just "go away".

title: How do I deal with my trauma?
author: listener
text: Treatment of trauma is like surgery, it requires a skillful clinician to help resolve it.

title: How do I deal with my trauma?
author: listener
text: While you are contemplating getting help, you can focus on calming techniques like meditation and yoga.

title: How do I deal with my trauma?
author: listener
text: They will aid you when you begin the therapeutic process.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: speaker
text: I'm fine when we start becoming intimate, but out of nowhere, I will get a flashback of what happened to me in the past. I start hysterically crying and freaking out when my boyfriend obviously has done nothing to hurt me.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: Have you sought the support of a therapist really qualified in working through sexual trauma?

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: It can take some work, but healing is possible.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: If you feel able to, it may also help to open a dialogue with your boyfriend about what you need from him when you have these flashbacks.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: Let him know what some helpful responses may be.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: speaker
text: I'm fine when we start becoming intimate, but out of nowhere, I will get a flashback of what happened to me in the past. I start hysterically crying and freaking out when my boyfriend obviously has done nothing to hurt me.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: Sexual intimacy can be very triggering for survivors even when it is both wanted and consensual.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: You may want to consider seeing a therapist who specializes in trauma to work through the abuse if you have not already done so.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: Often times triggers still hold such a powerful effect when the emotions related to the abuse  have not been fully processed.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: In the meantime, you may want to consider coming up with a Safe Word to let your partner know that you are being triggered or to communicate your physical boundaries to him.

title: How can I have a normal sex life with my significant other when I keep having triggers from past sexual abuse?
author: listener
text: Often times, the experience of communicating  your physical boundaries to your partner, having those boundaries respected and validated, and having a partner who is understanding and  willing to engage in intimacy in such a way that does not violate your physical boundaries  can reinforce a sense of safety with him.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: speaker
text: As a child, my parents injured my brother, so they went to prison. I was there when he had gotten hurt, but I can't seem to remember. I also can't remember being with them quite well. It's a blur.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: listener
text: It's important to know that there are counselors who are trained in working with survivors of trauma and you can get help.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: listener
text: The "blur" in your memories is your brain's attempt to protect you from the experiences in your past.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: listener
text: To recover them can be a slow process done by a trained professional that you trust.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: listener
text: When you are ready and feel safe, those memories can be recovered and can be integrated with other memories.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: listener
text: This will help to lessen the potency of the memory, help to make sense of what has happened, and allow you to begin the healing process.

title: How can I unblock my memories?
author: listener
text: Check into therapist who are trained in EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing).

title: Should we put off kids until my husband is mentally cured?
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend is seeking therapy. He is in his 40s and has some childhood issues. He has kids from his previous ex-wife and is unable to see them.

title: Should we put off kids until my husband is mentally cured?
author: listener
text: Probably the more important questions to answer concern how much confidence you have in you and your boyfriend becoming parents, how you each feel about the influence of his being banned from seeing his current children, and be clear about the circumstances that led up to the decision of him not being permitted to see his kids.Don't allow some random professional to pronounce your boyfriend as cured.

title: Should we put off kids until my husband is mentally cured?
author: listener
text: A relatively qualified therapist would never make this call.Psychological and emotional tensions emerge from our relationships within families.

title: Should we put off kids until my husband is mentally cured?
author: listener
text: You and your boyfriend are in a position to set a strong foundation for having children, assuming each of you wants children.Childhood issues, your boyfriend's, anyone's, are more likely to go away when new patterns of interacting emerge.If the two of you are engaged in setting a secure relationship as future parents, the disappointments and hurt from the very early years, will be replaced by better ways of interacting.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: speaker
text: An organization admitted to implanting thoughts in my head with technologies. The study was to implant a fantasy other people are having, but to me, it's a nightmare. I lost my kids, my job, and all that. I was an unwilling participant. I no longer trust a therapist. I'm too afraid to go under hypnosis or anything.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: Given your experience of being imposed upon against your will, and all the personal and professional loss that has come since, your fear of what will happen if you undergo treatment and trust a therapist is understandable.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: There is no technique or pill that can guarantee these thoughts will go away or be reversed, however, there are things that you can do which may help you to change your relationship to the thoughts and to the distress that they cause.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: I understand that working with a therapist sounds risky, given your experiences, and at the same time a good therapist may be a beneficial resource in helping you deal with the intrusive thoughts, cope with and alleviate the stress that they create, and perhaps even lead to the alleviation of the thoughts themselves.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: A therapist may also be able to help you discover strategies to work towards any goals you have around reconnecting with your children and working again.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: If therapy feels too unsafe at the moment, I would recommend looking into workbooks on how to deal with intrusive thoughts and coping with stress.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: Some popular approaches that you may want to look into are mindfulness techniques, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy.

title: Can implanted thoughts be reversed at all?
author: listener
text: You may even be able to find some of these resources at a library, if affordability is an obstacle.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: speaker
text: I have an emotionally abusive relationship. We have been together for a year and a half. He got out of prison exactly a year ago and a half ago, and we have a infant. I love my boyfriend, and I don't want to leave without fighting for this first. He's an emotionally disconnected person. We never say “I love you” to each other. Every fight is worse than the last one, and I don't know what to do. He doesn't let me speak because he's louder than me, and that makes me feel frustrated. I have another problem: English is my second language. I pay half of the bills, and every time I want to speak to him, he kicks me out of the house. He apologizes sometimes. I feel like I'm the only one fighting for this. He agreed to have counseling.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: I’m glad that you are reaching out for help.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: All of this sounds overwhelming and confusing.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: All of what you discribed is common in an abusive relationship.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, there isn’t anything you can do that will change his behavior.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: He has to make that decision for himself.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: It is difficult for abusers to do this because they have to admit that thier behavior is fully thier responsibility.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: Abusers, a lot of times, will say they’re sorry or make promises to change and then turn around and become abusive again.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: I would strongly discourage any couples counseling because in an abusive relationship this can become very dangerous for the victim.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: Individual therapy for both of you you be a safer rout.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: I would also encourage you to reach out to a domestic violence non profit near you because they can help you safety plan and provide counseling if you want it.

title: How can I help my boyfriend's anger issues?
author: listener
text: Here is some information on the cycle of violence that might be helpful for you  http://www.bfwc.org/pdf/Cycle%20of%20Violence.pdfI hope you are safe and I wish you the best.

title: I'm just not happy with my marriage
author: speaker
text: He is verbally abusive. When he gets mad, he just yells at me. At times, I feel scared.

title: I'm just not happy with my marriage
author: listener
text: Good for you on recognizing your own feelings.

title: I'm just not happy with my marriage
author: listener
text: Often in an abusive relationship, the person who is being abused, starts doubting themselves and starts tolerating, then accepting abuse.Marriage is based in love and feeling taken care of by the partner.

title: I'm just not happy with my marriage
author: listener
text: Feeling scared is the opposite of this.If you feel ready, tell him the way you feel and pay attention to how willing your husband is to being aware that he yells and that you feel scared.If he has no idea of what you're talking about, doesn't want to understand what you feel, then slowly take steps to understand within yourself whether or not tolerating your husband's behavior is acceptable to live with on an everyday basis.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: speaker
text: My kid’s dad and I broke up two years ago. He still wants me back, and I just started to fall for him again. But our kids are with Child Protective Services: that’s why we broke up. He started to talk to other women, and he put his hands on me.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: What you are experiencing is common with survivors of abusive relationships.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: Even abusive relationships have positive moments in them and typically for survivors those are things they still love and care about of the abuser.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: A lot of it could also be grief over the loss of the relationship and also your children.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: A lot of time people return to thier abuser because that’s the only support that they have.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: If this is something you are going through I would encourage you to seek out a domestic violence non profit in your area because they can provide you with additional support.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: I don’t know the whole situation but keep in mind that abusers will make promises and say what they think the other person wants to hear to get them to return.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: Attached is an example of what I am talking about: http://www.bfwc.org/pdf/Cycle%20of%20Violence.pdfBased on what you decide I would encourage you to keep  caution and boundaries.

title: I'm falling for my abusive and cheating ex-boyfriend
author: listener
text: It might be helpful to safety plan with a domestic violence non profit.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: speaker
text: I'm in college currently, so I am not a direct victim anymore. My father is very abusive with his words and actions, and my siblings are getting treated horribly.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Yes you can help!

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Emotional and verbal abuse can cause a negative impact in your family.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: It is important that you encourage your siblings to seek assistance with a therapist, and maybe help them find one, they should have school counselors available and if not our college counselor may help you to get referrals.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: It’s also a good idea to talk to your mom about the issue and ask her if she would like help as well.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: If you are concerned about your siblings' safety, contact Family Protective Services in your state, they will investigate and refer your father to classes or therapy as needed.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: It takes courage to do the right thing, you can do this!¿Hay algo que pueda hacer para ayudar a mis hermanos a escapar de nuestro emocionalmente abusivo padre?Actualmente estoy en la universidad, así que no soy victima directamente.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Mi padre es muy abusivo con sus palabras y acciones, y trata a mis hermanos horriblemente.¡Tu si puedes ayudar!

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: El abuso emocional y verbal puede causar daños graves en la familia.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Es importante que motives a tus hermanos a visitar e incluso encontrar a un terapista, la escuela debe tener uno disponible, y también puedes pedirle referidos a tu Consejero universitario.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: También es buena idea que hables con tu mama al respecto y le preguntes si a ella le gustaría buscar ayuda.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Si te preocupa la seguridad de tus hermanos, contacta a el Departamento de Protección a la Familia en tu estado para reportar el abuso.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Ellos investigaran y determinaran si el hogar es un ambiente seguro par tus hermanos y recomendaran terapia o clases para tu papa.

title: Is there anything I can do to help my siblings escape our emotionally abusive father?
author: listener
text: Hay que ser valiente para hacer lo correcto, ¡tú puedes hacerlo!

title: Is my therapist telling my abuser the results of my test a HIPAA violation?
author: speaker
text: After a domestic abuse situation, I went to a therapist, and then my husband went. The therapist discussed her assessment of borderline personality disorder with me. She then told my abuser the results of my tests.

title: Is my therapist telling my abuser the results of my test a HIPAA violation?
author: listener
text: It sounds like it may have been a violation of confidentiality for your therapist to disclose information about you without your permission.

title: Is my therapist telling my abuser the results of my test a HIPAA violation?
author: listener
text: There are some exceptions to the general rule of confidentiality however.

title: Is my therapist telling my abuser the results of my test a HIPAA violation?
author: listener
text: For example, when a therapist has a reasonable concern that a client (or someone else) is in imminent danger, he or she is generally allowed to disclose confidential information to protect that person.If you believe your counselor has violated your confidentiality, you can always contact your states' counseling regulatiory board.

title: Is my therapist telling my abuser the results of my test a HIPAA violation?
author: listener
text: The board will then investigate the allegations and can take appropriate action.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: speaker
text: My husband and I have been together for seven years now. I will be honest: I have a problem lying to him about stupid stuff. I recently stupidly lied to my husband about an accident because I was afraid to tell him what happened. Ever since then, he gives me the cold shoulder. He gets so mad and ignores me for days. He's really verbally and emotionally abusive. He tells me all the bad things about me and calls me awful names. Should we call it quits? I'm tired of crying, but we have a toddler together.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: Hi Texas, Thanks for your honesty; it helps me know where to go in answering you.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: What strikes me in your question is that you describe several ways in which your husband is hurtful/abusive/controlling with you, and then you ask "Should we call it quits?".

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: We?

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: I wonder if maybe the first step is for you to start seeing this decision as yours, rather than yours together.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: The way your husband treats you is not your fault, Texas.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: Your lies are a natural and normal way of you avoiding situations and encounters that feel unsafe for you.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: The problem is not your lying.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: The problem is that you don't feel safe enough to be honest with a person you're supposed to be able to trust.There's an analogy that I sometimes use; I don't know if this is scientifically true or simply a useful story, but it's powerful either way, so I will tell it to you.If you take a frog and drop it into a pot of boiling water, the frog will jump out immediately, knowing instinctively that if it stays in the pot, it will die.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: If you take a frog, however, and put it in a pot of cold water, and slowly, slowly, heat it to boiling, the frog will boil to death because it will fail to recognise the moment when it no longer has the energy to jump out of the pot; by the time it realises it's dying, it has lost its strength.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: It's called "learned helplessness".

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: When your power or your voice has been taken away for a long time, you get used to that, and you fail to see the options that are available to you.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: You have a toddler, and you may be under the impression that staying in the marriage is best for the child.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: In my experience, and what research backs up, is that children first and foremost need a safe environment and parents who are happy.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: You are likely underestimating the effects on your child of living in a home with woman abuse.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: This is a complex picture, and if you were my client, I would want to get you to a stronger place emotionally where you're seeing the situation clearly and gathering resources and supports before you make any big decisions, but I do see that there are decisions that are there for you to make that can lead to a happy life for you and your child.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: I sincerely hope you seek professional help, with either a shelter for abused women or a therapist.

title: My husband treats me terribly
author: listener
text: I wish you the best.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: speaker
text: I have anger issues that have worsened over the years because I’ve never dealt with my emotions. My anger has never been expressed physically until the past year. My girlfriend has had to endure these episodes. I love her, and I think I’m about to lose her, if I already haven’t. I throw things at her when I’m angry, and sometimes I hit her. I may not hit her enough to cause harm, but I still physically lash out at her. I don’t want to lose her, and I don’t want the situation to worsen. I am a lesbian in my early 30s, and I have been dealing with anger since my childhood. I'm ready to change. I need help now. I'm about to explode.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Hi Baton Rouge,I'm glad you're reaching out.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: The first step here is that you are taking some responsibility for your behaviours.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: I do hear you minimizing your actions (you say you don't "hit her enough to cause harm"?

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: ), but you're headed in the right direction.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: I hope that in your pursuit of treatment you learn that the harm you're causing isn't just superficial bruising.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: The effects of using aggression and anger to control a person are deep and lasting wounds.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Please seek treatment for yourself immediately.You say you love your girlfriend?

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Do you love her enough to leave the relationship while you address your issues?

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Are you brave enough to not lean on this relationship while you learn how to create a safe place for a partner?You have dangerous habits because you don't know how to manage your own emotional pain.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: You can unlearn this; and it doesn't mean you're a bad person.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Sometimes, however, the relationship in which you have done the hurting is best ended, for both of your sakes, because too much damage has been done.I know you don't want to lose her, but you don't own her, and you don't have the right to trap her in this because you're afraid of being alone.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Right now, she needs some space to figure out what's best for her and the freedom to make whatever decision she wants.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: This is potentially the first step to learning real respect; honouring her need for safety above your need for comfort.

title: I want to stop physically abusing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: I wish you well.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: speaker
text: I've been with my boyfriend over 3 years. He cheated on me and the woman is now pregnant. He is physically and mentally abusive towards me. I have attempted to talk with him in order to resolve our issues; however, he never wants to talk and often blames me for everything. I’m always there when he needs my help. He tells me although I help him doesn’t mean that I am a good person. He always discredits me as a woman and it’s hurtful. I spend most day crying and feeling lonely. I am unhappy and unsure of what I need to do.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: That sounds like a very hurtful situation.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, without a batterers intervention course or a desire to change, the abuse cycle is unlikely to stop.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: I do not recommend that you try to leave on your own due that being the most dangerous time when in an abusive relationship.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: As an abuser, his goal is to control you whether it's through mental or verbal means.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: I recommend that you contact a domestic violence shelter in your area.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: I have worked closely with Harbor House of Central Florida and know they provide housing, transportation, and any other needed resources to women leaving an abusive relationship.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: There is help out there and you are not alone.

title: How do I get out of an abusive relationship?
author: listener
text: If you need any additional resources in your area, please don't hesitate to contact me.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: speaker
text: Now I have anger and trust issues. How can I treat this and fix myself?

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: I will assume that for whatever reason, you either do not want to or are not able to seek counseling for this.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: However, I highly urge you to do so because long-term childhood abuse does have negative consequences for your life as an adult, as it seems you are already aware.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: There are confidential and free crisis hotlines that you can call that deal with sexual abuse.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Some/most also offer free counseling services in local areas.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: That would be a good place to start looking, especially if cost of counseling is an issue.The important thing to know is that what happened was not your fault and that you deserve to live a happy life free of the past.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Having anger and trust issues after something like this is a perfectly normal reaction to what happened to you.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Angry?

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Yes!

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: At your brother for what he did, at your parents for not protecting you.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Having trouble trusting?

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Of course!

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: The very people who were supposed to love and protect you hurt you instead.

title: I endured sexual and physical abuse by my brother as child
author: listener
text: Two books that might help you are Codependent No More and Boundaries: Where You End and I Begin.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: speaker
text: I snap easy and push people away. I need help before I push my boyfriend away.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: Meditation may be able to assist you in dealing and looking at your anger differently.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: Anger is not usually just anger.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: Behind our anger may lie rejection, grief, loneliness, a longing to reconnect, etc.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: When we ignore or repress our anger, we are always ignoring these other emotions as well.Meditation is the midpoint between expressing and repressing anger.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: It allows us a space to stay present with it as it arises and recognize the many faces of anger.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: By doing this, we are able to become aware of our feelings to learn more about them and not be swept away by them.

title: How can I control myself and my anger?
author: listener
text: Learn more here: https://www.therapybyshannon.com/blog-2/2019/4/26/meditate-to-manage-anger

title: How do I not be angry all the time?
author: speaker
text: My roommate is a unapologetic person who doesn't care who she hurts. She never apologizes to me or my family. She made me lose my temper today to the point where I was using swear words in front of my mom and brother.

title: How do I not be angry all the time?
author: listener
text: Must you keep this roommate in your life?If you've tried speaking with the person about your unhappiness to feel angry "all the time" , the problem has been going on for an extended amount of time and nothing changes, then the next step would be for both of you to part ways.It is possible each of you triggers the other in very deep and irrational ways on occasion.If the choice is to tolerate being triggered or to dissolve the relationship, then your decision is which of these two choices is better for you.Since you already know you don't like to be triggered, parting ways as soon as reasonably possible, seems the choice you prefer.Either choice is fine.

title: How do I not be angry all the time?
author: listener
text: Let the decision depend on which way makes you feel life is livable and happy!

title: How can I control my temper?
author: speaker
text: I get angry and act out. It scares my wife and child.

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: Yes you can..

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: If you cannot control your temper, who can?

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: You have more power of your emotions, thoughts and feeling than you are giving yourself credit for.

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: If this is scaring your wife and child, you need to get control of it immediately.

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: Try going to an anger management class.

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: It will help to discover what is the root cause of your anger, what triggers it and how you can control/manage it.

title: How can I control my temper?
author: listener
text: If you can't go to a class, try self help books or even better yet counseling and support of a professional counselor.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: speaker
text: Sometime when small thing happen, like losing a comb, I get furious. I even start throwing things. Do I have a problem?

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: Anger does have its place.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: When anger is experienced often or the magnitude of it does not fit the scenario, such as your losing comb, the question becomes, what does losing that comb mean to you?

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: In the very split second that you have realized the comb is missing, there is a reaction that occurs within you, accompanied by an image or thought that like lightening flashes so quickly that you may not be aware what it is.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: As Sherry noted below, awareness.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: Awareness is fundamental.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: Becoming aware of ourselves and what is happening internal that sparks it off.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: The next time you feel angry from a "small thing", stop and ask yourself, why am I angry that this is lost?

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: Find out what you are thinking or how you are speaking to yourself.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: You will become aware and once you are aware, steps can be taken to alter the experience for the better.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: A professional can assist with that!

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: speaker
text: Sometime when small thing happen, like losing a comb, I get furious. I even start throwing things. Do I have a problem?

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: Anyone who asks whether or not they have a problem, usually feels at least partly, that they do have a problem.Your answer to the question is what matters.Since you already understand that your reaction is overstated to the events which trigger them, the reactions you're having are more than likely anger that is leftover from past events, either in the near or distant past.Be aware, consider, reflect on  how you usually handle feeling angry.

title: Why do I get angry so easily?
author: listener
text: Based on your description here, it is quite likely that the anger you show toward what you call "little things" reflect anger at much bigger matters that are uncomfortable and not easy to understand.Knowing more about the more significant matters causing frustration for you, may very likely decrease reacting angrily toward smaller matters.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: speaker
text: We're in an eight year relationship. My boyfriend drinks a lot. He experienced childhood trauma. I don't know how to deal with violent outbursts.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: You shouldn't need to educate yourself on violent outbursts.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: He is the one in the position to change his violent outbursts.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: They are his behavior, not yours.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: All you're trying to do is have a relationship with this guy.The one task to do is during a quiet time to tell your boyfriend the way you feel about his outbursts.His answer, whether he denies having a problem, blames you for his problem, tells you the problem isn't so bad, why are you complaining, tells you a lot about his willingness to change.Whether or not he considers himself to have a problem and wants to change himself, is very good for you to know.This tells you what to expect from him in future.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: You can reflect and plan ahead for your own life depending on your tolerance and willingness to live with what he answers you.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: speaker
text: We're in an eight year relationship. My boyfriend drinks a lot. He experienced childhood trauma. I don't know how to deal with violent outbursts.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: First, let me extend my compassion to both of you -- it sounds like you have a lot on your plates.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Childhood trauma carries its negative effects into our adulthood and affects everyone who loves us.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Your question is brief, so I'll just try to give general answers as best I can.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: From my experiences treating many people with your boyfriend's experiences, the short, healthy answer is that you can't fix the situation and maybe not even be able to help.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: He needs a professional.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Period.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: What you can do, is take care of yourself.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: With his background, it is not likely that he will be able to help you or take care of you in a healthy way.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Your task needs to prioritize your own safety and well-being.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Trauma and substance abuse are the definition of being out of control, unable to set and manage appropriate boundaries, manage his own emotions and behaviors.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: So your boyfriend is unlikely to be able to change in the near-term, certainly not without professional help.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: You might also benefit from help and support, to understand your own role in your relationship and how you can make changes in your life.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: I am NOT blaming you for any aspect of your boyfriend's behavior, only acknowledging that there are two people in every relationship.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: If you have accepted your boyfriend's drinking and violent outbursts in the past (by staying in the relationship), that is likely to perpetuate his behavior.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: And there isn't any way to "handle violent outbursts."

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: They shouldn't be handled at all, and if you have to be away from your boyfriend during his outbursts in order to be emotionally and physically safe, then that may be what you will have to do.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: We can never really change anyone else.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: The only person we can change is ourselves.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Sometimes our behavior changes the odds of another person's behaviors, but it doesn't control it.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: I would recommend that you work with a professional to first, ensure your own safety above all.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Then make decisions about what behavior you are willing to accept or be connected to, and which you want to separate from.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Whatever your boyfriend does in his life, you will be happier if you manage your own feelings, set boundaries, etc.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Let me say again that you also would benefit from some good insight and support as you continue your journey.

title: How do I deal with my alcoholic boyfriend with a dark past?
author: listener
text: Wishing you and your boyfriend healing and recovery.

title: My girlfriend always brings up past events and talks negatively about them
author: speaker
text: Any time things get heated, the past gets brought up. I raise my voice at her to try to get a point across. She asks open-ended questions but always has to turn my own answer against me. She's seven months pregnant. I have drank in the past, but I'm not dependent on alcohol—I only drink at social events.

title: My girlfriend always brings up past events and talks negatively about them
author: listener
text: Have you tried to talk about the subjects of the past, in the present at a time in which there is no heat between the two of you?Since your gf would like to resolve situations from the past the best way to do so would be to talk about them.

title: My girlfriend always brings up past events and talks negatively about them
author: listener
text: The more you try to avoid certain subjects the more likely they will come up between you at worse possible moments.If you can get ahead of the pattern of old topics coming up without your control, then try scheduling a discussion about them.

title: My girlfriend always brings up past events and talks negatively about them
author: listener
text: This by itself will show your gf you care about what she cares about and this may be one quality she would feel good about.

title: Why did my boyfriend hit himself in the face during an argument?
author: speaker
text: When I got home, my boyfriend and I got into an argument. He got upset and he started hitting his face. That is the first time he has ever done that, but I would be lying if I said that didn't scare me. I locked myself in the room.

title: Why did my boyfriend hit himself in the face during an argument?
author: listener
text: Sounds scary to watch.

title: Why did my boyfriend hit himself in the face during an argument?
author: listener
text: I agree with you!Maybe he felt so overwhelmed by anger, hurt and frustration that he went back to an old behavior from his past in which someone hit him for having strong emotions.Now that the incident is past, bring up the topic to him so the two of you can discuss it.Just the fact of you having empathy and caring what he was feeling at the time, may be restorative to him.At the very least, you may find out exactly what the answer is to your question as to why he did this in the first place!

title: How can I just be happy and not mad all the time?
author: speaker
text: Everything just makes me upset.

title: How can I just be happy and not mad all the time?
author: listener
text: Anger often comes with a lot of other emotions.

title: How can I just be happy and not mad all the time?
author: listener
text: Consider what else you may be feeling at the same time and keep track of your different mood changes.

title: How can I just be happy and not mad all the time?
author: listener
text: You may be able to notice patterns, such as being more frustrated when you don't sleep well.

title: How can I just be happy and not mad all the time?
author: listener
text: If you do feel as though you are mad all the time, can you think of any exceptions so you can see what is different in those times?

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: speaker
text: My son claims that hes been having extremely violent thoughts and dreams. Not violent like he's hurting someone, but violent thoughts like horrible things happening to his loved ones. He explained one of his dreams the other day and it was so violent it was sickening. It was far beyond anything in a horror movie, he says he can't help these thoughts they just pop up. Please help!

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: If your son is reporting "extremely violent thoughts and dreams" please have an psychological evaluation done by a psychiatrist now before it gets even worse for him to bare.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: Don't take his reports lightly.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: For him  to tell you, he knows that something is not right.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: He is seeking and needing help.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: Get it immediately.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: Best to be safe than sorry.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?

text: My son claims that hes been having extremely violent thoughts and dreams. Not violent like he's hurting someone, but violent thoughts like horrible things happening to his loved ones. He explained one of his dreams the other day and it was so violent it was sickening. It was far beyond anything in a horror movie, he says he can't help these thoughts they just pop up. Please help!

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: Let me start my stating this is important to take seriously - taking to his PCP, getting a referral to a pediatric specialist, and getting him to a relational psychotherapist would be my first tasks.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: I wont label this occurrences as "normal" yet it is important to note these things do occur.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: My first observation is to say that it is a tremendous advantage that your son is communicating what he is experiencing.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: I'd encourage him to continue to do so, no matter the extent of his thoughts - his trust of you being able the handle his experience is of utmost importance.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: His containment and sense of security is also dependent on your reaction to what he shares.

title: How do I deal with my son's violent thoughts and dreams?
author: listener
text: Seek professional help, communicating your support, including a plan of action, and reassuring him you will figure this out together will help you as you begin.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: speaker
text: I been having anger problems a lot lately. It only takes one word wrongly said to set me off. I use to not be like this until I got with my soon-to-be husband. I think his mood and rage/anger problems have rubbed off on me a lot. I don't get nearly as bad as he does, but I yell almost constantly and I can't seem to just stop. I have two young babies that have to hear this, and I don't want my girls growing up with a mommy like I have been lately. I just don't know how to get back to my old self.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: With me knowing that a healthy relationship usually includes respect, trust, appreciation, companionship, spiritual solidarity, domestic support, feeling of being cherished, and  sensuous affection, I am wondering if you are lacking in several if not all of these needs in your present relationship.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: Before he becomes your husband, you should examine these areas and see if they are high in rating.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: Otherwise, yes this relationship will affect your girls and you negatively.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: I would suggest relationship counseling, specifically pre-marital.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: Not be surprised if through the process you realize that this relationship is not the best choice for you and your children.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: speaker
text: I been having anger problems a lot lately. It only takes one word wrongly said to set me off. I use to not be like this until I got with my soon-to-be husband. I think his mood and rage/anger problems have rubbed off on me a lot. I don't get nearly as bad as he does, but I yell almost constantly and I can't seem to just stop. I have two young babies that have to hear this, and I don't want my girls growing up with a mommy like I have been lately. I just don't know how to get back to my old self.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: My gut says that your own rage is being triggered partly because you feel trapped or shutdown by your fiance's moody/angry/rage responses and powerless to stop it.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: You can start by accepting that this is who he is and you won't change him.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: You can only change your own behaviours, and I see you taking responsibility for those, which is great.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: You want to protect your girls, and that's appropriate; children are greatly affected by this type of home environment.

title: How can I deal with the anger problems I've gained from my soon-to-be husband?
author: listener
text: I urge you to see a therapist so you can understand your own emotions and sort out the choices you have to make, knowing that your fiance has to make his own choices about his behaviours.

title: Why am I so mad?
author: speaker
text: My issue isn't resisting angry urges; it's the anger itself. My rage is extreme and vastly disproportionate to the direct stressor. It causes violent thoughts, but I never act. I stay lucid enough to know the rage is violent, not me. I don't want to drown myself in anger and resentment.

title: Why am I so mad?
author: listener
text: Knowing how you feel and also being able to stabilize yourself to act upon the tremendous anger you feel, are fine qualities.Anger, whatever the magnitude, generally reflects emotional pain that has not yet been placed into words.Try thinking over your growing up years because maybe you will discover certain repeated dynamics which upset you and that no one helped you feel secure through such times.Also, if either of your parents drank too much and raged when they were drunk, you may be repeating their patterns of how to respond to situations.

title: Why am I so mad?
author: listener
text: Even without drinking, the response patterns of yelling and throwing things are frightening enough to leave a permanent memory.If this describes part of your childhood, then it is possible you are becoming angry because it was the only emotion that either of your parents was able to express.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: speaker
text: Whenever I run into a situation that makes me upset or angry, I tend to start cursing and badly offending the person I am confronting. I say mean things to let my anger out. Whenever people tell me stuff about my relationship (like starting rumors or saying negative things about me or my relationship) I lash out not just them but at my boyfriend. I feel like I keep causing drama due to my personality. I want to be a better person and learn to let things not get to me and be happy and graceful. I hurt the ones I love with my words. I want to be better for myself and them.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Hi California,I'm happy to hear you want to get a hold of this problem.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Relationships don't tend to last when we treat people poorly.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: It is very possible for you to learn different ways of relating, with some strong effort.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: I would highly suggest working with a therapist, and I will give you a few things to think about in the interim.Sometimes anger is there because we feel something is unjust or unfair, but many times, anger is a "secondary emotion", and it's simply there to protect us from other, more vulnerable emotions that we would rather not feel and will do anything to avoid.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Discovering what vulnerable emotions you are protecting yourself from is important.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Perhaps you feel powerless, or unloved, or unimportant.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: It may take some time before you recognise this emotion.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Once you do, you can ask yourself about the other times in your life when you have felt that emotion.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Where did it originate?

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: At what age did you feel "too much" of that feeling...so much so that you can't stand it even in tiny amounts?You will learn in therapy to identify the thoughts you have that are connected to that feeling.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: They are typically incorrect thoughts, like "No one lifes me", or "People will always hurt me".

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Fear tends to generalize and predict bad things that aren't likely.Your habit is so strong that you likely have a poor sense of self-worth and you don't believe people will love you...so you hurt them to keep them at a distance.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: This happens in a subconscious level.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Do you see how that would help you to keep people off balance or afraid or a distance away if you didn't believe in your worth?

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: So, it's backwards really, because you think you're getting mad at people who "piss you off", but you're really just not wanting to face how mad you are at yourself.In addition to this work, you can start to purposely treat people more kindly.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: Find out what respect is, make amends and  resolve to spreading peace.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: It might sound too simple, but if you act as though you're a person of peace, you will start to feel more peaceful.But I hope you do contact a therapist.

title: How can I control myself and learn to let things go or communicate?
author: listener
text: It will take time and support to reach your goal.

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: speaker
text: I don't know how to notice or express my feelings besides anger. That's really the only one i feel.

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: listener
text: Well, then give yourself some credit for noticing that you recognize at least one feeling that you have!What is your own theory as to what is difficult to know your feelings?

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: listener
text: Your answer will give you clues as to unearthing your willingness to be aware of the way you feel.Sometimes the family in which someone grew up, did all they could to stop the kids from knowing who they were.In some families there were very severe consequences if a child spoke up with an independent mind.

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: listener
text: By knowing where your difficulties started, you may very well be able to release the situation in which you learned to suppress your feelings.Also, spend some time with yourself just enjoying who you are.

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: listener
text: Often, people who have difficulty in expressing themselves, suffered shame and humiliation as a child.

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: listener
text: They have a chronic sense of worthlessness, and feeling worthless certainly works against self-expression.

title: How can I be less confused about my feelings towards anything?
author: listener
text: By having a good time being with yourself, you may increase your self-appreciation and this will go a long way to believing that your feelings are worth knowing and stating.

title: I need to know how to cope with misophonia before I go completely insane
author: speaker
text: The sounds of eating and breathing gives me headaches—mostly mouth breathing and snoring. It makes me angry, and I want to solve it myself.

title: I need to know how to cope with misophonia before I go completely insane
author: listener
text: Probably good to know in what type of situations you are, in which you are hearing mouth breathing and snoring.If you're sleeping beside your partner who does these actions, would have a different response than if you overhear mouth breathing and snoring from a family member who is napping on the couch and you are walking past them on your way to take a snack in the kitchen.Basically, if the person who does these actions which bother you, start by telling them.Depending on whether they are empathetic to how distressed you are from their sounds, or not, willing to change, or not, has a good deal to do with next steps.I don't really see any step you're able to take to solve that you are sensitive to human sounds from the head.One path I don't recommend is expecting yourself to ignore the fact of being feeling bothered, or dismissing your own sensitivity someone.Your needs matter.

title: How can I control my anger?
author: speaker
text: I have a really bad temper. I get mad very easily then stay like that the whole day. I don't mean to be that way, but I can't help it.

title: How can I control my anger?
author: listener
text: A lot of times the anger someone expresses is from feeling a deep level hurt within themselves.

title: How can I control my anger?
author: listener
text: A surface situation, like, a store told you they'd have delivery of a certain item by Tuesday, and when that particular Tuesday comes, the store doesn't have what they told you they would, and you are furious.The fury may have more with many times before in your life, having been deeply let down by someone who mattered to your life at the time, who similarly promised something and failed to deliver whatever it.If at the time of feeling let down by someone important in your life, the relationship didn't allow for honest expression of all your emotions, you'd have learned to hold in what you realized would not be tolerated if you expressed it clearly.Without practice of being heard when feeling hurt by someone, eventually the person, possibly you, learned to contain and contain your emotions.It is possible that the anger you feel at a variety of situations lately, are muting hurt feelings that you've understood from relating to meaningful people in your personal history, to not talk about.As a way to find out if you feel other emotions in addition to anger, take some time to reflect on what triggered your anger and whether its possible that hurt emotions which nobody whom you know wants to hear,  are really the underlying source of your upset.I hope you will enjoy some new discoveries about yourself and your emotions!

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: speaker
text: I don't know what's with me. I'm almost constantly angry. Even when I'm happy, I still feel anger inside me. When I acknowledge it, it ruins my mood and takes over. I get angry at the littlest things. Even if I think someone said something they didn't, it infuriates me. Something perfectly normal can make me go off. When my anger flares up, I get a terrible pain in my chest that lasts for a while. It's like there is a fire constantly burning in my body, and anger is gasoline.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: Hi Nashville, I'm glad you want this to be different.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: It doesn't feel good to be angry all the time, and it's stealing your energy as well as affecting relationships, I'm sure.Working with a therapist, you can learn to recognise the deep emotions that lie underneath the anger.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: It's likely to be either powerlessness or worthlessness, and what happens is this... a small moment in the present touches on an old, tender, bruised emotion that we've simply felt too much of or too strongly in the past.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: We develop ways of avoiding these vulnerable emotions, and anger is one way of doing that.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: So, when someone looks at you in a certain way, or says something, you'd rather be angry than feel powerless, or unimportant (or whatever your kryptonite feeling is).

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: In that moment, your instinct is to blame whatever happened, no matter how small, because that's the thing that happened just before you got mad.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: You fail to recognise that the problem is not the look on that person's face, or the shoe that someone left in front of the door...it's that you can't stand feeling something and you want to avoid it like you want to stamp your foot out if it's on fire.I suggest finding a therapist to work with.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener
text: You can learn to take responsibility for your old emotions and find new ways to manage them.

title: Why am I constantly angry?
author: listener

title: My husband and I can’t talk to each other without arguing
author: speaker
text: Every time I speak, he says I anger him. Also, when he’s mad at something, like work, he gets angry at me. I feel like we’re so distant from each other now. We used to laugh all the time, and I feel like he lets too much negativity in. What should I do? We've been married for two years but together for seven.

title: My husband and I can’t talk to each other without arguing
author: listener
text: Hi, Newark.

title: My husband and I can’t talk to each other without arguing
author: listener
text: It sounds to me like your husband is going through something, and I think you understand that.
