title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager. I get random spurts of anger, like complete, pure rage. I figured it was hormones, but others notice it too. I get self-destructive. I used to cut but stopped. Now when I get mad, I bite my arms and fingers, pull my hair, scratch my face, or punch my thighs. Basically, I do things I can hide instead of breaking anything in my room and having to explain it to my mom. I don't live in a bad household. I have a great family, a great relationship with my boyfriend, and a good job. I have no idea what this is and I don't know how to control it. It's over any little thing. Tonight, it was because I couldn't get my earrings out. This happens maybe two to three times on a good week, and it's always over stupid, petty things.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: Hi.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: I'm glad you wrote.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: In general, when a small thing bothers us (and this happens to all of us), it's because the small thing triggers an emotion in us that we have felt "too much" or "too intensely" in the past, and we don't know how to manage that emotion effectively...we just want to avoid it as quickly as possible.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy with a qualified therapist can help you to understand what is being triggered in you and learn how to manage emotions productively.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: You say that your behaviours are self destructive, and I agree.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you have developed a habit of channelling your distress towards self-harm, and this is a separate and potentially more serious problem.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: This is a choice you make that points to shame being an issue for you.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: Again, a good therapist can help you learn what's behind your shame and self-harm.

title: Why do I get random spurts of anger over petty things?
author: listener
text: Your feelings are normal, and you can learn more healthy ways to deal with them with qualified help.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: speaker
text: I easily recognize this but have no control over it and need suggestions for managing my anger.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: I suggest that you work on emotional awareness.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Emotional awareness basically means knowing what you are feeling and why.Emotional awareness also means that you can identify the link between the way you are feeling and your actions.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: In other words knowing that your feelings dictate what you do.Often feelings of hurt or insecurity can come out as anger if we cannot properly identify and express the feelings.Being emotionally aware also means that you are able to express your feelings to others.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Being unable to do so leads to feelings of frustration and being misunderstood.Many people for many different reasons are not in touch with their emotions.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: For example, men traditionally have been brought up taught to not express sadness or weakness.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Therefore, many men learned to turn feelings of sadness, insecurities, or fears into anger and express these feelings as anger.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Being taught not to feel a certain emotion does not make that emotion disappear.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Instead it makes us learn how to express it in other, incorrect, ways.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: If a man never learns to say “I am sad” or “that really hurt my feelings” and instead lashes out in anger, then the response they get from those around them will be to the anger and not a response to the underlying true feeling, which will leave the man feeling alone and misunderstood.You can control yourself and not explode.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Walk away, remove yourself from the situation, do whatever you have to do to not lash out.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Instead of reacting the way you normally would, go somewhere by yourself and think about what just happened and try to understand why such a “simple” thing upset you.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: What is the real feeling driving these outbursts?

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Maybe you can begin to recognize an underlying pattern.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: It might help to keep an anger journal.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Write down everything that gets you upset.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: That might help you see a pattern and pinpoint what may be setting you off.

title: I have anger issues. I am extremely explosive about the simplest things
author: listener
text: Talking with a therapist about this would be beneficial in helping pinpoint the underlying cause of the outbursts you are experience.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: speaker
text: I have been having horrendous nightmares this whole month.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: There's a narrative approach that we call nightmare "rescripting" that may be helpful.Since we can't really control the nature of our dreams while they're happening, we try to alter them while we are in a waking state.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: In a nutshell, this refers to first writing out in detail the events of a recurring nightmare you have.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: Typically, there is an element of fear, danger or helplessness.Second, we rescript the nightmare by changing what happens in the dream in a way that engenders feelings of empowerment, control, competence, and/or safety.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: In other words, if the nightmare involved being pursued or assaulted, we might change the events of the story so that you call the police, get to a place of safety, or even fight back and protect yourself.Third, you can reread this new version of the dream over and over again, so that it becomes a well rehearsed story.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: The effect of this can make it so that the next time your mind goes towards the nightmare while sleeping, this new, more hopeful and empowering story competes with the old one and reduces the level of distress associated with the dream.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: Best of luck!

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: speaker
text: I have been having horrendous nightmares this whole month.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: Are you facing any type of overwhelming situation in your waking life?Dreams and nightmares are the non-logical ways in which we make emotional sense of what goes on in our everyday waking world.Besides having some type of relaxing bedtime routine to set a peaceful mood for your sleep, and avoiding viewing violent films and video games as entertainment, maybe even avoiding news stories which sometimes have similar themes of violence, the content of our dreams and nightmares is out of our direct control.Your nightmares may offer useful clues as to what you're trying to resolve in your life.

title: How do I get rid of my nightmares?
author: listener
text: Pay attention to the story of your nightmare because it reflects how you feel in waking life.If you feel helpless and silenced in your nightmare, or taken advantage of, or whatever dreadful situation goes on during your nightmare, then look for where in waking life, you may feel similar.In this way, you'll become clearer about stressors in your life that you may not have realized existed were it not for the stress of nightmares.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenage girl, and my dad is an alcoholic. I hate being at home with him because he just stresses me out. He can be picking me up from basketball practice or piano lessons, and half of the time, I don't even know if he's sober or not. I refuse to get into the vehicle with him and walk home sometimes. I've either been barely sleeping or I over sleep, so I'm always tired. I live in a small town, so there's no one I can really talk to because I'm not really that close with my family.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
You are clearly a
resourceful young person to reach out like this to find help.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: Good for you.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
I
have a few ideas and perhaps some other counselors will add some thoughts, too.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
First, good for you for taking care of yourself and making
really good decisions – such as not getting into the car with dad when he is
intoxicated.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
It is really important that you consider your safety above all
else.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
To answer your heading question, yes, it is quite common for
people to blame themselves for other people’s actions.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
There are various
reasons why we do this.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: For one thing, someone may tell us that their behaviors are our fault.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
And depending on things like our relationship to that
person, past experiences, and our self-esteem, we may actually start to believe
it.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
What is important to remember is that your parents have the responsibility
to be sure that you are safe and
cared for, not the other way around.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
As for the other things you mentioned, I am concerned about both
your physical and emotional safety and well-being.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
It sounds like your father
has an alcohol abuse problem, and living with someone who is struggling with
addiction can be hard for anyone, let alone a teenager who is also trying to
deal with things like school.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
You may want to see if your school has a counselor or
someone you can talk to about what is going on.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
I will tell you that in some
states, what you have told me may be something that a counselor would have to
report to child protection services, but not necessarily.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
If you are concerned
about that, ask the counselor what they are obligated to report.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
If you don’t know a counselor, think about any other adult
that you would feel comfortable talking to.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: They may have some ideas.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
Sometimes individual states have non-profit chat lines or
hotlines for teens to call if they are struggling with things.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
You may be able
to find something like that in your state.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
I do warn your about doing random
searches, not every website is good, so be careful.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
This is clearly a tough spot for you to be in, so one of the
things that I encourage you to do while searching for support is to focus on
taking care of yourself.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
Sometimes things like this can really bring us down and
we stop doing the things we enjoy.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: Try really hard not to let that happen.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
If
you have interests, do them.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
If you catch yourself thinking too hard about
things, try to find something fun to do to distract yourself.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
Try to take care
of yourself in other ways, such as eating well.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text:
Exercise can really help when
we get stressed.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: I hope some of this was helpful.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: Good luck.

title: Is it normal to blame myself for someone else's actions?
author: listener
text: Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: speaker
text: It takes me a long time to fall asleep; I’d estimate about two hours. I often have nightmares, starting with being eaten by a monster, and I often wake up frightened and unable to breathe. I believe I started losing sleep after breaking up with a girlfriend of 8 years. Also, my father’s business went bankrupt and my mother has a chronic condition. I was under a lot of stress, and life lost meaning. After improving my life and developing a habit of running and exercise to release stress, my symptoms improved. However in the past couple months, I started losing sleep again and having nightmares without warning. How can I solve this issue?

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: First of all, exercise is always beneficial for your physical and emotional health.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: That's great that you have added this in your routine.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Have you also considered altering your diet?

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Certain foods are linked with poor sleep.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: For example, alcohol, caffeine, nicotine and high fat content foods do not bode well with quality sleep, especially right before bed time.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: On the other hand, warm milk and foods high in carbohydrates have actually shown to positively impact sleep.Additionally, at bed time it's important to keep your room dim, cool and without distractions (i.e.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: TV, IPad, Phone).

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Stick to a sleep routine and avoid any activities close to bed time that demand a lot of attention and energy.As far as your nightmares, there could be many causes contributing to them.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Certain foods (many of the ones mentioned) or medications could be the culprit.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Doing a bit of research into the ones you are consuming may help you eliminate the offender.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: You may also benefit from talk therapy with a qualified therapist to discuss any underlying issues you are experiencing.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Oftentimes, depression and anxiety can manifest themselves during sleep, causing nightmares.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Finally, Yoga has shown to be very beneficial for quality sleep.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: There are many instructional videos available that can introduce you to the practice if you'd rather not join a class right away.

title: I’ve suffered from insomnia and nightmares for about 3 years
author: listener
text: Best of luck to you and I sincerely hope you are able to catch up on some well deserved Z's!

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes 3 times a night.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: Perhaps more dreaming means that you are making use of your mind to solve problems.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: I find that change states, while sometimes difficult, are very exciting.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: They give you opportunity to grow more rapidly.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: So I say: "congratulations!"

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: ~Mark (www.MarkMorrisLCSW.com and www.LivingYes.org)

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes 3 times a night.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: Dreams are our chance to make sense of our waking lives.If you've got a lot going on in your life then your dreams are your assistants in understanding these happenings and dynamics.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes 3 times a night.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: As a depth therapist (aka "psychodynamic practitioner"), I do a lot of dream work with clients; and they gain great insights from our explorations.We remember dreams, I believe, because dreams are messages (always in code) from the unconscious, communicating the crux of unresolved conflict between who we are and who we think we are supposed to be.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: You might be remembering so many dreams because your conscious mind is ready to hear these messages...and make some internal changes in response.Write them down!

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: You'll be glad you did.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: A broad cross-section of these these messages will help your therapist help you interpret the meanings of these communications from you to you, and possibly chart your best path forward toward to resolve the cause of psychological symptoms you might be experiencing.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: speaker
text: Sometimes 3 times a night.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: That's a difficult question to answer.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text: Dreaming is a normal (and healthy) part of the sleep cycle.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text:
The current thought is that we all generally
experience roughly the same number of dreams - the difference often is just
whether we remember the dreams or not.An increase in the number or frequency of distressing dreams
(or nightmares) can be a symptom of stress, anxiety, or PTSD.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text:
If the dreams are disturbing to you, talking to a local
counselor could help.

title: Why am I dreaming so much?
author: listener
text:
If the dreams themselves
are not troubling, you may just be remembering them more than most people do.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Your question highlights your pain very clearly.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What you are describing is one of the most common scenarios I see in my practice with couples: One partner feels terribly lonely and unimportant in response to the other partner either turning towards other people and activities or being withdrawn and turning inward.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: My mind immediately goes to a question for you: What happens when you are feeling alone and uncared for?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What do you say to yourself about you, about your spouse, and about your relationship?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What do you do in response to these feelings?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Do you ask for what you need?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Does this lead to arguments?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Do you stay silent or withdraw?Very often, couples enter into negative patterns where one partner feels afraid of rejection by the other partner and so withdraws from the relationship (and is often seen as "cold and aloof" towards the relationship), and the other partner feels afraid of abandonment by the withdrawing partner and so pursues the other (and is often seen as "critical and nagging").

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Regardless of "who started it," these patterns can turn into infinity loops that take on a gravity of their own, and ultimately cause both partners to withdraw and dissolve the relationship.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: If both partners want to work on saving and improving the relationship, the way out of this is to learn about your emotions and patterns together so that you can slow down the pattern and stay in touch with the emotions that pull people together.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: As the patterns slow down, partners are better able to get more deeply in touch with their vulnerabilities, needs and longings, and ask for them to be met in such a way that doesn't leave the other partner feeling criticized, threatened, abandoned, or uncared for.Some couples can do this without the help of a therapist.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: The book "Hold Me Tight: 7 Conversations for a LIfetime of Love" by Sue Johnson is a self-help book based on Emotionally Focused Therapy (the most scientifically validated couples therapy that currently exists), and has been helpful to many couples that I see.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: When a therapist is needed to help partners reconnect or overcome betrayals, I recommend seeking couples therapists who are trained in a scientifically tested model of couples therapy (such as Emotionally Focused Therapy.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: You can learn more about EFT or find an EFT therapist here: http://www.iceeft.com).To summarize:Your pain is understandable and valid.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: It's telling you what you are missing and what you want.Reconnection comes when we can listen to what our feelings are telling us, express those feelings in a safe way, and assert our wants/needs, while remaining open to the vulnerabilities and needs of our partner.If you can do that on your own, and your relationship is responsive, that's fantastic!

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: If you encounter challenges in resolving this yourself, consider therapy with a trained couples therapist using a model that is scientifically validated.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Pain means this is important!

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: You and your marriage are worth the effort!

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Piggybacking on the other respondent's suggestions, I also agree that most couples could use more frequent and more bonding communication in their relationships, and this is a GREAT place to get the ball rolling towards reconnecting.Surveying the demographical data on long-term relationships, it's pretty common for couples to start to struggle around the 7-10 year mark and in fact, that's often when first time divorces happen.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: And for lots of reasons...most of them having something to do with beginning to take one another for granted and no longer doing the little things that nourish the relationship and light our partners up.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Seems like you've encountered this in your own relationship...where he appears to be neglecting your need for emotional connection with him.Doesn't have to be this way though.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: And from my own personal clinical experience, I can tell you that when even ONE partner is willing to make some small but powerful changes, they can often ripple outward to the other partner and bring about miraculous outcomes!

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: So my encouragement to you is this - if you're still in love with him...even a little bit...and you're down to try something new, there's hope!

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: As hard as it may be, I would ask you to try and focus on YOUR own side of the street when approaching him.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Use an open and curious approach with him.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Ask him what he thinks he needs in a marriage.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What is it about you he fell in love with?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What helps him feel more fulfilled as a man and as a husband?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What little things that you have done over the years does he appreciate?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Like Sherry said, if you can get him talking, there'll be plenty to work with.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: We only need a spark to kindle a fire.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: If he can give you a list, you'll have a blueprint for getting him to reconnect with you and it opens the door for you to offer him little suggestions as well.By the time a couple reaches the point where you're at, there's usually very little fun going on.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: We've stopped enjoying one another's company.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Try and think creatively about some shared experiences he might be willing to do.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage

text: A picnic?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Happy hour?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Concerts, museums, cooking class, new sexual behaviors...the list is as infinite as you want it to be!

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Some of my favorite suggestions for couples looking to understand how they got here and how to build their way out are:"The Secret to Desire in a Long-Term Relationship" (Ted Talk) by Esther Perel"Getting Together & Staying Together: Solving the Mystery of Marriage" by William & Carleen Glasser"Divorce Busting - A Step By Step Approach to Making Your Marriage Loving Again" by Michelle Weiner-Davis"The Relationship Cure: a 5 step Guide to Strengthening your Marriage, Family, and Friendships" by John Gottman & Joan DeClaire"The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work" by John Gottman & Nan Silver"The Five Love Languages" by Gary ChapmanAnd of course, I'd be remiss if I didn't suggest that if you're open to the idea, maybe some individual and/ or couples counseling could be helpful too.My very warmest regards to you,Tamara Powell, LMHC

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: I'm sure you've tried to talk to your husband, but if not, could you?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Have a conversation with him about him and his life, his work, etc.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: See if he relaxes and opens up to you, even a little bit.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Don't try to have a heavy conversation or even unburden yourself to him during this first conversation - just try to be light-hearted and focus on hearing him.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: It's the first step towards getting your needs met too, and ending any emotional standoff that might have come about between you.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Feeling alone in your marriage is one of the most painful feelings.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Wanting connection with your spouse yet feeling the all too familiar distance that's keeping you apart can be so hurtful.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: But, change is possible.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: You might be able to move closer toward each other on your own but since there has been two years of distance, I would suggest looking into couples therapy with a trained couples therapist.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: They are trained in helping couples begin to examine what's been happening that has caused a drift in your marriage.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: I'm also curious if there was a significant event that occurred around the time you started feeling distant.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: If there was something that occurred during this time that is hard for you both to talk about, couples therapy can help with this also.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: It can provide a safe and supportive space for you both.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage

text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Absolutely.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Your question shows that you are going through a lot of pain and I'm sorry for that.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Many couples go through this disconnect and hope to come to reconnect before things get to a breaking point.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage

text: What I think can help is the following: 1.)

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: What you are describing is something I often refer to as "living with your roommate" phenomenon.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: This is the idea that you feel like you are living with a roommate and no your partner or spouse .

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: It is not uncommon for members of a couple to report to feel both physical and/or emotional distance.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: When we don't feel connected within relationships, this can be isolating and lonely.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: The emotional distance often makes us wonder: am I important to the other?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: These types of feelings need to be better understood in the context of your own background and upbringing I.e., who you are and also better understood in the context of your couple.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Feeling reconnected can occur-- but there is not a "one size fits all" solutoon.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: As a first step, do you or your partner have any ideas of how to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Have you considering talking to your partner about the emotional void?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Or how about discussing  solutions , together, that might help-- from individual therapy to couple therapy to a weekly date night to inquiring about one another's personal interest to starting off the conversation of what both of you want and can do to re-establish feelings of connectiveness.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: If this is too frightening I.e., to address the lack of connection between you and your spouse.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: a fist meeting with a couple therapist can likely help unpack what the possible solutions for your couple.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 11 years. Within the past 2 years we have drifted far apart. We coexist together but there is very little personal interest in each other. I often feel that my husband has "friends" at work that he is more emotional invested in than me. I feel very alone and just uncared for. Is there anything I can do to feel reconnected?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: I can think of several things that may help you to reconnect.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: I don't know how much time you actually spend together, but one thing you could try is to spend 15 minutes a week together talking about common interests or other things that make you feel connected.Have you considered a date night or anything (doesn't have to cost a lot of money, but could make each of you feel special)?Something else you could try is to consider talking to each other in a way where you summarize what you are hearing and reflect back to make sure that you got it right rather than just assuming so.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Communicating this way can feel awkward at times, but it could reconnect how you are listening and deeply connecting with your partner.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Also, you may discover that you are on two different pages about things on which you thought you understood what each other felt, wanted, or desired.Consider what makes your partner feel loved, valued, appreciated, or special.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Can you name a few things and get them right according to your partner when you check in?

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Can he do the same for you?You could also try doing two things every day that would be appreciated by your partner without either of you having to ask for it.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: There is some more information here, although what you do for one another does not necessarily need to be on this list: http://www.couplesinstitute.com/tracking-success-by-doing-the-daily-double/Reconnecting is a bit of a process.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: Try to praise yourself and your partner for attempts that you make and recognize that you're not going to get it right 100% of the time.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: You may also find this book to be helpful (or there are other similar ones by the same author): https://smile.amazon.com/Love-Languages-Secret-that-Lasts/dp/080241270X/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1471479801&sr=8-1&keywords=Love+languagesIf this still seems difficult, consider seeing a local mental health professional.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: As one more thought, recall that this relationship involves both of you.

title: I feel completely alone in my marriage
author: listener
text: If you are both committing to change your level of connection, change will likely not be a steady uphill climb (there could be plateaus or even some dips back in a negative direction) and each of you may change at a different rate.Best wishes in your quest for connection!

author: speaker

He and I talked about it afterwards and it made me feel better, and now I'm craving more of it. But before it gets close to happening I get this empty feeling. Why am I feeling this way?

title: I want to have a threesome with my husband and another girl, but I feel really nervous

title: I want to have a threesome with my husband and another girl, but I feel really nervous

text: You'll get the answer.The other thing that helps make something like this work is for both of you to listen and respect each other.

title: I want to have a threesome with my husband and another girl, but I feel really nervous

title: I want to have a threesome with my husband and another girl, but I feel really nervous

author: listener
text: A lot of people get that out of the way before settling down in a monogamous relationship.

author: listener

author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

author: listener
text: Nervousness, when doing something new, especially something sexual that can feel so personal, is very common.

title: Should I get a divorce?
author: speaker
text: I have cheated on my husband of five years roughly ten times. I pretend we aren't married at my work. Recently, he has caught on, but I lie to cover it. He use to talk to girls online, but I have caught myself constantly having a affair.

title: Should I get a divorce?
author: listener
text: Whether to divorce or not depends on your reasoning to do so.Marriage is its own unique existence dependent on what the partners want from it.Examine your terms of satisfaction from the marriage.Maybe you have very clear reasons to continue the marriage.Maybe you don’t.Only you can decide if what you’re contributing and benefitting is satisfying enough to stay.

title: Should I get a divorce?

title: How can I have a better sex life when I don't like sex?
author: speaker
text: My husband and I have been married for seven years, and in that time, we have only had sex four or five times. Others have told me that most men would have left me by now. Honestly, I think I have a low sex drive or neither one of us actually knows what we are doing. I want to be better connected with my husband.

title: How can I have a better sex life when I don't like sex?
author: listener
text: The numbers you write are low compared to how much sex many other people would be satisfied having.The key is your and your husband's satisfaction with the amount of sex you are having.And, know if there are reasons besides low sex drive that possibly explain this.Knowing the other possibilities matter because a low sex life may mean one of you is being satisfied sexually outside the marriage or that one of you prefers sex with a same gendered partner.If you've ruled out these possibilities, and you are satisfied with your emotional and financial life in the relationship, then a low sex drive may simply be the norm for the two of you.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: speaker
text: My fiancé and I have been together for 3 years and our relationship has always been good. The only issue we had was that he felt like he wasn't getting enough sexual attention from me.    I recently found out he cheated on me with another women. He says he wants his family back but I'm confused on what to do. Is it possible for us to get past the cheating, or should I just move on?

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: Thank you for your question.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: Many couples that experience infidelity in their relationship face this important question - "is it possible for us to get past the cheating, or should I just move on?"

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: Deciding to stay or leave is such a personal decision, one that only you can make.When an affair is disclosed or found out, it can have a traumatic impact on the betrayed partner.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: The betrayed partner might be overwhelmed by intrusive thoughts - Wanting answers to specific questions - Wanting details.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: And the partner that had the affair might be feeling overwhelm around "Will their partner ever forgive them?"

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: Because of the complexities cheating has on the bond couples have with each other, I would recommend seeing a couple therapist that specializes in working with the issue of infidelity.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: When infidelity happens, there are usually a number of secrets that accompany it, and this can be incredibly difficult for couples to work through on their own.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: Definitely yes, it is possible for a couple to trust each other again and become close with each other.Since your trust was broken, your fiancé would need to earn back your belief that he is faithful to you.Do you feel he empathizes with how you felt to find out about his cheating?Before you have this question answered, based on what you write there is a sense of your own doubt as to whether you are with the right partner.Before you and he address regaining your trust, first decide if you'd like to work on this.Ask yourself if the sexual attention he felt he wasn't getting from you was bc you're not as interested in him as you imagine or once felt in the past.If each of you sincerely wants to be together, it is possible to talk about your respective needs and help the other person feel safe again with the other.

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?
author: listener
text: In essence, many women tend to have more emotional needs than men, this is the way we are hard-wired, and there are exceptions to this of course, but if you have been feeling neglected emotionally than your lack of interest in sex is actually completely understandable and NORMAL!

title: Is it possible for a couple to overcome cheating if it only happened once?

title: How can I cope with being led on?
author: speaker
text: I was with my friends at the park, and we were talking and having fun. After a while, I met a girl there. We talked and flirted for a while, then we gave our numbers to each other and left. We talked for a few months, then we met up again. She kissed me, so I assumed we were dating. Then I found out she has a boyfriend.

title: How can I cope with being led on?
author: listener
text: I'm sorry for your disappointment with this girl.Maybe next time you start to like someone talk with the person to find out if they feel similar to you.

title: How can I cope with being led on?
author: listener
text: This way you have a good chance to avoid being hurt in the way you describe here.Even if the person doesn't give you a straightforward answer to their feelings for you, you'll gain a little more information by listening to how seriously they consider your question, what their body language is like, whether or not the person seems sincere.Listen to your gut.If you feel unsure the person likes you as much as you like them, then wait a little while to see if your feelings about the person or their feelings about you, change and in what direction they change.Keep yourself informed as best you can so you'll know you did as much as possible to kiss someone who understands your kiss the way you mean it to be understood.

title: What should I do about my husband's emotional affair with his ex-wife?
author: speaker
text: My husband had an emotional affair with his ex-wife in November. She invited him to dinner, alone, with their daughter. I wasn’t aware of this until after 11pm when I asked where he was. He had been drinking, and I told him not to come home that night. The next morning, we talked about going to counseling. He went out that night with friends and said his ex-wife wasn't going. I found out in April that she did go. I gave him the chance to get everything out in the open. I found out that he stayed that second night with her. I asked if they slept in the same bed, and he said yes, both nights. His daughter wasn't there the second night. He claims they didn't have sex, but what else should I think?

title: What should I do about my husband's emotional affair with his ex-wife?

title: What should I do about my husband's emotional affair with his ex-wife?
author: listener

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?
author: speaker
text: She's busy because her mom makes her clean all the time and go out places with her family. We don't talk much because of it. Also, we have little fights. We want to work it out but we don't know how.

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?
author: listener
text: Maybe your girlfriend feels torn in her emotions between loyalty toward her family and toward investing herself in a relationship.There are so many "maybes", that the best way to strengthen your relationship is to ask your girlfriend if she feels any pressure from her family to avoid involving herself with you.If the answer is "no", then continue to talk with each other as to what would make you each feel more secure with one another.Also, more simply, are the  two of you able to resolve the "little fights"?Differences of opinion are normal between two people, even to the point of each person feeling they are the only one who knows the correct answer.As long as each one of you has the goodwill to give a little, then the fights are a healthy way to respect and care about each other.If the fights are about the same topic which repeats itself, then there are strong differences between the two of you, including the possibility that her family places and she is willing to accept, some obstacle to this relationship.

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?

text: Maybe you can start with having 15 minutes per week that you know you will be spending time with each other (even if it needs to be on the phone).

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?

title: How do I make my relationship with my girlfriend better?

text: Then you know what each other is truly following about this.

author: listener
text: Also remember that following or understanding what someone is saying does not imply agreement, just that you are recognizing what they are saying and able to see where they are coming from.Also consider noticing what makes you feel valued, special, loved, or appreciated.

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?
author: speaker
text: I went to my ex-boyfriend to reach out to one of his high school friends who's attempted to commit suicide. When I went to him to reach out to his high school friend, he told me that I put him in a terrible position and put an enormous load on his shoulders. He was very angry that I went to him to do that. Am I in the wrong for going to him to reach out? He helped me so much with my depression and bad habits, so that's why I thought of him to reach out. He made me feel awful for thinking highly of him to help. Why did he react this way towards me? I think he's being selfish.

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?
author: listener
text: Your compassionate reach out to the friend is praiseworthy.That your ex bf has trouble accepting your gesture as kindness shows your ex bf is not seeing the situation clearly.I believe your ex bf's words about feeling burdened by your action.However, he is mixing up his own responsibility to know the root of his feelings.Blaming you for feelings he doesn't understand within himself is unfair and not helpful to anyone, including him.From what you write, you did nothing wrong and your action toward the potential suicider was gracious.My only guess which is also very general about your ex bf's behavior is that he doesn't yet fully understand himself and finds blaming others easier than understanding himself.

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?
author: speaker
text: I went to my ex-boyfriend to reach out to one of his high school friends who's attempted to commit suicide. When I went to him to reach out to his high school friend, he told me that I put him in a terrible position and put an enormous load on his shoulders. He was very angry that I went to him to do that. Am I in the wrong for going to him to reach out? He helped me so much with my depression and bad habits, so that's why I thought of him to reach out. He made me feel awful for thinking highly of him to help. Why did he react this way towards me? I think he's being selfish.

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

text: I'm glad you think so highly of your boyfriend and his ability to be there when you would like to talk about things that are important to you.I see why you would want them to reach out.

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

text: It sounds as if he is thinking that doing so would mean that he is responsible for his friend's well-being, although I can't say that for certain.Would you be willing to have a discussion with your boyfriend where for a few minutes (five minutes or so), you ask him about what made him react that way?

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

text: During this time, try to listen and ask questions is if you are an investigative reporter and are trying to learn more about his experience.

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?

title: Why is my ex-boyfriend upset with me?
