title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: Hi Seattle,While it's normal in many relationships for there to be a difference in sex drives, I believe that your wife has a major barrier to having a healthy sexual relationship.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: I'd be curious about what it was like at the beginning for you both, but these things can change.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: Sometimes people with sexual barriers are very active for a period when they're young because they're trying to prove something or overcome a fear.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: Right now, you can both accept that there is a barrier and it's hers and she can explore that in a safe relationship with a therapist and perhaps a doctor.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: It's possible she's asexual (not interested in sexual activity but very interested in love), or that a trauma has affected her.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: It's for her to explore.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: Tell yourself that it's not your fault, stop expecting it to change, and encourage her to seek treatment with someone who specializes in sexual issues.

title: My wife doesn't want to have sex
author: listener
text: Good luck.

title: I found my boyfriend talking to his ex-girlfriend
author: speaker
text: About a month ago, I went through my boyfriend’s phone and found him messaging his ex-girlfriend that he was dating before me. He gave her a promise ring when they were together, and he still had it hiding in his memory box in our son’s room. I found many things on his phone, but that broke my heart the most. He deleted all the messages but two. I can't help thinking they were talking about the old times together or something like that. It really kills me, and I can't stop thinking about it.

title: I found my boyfriend talking to his ex-girlfriend
author: listener
text: Your sense of hurt is very understandable.Do you and your boyfriend have an agreement on looking through each other's phones?I ask because the overall problem sounds like lack of trust and that there may be a difference in what each of you wants and expects from your relationship.Probably if the two of you talk about these topics and you each become clear as to the commitment status of each of you to the other, you'll have more clarity as to what either of you would like from the other.With this new level of clarity, his  past relationship involvements will likely be less meaningful .Once you have clear definition of the two of you as a couple, who he was as a past partner to someone else, will matter very little.

title: How do I fix my marriage?
author: speaker
text: I have been married for 20 years. He and I both cheated. I hid my cheating for 14 years. Over that time, I let life stress me out. I became depressed. When I finally woke up, he felt I had pushed him out.

title: How do I fix my marriage?
author: listener
text: Do you both want to fix the marriage?The relationship belongs to both of you so that one working without the other cooperating in this work too, will have one person who does all the changing.This dynamic itself creates problems of its own.About your husband telling you he feels pushed out, did he do anything on his own to address his problem of feeling like this?All you state is that he blames you for creating a situation he didn't like.If he did nothing because he felt unsure what to do, anything which shows he understands he has as vital a part in the marriage as you, is ok.Because affairs create mistrust between two people, the two of you would also need to be very aware to regain each other's trust.Talking as much as possible so you both know what goes on in the life of the other, how you each are feeling, what matters to you, is helpful to grow a new foundation for your marriage's future.

title: How can I like pets?
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend recently got a kitty. I hate cats in general, and he knows it. It grosses me out and makes me very upset when he pets his cat. I want to throw out the cat. I feel very jealous.

title: How can I like pets?
author: listener
text: Sorry for you and sorry for the cat because you're each in a tense position.What was the context of your boyfriend adopting a cat since he was aware that this would likely cause problems in the relationship with you?If you don't already know his answer, then find out.

title: How can I like pets?
author: listener
text: Doing so will tell you a lot about your boyfriend's expectations about you.

title: How can I like pets?
author: listener
text: Does he expect you to accept without question, whatever he does?

title: How can I like pets?
author: listener
text: Does he care about your views?

title: How can I like pets?
author: listener
text: Does a cat have some deep meaning for him that having one is essential to his life and he never told you so?Please don't be mean to the cat.

title: How can I like pets?
author: listener
text: Its not the cat's fault for being in your boyfriend's care.There are plenty of other cats on this earth so throwing out the cat will not solve anything between you and your boyfriend.Who knows, your boyfriend may come back home with three more cats!Start with a conversation about your feelings and his interest in your feelings.

title: Why do I hate sex?
author: speaker
text: I love my boyfriend and everything that leads to sex, but when it comes to the actual penetration, I hate it. I don't know why, but I just want it to be over. I feel like crying. I don't know why I don’t like it because all of my friends enjoy it.

title: Why do I hate sex?
author: listener
text: Does your boyfriend notice that you hate sex?If "yes", then it is a topic which the two of you would gain deeper understanding of each other, by discussing.If "no", then possibly one reason for hating sex is that your boyfriend doesn't notice who you are as a person, not simply a physical body engaged in sex.

title: How do I get my wife to forgive me?
author: speaker
text: I didn't trust my wife when I found out that she had a new guy friend that she was texting and calling. I investigated him before I found out that he was gay and that there was nothing going on. Now all my wife and I do is fight about trust.

title: How do I get my wife to forgive me?
author: listener
text: Instead of fighting about trust, is it possible for you and your wife to talk with other about areas which upset each of you?Whenever feelings are hurt, knowing what exactly is problematic and being heard and understood by the partner, goes a long way to building trust.These type of discussions are hard to have, and especially for the first time.

title: How do I get my wife to forgive me?
author: listener
text: A lot of emotions arise and often people lose their conversation focus from this.If you and your wife have a tough time opening up to each other, consider scheduling time with a couples therapist.Just by each of you committing time to invest in the relationship will show faith in the relationship, and this may contribute to restoring trust.

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: speaker
text: I've been in a relationship for over a year. He's cheated and lied. I heard he's married, but he says he's not. Everything is very up and down; there's no trust. Recently, he went on a trip, and I promised him I'd behave and not drink because when I drink, I drink too much, and I tend to make poor choices. This time, I made a huge mistake: I drank too much, and I cheated on him. I slept with another man for about five minutes before realizing what I was doing is wrong. I told him and he just got really rude. He called me names and threatened me. I feel bad as I do love him. We just have so many issues. I'm not a bad person, I've just made a lot of bad mistakes. It’s unintentional, and I know right from wrong, but why do I still make the wrong choice?

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: listener
text: Hi Calgary (Canada!

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: listener
text: ),  Let me get this straight...you're in a 'relationship', but he might be married.

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: listener
text: You both cheat and lie and he's abusive.

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: listener
text: The short answer is that there is too much wrong here for this therapist to try and fix it.

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: listener
text: Relationships don't heal us and they don't help us grow up.

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?
author: listener
text: We have to be mature and stable enough to love someone before it's going to work.

title: How can I stop myself from making poor choices and hurting the one I love?

title: What can i do if there is no trust in our relationship?

title: What can i do if there is no trust in our relationship?

title: What can i do if there is no trust in our relationship?

title: What can i do if there is no trust in our relationship?

title: What can i do if there is no trust in our relationship?

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: speaker
text: My dad cheated on my mom for 13 years. I cannot stop obsessing over the fact that my boyfriend might be cheating on me even when I know he isn't. I have full access to his phone, social media, and e-mails. I never find anything, but I'm obsessed with constantly checking just in case. How do I stop this? It's driving a wedge between us.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Hi Greenville, I respect that you're owning your own overreactions, and that you want to give your boyfriend the respect he deserves.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: The truth is that some people cheat, and some don't, and our partners deserve the benefit of the doubt unless they show signs they can't be trusted.The answer here is in two different areas.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Basically, if you want to feel differently (more trusting, in your case), you look at your thoughts, and your behaviours.Your thoughts are stuck... like tires in deep ruts in the road.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: These thoughts are only habits, they don't reflect the truth.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Fear is probably whispering in your ear things like "everyone cheats", or " you're not enough for him".

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Once you figure out what fear is trying to tell you, picture those words in red next time they come up.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Ask yourself what the evidence is that supports that thought (there won't be much...perhaps none), and what is the evidence that doesn't support it (I know lots of good men, I know I deserve love and loyalty, there is no sign of infidelity...).

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: You're learning to refute the thoughts that are connected to the fear.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: That's the first half.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Practise these thoughts.The rest of the work is in your behaviours.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Act as though you trust him.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Force yourself to not check or interrogate, and the less you check, the less obsessive and untrusting you will feel.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Acting "as if" something if true strangely helps us believe it.It's possible to change the way we think, and this is turn changes the way we feel.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Try this to start, and see a therapist for support and cognitive behavioural therapy if you want to dive more deeply into why this is happening and how to stop it.

title: How do I stop obsessively checking if my boyfriend is cheating?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: I just lost my grandpa

title: I just lost my grandpa

text: That you know you'd like another person to help you adjust, is a good sign of your own mental health stability.It is possible that reading online blogs and discussion forums, writing on these if you feel like doing so, and possibly joining a local free support group, will be all you need to feel better.There is no set timeline in grief.

title: I just lost my grandpa

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: speaker
text: What can I do to stop grieving my mother’s death? When I am awake I just cry every day. I don't have anyone to talk to. I need help; I am still cry over her. Will I ever stop crying? It’s been 3 years.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: I am sorry that you lost your mother.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: That is a really hard thing for someone to go through.There is really no set time for grief to be over, but I agree that if it has been three years and you are still crying every day then this is past the time for normal grief.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: I do not know how old you are and if you are in school or have a job, but I would imagine that if by now you literally were doing nothing but crying every day all day, someone would have noticed and would have gotten you some help.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: For one thing, bills have to be paid.There are typically five stages of grief and they can come in any order.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: You can go back to another stage that you previously experienced.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance are the stages.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: At first, people are usually in denial over the fact that they lose someone or are losing someone.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: This may mean that you deny they are ill or deny that they have actually died.Then comes bargaining, in which you may beg God that if you can only have this person back then you will do whatever.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Depression is when the reality has settled in and when we cry and really feel the loss.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are stuck in this phase.Finally, acceptance is when we accept that it has happened and we pick up the pieces of our life and move on.When we lose someone we never forget them.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: We may always have certain days that are tough, such as holidays or any special remembrance of your loved one.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: But we do get to the place where we accept that death is part of life and that it is inevitable, and that life goes on.A therapist can help you explore the reasons for your extended grief and can help you with coping skills to better deal with it.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: One suggestion I have is not to try to run from the sad feelings, don’t try to not feel them.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Embrace the feelings.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Let the feelings wash over you and accept them.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Trying not to feel something is not going to help.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Sadness is a part of life and needs to be felt just like happiness does.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: Unpleasant feelings are not to be avoided.I am sincerely sorry that you lost your mother and that you have had such a hard time of it for three years now.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: You deserve to be happy and to live a full life.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: I am sure your mother would not want you being sad for so long.

title: How do I stop grieving my mother’s death?
author: listener
text: I wish you all the best as you continue to try to heal from this loss and deal with your grief.

title: I over endulge when I drink alcohol and feel extremely guilty about it the next day

title: I over endulge when I drink alcohol and feel extremely guilty about it the next day

text: And of course, along the way, you may want to look at triggers, situations, biological vulnerability, social pressures, coping skills, relapse prevention planning and so on.

title: I over endulge when I drink alcohol and feel extremely guilty about it the next day
author: listener
text: Depending on where you are in your drinking, you might very well benefit from expertise and support.

title: I over endulge when I drink alcohol and feel extremely guilty about it the next day
author: listener
text: Remember also that alcohol depresses our central nervous system and disinhibits us.

title: I over endulge when I drink alcohol and feel extremely guilty about it the next day

text: That means that alcohol is often a substance of choice to relax, destress, calm down, etc.

title: I over endulge when I drink alcohol and feel extremely guilty about it the next day

text: Also, it allows feelings, thoughts, and behaviors that we usually inhibit to be expressed.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: speaker
text:
I'm planning to have baby, so I have to quit smoking - but it's hard. Sometimes it's not a physical need, it's mental.
   I cannot help myself from thinking about smoking. What can I do to get rid of this addiction?

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: Hi.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: Good for you in planning ahead to do what's healthiest for your baby (and yourself).

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: That's a great first step!

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: It's also good that you are able to identify that it's not always a physical need that's driving the addiction.For the next steps, I would suggest trying to figure out when the psychological cravings for a cigarette occur.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: The psychological (or mental) cravings are usually based out of habit, such as having a cigarette after a meal.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: And if you're consciously trying to quit, you'll find the craving starts with simply thinking about having a cigarette, then usually moves on to thinking about how good it made you feel, etc., etc.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: Well, if I'm on a diet and I continue to let myself think about the ice cream sitting in the freezer, eventually I'll give in and eat it.You're going to have thoughts about smoking a cigarette.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: That's normal and, for the most part, out of your control.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: But you choose whether or not to CONTINUE thinking and dwelling about it after that initial thought.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: That's what you would have to work on changing.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: When you have that initial thought, acknowledge it ("Ok, I kind of want a cigarette now.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: "), but then change the thoughts that typically follow.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: Distract yourself, think about something else, do something else, whatever it takes to get your mind off of that cigarette.I've suggested to clients before that they should plan these scenarios out ahead of time so they already know what they're going to do when the time comes.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: Write down when you usually have the craving for a cigarette and then write down new thoughts or things to do to get your mind off of it.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: Eventually, it will become easier and easier to brush off that initial thought until you no longer have it.Best of luck, and you have a really great motivator to quit - your baby!

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: speaker
text:
I'm planning to have baby, so I have to quit smoking - but it's hard. Sometimes it's not a physical need, it's mental.
   I cannot help myself from thinking about smoking. What can I do to get rid of this addiction?

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: First off, I would like to congratulate you on making the decision to stop smoking.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?
author: listener
text: The next thing I want to share is that there are so many different ways to kick the habit.

title: I'm addicted to smoking. How can I stop?

title: Is it okay if I take my friend's pills away?

title: Is it okay if I take my friend's pills away?
author: listener
text: Your good intentions to help your friend stay clean, are very caring about her.Unless your friend feels like stopping pills,  taking them away will mean she finds them some place else.The problem that anyone who is addicted to pills has, is that the person is psychologically and at least with xanax, physically addicted.Taking pills has basically become a standard part of your friend's life.Her problem is bigger than your ability to care.If you haven't already done so, tell your friend directly about your opinion on the way she is using pills.This is not a guarantee that she'll stop.It isa way of you showing that you care about her.Offering love and advice are the only things you can do for her.Meanwhile, knowing she is hurting herself is probably hurting you.Be sure to keep a sense of balance within yourself.

title: Is it okay if I take my friend's pills away?

title: How can I stop abusing alcohol?

title: How can I stop abusing alcohol?
author: listener
text: How to stop abusing alcohol involves a few steps, most of them time consuming, with slow progress and very often with tremendous emotional pain.The basic path is to figure out what motivates you to drink too much and be addicted to weed.

title: How can I stop abusing alcohol?
author: listener
text: Almost always, addictions are rooted in the person having suffered feeling deeply ignored, humiliated, shamed, invisible, nothing very pleasant, since a very young age, usually starting around 18 months.Most often addicts are sensitive people who have been emotionally overburdened by the grownups in their family.With no outlet for emotional expression or nurturing, the frustration goes inward until the emotional pain feels very big and without an outlet.So, people mask and numb by substances, whether this is food, chocolate, work, alcohol, weed.Therapy that is humanistic based, is a better fit than one which is drug oriented and diagnosis oriented.If you'd like getting serious about knowing who you are, including any unfair treatment of you during your growing up years, you can do this.Once you have a stronger self-respect and awareness, you would naturally avoid substances because they harm people.

title: How can I stop abusing alcohol?
author: listener
text: Harming oneself is the opposite of self-respect.Also, about your diagnosis, it may not be true at all.

title: How can I stop abusing alcohol?
author: listener
text: the US healthcare system loves selling drugs to people and clinicians in agencies and clinics are encouraged to find something wrong with people in order to find a new customer who will take drugs.See if you can find a therapist who is independent minded, and therefore free to interact therapeutically with you as a human being, not as a potential customer if they are able to label you as having something "wrong".This simply continues the long line of being shamed by others that created the addiction problem in the first place.Good luck!

title: My daughter-in-law is smoking marijuana while pregnant
author: speaker
text: My new daughter-in-law just informed me that she is smoking marijuana while pregnant because of her morning sickness. I’m in shock and I don’t know how to respond. I just lost my mom, and she was good with advice.

title: My daughter-in-law is smoking marijuana while pregnant
author: listener
text: Have you reached your own conclusions and reasons for these, regarding the topic?

title: My daughter-in-law is smoking marijuana while pregnant
author: listener
text: When you feel confident in your own reasons for your conclusions, then obviously ask your daughter in law for some time together and tell her what you think and your reasons for opinions.Plan for this meeting according to the type of relationship you have with your daughter in law.Since your son will also be affected by the prenatal conditions of his child, he may also be interested in being part of this conversation.Also, during your discussion, find out the exact ways the morning sickness affects your daughter in law.It is possible that scheduling adjustments in routines can be made so your daughter has more time to rest or fewer responsibilities for a while until she feels better.Maybe you and other family members can lighten her daily routines so she has more time for herself to manage her morning sickness in a less risky way.Sending Good luck!

title: No matter what I do, my mom will almost always find something wrong with it

text: It is challenging to see one's parents age and to cope with the new demands.

title: No matter what I do, my mom will almost always find something wrong with it

author: listener
text: It's a good question man, and it must be terrible to see your mother in the state she's in.Understand that Alzheimer's is due to under-performing function of kidneys, adrenals, and connective tissue strengtheners; all of which may be corrected with appropriate protocols that are inexpensive and generally simple to follow.Imagine it like a flower that is not fed properly:  A once, beautifully blossom flower APPEARS to be wilting, but it's life-force, spirit, and essence remain fully there and present.

author: listener
text: From your initial description, I would say that your mother is "Maloriented".

author: listener
text: In this stage of Alzheimer's individuals tend to be blaming and difficult to deal with.

title: No matter what I do, my mom will almost always find something wrong with it
author: listener
text: They may often hide or throw things away and then blame family members for this.

title: No matter what I do, my mom will almost always find something wrong with it

title: No matter what I do, my mom will almost always find something wrong with it
author: listener
text: You need to be able to center yourself and come to acceptance that this is your mother's illness that is the problem, not her and certainly not you.

title: How do I tell my elderly mother that I can’t stay for long visits?
author: speaker
text: My mother has Alzheimer's and I can see that she has lost some of her intellectual abilities. Even though I know this disease is not her fault, I’m still finding it difficult to separate my own feelings of disappointment and frustration when my mom seems to ignore my opinions and wishes, and seems

title: How do I tell my elderly mother that I can’t stay for long visits?
author: listener
text: Good observation on your part, to distinguish that your feelings in relation to your mom are not necessarily connected to the way she handles her part of the relation toward you.Has your mom usually ignored your opinions and wishes in relating to you?If prior to the onset of Alzheimer's, she never examined her way of relating to you, and if both of you have never had an open conversation about your sense of feeling hurt by her attitudes and manner with you, then the relationship between you and your mom will change in ways other than rational dialogue.She may continue ignoring or overlooking your wishes because she's been stuck in this attitude for most of your life.The good news for you about this is realizing that who you are and your way of relating to your mom, has very little to do with the way she relates to you.This is a more profound disappointment because it shows that her disconnect from you has been for longer than when the Alzheimer's began.You can however, feel a little more free knowing that you're not deserving of being ignored.

author: listener

author: listener

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: speaker
text: I have a mother who is still running my life even though I'm almost 30 years old. I want to move out and live my own life, but it feels like as long as I do what my mom wants our relationship is okay. It's never okay if I don't do what she wants.    I don't know how to start making my own decisions and not worry about whether it's right in her eyes. Would it help for me to talk to someone about this?

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: ABSOLUTELY.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: Having someone who's outside the situation and, even more so, with knowledge and experience in human behavior and relationship dynamics such as a counselor can do wonders in helping us feel less alone in frustrating situations like the one you're currently stuck in with your mother.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: A professional can also assist you in finding some assertiveness techniques, communication strategies, and coping skills to help you find your voice and stand your ground in a way that feels most authentic to you.In a healthy parent-child dynamic, there comes a normal developmental shift when, as the child reaches each new stage of maturity and responsibility, the parent backs off to provide a more supportive role instead of directive role.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: We call this "redefining relationships."

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: (We also do it with our friendships and colleagues here and there over time as needed).

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: It's absolutely vital.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: Sounds like your mom may have missed that memo.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: Like many parents, she may feel your behavior and choices is a direct reflection of her.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: Or that her role as your mother allows her greater latitude than it should.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: Or like many other people in general, that her way is the ONLY way.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: Regardless, this is YOUR life.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: And as far as we know, it's not a dress rehearsal.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: You certainly don't want to wake up some 50 years from now regretful or resentful.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: That being said, there are certainly ways to show her love and respect while doing what makes you happy.

title: I want to make my own decisions
author: listener
text: I would encourage you to Google therapists near you whose bios resonate with you and what you're looking for and start on a the journey towards a new chapter of freedom and hopefully a deeper, more satisfying mother-daughter relationship for both of you.Warmest regards,Tamara Powell, LMHC

title: How do I get my dad to understand that I don't want him to date or marry my best friend?
author: speaker
text: I have known her for years. She was dating my brother-in-law when we met. My kids think of her as their aunt. On Halloween 2014, I lost my mom to cancer. My mom and dad were still married when she passed away. My friend was there for me through that and my own cancer diagnosis. She has been a very big part of both me and my kids’ life, but now last month, my dad told me that he really likes my friend and wants to marry her. She’s like a sister to me. My kids hate the idea.

title: How do I get my dad to understand that I don't want him to date or marry my best friend?
author: listener

author: listener

author: listener
text: I wonder if you have let your dad know what's going through your mind with this and how it is affecting you.

author: listener
text: I can imagine that could feel awkward and emotional.

author: listener
text: Still, getting him to understand might be as simple as letting him know, in your words, how this feels from your view as well as what you wish.

title: How do I get my dad to understand that I don't want him to date or marry my best friend?
author: listener
text: It may not change the outcome (he may still marry her), but your thoughts will not go unsaid and opens it up for conversation.

title: How do I get my dad to understand that I don't want him to date or marry my best friend?
author: listener
text: Best luck!

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: It's most important that you accept yourself and surround yourself with a group of friends who are kind to you and love you.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: Family hearing news of any kind for the first time if they are an anxious type of character, will always be tough to digest.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: Time is important to let it all settle in and also making sure you're taking good care of yourself...

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: I think you're brave and I give you a lot of credit for not denying who you are -- you will inspire so many people to do the same in your life.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: Wishing you all the best.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: Gina

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: speaker
text: After I told them, they yelled at me.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: That has to be incredibly difficult because you were very vulnerable and open about what you were feeling and I imagine the response was very hurtful.Here are a couple of things to do right now:Practice giving yourself some love.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: Bring your awareness to the room around you and some of the positive energy within you.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: As you become a bit centered, you're likely to be able to work through your emotions more easily.Surround yourself with people who do accept you.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: I'm hoping that you have friends or acquaintances who accept you as you are.You can also find some support here through this organization that often have events related to offering support: https://www.pflag.org/needsupport.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: I have not spoken with this organization directly, but they are often discussed in therapeutic trainings as a reputable organization.Related more specifically to your family, that change may take some time.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: There is often a large adjustment in families because of the huge variations in reactions and what each person thinks, feels, and believes.Consider talking with a local therapist about how to communicate more effectively with your family, as there are a lot of variables there, so it is difficult to give you specific ideas in this format.Remember, there are lots of people who accept you as you are right now.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: speaker
text: After I told them, they yelled at me.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: There are a lot of ways one could go about handling this kind of conflict.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: It is hard to know which way might be advisable if we don't know quite why they would yell (or, why would they care who you choose to sleep and/or partner with to begin with?

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: )However, it is of utmost important that you accept yourself as bisexual, and sometimes that is easier said than done.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: But, when you are able to get to that acceptance that you are not in the majority in society as far as sexual orientation goes, and all that comes with that, and perhaps other issues you might have with it, it will be significantly easier for you to tolerate your family's lack of acceptance, and perhaps chalk it up to a severe lack of open-mindedness.But because it is family, and we don't choose our families but are forced to deal with them for the most part for better or worse (admittedly I'm not the biggest fan of outright estrangement), processing the loss of "the family that I hoped I had" will also be important for you moving forward in your life.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: You likely will be able to realize you don't need them to accept your sexual orientation for you to live a healthy and happy life.

title: What can I do about my family not accepting me as bisexual?
author: listener
text: Perhaps when they see that they can't change you, they will actually just learn to accept it.

title: How should I deal with my mom's controlling behavior?
author: speaker
text: I'm an adult, facing problems with my mom. She's way too controlling. She decides things for me, disregarding whatever I say. I tried explaining my side to her calmly, but she eventually gets angry and doesn't wish to listen to me regardless of how I speak to her.

title: How should I deal with my mom's controlling behavior?
author: listener
text: The part of your life which is in your control is the way you handle what your mom does and the way she talks to you.It is possible the two of you have very different opinions on a great number of matters.Each person, including you, has the right to decide whether and how to respond to someone.Stick up for your own right to make decisions.If she doesn't accept your independent viewpoints, then this doesn't give away your right to have these views.Since she makes herself clear as to her unwillingness to listen to you, then consider this as an easy way to avoid directly speaking with her about what's on your mind.If she ever shows an interest in your opinions and you feel like discussing these with her, then feel free to make this choice.

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenage gay girl, and I'm in love with a girl a few years older than me. She loves me too, but we're not physically together at the moment. I've been thinking about being transgender soon too, but my family doesn't accept me, so I honestly don't know what to do about that because I feel like I have to constantly hide the real me. It hurts so much to hide the real me. What can I do?

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: listener
text: They would probably be helpful to speak with a local mental health professional about this, not because there's anything wrong with the real you, but because having these conversations can be difficult and you may choose to talk about your real self in different ways with different people.Maybe you could talk about your concerns with your significant other and discuss different ways you may be able to discuss your relationship that fit with how each of you defines your love for one another.Because you are saying openly that you are gay, and it sounds like you already identify yourself as gay, as compared to considering being transgender "soon," it may be worth considering disclosing the fact that you are gay now and disclosing the idea that you are transgender after you have worked through that yourself.

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: listener
text: I would like for you to be able to be true to yourself and show the real you.

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: listener
text: It could also be that you already know that you are transgender, but with the way that you  phrased it here, I'm not certain.Here is a link to a hotline that you may want to consider using.

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: listener
text: The Trevor Project is about helping teenagers who identify as LGBTQ: http://www.thetrevorproject.org/Here is another national site where you may be able to find a local chapter: https://www.pflag.org/I don't know what you mean when you said that your family will not accept you, but since you are concerned about your family's reaction, I would suggest that it may be helpful to have a therapist or some other support in place before telling your family.

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: listener
text: The decision of whether or not to wait longer to tell them is ultimately yours, but I wonder if you have a likelihood of explaining what you are experiencing in a way that would be truer to you and also perhaps easier for your family to follow if you had time to process it with supportive people first.Please remember that you are not alone in this.

title: What can I do when my family doesn't accept my sexuality?
author: listener
text: There are people in the world who can and will accept you for who you are.

title: Should I talk honestly to my brother about his girlfriend, risking our own relationship?
author: speaker
text: My older brother (in his 60s) started dating a lady with Asperger's. She is hyper-sexual and flirty. She does not understand boundaries. They’ve been dating for a few months, and she's talking marriage. Another sibling and his wife have met her, and they have said she is never invited back. My brother always picks similar ladies. Do we speak honestly and risk losing a relationship?

title: Should I talk honestly to my brother about his girlfriend, risking our own relationship?
author: listener
text: If you and your brother are open w each other and respect each other’s opinions then there is little risk your relationship with him will end.If there already is strong animosity, mistrust, dislike between both of you then there is more chance he will not seriously consider your advice.For your own peace of mind, say whatever you feel must be said to him.The person you’ll need to live with is yourself so do what you believe is needed for you to feel good about saying what’s necessary.Even if he never follows through with your advice then you’ll still know you tried your best to advise.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: speaker
text: She constantly tells me what I am doing wrong. For once, I want her to be proud of me. It’s like no matter what I do, she does not have one nice word to say to me. She is always hateful towards me and always has been.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: I imagine this is very difficult and confusing for you.It sounds like there are things for which you are proud of yourself, which is really good.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: I hope there are also other people in your life that are currently able to recognize the good things that you're doing.If you think your mom would be willing to go to see a local mental health professional with you, that may be a good place to have some discussions about the relationship that the two of you have.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: The reason I'm suggesting that it may be easier to have the conversations there is because sometimes the mental health professional can point out parts of conflict that are not easy for the people who are involved to actually see by themselves.If you want to try to talk with you mom to see how she is feeling, maybe she would be willing to discuss it with you.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: If you're going to have a conversation like that, I would suggest you try these things:Ask her if this would be a good time to have an important conversation.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: If she says no, consider asking her when would be a better time.Try to have the conversation with the goal of taking about five minutes to learn more about where she is coming from on this.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: If you can ask questions to learn more about that, you may be able to know more about what she is thinking and feeling.This doesn't mean that you have to agree with her, but just that you are able to hear where she is coming from.Try to ask questions that start with the words who, what, how, where, when.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: Questions that start with the word "why" can be difficult to answer and can lead to a lot of extra emotion.Try to summarize what she is saying to see if you have it right.If you want your mom to know how you feel, after you can listen to what she is saying and see if she is willing to listen to what you would like to say.If you're going to tell your mom about how you feel, consider having some points written down ahead of time so you can explain yourself the way that you want to.It will probably be really hard to listen to her without being defensive right away.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: I know I would be wanting to jump right into the conversation.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: Remember that jumping in right away will probably make it more difficult to learn where your mom is coming from.Also, if she says she doesn't want to have a conversation, remember that she has that choice.If your mom does not want to go to see a counselor with you, remember that you could go on your own.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: Depending on your state and exactly how old you are, you may need your parent's permission to be in treatment, but not always.

title: Why can't my mom ever be proud of me?
author: listener
text: If you need help to figure that out, try contacting a couple of local mental health agencies to see if they can help you figure out what to do if you want to talk to someone.

title: What's wrong with me for going to summer school?
author: speaker
text: It's the way my mom said I was worth nothing, stupid, no point of being in school. I'm "lazy little fat."

title: What's wrong with me for going to summer school?
author: listener
text: There is nothing wrong with going to summer school.

title: What's wrong with me for going to summer school?
author: speaker
text: It's the way my mom said I was worth nothing, stupid, no point of being in school. I'm "lazy little fat."

title: What's wrong with me for going to summer school?
author: listener
text: Your mom is telling you cruel words.The fact that she is your mother and is not supportive and willing to point out your strengths, is a good reason to not believe what she tells you.Parents are meant to nurture their children, not take them down with words.Kids go to summer schmo for all sorts of reasons.

title: What's wrong with me for going to summer school?
author: listener
text: If you were unable to concentrate during the school year on academic subjects, for whatever reason, summer school is a way to catch up so you will stay with your classmates in the school year which starts in September.I understand not liking the idea of school in the summer.

title: What's wrong with me for going to summer school?
author: listener
text: Only this is different than being putdown the way your mother does to you.

title: I feel like my relationship is falling apart
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend and I have been arguing every night about the same thing. He also tells me that if I go visit my mother out of state he will be gone when I get back. He and my mother do not get along. What should I do?

title: I feel like my relationship is falling apart
author: listener
text: A relationship gets weaker, not stronger by threatening control of the other person.Start by telling your boyfriend to keep his remarks about you and the interests he is in which you two disagree, limited to these areas.Your relationship with your mother is between you and her.Regardless of how much he doesn't like her, to not respect your mother daughter relationship is unreasonable and disrespectful toward you.Threatening to take action against you by withdrawing himself from your relationship, is almost guaranteed to harm the good feelings between the two of you.Does you boyfriend dislike your mother for any reason having to do with her being a danger to you?Ask his reason since if he does this from concern for your emotional or physical safety, then this is good sentiment which is handled incorrectly, by a threat to you.What you should do is ask your boyfriend to not threaten you and to calmly talk about the topics you bring up here.

title: Is it wrong that I don't love or even like my sister?
author: speaker
text: I don’t love my sister. I would never wish her harm, but if I could, I would wish for us not to be related. Is this cruel? Why must blood mean we have to be friends? Am I being unreasonable and is there a way to fix this? I do care about her, like I do every human being, but I’d rather be with my friends than be with her at all. It’s not just a "teenager phase." I still love my mom and dad, and I’m very close to them. However, it’s my sister I don’t love or have ever really liked at all.

title: Is it wrong that I don't love or even like my sister?
author: listener
text: No one can force emotions.

title: Is it wrong that I don't love or even like my sister?
author: listener
text: Its fine to not love your sister.You may make some discoveries about yourself and your relationship with your sister by studying the reasons for why you're not close.Usually this has something to do with how the parents positioned the kids.

title: Is it wrong that I don't love or even like my sister?
author: listener
text: Some parents obviously favor one child over another, and this would heavily influence how the kids view each other once they are grown people.The patterns of interaction set down during our growing up years stay with us until we change them consciously.Its possible your sense of not loving your sister started in your early years.You now have a chance to know your sister through your grown up eyes, or not.Either way, you still may decide you don't love her.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: speaker
text:
My wife and mother are having tense disagreements. In the past, they’ve had minor differences. For example, my wife would complain to me my mother is too overbearing; my mother would complain my wife is lazy.
 However, it’s intensified lately. I think the cause is my wife talked back to her once. Now, any little disagreement is magnified, leading to major disagreements. What can I do?

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: One choice is for you and your wife to decide together what are reasonable ways and expectations to have of your mother.From what you write it sounds like your wife and you have differences as to what is the proper and right way to talk with your mother.Once the both of you agree on overall philosophy and some specific details for examples, then ask your mother to make time for all three of you to discuss together the expectations and standards you and your wife would like to see happen.This is only the first step since it is possible and likely that at least on a few points, your mother will disagree and have different views.These need to be discussed and integrated into an overall plan which all three of you are happy to live with.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: speaker
text:
My wife and mother are having tense disagreements. In the past, they’ve had minor differences. For example, my wife would complain to me my mother is too overbearing; my mother would complain my wife is lazy.
 However, it’s intensified lately. I think the cause is my wife talked back to her once. Now, any little disagreement is magnified, leading to major disagreements. What can I do?

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: What you are describing is something psychologists have termed "triangulation" which is what happens when one family member will not talk to the one they have a problem with and goes to a third member of the family to complain instead.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: You have been "triangulated" by your wife and mother.This is often seen in families.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: It's seen everywhere.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: How many times have you had a problem with someone but you didn't go to them to tell them, you went to someone else to complain?

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: It is usually difficult for a person to confront another, especially in relationships where there is a power differential.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: For example, I bet it's easier to complain to a coworker about your boss rather than go to the boss with your complaint.I'm not saying triangulation is always a bad thing.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Sometimes a third party mediator is needed to help solve problems between two people who disagree.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: That's what therapists do every day!

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Sometimes just getting someone else's perspective can help you see the issue clearer.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: However, in your situation it sounds like this is becoming a problem.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: You are stuck in the middle between two people that love you and that you love.If you want to put a stop to this triangulation, you will need to encourage the two of them to talk to each other and work out their differences.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Perhaps it was a simple misunderstanding that some open communication can clear up.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Even if they really don't like each other and can't get along, your relationship with the both of them is going to continue to deteriorate the longer you are stuck in the middle.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Try to understand what might be the feelings behind their behavior.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: It is possible that they may both feel threatened by the other.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: These are the two most important women in your life and they both know it.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Your mother may be afraid that she will lose you if she confronts your wife.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: I heard one mother-in-law describe her son's wife as the gateway to her son.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: The wife has the power to dictate when and how often the mother gets to see her son.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: The wife also is the gateway to the grandchildren.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: If your wife doesn't like her mother-in-law she can severely hamper or damage her mother-in-law's relationship with you and any children you two may have.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: From your wife's viewpoint, this is the woman that she may feel like she can never live up to.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: If you regularly praise your mom's cooking, her housework, gardening, or anything else your wife may feel that you are putting down her own efforts in these areas and can feel unappreciated.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: This can be especially difficult if your wife and mother are nothing alike.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: I am not saying that this is the case with your family's situation.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: These are just a few examples from other families in a similar situation as yours.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Regardless of what the cause is, if this dysfunctional pattern is allowed to continue, your mom and your wife will begin to get upset with you when you don't agree with them.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: They will get upset if you don't align yourself with them against the other.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: They will be offended when it seems like you are choosing the other one's side or that you are not standing up for them like they think you should.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: In worst cases, if it continues to escalate you may even find yourself in the impossible position of having to choose between your wife and your mother which may mean cutting off contact with the other, ending that relationship.

title: Escalating disagreements between mother and wife
author: listener
text: Change the dynamics before it spirals even further.

title: My dad is mad because I identify as a male and I was born a female
author: speaker
text:
My dad doesn't like the fact that I'm a boy. He yells at me daily because of it and he tells me I'm extreme and over dramatic.
   I get so depressed because of my dad's yelling. He keeps asking me why I can't just be happy the way I am and yells at me on a daily basis. Is this considered emotional abuse?

title: My dad is mad because I identify as a male and I was born a female
author: listener
text: Maybe this is emotional abuse.It certainly is irritating and annoying to be yelled at for being yourself.Maybe at a time when he's not yelling you can bring up the topic of your own willingness, if this is true, to discuss questions he has about your gender.There's no guarantee he won't start yelling midway through a dialogue like this.

title: My dad is mad because I identify as a male and I was born a female
author: listener
text: Only then you will be on firm ground to excuse yourself from the conversation since you already explained that you're willing to talk with him and not to be yelled at by him.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: speaker
text: I have known I was always different. This year, in December, I found out that I never felt female. I did research and have identified myself as male but don't know how to tell my dad.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: I admire your courage.If you are concerned about telling your dad regarding your gender identity, I would suggest a couple of things.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: There are a lot of groups or other supports for people who are working through some of the same changes that you may be going through now.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: I don't mean to convey that everyone thinks, feels, or acts the same by any means, but rather that it may be helpful to talk to others who have had some similar experiences.I was trying to include some links for you, but that particular button isn't functioning window.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: If you search for "transgender support" on Google, you'll find GLAAD and PFLAG, both of which are national organizations.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: This does not mean that you have to identify as "transgender," but researching that term may help you to find both national and local resources.As far as telling your dad, if that is particularly concerning for you, I suggest either talking through the details with a local therapist or considering if you have a trusted friend or family member (one who will respect your privacy with regard to who you would like to know about what you are experiencing at this time) so that you can talk with some people to have support.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: This may help with two things: allowing you to find some support for yourself as you work through the changes that you are going through now and also possibly talking with someone who knows your dad and may be able to talk with you regarding how or when to tell him.One thing that I tell anyone who wants to discuss something that is very important to them is to ask the person they want to talk to whether this is a good time for an important conversation.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: That way, you have greater chances of having the person's attention and/or not needing to end the conversation quickly.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Also, please remember that you know yourself best, as each of us does.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: speaker
text: I have known I was always different. This year, in December, I found out that I never felt female. I did research and have identified myself as male but don't know how to tell my dad.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: This is certainly a tough spot.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: I have a few thoughts and perhaps some colleagues will add some things.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: You may want to spend a few minutes calling to mind any conversations that you have had with your father about transgender issues, or if you have ever heard him talk about it.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: That may give you a small clue about how well he may accept this news from you.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: For example, if he has been watching the news lately, transgender rights is something that is being talked about a lot.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Has he had an opinion?

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: This won't tell you for sure if he would be okay with learning you are transgender, but at least you would know if there is hostility toward transgender people.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: To tell you the truth, the best way to tell your dad is whatever way feels right to you.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: There is no right or wrong way, best or worst.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: If you want to tell him when you are by yourself with him?

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: That's perfect.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Want to have a friend with you for support?

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Equally perfect.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Whatever thing you need to do.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: And, of course, there is always the option of not telling him anything until you are comfortable doing so.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately, the response from your dad can't be predicted.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
author: listener
text: Some parents are totally cool.... others not so much.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?

text: This is one reason why having someone with your for support is sometimes a good idea.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?

text: If things get heated, you have someone in your corner.

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?

title: How can I tell my dad I'm a female-to-male transgender and I want to start binding?
