title: How can I make my mom love me the same as my siblings?
author: speaker
text: I have three siblings. My mom loves them and not me. She’s always yelling at me, but when it comes to my siblings, she talks to them. I’m always crying in my room.

title: How can I make my mom love me the same as my siblings?
author: listener
text: Have you ever tried talking with her about this when she's not angry?

title: How can I make my mom love me the same as my siblings?
author: listener
text: While I hear you saying that it feels like she doesn't love you, there could be a lot of other pieces to this.

title: How can I make my mom love me the same as my siblings?
author: listener
text: Have you ever told her about how much she means to you (when she's not angry)?

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: speaker
text: My stepdad and I always mess around. I've noticed that whenever he playfully hits me, it's always my butt that he hits. He always comments on my outfits and always scans me head to toe when I walk into a room. I'm a teenager female, and I want to know if this is normal.

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: listener
text: It's hard to tell from the way you described it.

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: listener
text: Do you think he would be open to an honest discussion?

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: listener
text: It could be that his comments about your outfit are designed to make you feel good or to help them show how much he cares about you as his stepdaughter.

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: listener
text: As far as scanning you from head to toe, I can think of reasons that parents might do that.

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: listener
text: I also think that talking about it is probably very important so you really know what his intentions are.

title: Is my relationship with my stepdad normal?
author: listener
text: That way, it removes the guesswork and you have the opportunity to know what he is thinking and feeling and he can also know what your reactions are.

title: Is it normal to hate my mom?
author: speaker
text: She has chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, and I’m her caregiver. All she does is complain, hit me, call me names, and say things happened that didn’t. When I tell her, she explodes. I didn’t always hate her, but now every little thing she does irritates me, and I don’t have the means to live on my own.

title: Is it normal to hate my mom?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are hating some of the things that your mom does rather than hating her.Something you may be able to do is call the area agency on aging for the county where you live and ask for information about having other people help to care for your mom.

title: Is it normal to hate my mom?
author: listener
text: I don't know how old your mom is, but if she is younger, they would probably have resources to other ways that you could have help.

title: Is it normal to hate my mom?
author: listener
text: If you are both open to the possibility of someone else helping out, this may help with some of the difficulties between you if you are not spending quite as much time together.

title: Is it normal to hate my mom?
author: listener
text: Do you think your mom is able to actually recognize how what she does and says affects you?From whom do you have support during all of this?

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: speaker
text: My dad is doing some really bad drugs, and I'm not allowed to see him anymore because of what he can do to me or my siblings on this drug. It has affected me tremendously in my life. It’s even caused me anger and stress.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: It seems like you are going trough stages of grief, since the inability to see your father causes you similar feelings as if you had lost him.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Perhaps you could send him letters expressing your feelings and hopes.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: But do understand that if he is under the influence of drugs he might not be able to empathize with your feelings or react in the way that he would have done so in the past.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: As the issue evolves find a therapist or counselor to help you work on letting go of that anger and stress, which may affect you negatively.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Find forgiveness so you can have a relationship with him in the future.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: ¿Qué puedo hacer con mi padre usuario de drogas?Mi papa está usando drogas muy malas, y no estoy autorizada a verlo por lo que me puede hacer a mí y a mis hermanos.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Esto afecta mi vida tremendamente.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Me causa coraje  estrés.Parece que estas pasando por estados de luto, ya que el no poder ver a tu padre causa sentimientos similares a cuando hay una perdida.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Tal vez puedes escribirle cartas expresando tus sentimientos y esperanzas.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Pero comprende que si el está bajo la influencia de drogas puede que no sienta empatía o te responda como lo solía hacer.

title: What can I do about my dad being on drugs?
author: listener
text: Mientras el problema se resuelve busca un consejero o terapeuta que te ayude a trabajar en resolver los sentimientos de coraje y estrés, trabaja también en perdonarlo para que puedas tener una relación con él en el futuro.

title: How can I free myself from my narcissistic, codependent, ill mother?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my mid-twenties now, and my boyfriend of seven years and I want to start a life. My mother is 100% codependent on me and is extremely manipulative. She suffers from type 1 diabetes, which she uses to guilt me if I ever leave her. The problem is that I will feel guilty.

title: How can I free myself from my narcissistic, codependent, ill mother?
author: listener
text: Focus more on your own life and less on the very heavy descriptors you wrote to describe your mom.All the words you wrote represent psychological conditions which are either lifelong or take a lot of motivation and effort to change.Since the only person who can change how your mom handles her life, is your mom, and you are the only one who can do the same for yourself, devote more energy and time to living your own life fully, despite the emotions you feel regarding her.

title: How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?
author: speaker
text: My mother and I have an okay relationship. I know she loves me unconditionally, and I love her the same. However, more times than not, I'm afraid to tell her anything personal because she either doesn't listen, she turns it around and makes everything about her, or she ignores things - even when they are about my mental health.

title: How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?
author: listener
text: Could you tell her ?

title: How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?
author: listener
text: What would happen if you said "Mom, I love you and I really want to share myself with you, but often I you get upset and I don't want that to happen.

title: How can I get my mother to listen to me without her freaking out?
author: listener
text: I really want to be able to talk to you."

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: speaker
text: It happens especially at me and my sister, and then she gets emotional and brings up the past. How should I deal with it? She is always stressed about her work and doesn't put her family first.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: You are very wise for a young person.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: You have already figured out that other people's behaviours...how they treat you...it's not about you...it's about them.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: I love that you don't blame yourself for your mom's behaviours.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: It's not your fault.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: She's getting upset because she doesn't know how to manage her emotions, and these emotions have to do with her past and her present stress.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: You're just the trigger.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Yes, this is normal, but it's not necessary.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: She can find another way to manage her "stuff".Unfortunately, you can't help your mom a whole lot or even help her recognize this.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: But for yourself... remembering that her behaviours are her issue is the biggest piece of "dealing with it".

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: You can always try some new strategies when you talk to mom...you can say "I'll listen you better if you don't bring up past stuff", or "I'm worried about you mom.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: You seem stressed", or even "I don't like the way you talk to me".

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: speaker
text: It happens especially at me and my sister, and then she gets emotional and brings up the past. How should I deal with it? She is always stressed about her work and doesn't put her family first.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Anger is a normal emotion, and yet it is a really hard one... how much is too much?

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: and how do you express it without damaging those around you?

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: yes mom's get angry, sometimes too easy... but its their responsibility to manage their anger-- get their own support and put themselves in time outs when they cannot handle it well.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Since you are the kids, you shouldn't have to fix or calm down mom's anger.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Maybe in a calmer time when you guys are being silly talk with her one on one?

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Tell her  you are feeling sad and hurt that she gets upset at you girls.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Ask her if there is 1 thing you can work on this next month to help her.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Ask her if she would work on 1 thing for you this month-- not yelling?

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: taking a time out?

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: telling you before she blows her top so you can exit the room?

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Also for you, check out a library book on anger so you know how to handle yours, and one on parents and anger.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: Number one to remember, if you don't feel safe, if she is calling you names, or hurting you, breaking things etc.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: make sure you go to a trusted adult--school counselor, neighbor, aunt, church friend as soon as possible.

title: Is it normal for my mom to get mad easily?
author: listener
text: You are much too important to be hurt and if mom is out of control, someone else needs to be --caring for you.

title: I'm scared to tell my family that I'm bisexual
author: speaker
text: My parents seem okay with other sexualities, but normally they only talk about being gay. When they do talk about bisexuality, they say things like “they'll do anything” or things that make me very uncomfortable because I am bisexual. I don't know if I am ready to come out to them.

title: I'm scared to tell my family that I'm bisexual
author: listener
text: Coming out to family members can cause a lot of anxiety.

title: I'm scared to tell my family that I'm bisexual
author: listener
text: However,  although I cannot promise what their reaction will be, the benefit is that you will no longer have to hide who you are.

title: I'm scared to tell my family that I'm bisexual
author: listener
text: Perhaps researching or getting information on bisexuality can help your family understand what it truly is to be bisexual.

title: I'm scared to tell my family that I'm bisexual
author: listener
text: Many times,  people are just not educated on certain things.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: speaker
text: I work two jobs and go to school for criminal justice. Over the summer, my father had a stroke. It was very devastating. My father isn't the same, and my family fights every day. I have been kicked out the house many times. I break down a lot.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: You undoubtedly are carrying a huge weight on your shoulders.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: Stressors come in many forms and you are engulfed in a few of the major ones as it relates to dealing with the declining health of your father, family conflict, as well as trying to balance a work and school schedule.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: Stress, if left unchecked has many negative health related implications.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: First and foremost I would recommend going to see a counselor at your college/university.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: Most colleges have counseling centers for students that usually allow for 5-6 free counseling sessions (your tuition actually pay for these sessions so take advantage of them).

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: Secondly I would advise you to take a minute and breathe.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: When confronted with overwhelming life issues it is common to busy ourselves in an attempt to distract ourselves from the drama, but sometimes that can compound our stress.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: When dealing with stress it is important that you engage in self care.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: In other words find time to engage in activities that bring you a sense of peace, enjoyment, and fulfillment in order that you may get a momentary release from your daily hectic life.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: Even with a normal life there is no way to escape stress, it is inevitable and a part of life, but how you deal with stress, as well as how you take care of yourself in the midst of these whirlwind events will determine your quality of life.

title: How do I handle all of my stress?
author: listener
text: I hope this helps...

title: What should I do if I found out one of my parents are cheating?
author: speaker
text: I saw my mother cheating on my dad before. I said something to her, and she said it was in the past. Yesterday, I saw her texting dirty things to the same guy. Should I talk to her again? I don't want my parents to go their separate ways, I just want her to stop. it's not fair.

title: What should I do if I found out one of my parents are cheating?
author: listener
text: You as the child in the middle of your parents' problems is the worse position to be in.

title: What should I do if I found out one of my parents are cheating?
author: listener
text: I can only imagine your hurt, pain and confusion on what to do.

title: What should I do if I found out one of my parents are cheating?
author: listener
text: Honestly, this is a hard question to answer without knowing your age, your parents' ability to handle hearing information from you and your maturity to handle what may happen in the end.

title: What should I do if I found out one of my parents are cheating?
author: listener
text: One thing I would like to note....your parents may be in the same house but if your mother is cheating, they have already gone their separate ways.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: speaker
text: I avoid talking to him because he always makes me more upset. I can't be honest with him about anything because he is always rude to me.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: Hi Troy, I totally get this.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: It's a dilemma; you want your dad to know how he's hurting you but you don't feel safe enough to say anything to him.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: Your reaction is understandable; it's his responsibility as a parent to work harder than you to create that safe place for you to be open.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: But that's not who your dad is.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: Your dad is your dad, and waiting for him to change won't really help.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: Nothing you do can change your dad, but...there are things you can do for yourself and your relationship with him.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: While your response of avoiding him is understandable, I wonder what effect it has on your dad.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: It's possible that he's feeling frustrated, rejected and punished by your withdrawal.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: You may think he knows that you're feeling hurt, but he probably doesn't.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: So this is the squirrel chasing its tail: your dad is rude, so your habit is to be silent, then he maybe feels abandoned and frustrated.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: His frustration comes out as more rudeness, which makes you want to withdraw more, and the cycle starts all over again.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: You can't change his part of the cycle but you can change yours.Are you willing to take a risk?

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: Can you be honest about how you're feeling?

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: What's the worst thing that could happen if you said to your dad "You know why I avoid you?

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: I stay silent because when I talk to you say rude things.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: So if you want me to talk, I need to know you can listen."

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: I imagine it would come out differently because you're a few generations younger than me, but put that into your own words.I don't know the level of your dad's 'rudeness'.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: If he is abusive, then a better plan is to see a therapist alone or talk to someone about this.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: I don't want to put you at any risk.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: But if you don't worry your dad will hurt you, maybe give honesty a try.My point is that, as rude as your dad may be, checking out of a relationship by being silent is also rude.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: It's powerful...your silence.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener
text: Your dad can't read your mind, and if you want things to be better you will need to get in that ring with him.And, if you're both open to it, seeing a therapist together can be really helpful.

title: How can I be more open and honest with my dad?
author: listener

title: My daughter is in her 30s, not married, and pregnant. How can I break the news to the family?
author: speaker
text: She is living with her boyfriend of seven years. He is in therapy for depression and social anxiety. He hasn't worked in all this time.

title: My daughter is in her 30s, not married, and pregnant. How can I break the news to the family?
author: listener
text: Congrats on your upcoming grandchild!Does your daughter want you to break news of her pregnancy, to the family?Talk with your daughter first, whether or not she would like you to tell other family members.Also, given the other facts you mention in your post, if household and financial management are areas you feel your daughter is vulnerable, then bring up these topics too.Stay open minded about your daughter having views which are different from yours.

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: speaker
text: I keep being mean to my best friend, and I don't know why all the time. I did come to maybe some kind of conclusion that it is because my mother is mean to me all the time. Could that be a cause?

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: Hi Morristown,There's a saying that goes "hurt people hurt people".

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: It's possible that your aggression towards your friends is connected to your mother's behaviours.

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: When we are treated poorly, especially as children, it affects how we ourselves, others, and the world.

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: It's also powerful modelling of aggressive behaviour.

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: The good news is that you have this lovely awareness and I think a desire to learn about yourself and grow in your ability to be respectful to people you care about.

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: I recommend you consider sitting down with a therapist and exploring these ideas and moving forward on that path you seem to want to be on.

title: Can a person be mean towards another person if that person was treated poorly before?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: speaker
text: My mom made a lot of mistakes a couple years back, and I can't seem to forgive her. I want to say that it's okay, but I can't. I feel like even if I did forgive her, I wouldn't be able to say it to her face.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Hi Cleveland, I think I get what you're feeling.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: You're scared that if you forgive your mom, that would mean it wasn't so bad, or she'll think it's okay to do it again, or she won't realize how hurt you are.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: I invite you to look at forgiveness in a different way.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Forgiveness doesn't have to mean what she did was okay.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Not at all.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Forgiveness can mean "I accept what she did, and I don't want to live in her worst moments constantly.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: I want to put it down and move past it because I want her in my life, because fear and resentment interfere with my relationship with her, and mostly because I'm tired of carrying them (fear and resentment) around constantly.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: "You can forgive your mom for yourself, not for her.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: If there is evidence that your mom wants to respect you moving forward, then it might be worth it to risk putting down the resentment and the grudge that you think you need to protect yourself.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Your ability to draw boundaries with her in the present is your biggest protector; let her know in the present what hurts you, and notice her responses.You don't have to say it to her face.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Saying it to yourself is more important.

title: How am I supposed to feel when I forgive someone?
author: listener
text: Again, forgiving your mom helps you...it reduces your own burden of fear and resentment, leaving space for better things.

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: speaker
text: Hello, I have a cousin in my family who has been making me feel belittled, insecure, and frustrated during her stay here in the city. I know she comes from a place of love, but she has always been short-fused and highly temperamental if something doesn't work out the way she planned it. I have tried my best to coordinate plans with her, but she always ends up frustrated about the lack of communication I seem to have on my part and then makes condescending comments about my character that include: inconsiderate, negative, oblivious, and self consumed.    I have tried to talk to her openly about this, but it always comes back as an attack on my character and I have never heard these comments from anyone else before. I have been thinking a lot about her comments and whether I truly am an inconsiderate person who is not thoughtful, spatially aware of surroundings/people, or positive, but in the end, I am feeling awfully hurt about how this has affected our relationship.    What can I do?

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: listener
text: Do you have a close friend or relative who's opinion you trust?

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: listener
text: Ask them for their honest feedback and if they see you like your cousin does.

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: listener
text: If they don’t see these qualities in you, then it may be your cousin’s issue and she’s taking it out on you.

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: listener
text: You can always ask her what would be the best way to communicate plans with her so you know, specifically, what she is expecting.

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: listener
text: Then if you meet these expectations and she still blames you and comments on how inconsiderate you are, it's her issue and she is not coming from a place of love.Even if you do resemble her comments, the way it sounds like she approaches this problem is not out of love.

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?
author: listener
text: The fact that you're introspective enough to consider your own behavior suggests the problem is not with you.

title: What do I do about a cousin who makes me feel belittled, insecure and frustrated?

title: I lie to my mom about my relationship

The week after his birthday, my mom made me stop talking to him. It broke me. He came to my house and talked to her, and she let us date again but not see each other. He comes up to my school every day and it tears me apart that I have to lie to her.

title: My ex-boyfriend wouldn't let me have my daughter because I didn't know my stepdaughter's pick-up details
author: speaker
text:
I am constantly having problems with the same two people who will always be in my life. I had a daughter with my ex-boyfriend. I am now married, and my husband’s ex-girlfriend is involved with my ex-boyfriend. They also have a daughter together. My issue is that there is always drama. I am pregnant, and I told my ex-boyfriend that I don't want any drama or arguments. I want to get along as much as possible, and he agreed. However, we just had an incident where my ex-boyfriend started discussing drop-off details about my stepdaughter. I told him that he needed to ask my husband because I can't make decisions about my stepdaughter regarding the matter. That led to an argument. I told him all my concern is when I pick up my daughter. My stepdaughter’s pick-up details are between my husband and his ex-girlfriend. I especially told him I didn't want to be involved. Somehow, he turned it around and then wanted to change the schedule we agreed on. He threatened me and got ugly because I wouldn’t discuss my stepdaughter’s matters with him.
   The point is there is so much drama. I try my best to get along with everyone. I don't understand where I went wrong (besides replying back to his question). I feel like I'm going crazy because this is a constant battle where everyone’s frustrations are taken out on each other, and it's the children that are hurting. I had a party planned for my daughter’s birthday, and my ex-boyfriend told me to cancel those plans because he wouldn’t let me have her. In my eyes, it’s the child that is hurting. I was throwing a party for her birthday, and because of the problem with stupid pick-up details about my stepdaughter, which I have no control over, he took it out on our daughter.

title: My ex-boyfriend wouldn't let me have my daughter because I didn't know my stepdaughter's pick-up details

title: Why does my mom show more love to my brothers than me?

title: Why does my mom show more love to my brothers than me?

title: Why does my mom show more love to my brothers than me?

title: I'm in love with a sex offender, but my family doesn't accept him

Should I forgive this man that I'm falling in love with or should I dump him? If I stay with him I will never see my family and granddaughter again.

title: Keeping secrets from my family
author: speaker
text: I have secrets in my mind, and I don't know what to do with them. I don't want to tell my wife and mom because I don't want to hurt them. But I'm not sure how long that I can keep the secret to myself. What should I do? It's becoming annoying and making me anxious. Help me out

title: Keeping secrets from my family
author: listener
text: It sounds like keeping the secrets has become a problem for you now.

title: Keeping secrets from my family
author: listener
text: There are several things to consider before you make a decision.- You mentioned that you don't want your wife and mom to know because you don't want to hurt them – why would it hurt them?

title: Keeping secrets from my family
author: listener
text: - Is it necessary for them to know this information?- What are the consequences of either telling them the truth or not telling them?

title: Keeping secrets from my family
author: listener
text: (for you and for your wife and mom).- Once you have considered these, think of what you would tell your friend if they were in your exact situation?- Also, if your wife or mom were in your situation right now, what do you think they would do themselves?- If your wife and mom were in this situation, how would you feel?

title: Keeping secrets from my family
author: listener
text: Would you want to know the secrets?- How has keeping these secrets affected your own mental and physical health?Once you have looked at the problem from all angles, you will be able to better make a decision on whether it is right to tell them or not.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: speaker
text: What makes a healthy marriage last?

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: This is a fantastic question.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: In one sentence, I would say the following:Recognize that while you and your partner probably have common interests and areas of commonality, you are separate people, each with different wants, wishes, and desires – if you consider a diagram of two overlapping circles, they may share perhaps a third of the circle with overlap to indicate commonality (could be more or less) and then there are parts of the circles that are not overlapping, indicating separate interestsAs for ways that may strengthen any relationship, even the great ones, this is what came to mind.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: There are certainly more specific unique answers or elements for different people as far as the details, but here are some general ideas:Try to have at least 15 minutes a week where you are spending time together and not problem-solvingRealize that listening to your partner does not mean that you are agreeing with them, it just means that you are saying that you hear where they are coming fromLearn to hold on to your own wants, wishes, and desires while also recognizing those of your partnerSet boundaries for what is and isn't acceptable behavior during an argument or difficult discussionDiscuss how having important discussions can be anxiety-producing and consider having an understanding that if one of you (or both of you) feels overwhelmed, you can take a timeout for a certain amount of time.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: For example, you may say "okay, I'm feeling really stressed about this right now.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: Let's discuss it in an hour."

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: And at that time, go back to the discussionConsider what your partner's top three or four complaints about you may be.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: Check in with them and see how accurate you are.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: If you see validity in their responses, consider whether or not you may want to make changesDiscover what makes your partner feel loved, valued, appreciated, or specialRelationships are always in progress and constantly changing.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: Some anxiety around change is typical.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: Being able to effectively discuss the anxiety and actually listen to one another without being defensive, name calling, finger-pointing, or asking each other to change is a true gift.You may enjoy this quote: "Connection is the energy that is created between people when they feel seen, heard, and valued; when they can give and receive without judgment."

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: ~Brene Brown

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: speaker
text: What makes a healthy marriage last?

title: What makes a good marriage?

title: What makes a good marriage?

title: What makes a good marriage?

title: What makes a good marriage?

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: In addition to suggesting this great read from 2016 (but feels timeless):https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/29/opinion/sunday/why-you-will-marry-the-wrong-person.html?_r=0I will give my summary on what the author of the article is speaking to: don't get too comfortable.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: But, in truth, no one really has the answer to your question, otherwise wouldn't we all have a "good" marriage?

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: Also, what even is a "good marriage?"

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: What is it that YOU want from a marriage, a relationship, a partner, and what your other-half also wants for themselves, is going to be what defines all of this, because every relationship is different.And in answering that "what YOU want" question, you might actually stumble upon what would make for a healthy relationship: vulnerability.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: You will have to be vulnerable to be able to explore what you really want, and listen to what your partner really wants, as that kind of processing can be uncomfortable.

title: What makes a good marriage?
author: listener
text: But, with vulnerability comes intimacy, and in most opinions, there is much of a relationship if there isn't much intimacy.

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?
author: listener
text: Does your husband want to listen to you?Find this out by asking him the question!This way you know whether the goal you'd like to reach is even possible.Some partners prefer that one person is the rule maker or the only one who is entitled to talk about themselves.If your husband tells you he wants to listen to you, or even that he does listen to you, then you can explain in detail the way you define "listening", which may be very different than his definition.Basically, no one can directly change someone into being more openminded.What is possible is to tell him your wishes, your willingness to be patient while he develops the habit of listening to you and point out that a relationship is more fulfilling when both partners feel they are receiving from the other one.

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

author: listener
text: Unfortunately you can't directly change another person's behavior.

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

text: The best way to provide feedback is in 3 parts.

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?
author: listener
text: The first part is telling him the emotion you are experiencing when he doesn't listen, such as hurt, sad, and unloved.

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?
author: listener
text: And the last part is the most important, tell him what you want him to do, and again be specific!

title: How do I get my husband to listen to me?
author: listener
text: Example: I would rather you turn off the tv, give me eye contact and reassure me about my day.

title: My husband seems to be changing, and I feel angry and hurt
author: speaker
text: My husband took a job out of state for the next year and seems to be a different person. Before, he worked and slept, and on off days, he'd stay home because he didn't want to do anything else. He's suddenly saying he misses me and wants me to be his adored wife, but the whole time, I'm remembering how I've been emotionally starving for the last five years.

title: I'm disgusted by my own fetish
author: speaker
text: I have an overwhelming desire to watch my wife have sex with another man. I talked to her about it, and she said she will do it for me. The idea excites me to no end, but I don’t want to because it disgusts me. How can I stop wanting it, or should I just give into it and do it? I’ve been struggling for years with this. It won’t go away. By the way, I am in my mid 30s and my wife is in her mid 40s.

title: I'm disgusted by my own fetish
author: listener
text: Try to understand your own ambivalence to having your wish fulfilled.Since you and your wife are in a relationship, the sex she will have with another man will affect emotions in both you and your wife.I suggest you and her prepare emotionally before you both go ahead with the sexual arrangement,By anticipating any jealousy or feeling helpless or out of control, or in control, since it's your wish being fulfilled, all the feelings you and her are able to expect, you'll be more prepared for the actual emotions from the episode, which may also resolve your conflicted feelings about creating the event.There are a lot of unknowns in the situation you're considering.

title: I'm disgusted by my own fetish
author: listener
text: Having your partner, who will be key in satisfying your sex wish, be active in understanding these unknowns, is a good way of keeping your relationship strong overall.

title: Can my marriage be saved?

Can this marriage be saved or is it too late? He said he would go to counseling, so I don't think he has given up.

title: Can my marriage be saved?

title: Can my marriage be saved?

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: speaker
text: My husband doesn’t trust me for some past we had. I know all marriages have their ups and downs, but sometimes, I feel I am getting tired of the same thing over and over: that I am messing around, which I am not.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: The good news in the way you're feeling is recognizing that your husband's trust of your actions, makes a difference to you.The typical therapy formula for restoring trust between two people after some sort of betrayal, is for the one who has broken the trust, to earn it back.Restoring trust requires both persons to actively involve themselves in this process.The person who tires earning back trust, must know what standards for this, of the one who was betrayed.The person who feels betrayed must willingly be open minded to accepting the efforts of the one who tries earning back their trust.As simple as this formula sounds, the actual process of restoring trust raises a lot of emotion on both sides, therefore causing difficulty in keeping discussions in this area, on track.The best way of success in restoring trust between partners, is utilizing a couples therapist who would be able to guide your conversations back on track, and also open emotions for discussion when relevant to restoring trust.Good luck in establishing new terms with your partner!

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: speaker
text: My husband doesn’t trust me for some past we had. I know all marriages have their ups and downs, but sometimes, I feel I am getting tired of the same thing over and over: that I am messing around, which I am not.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: It is incredibly frustrating to not be trusted when you know you are doing nothing wrong.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: If the lack of trust on your husband's end has to do with something you did in the past, then be patient and give it time.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: Once trust is broken it takes time and effort to gain it back.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: Try seeing the situation from your husband's perspective, as often times looking at situations from different angles, gives us new understanding and insight.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: Remember that you can't change how he feels, but you can help him to regain the trust by asking him what he needs and responding to his needs as best you can.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: Seeing a couple's counselor is never a bad idea and it would also be beneficial for you and or/your husband to seek out individual therapy.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: There may be other unknown factors that you are unaware of that are contributing to the trust issues and inability to resolve them.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: Hope everything works out for you!

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: speaker
text: My husband doesn’t trust me for some past we had. I know all marriages have their ups and downs, but sometimes, I feel I am getting tired of the same thing over and over: that I am messing around, which I am not.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: Hi Louisiana,It's normal when trust has been broken in the past for fear and insecurities to come up from time to time.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: His reactions may not mean that he doesn't trust you, but rather that he gets scared that he's going to be hurt again.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: You're a bit vague about the past.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: You don't say whether you cheated or not.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: If you did, then you might try taking an approach where you a) take responsibility for your past actions, b) show an understanding of and compassion for his pain about that, c) do everything you can to demonstrate trust and show that he is your priority, and d) reassure him when he says he's scared or feeling insecure.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener
text: I'm suggesting that part of healing is you having tolerance of his emotions and demonstrating that you're so confident you can be faithful that you can handle his moments of fear.

title: My husband doesn't trust me
author: listener

title: How can I stop bulimia after 6 years?

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: speaker
text: I have a problem with binge eating, especially during times of stress. I binge eat and feel so overwhelmed with shame and disappointment that I end up going to the gym and trying to exercise the calories off. I am in my late 20s, and I have been dealing with this since I was a teenager. Are there any coping mechanisms I can use to break this cycle?

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: Hello,This question describes a very typical setup of what is called the  Binge, Repent, Repeat cycle.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: This means that typically after you binge, you experience emotions as you described "shame and disappointment" and then because of these emotions you "repent" (i.e.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: vow to never binge again, promise to "do better," go to the gym, etc.)

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: and then ultimately end up bingeing again.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: There are many coping mechanisms for binge eating and one of the best is actually attempting to NORMALIZE eating.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: Meaning you need to attempt to eat normally, eating appropriately portioned meals 3 times a day, with snacks in between.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: IF you binge, then it may be helpful to remind yourself that when you attempt to compensate for your bingeing behaviors, and you end up feeling restricted from over exercising or undereating, then this actually leads to a binge again.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: Thus, reverting you back to the cycle.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: If you binge, it will be helpful to try and get back on a normal schedule of eating instead of trying to compensate for the binge.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: Although it may feel counterproductive, getting back on a normal eating schedule will prevent you from entering into the restrictive cycle.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: It can also be helpful to remind yourself that the binge has already occurred, it is in the past and the goal is to move forward without focusing on the past.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: Focus on what you can do differently next time.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: What emotions or situations led up to the binge?

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: What can you to do prevent or change the circumstances that led to the binge, or the way that you handled the situation?

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: Lastly, if you're struggling with "normalizing" eating, it can be helpful to work with a professional that can provide counseling and coaching to help you learn how to eating normally, mindfully and without feeling the guilt and other harmful emotions sometimes associated with disordered eating.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: I would be more than happy to assist you if you ever have any questions or want to reach out to somebody.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: You can contact me via my website: http://www.maddenwellnessky.com/

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: speaker
text: I have a problem with binge eating, especially during times of stress. I binge eat and feel so overwhelmed with shame and disappointment that I end up going to the gym and trying to exercise the calories off. I am in my late 20s, and I have been dealing with this since I was a teenager. Are there any coping mechanisms I can use to break this cycle?

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: I believe that for results that last, the best approach is to understand why someone feels like doing a certain behavior.

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener

title: How do I handle my binge eating?
author: listener
text: This is a valuable awareness of realizing you deserve patience and respect, not humiliation and severe criticism when you are lost as to best ways of self-care.

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?
author: speaker
text:

   How can I get rid of these insecurities and be more trusting with her?

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?
author: listener
text: Two paths are possible.You're not overreacting and instead are genuinely sensing that something feels unsettled within your girlfriend.You are overreacting because you have difficulty accepting how safe and loving your relationship is with this person.The only way to find out is to start conversations with your girlfriend on how you feel.This will allow new light to open an answer as to the truth.Once you know what truly is going on between the two of you, your self-trust naturally will grow stronger.

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?
author: listener
text: Self-trust will give you an accurate read of what and whom you are able to safely trust.

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?

text:

   How can I get rid of these insecurities and be more trusting with her?

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?
author: listener
text: What's most important is that you recognize that what you've been doing is off base - that what you've been feeling is "overreacting," that you have "insecurities," and you suspect your actions and reactions are connected to your own past and not to the current situation or to your partner.

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?
author: listener
text: That's an excellent first step because without recognizing these things about yourself, it's unlikely that you would change.That said, you sound as if you are really ready to start some therapy to work on your own personal growth... not because there is something "wrong" with you, but because you're ready to learn more about yourself and make some creative changes in your behavior.

title: Why can't I let myself trust my partner?
