title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: speaker
text: I’ve been in a long distance relationship with my girlfriend for just over a year. This past week she admitted to me that she has feelings for another guy. She says it’s “just a crush” but I don't know how to cope with it.    How should I deal with this?

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Long distance relationships are very difficult to maintain, not just for the lack of communication, but also because of the lack of intimacy that comes along with it.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Even if you have spectacular communication while in a long-distance relationship, it is difficult to maintain intimacy because you are lacking in the physical contact aspect of intimacy.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Here, we are not talking about sex, but about the emotional connection that happens along with physical contact.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: It is also hard to have shared experiences when the two of you are in separate places.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: These are the challenges that you face, but there are some ways to improve your odds.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: The first thing to remember here is that dating is all about finding a person that you want to eventually dedicate your time, resources, and self to.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: If either of you finds that the relationship is one that you are not necessarily committed to, it is better to find out and have the opportunity to date others before a commitment is made.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: The second thing to remember is that open communication is a good sign in a relationship.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: That being said, I do not believe that sharing details about your "crushes" is the best thing for a relationship.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Instead, I would recommend working on improving the relationship as best you can.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: It is a wonderful thing when we can feel that we have given our best efforts on something, especially something as important as the act of loving.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Here are a couple things that you can do to improve even a long-distance relationship.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Start by downloading the Gottman Card Decks App here https://www.gottman.com/couples/apps/.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: While on the phone or video chat, try asking each other some of these questions so that you can build a deeper knowledge of one another.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Some may seem silly, but they help you know the other person more intimately.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: It is also helpful to make sure that you are having regular communication with each other.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Some situations make it very difficult to communicate, but if at all possible, daily communication via phone or video chat would be best.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Even if it is just for 30 minutes a day, really dedicate your time and attention to each other during those calls.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Next, it can be helpful to know each other's love languages so you can show each other how much you really care.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Take the assessment for the 5 Love Languages and talk about the results together.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: You can find the assessment here: http://www.5lovelanguages.com/profile/Attraction to other people is completely normal and involves biological processes.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Intimacy, on the other hand, creates real connection and dedication to each other.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Learn about each other, spend time together, and you will create intimacy.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: speaker
text: I’ve been in a long distance relationship with my girlfriend for just over a year. This past week she admitted to me that she has feelings for another guy. She says it’s “just a crush” but I don't know how to cope with it.    How should I deal with this?

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Thanks for writing in.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Several things come to mind:I don't know how you are communicating, but there is a great deal of difference between communicating through videoconferencing compared to text message when discussing subjects like this.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Being able to hear and/or see each other will help you to be able to gauge a lot of the emotions connected to what is going on.Are you in a place where you can ask your girlfriend questions about this crush and actually listen to her answers?

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: If you can listen non-defensively and ask questions about what is actually going on (kind of like an investigative reporter might), you are likely to hear about her experience, thoughts, feelings, etc., so you can actually see what the crush is like for her and how you want to react to that.Then you could see if she is willing to listen to your questions and answer them for you.Another tip: Find out when is a good time to have this conversation.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: If you are talking to your girlfriend after she just worked a 10 hour shift and she is frustrated about that, it is likely that the emotion will transfer to the conversation that you are having even though it doesn't have anything to do with that.Find a way to keep yourself grounded and centered during the conversation.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Notice your feet on the floor or your hips in the chair.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Mindfully play with an object or something like a paperclip or a pen.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Doing this mindfully (by being aware of your senses) will help you to not feel so overwhelmed during the conversation.After you have more details, communicate about what it is that you want or wish for.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: It is often easier to hear and discuss as opposed to talking about something that you need.Remember that while anger is a very real emotion, there is always something else under it.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Be aware of what else could be there: hurt, disappointment, betrayal, fear, etc.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: speaker
text: I’ve been in a long distance relationship with my girlfriend for just over a year. This past week she admitted to me that she has feelings for another guy. She says it’s “just a crush” but I don't know how to cope with it.    How should I deal with this?

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Did your girlfriend tell you her reason to tell you about the new person?Your feelings of insecurity is natural because you don't know where the crush fits into her life.Since any long-lasting relationship in which both people thrive, means each partner freely speaks their mind and will be listened and responded, then your current situation is a good one to start these foundations of talking with one another.Tell your girlfriend whatever is on your mind regarding her crush.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: As your trusted partner, theoretically she would like to know all about how you feel.Keep the expectation that talking about anything at all, is the best sign of closeness.Once you learn more about this crush you can decide what, if anything to do differently in your relationship.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: speaker
text: I’ve been in a long distance relationship with my girlfriend for just over a year. This past week she admitted to me that she has feelings for another guy. She says it’s “just a crush” but I don't know how to cope with it.    How should I deal with this?

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Those words must have been extremely difficult to hear or read.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are both having difficulty with the distance, and I can only imagine that you have both been coping with this distance as well as you can.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: There are a few scenarios that I think would have pretty radically different paths for your own mental health, and I would like to explore them separately.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: The first scenario is that she has this crush, but still chooses you and wishes to stay with you.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Keeping the value of her choice in mind, and the bravery she has shown in admitting this crush, handling her gently in that vulnerable place will pay off.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: You may find it worthwhile to explain your feelings about it, to share how it is hurting you to know of this, and what she means to you.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Explaining those feelings will help you to not act out in your with emotions to cover up by becoming angry or withdrawing.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Acting in this way will help assure her of her choice in you, and sharing these emotions and feeling supported by her may help you cope with this.The other scenario is that she has a crush on this man and she is wanting to leave the relationship with you to have one with this other person.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: As before, it would be useful for you to share your feelings with someone.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: It can be difficult to process through these emotions, as they are intense and often overwhelming.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: In this scenario, it may be too difficult to share these feelings with your girlfriend, but it is still important that you acknowledge this loss and allow the associated emotions to have its place.

title: How can I deal with a “crush” in a relationship?
author: listener
text: Grieving the end of this relationship could be a great source of personal growth.I hope this has been of some help.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: speaker
text: I've been with a man for four years. For the last year, he has said he is done, but he still talks, texts, visits, and has not moved on with anyone else. His words do not match his actions. I love this man, but it's hurting so much.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: If I understand you correctly, this "maybe-boyfriend" has done a partial break up, and wants to maintain a partial relationship.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: Is that ok with you?

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: And, if it is, what does it cost you?

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: He says he's "done" but still wants the connection.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: That seems to leave him free to explore other options, but it doesn't allow you to do the same.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: Break ups are painful, and I know you'd like to avoid that.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: I get it that you feel attached to him - you have been in a relationship with him for 4 years, so that makes sense.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: However, loving him appears to be costing you a lot, without much in return.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: If you wait for him to define what he wants, you could be on hold for a long time.Please don't wait another year to advocate for yourself.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: See a therapist who can help you figure out what you need out of relationships and why you have allowed yourself to be on "pause".

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: It is possible that once you get clear, you will be able to have a true relationship with him.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: If not, please don't settle for this.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: Take good care of yourself.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: speaker
text: I've been with a man for four years. For the last year, he has said he is done, but he still talks, texts, visits, and has not moved on with anyone else. His words do not match his actions. I love this man, but it's hurting so much.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: This can be difficult and confusing.If you think your boyfriend would be open to having a discussion, try asking him for a time when he is willing to have an important discussion.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: When that time matches with a time that is good for you, try discussing the type of relationship that you each want to have and what you can start and stop doing to get there.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: He may want to be really good friends.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: He may also be trying to figure out what he is feeling.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: If you end up talking over one another, try letting one person be the one who is talking about their feelings for about five minutes and during that time, try having the other person asked questions to gain more understanding of their experience.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: Then you can switch.

title: My ex-boyfriend say we're finished but still acts like we aren't
author: listener
text: Also consider asking questions that cannot be answered with yes or no, but lead to more explanations.Questions that start with the words how, what, when, who are usually better than questions starting with "why" because they can be emotional triggers for some people.If this is difficult to do between the two of you, consider seeing a therapist who specializes in couples.

title: I want to become a better man
author: speaker
text: I'm having relationship problems and I want to fix them to make things right before I lose her. How can I learn how to listen and get myself together?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: First, I want to say that it is great that you are are willing to admit that you share some responsibility in some of the relationship problems you are having.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: This isn't always easy to do, but it sure is important if you want to see improvement.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: It does sound cliche, but communication really is the bedrock of relationships.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: And not just intimate partner relationships, but really any relationship that is significant to us.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are saying that you have a difficult time really listening to what your partner is telling you and then responding in a way that is helpful.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: I want to tell you that you are not alone.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Good communication skills are not really something you are born with, we actually have to learn them.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: The good news is that there is great information available to help you do that.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Ultimately, some people must seek professional help through couple's counseling in order to get help with this process.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: This is because some of the hurt and anger could be at such a level already that you may need help setting boundaries, creating a plan, learning new skills, and staying on track.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: If that is not something you can afford or can do right now, here are a few suggestions that may help.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Personally, I am big fan of Dr. John Gottman.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: He is an expert in relationships and wrote a really great, easy-to-read book called The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Dr. Gottman discusses the kind of communication that healthy couples seem to have, which can be helpful and worth trying.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: You can buy Dr. Gottman's book on Amazon for under $9.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: It's a good deal.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: There are a variety of websites that have good information that may help you build your communication.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Here is one that I found that has a few good tips.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: http://www.helpguide.org/articles/relationships/effective-communication.htm You can try them and see if they are helpful.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: ***It is important to remember that like all new skills, communication requires practice and we surely fail several times before we start getting good at it.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: If you were ever a pitcher in baseball, then you know you have to throw thousands of pitches before you really start hitting your strike zone consistently.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Allow yourself to make mistakes, own them, and start again.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: I hope these suggestions help, and good luck.Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC

title: I want to become a better man
author: speaker
text: I'm having relationship problems and I want to fix them to make things right before I lose her. How can I learn how to listen and get myself together?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Thanks for your question.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Becoming a good listener is an essential piece in being a better communicator.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Being an effective communicator will almost always improve the quality of your relationships.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: What stands in your way of listening to her?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Do you find yourself becoming defensive when she brings up issues?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Do you often find yourself thinking of what you want to say next?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Do you take her words personally, preventing you from having the ability to problem solve?Here are some tips that may help you with being a better listener:1.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Concentrate on what you are hearing, not on what you will say next.2.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Ask questions if you need clarification or don't understand.3.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Summarize what you're hearing after every couple of minutes to make sure that you're not missing anything.4.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Ask your partner what she needs from you.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Is she expecting advice or does she simply need to vent?5.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Keep eye contact and avoid using non-verbal cues that demonstrate defensiveness or irritation such as eye rolling or crossing your arms.6.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Remember that it's okay to disagree and, if this is the case, then decide as a team, how you want to move forward.I hope this helps.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Good luck to you!

title: I want to become a better man
author: speaker
text: I'm having relationship problems and I want to fix them to make things right before I lose her. How can I learn how to listen and get myself together?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: I love that you are so thoughtful and proactive about this!

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: If only every client came in as solution focused as you, my job would be so much easier.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: I would second Robin's suggestion of reading ANYTHING by Gottmann.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: He's fantastic.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Other favorites of mine are:“Getting Together and Staying Together: Solving the Mystery of Marriage” by Dr. William & Carleen Glasser“Eight Lessons for a Happier Marriage” by Dr. William & Carleen Glasser“Hold Me Tight” by Dr. Sue Johnson“Divorce Busting: A Step-By-Step Approach to Making Your Marriage Loving Again” by Michele Weiner-Davis, M.S.W.“The Five Love Languages” by Gary Chapman“The Flight from Intimacy: Healing Your Relationship of Counter-Dependency – the Other Side of Co-Dependency” by Drs.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Janae & Barry WeinholdI'll also add to Miriam's assertion that your partner is the expert on her.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: You can help things along by becoming a better expert on you as well.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: What is it that you are craving and likely trying to get your need met in potentially unhelpful ways from your girlfriend or in ways she doesn't understand or vibe with?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: If you can better explain your own needs while trying to understand hers, you all have a recipe for great success!

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: When both partners seek to serve one another and stay curious about each other in the process, intimacy abounds!Best of luck my friend!

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: And if you get stuck, of course seeking help from a professional is always a great idea too.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener

title: I want to become a better man
author: speaker
text: I'm having relationship problems and I want to fix them to make things right before I lose her. How can I learn how to listen and get myself together?

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: The first step for making this sort of change is being motivated to change and it sounds like you have that, so you are already on the right track.As far as learning how to listen, try some of these steps:Ask whether a certain time is a good time for your girlfriend to have an important conversationIf she has a subject that she would like to discuss, consider listening to her as an investigative reporter and asking questions that help you to gain more understanding of her experience.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: These questions usually begin with words like who, what, where, when.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Questions starting with the word why can sometimes make people very uncomfortable because they may not explicitly know why they are asking for something or feeling a certain way.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: You can try communicating this way for just five minutes or so on until you feel as though you can restate what your girlfriend is saying and have her agree that you are recapturing the essence of what she is trying to communicateThen you can switch so she is listening to you trying to understand your experience.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: You could also start by talking about something that is important to you.Remember that stating that you follow or hear something that she is saying doesn't mean that you agreeAlso, try sticking to one subject at a time.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: It's difficult to really understand one topic if you are on to the next within just a minute or twoTry to use the word want or wish instead of need.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Saying that you need something (or if your girlfriend would say that) that is not a need for safety or something like that can make whatever you are asking for sound like an obligation.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: That takes away from that whole motivation to change from inside the partner who is agreeing to change or try to changeSomething else to try would be using some sort of timeout.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Consider this:Discuss the idea of using timeout before you actually need it and before the discussion starts.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Timeout is a way to give each of you a way to calm down for five, 10, 15 minutes, or maybe even an hour.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: When there are a lot of emotions happening, each person gets wrapped up in protecting themselves from the emotions they are feeling and can lose track of what is actually going on in the conversation as compared to what they are perceiving.When using timeout, say to your girlfriend (or she can say to you) "I need an hour before we can go back to this."

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Then actually come back to the discussion.Some people are very afraid to use this technique because in the past not talking about something right away meant that it never was returned to and was never resolved in any way.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: This is why the agreement is important before you need it.While it may be helpful to ask your girlfriend what it is she may want from you, it is you that would be in charge of deciding whether you want to make that change and putting it into practice.Try to remember that part of being in a couple is holding onto your own wants, wishes, and desires while recognizing those of your partner.As one final idea, consider spending about 15 minutes a week together where you are not problem-solving about anything, just connecting with one another.I encourage you to see a therapist who specializes in couples if you would like some more specific ideas for what is happening within each of you and between you.Best wishes!

title: I want to become a better man
author: speaker
text: I'm having relationship problems and I want to fix them to make things right before I lose her. How can I learn how to listen and get myself together?

title: I want to become a better man

text: Hard to say a whole lot without knowing more.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: However, if you focus your attention on her, what she's saying, what she's feeling instead of trying to make yourself heard and understood first, that's often a good step.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Also, work on building win-win agreements with her, and follow through on them.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Those are the areas I see men fall short on most often.

title: I want to become a better man
author: listener
text: Hope that helps!

title: Should I wait for this guy to make a move, or just move on?
author: speaker
text: I told him I liked him. He called me lovely and pretty but he said he didn’t want a relationship. He would always flirt with me.

title: Should I wait for this guy to make a move, or just move on?
author: listener
text: Well, as disappointed as you may very well feel from hearing this guy's answer, you know he doesn't want a relationship.What type of move would you like him to make?If you mean you'd be happy to have sex with this guy and not a relationship, then wait for as long as your patience allows.To wait for him to change his mind that he does want a relationship, doesn't have a very strong base on which to stand.Its possible to do this only consider the emotional price of your frustration to wait for someone to change their mind.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: speaker
text: I'm in a long-distance relationship with my ideal man, but I'm not as attracted to him as I should be. Everything else is perfect about him, but I find myself lusting over more attractive men. The next step is marriage, but I want to marry someone who I can wake up to and fall in love with all over again. However, I also don't want to throw away a great relationship over what might just be lust. Am I asking for too much in the "perfect guy"? Is there such a thing? Am I truly in love?

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Hi Montgomery, Your first sentence says it all.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: He might be an amazing person, but there's something missing for you.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: I'm curious...you say this is a long distance relationship.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Did you make a connection through social media or email first?

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Maybe a dating website?

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: I'm just wondering if this is the case.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: These modern ways of meeting people are awesome because we can be exposed to a wide variety of people who we never would meet in the grocery store or a friend's party.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: There are complications, though, and one of the drawbacks is you can feel very connected to someone and care about them a great deal before you ever meet them in person.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Then, when you finally meet them and there isn't that spark of magnetic physical attraction, you're in a bit of a difficult spot because you've already established that you're drawn to each other in other ways; you're already connected.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: It can be very awkward then to say "Now that I meet you, it doesn't feel the way it should for me".

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: In the future, I suggest meeting up in person early on, to answer that crucial question "Are we physically attracted to each other?".

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Clearly, this is not only important for you, but it is for most of us.My guess is that you feel you owe this man your affection and commitment even though you're not really all that into him (lusting after other men is a sign of that), because you like absolutely everything else about him.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: But honesty is crucial here, both with yourself and this man.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Just because you don't find yourself attracted to him doesn't mean that you're a bad person, or that he's not attractive.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: Someone else might drool over him and I think he deserves someone who does just that.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: You can have both love and lust.

title: I have the perfect guy, but I'm not attracted to him
author: listener
text: For most people, only one of them isn't enough.

title: How can I get over this girl I only knew for a year?
author: speaker
text: I met this girl in high school. She had switched schools at the end of the year, and I have not seen her since. It's been a few years. We had a very good and friendly relationship, and we seemed to have a lot in common. I never gained the courage to ask her out.

title: How can I get over this girl I only knew for a year?
author: listener
text: One way to make good use of the situation you describe is to prepare and rehearse within yourself the way you'd handle a similar situation in the future.Since a lot of time has gone by since you and this girl saw each other on a regular basis, right now you've got no idea if you'd feel the same way about her today as you did a few years ago.The relationship does point out the priorities and values you hold for a potential partner.

title: How can I get over this girl I only knew for a year?
author: listener
text: That you liked the friendliness you shared is good for you to recognize.

title: How can I get over this girl I only knew for a year?
author: listener
text: This way you realize you like friendship as a relationship property.

title: How can I get over this girl I only knew for a year?
author: listener
text: To have lots of similar interests, is another quality you appreciate in a partner.The more you know about what you do and don't like in a partner, the greater your chance to notice these qualities in someone new who comes along your path.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend is in recovery from drug addiction. We recently got into a fight and he has become very distant. I don't know what to do to fix the relationship.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: My empathy goes out to you.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Relationships are tough enough and i'm sure your partner being distant has been upsetting for you.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: You are confused and want to mend the relationship with him, but are finding it so hard to do.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Relationships require both people to work consistently in order to keep them happier, but if it is only you that is actively trying to repair the relationship, it can be emotionally draining.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Perhaps expressing you feel using I, you statements can be beneficial.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Do not accuse him or use "you" statements like "you are so distant"  or "you don't even care".Start out sharing your feelings by saying "I feel sad when you don't return my phone calls" or "I feel confused about our relationship ever since you have been keeping to yourself".

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: He may have a valid point, or might have been hurt by the argument and retreated as a result of it.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Regardless of why, use this time as a great opportunity to practice healthy communication.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: If you think you are not ready for a conversation like that, couples counseling can be excellent.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: You will have a skilled facilitator guide the conversation and help you both communicate with one another.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend is in recovery from drug addiction. We recently got into a fight and he has become very distant. I don't know what to do to fix the relationship.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: I'm sorry you have tension between you and your bf.A relationship means two people who relate, right?!

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: If only one person does all the work to change their approach, what they expect, what they offer the other, then this becomes the new problem to solve.If you've already done a significant amount of reflection and change in the way you relate to him, then the next step may be to be patient as long as possible while he decides what to change about his part in the relationship toward you.Substance abuse recovery requires profound effort and reflection.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: If it is successful then the result will show very different qualities in your bf than the ones you know currently.He may be so absorbed in the recovery that he can only concentrate on this.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Of course if the fights persist and you have been patient for what feels too long, then there are different questions to address.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: speaker
text: My boyfriend is in recovery from drug addiction. We recently got into a fight and he has become very distant. I don't know what to do to fix the relationship.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: I would first suggest you sitting down with him and voicing your concerns about how distant he has been, or more importantly you have felt that he is.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: This will give clarification to the situation as we need to remember that everyone's perception can be different.

title: How do I fix my relationship?
author: listener
text: Remember that relationships take work and take communication.

title: How come no man sparks my interest?
author: speaker
text: I was never single, afraid to be alone, and I looked for my boyfriend to make me happy. I finally worked on my self, was in a relationship, and I did everything a healthy girlfriend does and it didn't work out. Now months later, no man peaks my interest. Am I ready to date again? Is there a reason no one sparks my interest?

title: How come no man sparks my interest?
author: listener
text: Yes, of course there's a reason!There's always a reason for most dynamics!Depending on the nature and qualities of what changed as a result of your new self realizations, you may be more deeply affected by your new awareness than how you imagined these would go.Since you already are on the best road possible for yourself, since this resulted from your own introspection, keep trusting your own self work as to what develops and at what pace your relationship attraction qualities grow.

title: I'm having a hard time with a breakup
author: speaker
text: I was with my boyfriend for years on and off. We dated and broke up three times. Since we broke up five months ago I can't move on. I want to get back together but he won't talk to me. What should I do?

title: I'm having a hard time with a breakup
author: listener
text: Probably being sad to lose the relationship would be a good next move for you.When a relationship ends the daily life structure changes significantly.

title: I'm having a hard time with a breakup
author: listener
text: A break up means adjusting to differences in everyday life, not only that the person is no longer connected with us.Since your boyfriend isn't talking to you then you're keeping yourself sadder than necessary to not accept his actions.

title: I'm having a hard time with a breakup
author: listener
text: There's nothing you or anyone else can do change the fact that when someone decides to stop talking, this person is the only one who's in charge to start talking.Maybe since you've had several breakups w this person that you require more time to pass before you're willing to accept that his changed interest in the relationship is permanent.Be patient with your uncertainty as to whether he will or will not resume the relationship.

title: I'm having a hard time with a breakup
author: listener
text: Once enough time passes so that you're considerably past the point at which you and he come together, then accepting his leave-taking will feel natural.Right now its very understandable to have hope since you've been on this road before.

title: I'm having a hard time with a breakup
author: listener
text: In time you'll have your answer as to whether your future is with him or not.

title: My boyfriend feels that I have taken advantage of him
author: speaker
text:
I feel like I took our relationship for granted and he's now to the point that he's giving up.
   I have had trouble feeling like I could trust him but he's given me no reason not to trust him. I know my attitude is also a big issue for him. I have a lot of obligations at home so we don't spend a lot of time together.    How can I fix this relationship?

title: My boyfriend feels that I have taken advantage of him
author: listener
text: A key factor in a relationship is trust.I'd start by understanding more about why you feel unable to trust your bf.Does this have something to do with a bad encounter you had from previous relationships, or with a sibling or parent?Its also possible you're intuitively sensing you can't trust your bf bc he's not trustworthy.

title: My boyfriend feels that I have taken advantage of him
author: listener
text: Sometimes people sense the basic safety items in a relationship before they emerge.Also, your bf may have similarly suffered broken trust and he gives off a feeling of not welcoming your trust.Its possible you're feeling his own self-protection about being in a relationship with you.The best way to open these topics is to actually talk about them together with him.Whatever the underlying tensions are, talking about them always adds positive feeling and confidence to a relationship.

title: Why does my boyfriend think every some I like means something about our relationship?
author: speaker
text: Whenever I sing along with a song that I like (even if it's just for the beat and not the lyrics), my boyfriend assumes that the words of the song mean something negative about our realationship.    I don't why he gets so mad and assumes I mean something negative from every song. Now I can't enjoy and sing a song without him thinking I'm trying to give him a hint. He even accuses me of cheating and lying. It's driving me nuts. I love him and would never do such an awful thing ever. How can I get him to understand?

title: Why does my boyfriend think every some I like means something about our relationship?
author: listener
text: Well, have you told him similar descriptions of your feelings as you just wrote here?This will give him the same understanding you're allowing us to have here on this site.Keep in mind that the best, the amount and the number of times you tell your boyfriend some information about you, still means that whether or not he is willing to accept and rely on your information, is in his hands only.Try to feel satisfied with your own effort to explain yourself.

title: Why does my boyfriend think every some I like means something about our relationship?
author: listener
text: Another path to open is to ask your boyfriend his reason to feel insecure about your love for him.

title: Why does my boyfriend think every some I like means something about our relationship?
author: listener
text: This may open a wider discussion about what he feels he'd like from you so he feels good in the relationship.

title: I'm scared of losing my girlfriend
author: speaker
text:
My girlfriend recently started hanging out a lot more with one of her friends who did her wrong in the past and just walked out on her. So for the past 3 years its been just me and my girlfriend. Things have been great up until the last month. Now she ignores me and texts and hangs oit with her friend more and more.
   I dont know what to do anymore. My girlfriend is so distant. How do I keep from losing her?

title: I'm scared of losing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Well, if you each want to be with the other, than no one will be lost.Have you told her about feeling slighted?

title: I'm scared of losing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Start telling her about your feelings.

title: I'm scared of losing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: How she responds to you will tell you a lot about where her heart is and maybe too some of the reasons she has been so involved w the friend.Who knows, maybe the friend has problems of her own and your gf is spending extra time w the friend to help the friend, and doesn't even know you feel hurt.You would do yourself and your gf a lot of good to tell more about your feelings.

title: I'm scared of losing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: Either you will get more closeness and consideration, or not.

title: I'm scared of losing my girlfriend
author: listener
text: At least you will have the truth.

title: How can I be less dependent on my boyfriend?
author: speaker
text:
My boyfriend and I have been dating for almost 2 years. I've been really sad lately and for the past few months I've realized I'm just way too dependent on him. It makes me really upset to be so dependent on someone else, but I can't help it. I don't even know who I am without him.
   How can I be less dependent on my him?

title: How can I be less dependent on my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: From what you write you've got good motivation to change and awareness as to what you'd like to change.

title: How can I be less dependent on my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: These are very good predictors that you'll be successful in what you'd like to change.Try, the next time you realize you're depending on your bf instead of friends, yourself, to interrupt whatever typical action you'd take.Do something different instead!If when you'd like advice and usually ask your bf, ask a different trusted someone.Or, when you feel lonely, contact a friend or introspect on your own if usually you'd contact your bf.Also, being dependent on a bf is part of a trusting intimate relationship.

title: How can I be less dependent on my boyfriend?
author: listener
text: Dependency in the sense that you each are reliably available to each other, is a good quality.Only if it seems excessive, such as you're isolating yourself from other close friendships, is dependency on a partner, a problem.

title: I just feel so alone
author: speaker
text: I feel so alone. I have so many people around me, but it seems as they just listen and dont understand. They say it will all be okay, or they don't listen to me st all. Everyone says they are here for me but it doesn't feel like they are. Why do I feel so alone?

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: Although we can have moments when we feel alone, even with the presence of family and friends, feeling alone most of the time could be a sign that there is a lack of connection between you and your loved ones.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: Generally, the lack of connection can occur when you don't feel heard, understood or valued.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: These are common emotional needs that result in a good and secure emotional connection that reduces feelings of loneliness.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: You mentioned that "they listen but don't understand."

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: Do you communication clearly about what you need emotionally (understood, accepted, valued, heard, empathized)?

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: To help you ask for the right type of support, you can ask yourself what it is about the situation that is bothering you and how you would wish for your friends and family to respond to you.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: The result may be an answer that is more informative to your loved ones.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: For example, you might say, "Thank you for listening to me.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: When I feel alone, I feel like nobody cares about me because everybody seems busy with their lives.

title: I just feel so alone
author: listener
text: I just wanted to hear and feel that I'm valued by receiving caring messages and phone calls."

title: I just feel so alone

title: How do I start taking initiative in my relationship?
author: speaker
text: I don't speak up if I'm uncomfortable and hardly ever make plans for us when we hang out. He is a very open and straightforward person, so he is getting upset with me for my lack of proper communication. We've been together two years and have identified this as our main problem. Arguments have arised from this single issue many times.

title: How do I start taking initiative in my relationship?
author: listener
text: Do you know what you're afraid may happen if you do speak up?Usually people don't talk freely because they feel afraid to do so.

title: How do I start taking initiative in my relationship?
author: listener
text: Sometimes the fear of being rejected by the other, of being criticized or judged by the other person, or that what you will say stirs anger in the other person.If you are able to know what your particular reason is for not talking, then maybe you and your partner can talk about what makes talking easy or hard.Also, since speaking up is new for you, then ask your partner to be patient while you learn to do so.

title: How do I start taking initiative in my relationship?
author: listener
text: Everyone does better at learning new skills when they feel supported and welcomed.

title: Why do my boyfriend and I have such trouble communicating?

title: Why do my boyfriend and I have such trouble communicating?

title: Why do my boyfriend and I have such trouble communicating?

title: Why do my boyfriend and I have such trouble communicating?

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?
author: speaker
text: I'm dating this guy, Peter. My friend Jennifer used to date him a while ago, and she's fine with us dating. My ex-boyfriend, Paul, broke up with Jennifer, and she's devastated about it. Peter and I are going through a rough patch in our relationship. All of a sudden, Paul is in "love" with me, and he wants me back. I don't know what to do because I can't hurt my friend or my boyfriend, but I think I might Paul again.

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?
author: listener
text: The dynamics of having a romantic relationship with someone is not always clear.

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?
author: listener
text: Sometimes we jump from one relationship to another without giving ourselves a chance to adjust and grieve for the one we had to leave behind.

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?
author: listener
text: When you find yourself in a situation where a previous partner is coming back into your life and desires to be with you again, it is important to ask yourself what the motivations are prompting that return.

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?

title: I'm in a relationship, and I think I like my ex-boyfriend. Who do I choose?

title: Why doesn't any guy want to date me?
author: speaker
text:
I have high functioning autism and I have been on a lot of dating sites like meet me, match, and zoosk. I haven't had any luck on any of the dating sites I have been on.
    I really want a boyfriend but I don't know what I should do. I just want to be in a relationship. How can I meet someone?

text: Are there dating sites for people who have autism on the high functioning end?If not, then find out the names of different organizations which support people who have autism.

title: How can I ask my boyfriend about who he's texting?

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?

text: Hello.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: You are asking a very good question about how to sustain a long-distance relationship.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: Although maintaining a long-distance relationship has its challenges, with the proper communication, commitment, and understanding, many long-distance couples are able to thrive and maintain a close connection.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: Without knowing more about the "complicated" nature of your relationship, I wonder whether your boyfriend has given you reason not to trust him that makes afraid that he will find someone else.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: Has he cheated on you in the past and has shown romantic interest to another person that made you fear losing him?

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?

text: Or, is your thought just a fear but not based on evidence?

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: Knowing that distinction is important because if it is the latter, you may benefit from refocusing on the wonderful qualities about your partner that makes you feel good about him and the relationship rather than focusing on the unknown or uncertainty of the future.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: The more you focus on "what if" situations, the more you may feel anxious about a reality that is not accurate and make you act in ways that are insecure.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: However, if there is reason for you to question his fidelity, you may have to speak to your boyfriend about how to build trust in the context of a long-distance relationship.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: To help the conversation, you may need to consider what you may need to experience or receive as support to feel safe in the relationship to build trust.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: For many of my clients in my private practice, that may include talking to their partner often and using a variety of modalities including text, phone, and Skype.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: It's hard to believe in a relationship when you never talk to your partner, and it's hard to build a relationship when you don't know what's going on in your partner's life.

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?

text: Other times, it is Making sure they talk often to their long-distance partner so that they can participate in each others lives and to feel their presence..

title: How can I keep a long distance relationship going?
author: listener
text: Regular communication, understanding and caring is the key to sustaining any relationship, but this is especially true for long-distance ones.

title: My girlfriend is always accusing me of cheating on her when I haven't
author: speaker
text: Over a year ago I had a female friend. She turned out to be kind of crazy so I decided to stop talking to her. When she would call me I wouldn't answer the phone. This made my girlfriend really suspicious. She would ask me why I wouldn't ever answer that phone number. I told my girlfriend that I don't want to be friends with that other woman, but I don't think she believes me. How can I get my girlfriend to understand?

title: My girlfriend is always accusing me of cheating on her when I haven't
author: listener
text: Do you know why your girlfriend doesn't believe you?It is strange that your girlfriend prefers you to take the phone call of another woman.Have you blocked the unwelcome phone calls?Has your girlfriend said she doesn't believe you or is this your interpretation?Find out the answer and then ask your girlfriend to tell you her reasons behind her thoughts.It is much easier to help someone understand a situation if the person is engaged in a conversation.Whether or not she understands is up to her.All you can be responsible to do is to offer your explanation, which sounds like you've already substantially offered.Keep or reintroduce the topic for the two of you to talk about again.

title: What can I do about my partner's parents not liking me?

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: speaker
text:
About two and a half months ago, I met a woman on a dating site. We went out on two dates, and then despite her original plans on how to pace and conduct the relationship, I ended up at her house on a the Friday night one week after our first date. We respectfully tried not to have sex, but after hours of trying to resist each other, we gave in and we had sex. After that, I slept at her house every night for almost two weeks. Then one day, she went to her family’s house on Thanksgiving and everything changed. Within the short time we were together, we got so close and serious really fast. We had finally found each other. We told each other that we loved each other all the time, even while we were making love. A few days after Thanksgiving, she told me that we would have to go back to her original plans of seeing each other much less frequently. I was very hurt and didn’t understand. Then another week later, she told me she couldn’t do it at all anymore. I was crushed!
   A few days later, she tells me how much she’s missing me and “let’s get together for lunch” or something like that. Then about two weeks later, we finally get together one night and we were so hot for each other (in love, not just sex), but she confessed that the reason for the sudden distance was that the father of her very young child told her he wants to get back together and this totally messed with her. So for her child’s sake, she is now considering the possibility of allowing that to happen. She had told me all about him previously, and it is definite that she has little to no attraction to him, but she would do this putting herself in misery again for her child. Our love for each other is fully established and acknowledged, but she is torn and confused. She doesn’t even think it would work between them as she had to kick him out before for not fulfilling his role properly. I know she needs time, and all I can do is take care of myself. We have agreed to remain friends, and if this doesn’t work out for her, we will try again. I’m completely in love with her, and I’m in extreme pain.

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: listener
text: That sounds really heartbreaking.

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: listener
text: It is tough falling in love and not being able to dive fully because of complications on the other side.

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: listener
text: It sounds to me that you are doing exactly what you need to be doing by taking "care of myself" while the rest sorts itself out.

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: listener
text: While I admire your desire and courage to stay friends - the "extreme pain" that you mentioned may make this too challenging and at odds with your taking care of yourself.

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: listener
text: Since there is no commitment on her end to give it a shot with you I would make sure that you really honour your own feelings about what feels right to you so that you don't end up feeling strung along or resentful.

title: The love of my life wants to try getting back together with her child's father
author: listener
text: Make sure that you lean on friends and family at this time - we need all the support that we can get when we are heartbroken.

title: My ex-boyfriend put himself on a dating website because he thought I wasn't interested

title: What can I do to keep my relationship as good as it could be?
author: speaker

I try every day to show her she's the most important thing to me, but she can't even stay relatively sober at a fraternity party for me so that I won't worry about her doing anything regretful. We love each other, but we're in a rough patch.

title: What can I do to keep my relationship as good as it could be?
author: listener
text: You may already be doing as much as possible for your relationship.Each of you are 50% of the relationship.Is the 50% which your GF contributes to your relationship, based on the same understanding of the couple's problem, as you have?Maybe a good starting place for the two of you to talk about is defining what problem the two of you have as a couple.This way, each of you will be able to know if you have similar values and definitions of your reasons for being together.Depending on what you each expect from your partnership, you each will clearly know whether, and then how, to accommodate the other person.These discussions stir a lot of emotions in each person, so that sometimes staying clear minded becomes very difficult.

title: What can I do to keep my relationship as good as it could be?

title: Should I get back together with my ex-boyfriend who has trust issues?

text: Also, are you wanting to make things better with him, do you just want an ear to vent to, are you looking for validation, or do you hope someone will help you wake up to an unhappy situation?

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: It helps me if I know what you want.Whenever I meet someone who has a lot of complaints about their partner or boyfriend, I encourage them first to look at the language they're using.

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: Some of your words tell me that you think you know what he's thinking (that he wants to fight so he can leave, that he thinks he's perfect).

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: It's always tricky when we assume what someone's thinking, and in an argument or dialogue, these kinds of statements tend to lead to defensiveness and an escalated argument.

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: I'd encourage you to focus on his actual behaviours and how they affect you, rather than the motives or beliefs you think are behind the behaviours (because you really can't know what he's thinking unless he tells you).

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: As a general rule, the "When you do X, I feel Y" sentence goes far in helping others understand what we feel.So, it's fair to say "when you lie to me, I can't trust you", or "when you end our date early to hang with your friends I feel like I'm not important to you", or "your mood swings are difficult for me", or "I don't seem to get apologies from you".

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: Try to focus on his actual behaviour when you talk to him about this stuff.

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: A relationship counsellor can help you each understand the other better beyond the surface behaviours if you want to improve the relationship.That said, I have to ask...if you haven't been with Mr. Not So Great for very long, is it maybe time to rethink the relationship?

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: Unless there is a balance of really loving and positive behaviours that you're leaving out, you don't seem happy.

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: A good therapist can help you understand why you are stuck in an unhappy relationship, if that is what's happening.

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: There's a lot to sort out here...how to communicate about your needs, how to know when to call it quits if something doesn't feel good...

title: My boyfriend thinks he's perfect and puts his friends before me
author: listener
text: I wish you the best as you continue to examine these questions with assistance from friends or professionals.

title: I don't know where the lines should be drawn with my boyfriend's ex
author: speaker
text: I want us all to get along, but feel that I am not being respected. Of course I do have some insecurities because he was with his ex for 8 years. He wants to see his step daughter and ex makes it so he has to go there to see her, but she doesn't want me around. She has a boyfriend, but mine fixes their vehicles, goes over once a week and hangs out with the ex and does family things with her. Since he works nights, I only see him parts of Friday-Sunday and we live together. He won't let me use his phone when I forgot mine, says his ex used to mess with it. I don't think he's cheating, but he will lie about what time he actually left her place to come home or about going over early to be with them. I feel like the other woman. She has tried to mess with holiday plans by restricting when he can see the child. He only dated once person before her, so this could be why. I don't feel he has let go enough. He is a wonderful boyfriend other than this.

title: I don't know where the lines should be drawn with my boyfriend's ex
author: listener
text: How much of your unhappiness with your boyfriend's way of handling himself regarding his ex, have you told him?The topics that upset you are the core of any intimate relationship.The good news is your own awareness of priorities and expectations from a partner.There may not be any bad news, depending on whether your boyfriend has the interest to adjust what he does regarding the ex.Talking the matters you list, may open a lot of emotion and become sidetracked very easily.A couples' therapist, whose focus is on the couple, not either of you as individuals, may be useful to you and your boyfriend so that you are able to complete your discussions without getting lost by the emotions raised.

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me
author: speaker
text: Then turn right back around and say he loves me and needs me. This rollercoaster is crazy.

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me

text: Your partners obviously very confused when it comes to love.

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me

text: Sometimes people shy away from good and positive relationships and companionship because their afraid.

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me

text: They know that it's something worth holding on to but most feel they can't handle it and can't meet up to their partners expectations.

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me

text: Your partner loves you but must have fear that keeps standing in his way.

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me

title: My companion tells me he wants nothing to do with me

text: Give your partner comfort and reassurance that they can come to you to confide in you about anything that may be bothering them.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: speaker
text: I'm in a relationship with my fiancé and I currently found out that she's been cheating on me with a co-worker. I was very upset none the less. I understand what she did was wrong, but I want to spend the rest of my life with her. So I'm willing to forgive and move on. We have been together for a little over 9 years, and we have a son. At the beginning of our relationship, I was unfaithful and she caught me cheating. She forgave me for what I've done to her and since then I been completely faithful. I'm worried about our relationship and want to move forward but its been very unsettling. All I can think about is her with another man. I don't know what to do or where to go for advice?

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: What Makes Love Last?

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: how to build trust and avoid betrayal by John Gottman is a great book for you both to start reading.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: You may also want to invest some time and energy in couples therapy.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: It sounds like there is a lack of trust in your relationship, likely a hangover from your beginnings, that would be helpful for you both to work through to truly be able to forgive and move forward.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?

I understand what she did was wrong, but I want to spend the rest of my life with her. So I'm willing to forgive and move on. We have been together for a little over 9 years, and we have a son. At the beginning of our relationship, I was unfaithful and she caught me cheating. She forgave me for what I've done to her and since then I been completely faithful. I'm worried about our relationship and want to move forward but its been very unsettling. All I can think about is her with another man. I don't know what to do or where to go for advice?

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: My first question for you would be to see if you've talked with her about it yet?

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: It can also be frightening to bring up the experience when it hurts a lot, when you feel so unsettled as you mention.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: But you can look at this as a vital and important piece of information about what's happening in your relationship, and an invitation to get really honest and genuine with each other.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: You have a long history, being together 9 years, and a son, so you are very bonded no matter what changes happen in your relationship.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: It may be incredibly helpful to find a counselor you can both go talk with.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: Having a third party who is neutral and cares about your process and hers can be such a relief when you need to discuss things you feel scared about.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: Even just a few sessions can make a huge difference.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: If this doesn't feel possible for you right now.....ask your fiancee for time to set aside for a meaningful heart-to-heart talk.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: Say you'd like to set it up on the calendar, and make sure you have a babysitter for your son.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: Set aside at least 4 hours.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: Let her know that you'd like to hear her honest truth about what's going on, and share with her your truth as well.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: It's not a time for criticizing or condemning, and I don't sense that is your intention at all--you have a great deal of love for her.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: Speaking honestly and listening openly is an amazing gift, both for yourself and for your partner.

title: My fiancé cheated. How can we mend our relationship?
author: listener
text: You can do it.

title: There's this girl I've been dating for months

text: It can be really difficult when someone you care about doesn't feel the same about you.

title: There's this girl I've been dating for months

text: The most important thing to remember is that you can not make her feel a certain way.

title: There's this girl I've been dating for months
author: listener
