title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: speaker
text: I know someone who is extremely sensitive to stress and very sensitive to a negative tone of voice. Sometimes during a disagreement he tells me that my communication is having a harmful impact on him. Once he believes I am being negative I can't seem to find a better way of communicating. In fact, it is often a self fulling prophesy because his accusatory manner becomes unbearably frustrating.    What advice might you offer?

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: With any type of criticism, it is usually best to introduce the topic at a neutral time, ie: when both of you are relaxed, with no current stressors involved, having fun, etc.

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: Begin with a non-judgmental reflective comment about a recent bothersome event, as if it were just then crossing your mind (therefore not something you've been consumed with ruminating over - eases the impulse for him to dive straight into defense mode).Then share how you felt at the time of the event.

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: Just say when....

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: I felt kind of hurt / shocked (or whatever the feeling was).

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: PERIOD.

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: THATS ALL YOU SHOULD SAY.

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: Wait for him to respond to your matter-of-fact statement.No matter what his response is, stick to your same message - don't get overwhelmed by trying to rephrase or explain your view as that will likely set you up for continued arguing.

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: You can even add, "I agree I could have misunderstood  it (event)....

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: I just know it made me feel uneasy.

title: What can I communicate with a person who is sensitive to negativity in a disagreement?
author: listener
text: "Here you give him little wiggle room for a debate.Good luck & I'd love to hear how it goes!

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: speaker
text: What do I do if I have been feeling like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me. Or I couldn't have many friends because of who I am. It's strange I want to be loved but I'd hate to be because I always lose.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: As a relationship therapist I work with a lot of people who feel similar feelings to some degree or another and almost always find that the origin of these feelings point back towards childhood.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: How did you caregivers express (or not express) love towards you?

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: How did they express (or not express) love towards one another.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: These early messages become your template for how you have learned to see yourself and what you expect from others.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: In his book Wired for Love, Stan Tatkin, PsyD writes “We learn to love ourselves precisely because we have experienced being loved by someone.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: We learn to take care of ourselves because somebody has taken care of us.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: Our self worth and self-esteem also develop because of other people.”  This could be very fruitful to explore in individual therapy with a relationship therapist who really gets it, you may have to interview a few to find the right fit; that's OK. Maybe you'd even want to read that book I linked above.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: :) Noticing this pattern is HUGE, it's where transformation begins.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: And now that you have be kind with yourself, it begins there too.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: speaker
text: What do I do if I have been feeling like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me. Or I couldn't have many friends because of who I am. It's strange I want to be loved but I'd hate to be because I always lose.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me

text: I'm sorry you are feeling uncared for.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me

text: Sometimes when we get upset we may think irrationally and see the world as all or nothing.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: However, take a deep breath, relax and start focusing on the positive relationships you have with others, regardless of how small or insignificant they may seem.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: I think you will quickly realize there are people out there that care a great deal about you.I also think it would help for you to surround yourself among people who you can identify with and share common interests with.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: Maybe you can attend a religious service, join an interest group (i.e.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me

text: or start a group of your own.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: Most importantly, you need to tap into your interests and surround yourself with things that are beneficial for your own mental and physical health.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: From this, relationships will start to immerse.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: You may also like to talk with a therapist regarding your feelings of being unloved.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: This is an unhealthy way to think of yourself and I think with a little help, you can see that you are more than deserving of a great relationship.

title: I feel like I could never be with anyone because no one would want me
author: listener
text: Thanks for reaching out and I wish you the best of luck moving forward.

title: I cheated on my husband with one of his good friends a few years ago
author: speaker
text: We kissed and he grabbed my boobs and we exchanged some texts and a few calls. It went on for about 8 months. Just when we were all together and our spouses were out of the room. Once I met him for lunch to tell him that we needed to stop. We ended up kissing after lunch and then I sent him a few more texts that day telling him I was serious and that was the end of it. His wife (my good friend) saw us kiss once and told my husband. I told him a couple of things then and we got over it. A year later she told him a couple of other things. Same story. It's been about 3 years since. They are now divorced and my husband and I have been happy. A few weeks ago the wife called me and said that her now ex told her more stuff we did. I decided to just tell my husband everything. We are trying to work things out. But he is having a really hard time believing that he knows all of it. How can I help him believe me?

title: I cheated on my husband with one of his good friends a few years ago
author: listener
text: The issue at hand here is that you're betrayal broke his trust.

title: I cheated on my husband with one of his good friends a few years ago
author: listener
text: In order to repair your relationship you will both need to confront the infidelity.

title: I cheated on my husband with one of his good friends a few years ago
author: listener
text: And both of you will need to honor yourselves by communicating your feelings and ensuring that those feelings are heard and validated.

title: I cheated on my husband with one of his good friends a few years ago
author: listener
text: It would be really helpful to do this work with a Gottman or Emotionally Focused Couples Therapist.

title: I cheated on my husband with one of his good friends a few years ago
author: listener

title: My new husband constantly talks to himself

title: My new husband constantly talks to himself

title: My new husband constantly talks to himself

title: My new husband constantly talks to himself

title: My new husband constantly talks to himself

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure
author: speaker
text: My girlfriend's grandma passed away 5 months ago. They were very close. She took care of her till she died. Things kinda returned to normal few weeks later. Last month it feels like we hit a brick wall. Intimacy fell off. I asked what's up. She says she can't connect with anyone and that it's not me. She used to be very open and expressive. Now she gives short answers and has no interest in sex or any touching. When we did have sex in the last month, something felt really off. Now I'm very insecure about us and have thoughts of her cheating. She says otherwise, but I don't know. It just feels like something is really off.

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure
author: listener
text: Grief has a huge impact on us and everyone's reaction is different.

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure
author: listener
text: The one common reaction however is to shut down and distance ourselves.

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure
author: listener
text: Her relationship with her grandmother was close, given she took care of her up until she passed.

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure

title: My relationship feels off and I feel insecure

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: speaker
text: I find myself lying about small everyday things that there is really no need to lie about. How do I figure out what triggers me to do this? And how do I help overcome this problem? I would like to become more honest and open no matter the situation.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: Well let's start with the awesome realization you've already had, you want to notice that you have triggers.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: That's huge.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: Really.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: I find that when people lie, it's most often as a defense mechanism.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: Which is likely a flag that something doesn't feel safe.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: What exactly doesn't feel safe could be lots of different things but the key to notice is that it's that feeling of insecurity that is very likely triggering you.

title: I recently lied to my fiancé about my past
author: listener
text: It could really help to explore this with therapist, perhaps even someone with a trauma specialty -- that's not to say this is related to a trauma but more so to suggest that therapists specializing in trauma are very skilled at helping to identify and assist in repatterning your triggers!

title: I have been in a relationship for a year and 7 months these few weeks have been bad
author: speaker
text: He's been losing feelings and he doesn't know why. I love him very very much. He sometimes thinks I'm obsessed when I'm not at all. I give him his space and I make sure he's okay but sometimes I think if me and him saw each other more it would be better? I truly want me and him to get better, it's kind of hard not to stress about it, because the love of my life is losing feelings which is a sad feeling. He's a great guy! I just don't know why he's been losing feelings towards me. He's starting to put less effort in talking to me. At this point I'll do anything to just make us better as a couple. I tried talking to him but he doesn't like talking about it much. Advice on what to do?

title: How do I start talking again after a fight?
author: speaker
text: I haven't uttered one word to my boyfriend in days. Now I'm over it and don't know how to approach the situation?

title: How do I start talking again after a fight?
author: listener
text: In any relationship, it is important to be able to say "I'm sorry" because it shows vulnerability and openness.

title: How do I start talking again after a fight?
author: listener
text: I recommend that you sit and have a discussion with him now that you are calm about why you were upset and how you would like to handle such incidents in the future.

title: How do I start talking again after a fight?
author: listener
text: If you find yourself becoming upset again, I encourage you to take a 20 minute break and then come back to the conversation once you are no longer heated.

title: How do I start talking again after a fight?
author: listener
text: Studies show that talking or discussing arguments are more effective once you have cooled down and you are more likely to hear/understand what your partner is trying to convey.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: speaker
text:
I've been abused emotionally all of my life and for some reason I keep getting with men that I let emotionally abused me.
 How can I stop it? I know the mistakes that I've made in my life. I'm having a really hard time getting back on my feet. Can you help me please?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: I want to applaud you for taking this first step towards realizing that this is an issue and wanting to do something about it.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: You are already on the road to a happier life with this realization.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: A lot of women do not recognize that it may be something about them that continues to attract a man like this and will only blame it on the men for treating them that way.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: Until you realize there is a problem you won’t start looking for a solution.Don’t misunderstand me!

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: The abuse is not your fault!

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: You are seeing a pattern, though, so this does need to be addressed.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: The first step is to work on whatever it is in you that makes you feel like you need another person in your life.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: Identify those needs and then learn to fulfill them on your own.I was doing a couples therapy session and the husband was being emotionally abusive to the wife.

text: This was a recurrent theme for her, like you are saying it is for you.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: The difference this time was that she had done a lot of work on herself and had become a stronger person.

text: When she looked at him in our session and said to him “I don’t need you.

text: I want you.

text: But not if you are going to continue to act like this.

text: So you leave the house and don’t come back until you are ready to make some changes.”  She stuck to that, too.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: He didn’t leave for two more days because he kept telling her he would do different and begging to be allowed to stay.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: She had drawn a boundary and stuck to it, and he left.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: She was fully prepared to be single again.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: They actually did end up working things out in the end.You can’t let someone stay and continue to treat you badly.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: Sure, a marriage takes work and compromise on both sides.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: Couples therapy can help you both learn to communicate in a healthier way with each other and can help you realize what areas in the relationship need work.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: You may not realize how some of the things you say to him comes across, and he may not realize how what he says does to you.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: A therapist can help you with this so that you both learn how your words can hurt.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: But you need to know your boundaries and be prepared to stick to them and not compromise your boundaries.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

text: That means following through on the threat to leave when he continues to abuse you.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: Someone can’t do that if they are too scared to be alone.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: If they feel they need the other person in their life.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?
author: listener
text: These patterns are developed in early childhood from what we learn from our parents.

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: Why do I keep getting with men that emotionally abuse me?

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?
author: speaker
text: After 40 years of being straight, how could I now find myself interested in people of the same sex? I have had a few same sex encounters of my own doing.

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?
author: listener
text: What most people don't know is that sexual preferences can be fluid, meaning our sexual orientation is not as fixed as most people believe.

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?
author: listener
text: Women in particular tend to be more fluid in their desire to express and experience sex.

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?
author: listener
text: It is not uncommon for heterosexual women in their mid-life to explore new sexual appetites.

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?
author: listener
text: That said, men tend to be more rigid in their orientations particularly if they are hetero while gay men tend to be more fluid.

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?
author: listener
text: So if your distress is over your new interests I would tell you, you are not alone and not abnormal.

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?

title: How can I be interested in the same sex after nearly 40 years of being straight?

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: speaker
text: I'm a girl, and I can't tell whether I'm bisexual or gay. I like girls a little more than boys, but I don't really know.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: listener
text: Sexual orientation is not always something that is clearly definable.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: listener
text: Some people look at it on a continuum where being attracted to only boys is at one end, only girls is at the other, and bisexual is in the middle.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: listener
text: Anywhere in between those points can be any amount of attraction to boys or girls.If you don't know whether you are gay or bisexual, that is okay.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: listener
text: A lot of people don't know for quite some time.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: listener
text: In addition to that, after people do know who they are attracted to, a lot of times they do not use the terms "gay" or "bisexual" for quite a while.It's okay not to know.Think about what sorts of expectations you have for your ideal relationship.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?
author: listener
text: Some examples may include trust, respect, availability for conversation or connection, etc.

title: How do I know what my sexual orientation is?

title: My wife outed me to her sister

title: I’m afraid that I’m gay

I keep thinking about it and shake all the time.

title: I’m afraid that I’m gay

text: Are you able to give yourself some peace of mind while you take the time to further address whether or not you are gay?Whether or not and to what degree a person accepts their sexuality, depends on dense factors such as the culture of your family, the beliefs about gay people with which you were brought up, and your own tolerance for being a unique individual.Examining these factors, whether inwardly by yourself, in online blogs and sites, or live with other people, requires patience and effort.The more you are willing to commit to figuring out your own truth, the greater is your chance of finding it!

title: I crossdress and I don't know how to feel about it
author: speaker

title: I crossdress and I don't know how to feel about it
author: listener
text: If you enjoy cross-dressing and are comfortable with how you feelaand aware of your own thoughts and feelings about it in private as compared to in public,  I see no problem with that.If you would like to become more comfortable with it or express more feelings about it, I recommend that you  see a local mental health professional, not because there is anything wrong with what you are doing, but so you can learn more about yourself in the process.

title: I crossdress and I don't know how to feel about it
author: listener
text: You may find  that doing this in private and having a partner  who accepts that is your view of how you would like things to be.

title: I crossdress and I don't know how to feel about it
author: listener
text: You may discover that you would like to do this in public.I appreciate your honesty.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: speaker
text: I have always wanted to have a transition from male to female for some time now. This issue has persisted for 10 years already but I don't know where to start. I do not have the soundest information either.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: Wonderful!

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: I am so excited for you.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: What a huge decision.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: I am writing from Toronto Canada so it is hard for me to direct you specifically.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: I would start with two things 1) Find a doctor that is comfortable perscribing hormones and 2) find a Counsellor or Therapist that is transgender specialized.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: They will know how transitioning works in your health care system and other supports as well.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: Google is a wonderful way to find these resources.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: I wish you well.

title: I'm going through dysphoria
author: listener
text: Thanks for writing!

title: Am I gay if I like neither girls nor guys?
author: speaker
text: I'm a guy. If I don't like girls, nor do I like guys, does that mean I'm gay?

title: Am I gay if I like neither girls nor guys?
author: listener
text: No, it does not necessarily.

title: Am I gay if I like neither girls nor guys?
author: listener
text: Your sexual preference is based on who you ARE attracted to, not what does not turn you on.

title: Am I gay if I like neither girls nor guys?
author: listener
text: If you find you have no sex drive at all, this is called asexual.

title: Am I gay if I like neither girls nor guys?
author: listener
text: But you did not mention what you do find arrousing either.

title: Am I gay if I like neither girls nor guys?
author: listener
text: Hope this helps.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: speaker
text:
I'm transgender, I know I am, but I've only told a few friends. I know I can't tell my family because of previous conversations we've had. They just wouldn't accept it.
 My gender dysphoria is getting really difficult to deal with on my own. I need some strategies for dealing with it. What should I do?

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Hi.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: It can be difficult to handle such a transition on your own.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I work with clients to understand their needs and wants.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: This can involve how to communicate effectively with friends, family, and other loved ones; or, learning how to have self-acceptance.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I strongly recommend speaking with a licensed clinician one on one to help facilitate the change you are looking for.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: speaker
text:
I'm transgender, I know I am, but I've only told a few friends. I know I can't tell my family because of previous conversations we've had. They just wouldn't accept it.
 My gender dysphoria is getting really difficult to deal with on my own. I need some strategies for dealing with it. What should I do?

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I am so glad that you reached out for help.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I know that the dysphoria can feel nearly impossible to handle, especially since you have limited support from people who accept who you are.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: You may already know some of these resources, but I am going to share a few.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: The website www.letsqueerthingsup.com is a blog from a very good writer that I know.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: His name is Sam Dylan Finch, and he is transgender.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: He writes about mental health, transgender issues, and many other topics.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I know he has frequently written about gender dysphoria and ways to manage it.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: You may want to check out his site and do a search on there.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: The website www.everydayfeminism.com employs many transgender writers and several have written about gender dysphoria and have given ideas for managing it.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: If you search for gender dysphoria on their site, many articles pop up.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: It may be a good resource for you, especially if you ever feel lonely and start to forget that there are others out there who are like you and have your back.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I am not sure where you live, but there are counselors who specialize in affirmative therapy, which is what is recommended for folks who are part of the LGBTQ community.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: So, if you decide to see a counselor about the dysphoria, try to find one that specifically says they have been trained in the affirmative approach.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: In addition, feel free to ask questions of the counselor before agreeing to see them for counseling.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: An ethical counselor would have no problem answering them before having you come in.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: If there are some LGBTQ resource centers in your area, try to reach out to them and see if there are support groups.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Gaining more support from others would be helpful.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Sometimes LGBTQ-friendly counselors leave their contact information for people in resource centers.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Finally, I know you have not mentioned being depressed or suicidal, but I also know that it is very common for people to consider suicide when they are struggling with dysphoria, dealing with transphobia, etc.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: If this ever happens to you, please call 911 or the Trans Lifeline.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Visit their site at www.translifeline.org.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I hope some of these ideas help.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Feel free to send another message if you have a follow-up question.Be well....be YOU.Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: speaker
text:
I'm transgender, I know I am, but I've only told a few friends. I know I can't tell my family because of previous conversations we've had. They just wouldn't accept it.
 My gender dysphoria is getting really difficult to deal with on my own. I need some strategies for dealing with it. What should I do?

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Hi!

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I am so glad you're reaching out!

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Sounds like you have some solid support in some areas of your life but are still dealing with some difficult dysphoria.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I think it can depend on what kind of dysphoria you have - sometimes it's physical, social or mental.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Sometimes physical dysphoria means less time around mirrors or plans to make showering less stressful (music, audio books, distraction).

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Sometimes online support networks can be a great source of ideas in this way (for social and mental dysphoria as well).

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Some of my clients do things that help them feel better in their bodies that don't require anyone to know (hair removal, binders, packing, hormones,) and other things.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I recommend stopping by a website called Conversations with a Gender Therapist.

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: There are some awesome videos there that might help you!

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: I hope this helps some!

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Don't forget to try to connect with other trans folks (even online) - it can be a great relief to know you're not alone in how you're feeling!

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener
text: Best of luck!

title: How can I deal with gender dysphoria in a positive way?
author: listener

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: speaker
text: I got sick really bad and was throwing up for three days and nights. I thought I was going to die. Then about a week later, I started having this desire to be female. I never had this desire before. All I can think about is being a woman. I don't get pleasure from my penis anymore either. Women are attractive, but not like before. I can also find men attractive now. I'm too ashamed to tell anyone.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for reaching out to ask for help.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: Surely this is a very confusing time for you!

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
If you have never had these
feelings and desires it could certainty shake everything you thought you knew
about yourself.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
My guess is that you becoming sick around the time that this
started is likely a coincidence, but I understand how you would make the
connection.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: I have a feeling that a few things may be going on here.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
It
is really hard to say since I don’t know you, how old you are, etc.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
But, I will
share you with you some thoughts.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
Some people, when they have undesirable thoughts that really
surprise them, have a really tough time getting rid of them.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
Our reaction to
the thought can be very strong and our tendency to try to block it out, stuff
it, avoid it, etc.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: is not always successful.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: In fact, it’s usually not.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: It’s like telling you not to think of pink elephants.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
I
would be willing to bet that you thought of a pink elephant just now.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
So, rather than fighting thoughts that you find confusing,
sometimes it is helpful to allow yourself to explore the thought with curiosity
and without judgement.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: Where is this thought coming from?

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
What are my feelings
about it?

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
Asking yourself these questions may help you come to a resolution
about what is going on.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
One possibility is that you have developed an anxiety about
your thoughts and now you are in the process of obsessing about them, but
another possibility is that you are legitimately exploring your sexuality and
gender.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
I get the feeling from your question that you do not want to believe
that it is second possibility.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: And that is okay.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
You can try some of my suggestions, but you can also see a
counselor who may be able to help you work through your confusion.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
I would
suggest someone who has experience working with sexuality issues.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
You can
usually find out what a counselor works with on their website.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text:
What is
important is that you find someone who is non-judgmental about what you are
experiencing.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: I wish you well.

title: Why do I want to be the opposite sex so much?
author: listener
text: Robin J. Landwehr, DBH, LPC, NCC

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenage girl. I don't know if I'm straight, bisexual, or gay. I've been straight all my life, but a sudden rush of questions have come over me, and I don't know anymore.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: Hi Brentwood, While our society tends to want to put us into categories...slots...when it comes to sexuality, because this is nice and neat and convenient...many people find that they don't fit perfectly into one or the other.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: All you have to do is exactly what you're doing; be aware of yourself and allow yourself to explore these thoughts and emotions both alone and in connection with a safe partner.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: The people who love you will continue to love you as you sort through this.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: You can resist the temptation to please others by giving yourself a label.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: We are attracted to, and fall in love with, people...and we can't always predict what gender they might be.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: I love how open you are to discovering yourself.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener
text: Keep on that track.

title: I'm questioning my sexuality
author: listener

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: speaker
text: I feel like I would be more comfortable as a girl even though I still like girls. I think I'm like a girl stuck in a guy body. I imagine myself as a girl too. I think this more because my friends say that if I was a girl I would be a hot looking one. And I don't care about having boobs or anything. I just feel like the way that I do act will make more sense if I was a girl.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: I understand that gender and/or sexual identity crises can be very difficult to navigate, although in today’s time I think we have made a lot of progress and it is becoming easier for individuals to find themselves and also find acceptance from society.I am unsure how old you are.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: If you are a child or teenager, this is a normal time to have identity questions and to be in a phase where you are trying to figure out who you are and what you want out of life.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: I hope that you have understanding and supportive friends and family that you can talk to and who will support you in how you feel and what you may decide to do.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: A lot of people, unfortunately, do not, and if this is the case then it makes it harder for you.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Because then you may not feel safe exploring these feelings and decisions.I urge you not to try to make any permanent changes for quite some time.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: By this I mean a sex change.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Anything permanent like surgery or hormone replacement to change your actual gender is something that does not need to be done lightly.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Please find a therapist that can help you explore your feelings and your identity crisis.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Of course there are things that you can do that are not permanent changes.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Many people decide to dress like their gender of choice.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Maybe experimenting in this way is something that you could do.See if you have a local chapter of PFLAG in your area.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: PFLAG stands for Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: They are able to help not only with those who identify as lesbian or gay, but also transgendered and asexual.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: I wish you all the best in your identity crisis.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: It would be very easy for you to sink into depression if you do not have good support and understanding from those around you during this time.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Find a professional that can help, especially if you experience depression or any thoughts of harming yourself.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: speaker
text: I feel like I would be more comfortable as a girl even though I still like girls. I think I'm like a girl stuck in a guy body. I imagine myself as a girl too. I think this more because my friends say that if I was a girl I would be a hot looking one. And I don't care about having boobs or anything. I just feel like the way that I do act will make more sense if I was a girl.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Gender is personal thing.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: There is not just boy and girl.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: It is ok to be a boy and feel feminine and date women.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: It is also ok to be a transgendered women and date women.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: Have fun with it and feel it out.

title: How can I determine if I should be a boy or girl?
author: listener
text: What is right for you?

title: How can I concentrate?
author: speaker
text: I can't understand what I pay attention to.

title: How can I concentrate?
author: listener
text: One way to concentrate is that if your mind starts to wonder then remind yourself to bring your attention back.Start with short time spans of expecting yourself to concentrate.

title: How can I concentrate?
author: listener
text: You'll more likely succeed with concentrating with small time spans than longer ones.Once you start seeing your success, this will motivate you to try increasing the length to expect yourself to concentrate.The task of self-reminding is the same, whether for long or short time periods.Also, before starting this exercise ask your medical doctor if the problem can be related to a physical health problem.If there is, then have the possibility ruled out that your difficulty concentrating comes from the mental ability to concentrate, and not some medical reason preventing this.Before someone can engage their psychological will there must be a clean medical body and mind with which to work.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager and I've been sneaking out of my house at night for a year now. I've been caught several times. I want to stop doing this but I don't know where to start. How do I stop?

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: I've talked to many teens who frequently sneak out.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: The question I always ask them is, "What are you getting from sneaking out that you aren't getting at home?"

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: Many teens answer they are hooking up, using substances, and engaging in other risky behaviors.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: As uncomfortable as it might be, I encourage you to talk with your parents or guardians about the reasons why you are sneaking out.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: What are you getting "out there" that you aren't getting at home?

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: A good family counselor can help sort through those issues.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager and I've been sneaking out of my house at night for a year now. I've been caught several times. I want to stop doing this but I don't know where to start. How do I stop?

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: When you say you've "been caught", I am assuming that means your parents know you've been sneaking out.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: If that's the case, could you ask for their help?

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: Sometimes just knowing someone else is holding you accountable really makes a difference.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: That could be as simple as Dad checking in on you at, say, 2 am, just to make sure you are where you are supposed to be.If you are sneaking  out to hang out with friends, find another way to connect with them - if they are truly friends they will want to support you in your resolution to stay put at night.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: Maybe you can ask for their support by telling them to stop including you in late night plans.There is likely a reason you were sneaking out, but there's a reason you want to stop too - so get support.

title: How do I stop sneaking away from home at night?
author: listener
text: No one changes hard habits on their own!Best of luck to you - you can do this and it will help you change other things in the future.

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I suffer from checking and cleaning OCD. Can counseling help me to get over it?

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Counseling can be very effective for OCD.

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: listener
text: In particularly, a kind of therapy called Exposure Response (Ritual) Prevention Therapy is considered the 'gold standard' for the treatment of OCD.

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: listener
text: What this is, is a specific protocol that helps you build relaxation strategies and to increase the amount of time between your checking/cleaning rituals while also helping you to face any of the fears that OCD given you until those rituals and fears are no longer interfering with your life.

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Research has shown that this kind of therapy may even be more effective for OCD than medication, https://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/doi/full/10.1176/appi.ajp.162.1.151

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: speaker
text: I suffer from checking and cleaning OCD. Can counseling help me to get over it?

title: How can I get over my OCD and anxiety?
author: listener
text: Possibly yes, and definitely worth a try.First read about different types of therapy for OCD so that you find a therapist who does the type of therapy which feels best when you read about it.

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager and I get these really intense mood swings.    My mood will be really high and I'll think of something that I want to do. When I start to make it happen I get irritated by other people if they intervene. Then if the thing I wanted to do doesn't work out, I have these tendencies to blame other people for it not working out.    Can you explain what's going on?

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: Mood swings and getting frustrated when things don't work out is totally normal.

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, we get tied to one thing we really want to do and it can feel pretty intense when that gets interrupted or doesn't work out.

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: This said, you're coming to CounselChat and so I'm guessing this is something that is pretty intense for you and something that you are concerned about.

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: If this is getting in the way of your life, it may be worthwhile to reach out to a therapist or doctor to get some help with this and see if there might be something more going on.

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: While for most people frustration/mood swings is related to typical life and stress, if very intense it can be a sign of a number of challenges ranging from anxiety to a traumatic experience to something like Bipolar Disorder where a person's mood and energy might fly so high (mania) that one feels like they can do anything but often become frustrated when interrupted (note: there is a lot more to Bipolar Disorder than this and this is certainly not a diagnosis).

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: Wish you well!

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager and I get these really intense mood swings.    My mood will be really high and I'll think of something that I want to do. When I start to make it happen I get irritated by other people if they intervene. Then if the thing I wanted to do doesn't work out, I have these tendencies to blame other people for it not working out.    Can you explain what's going on?

title: What's going on with these mood swings?
author: listener
text: Why do you blame other people who had nothing to do with your actions?If it is because after the fact you wish you had accepted their help, then the person who is responsible for this is you!Since you are aware of your tendencies and how the interfere with your life, try to become aware of when you do these habits.This way you can interrupt your own patterns a little bit at a time.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: speaker
text: For the past four weeks, I've been having nightmares and hearing voices telling me of horrible things. They're not random voices, but rather, the voices of those I care about.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Voices and dreams could be suppressed feelings or thoughts that result from negative experiences.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Many times when people go to trough traumatic incidents or changes in their lives without being equipped to manage them and as a result they start having similar symptoms.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: It is helpful to find a therapist to talk to about those dreams and voices, once you get them out, you could analyze the concerns and fears that they reflect and normalize them, which will also be a good time to discuss their source, if any traumatic event has occurred in your life.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Also, I recommend to journal your dreams, especially if they keep you awake at night, and meditate after, so you could go back to sleep.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: ¿Cómo puedo hacer que los sueños y las voces desaparezcan?Durante las últimas cuatro semanas he estado teniendo pesadillas y escuchando voces que me dicen cosas horribles.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: No son voces que hablan al azar, pero voces de las personas que me importan.Las voces y los sueños pueden ser sentimientos supresos o pensamientos que resultan de experiencias negativas.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Muchas veces estos síntomas surgen cuando las personas pasan por situaciones traumáticas o cambios que no estaban preparados para enfrentar.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Es útil encontrar a un terapeuta con quien puedas hablar de esos sueños y voces, y aprender a normalizar el contenido de los mismos.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: También sería un buen momento para discutir cualquier situación traumática que te haya ocurrido.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Además te sugiero que escribas tus sueños, especialmente si te mantienen despierto  en la noche, y que medites luego de escribirlos para que puedas volver a dormir.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: speaker
text: For the past four weeks, I've been having nightmares and hearing voices telling me of horrible things. They're not random voices, but rather, the voices of those I care about.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Are you in the middle of extreme emotional pressure right now?Or, is someone with whom you're close, under stress or somehow suffering?Dreams and nightmares are when our feelings and pressures we feel, try working themselves out without logic and language.Even though the nightmares are horrible, they are one way your psyche is trying to come to terms w extraordinary difficulty in your life or someone's life whom you feel greatly attached.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: speaker
text: For the past four weeks, I've been having nightmares and hearing voices telling me of horrible things. They're not random voices, but rather, the voices of those I care about.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: It's important to take a look inside and find out why you are experiencing these feelings.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: It could anything and it will change your life to know what your particular issue or trigger is.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Please contact us a call with the method that is most comfortable for you.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: speaker
text: For the past four weeks, I've been having nightmares and hearing voices telling me of horrible things. They're not random voices, but rather, the voices of those I care about.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: Write down your nightmares and discuss them with an analyst or psychotherapist who specializes in dreams, as I do.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: If you are hearing voices while awake, see a doctor right away.

title: How can I make the dreams and voices go away?
author: listener
text: If the voices are strictly in your dreams, do call for therapy and talk to your caring others about what's happening.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: speaker
text: My doctor seems to think I am in danger of having one. I neglected to ask how this was different than an episode. I have been formally diagnosed with bipolar type 1.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener
text: I do not think there is such a thing as a psychotic seizure, however, there is something called a pseduoseizure or psychogenic non-epileptic seizure.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener
text: Basically, this is when a person shows signs of a full-on seizure (such as falling and convulsing) but they are not producing brain waves consistent with a seizure.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener
text: Psedoseizures tend to be brought on by high stress, emotional challenges, and trauma history.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener
text: You can learn more here, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441871/ Still, the best way to now what your doctor meant would be to ask them!

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: speaker
text: My doctor seems to think I am in danger of having one. I neglected to ask how this was different than an episode. I have been formally diagnosed with bipolar type 1.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener
text: The best path is to ask your doctor what s/he meant when telling you about your high risk for psychotic seizure.Your doctor knows you better than any of the therapists who write on this blog.

title: What is a psychotic seizure?
author: listener
text: And, because your doctor knows your health, will likely have suggestions and advice for you regarding the seizures s/he thinks you may develop.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: speaker
text: Often times I find myself thinking scary thoughts and sometimes I even scare myself into thinking that something bad is going to happen to me. Once it starts, the thought continues going through my head and I can't get it out. How can I stop these thoughts?

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Scary thoughts can feel overwhelming at times as well as feeling quite real.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I want to acknowledge how scary they can feel, but there is hope and new skills you can learn to work with these types of thoughts.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: The first step in working with scary or negative thoughts is to acknowledge that they are just thoughts and we can choose to follow the scary thought streams or work with cutting them off or ignoring them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I also realize that might seem really hard to do, but here's a good way to think about the brain and how thought patterns work.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Thoughts arise in the mind all the time, our brain is a thought machine.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Many thoughts drift by like clouds and we don't pay any attention while other thoughts arise and they trigger us in a particulate way, i.e., scary, angry, happy, sad, and when those thoughts arise we can chose to pay more attention to the thought which can lead us down that particulate thought stream that will lead to fear and anxiety.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: So, how do we work or stop those scary thought streams?

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: One new skill to implement comes from the work of Rick Hansen, he wrote the book Buddha's Brain," he teaches that we need to give more energy and attention to the positive thoughts or positive memories we hold in our mind and pay less attention to the negative thoughts.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Hansen asks us to imagine the brain this way, the brain is like Velcro with negative thoughts and like teflon when it comes to positive thoughts.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: There are reasons that our brain works this way, but I don't have time to go into all of that in this response.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: So, it's just important to remember we have to work at positive thinking, actually pausing throughout the day to focus on positive feelings and memories,  this will help the mind reinforce positive thought streams and help reduce negative thought streams over time.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: If a scary thought arises try to replace it with a happy experience for at least a couple of moments, and see if that helps reduce the negative charge connected with that scary thought.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: speaker
text: Often times I find myself thinking scary thoughts and sometimes I even scare myself into thinking that something bad is going to happen to me. Once it starts, the thought continues going through my head and I can't get it out. How can I stop these thoughts?

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Such a great question!

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I'm so sorry you are struggling!

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: You may be experiencing Intrusive thoughts.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: These are thoughts that seem to come from no where and victimize us.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I can strongly recommend a book called "When Panic Attacks" by Dr. David Burns.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: It helps you to identify the thoughts, and the help you create ways to counteract them!

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: There is another technique, called Thought Stopping.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Thought Stopping can be as simple as saying "Stop!"

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: loudly (if you are alone) or in your head, if you are in public.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: It's a quick way to distract you from the distressing thought, and allow you to refocus.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I recommend using this technique, followed by some deep breathing, while visualizing something that helps you feel relaxed (a favorite place, a pet, etc.).

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: These three things in conjunction can be of great assistance.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: One key component in addressing anxious thinking is building the skill of relaxation.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I recommend an App called Headspace which teaches relaxation through some simple guided mediation.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Super easy to do, and a great way to begin to build relaxation skills.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Plenty of sleep and reducing caffeine intake can also be things to explore.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Hope this helps!

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: speaker
text: Often times I find myself thinking scary thoughts and sometimes I even scare myself into thinking that something bad is going to happen to me. Once it starts, the thought continues going through my head and I can't get it out. How can I stop these thoughts?

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Hi there,I first want to let you know that having these thoughts is completely normal.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Studies have been done that show that 80% of human thoughts are "negative" so you are not alone.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I like to think of thoughts as a tornado... if you are in a tornado, you are completely consumed by it and it is nearly impossible to do anything beneficial.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: However, when you are, let's say, a mile away from a tornado, it is still scary but you have the option to do something that is important to you such as get shelter or make sure your family and friends are safe.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: When unhelpful or scary thoughts arise, we tend to start a "war" with them, which is the equivalent of jumping into the tornado.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: This makes the thoughts and emotions bigger and intensifies the feelings that go with them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: So the question I imagine you have is "how do I get out of the tornado?"

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: There are 3 steps to doing this:Get distance from your thoughts by adding "I am noticing I'm having the thought that...." to the front of them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: For example, "I am noticing I am having the thought that something bad is going to happen to me."

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: The purpose of this is not to decrease your fear or get rid of the thought.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: These thoughts might always be there and that is okay because that is how the mind naturally works so struggling with that is a waste of time and energy.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: The purpose is to gain some distance from the thoughts so you don't get swept away by them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: You can imagine them floating along like leaves in a stream or clouds in the sky (and often the same thought will come back again and again but that's okay... just continue to notice it with curiosity).

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: I imagine the thoughts get in your way of doing what really matters to you so if you can get a little bit of distance, you can do things that are fulfilling and meaningful to you.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Tune into your body and notice what sensations come up and where you feel them most intensely.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Then breathe into them and make room for them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Our 5 main emotions are: joy, sadness, fear/anxiety, shame, and anger.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: ALL of these emotions are part of being human and there is no escaping them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: So again, struggling with them ends up intensifying them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Instead, let them be and make a little bit of room for them.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Often a side effect of this is the intensity will decrease but it might not.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: The purpose is to keep them from becoming more intense.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Contact the present moment.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Notice what is happening here and now.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: One way of doing this is tuning into the five senses.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: What are some things you hear, see, taste, smell, and feel?

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Another way is to notice what is happening in your body (without trying to change it).

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: How deep are your breaths, what is happening with your heart rate, are you cold/warm, etc?Implementing these three steps can help you to refrain from getting caught up in your unhelpful thoughts.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: Unfortunately there is no way to get rid of thoughts or feelings completely.

title: How can I get "out of my head" and stop obsessive thoughts?
author: listener
text: So the only option that works in the long run is to accept them while continuing to do what matters to you and what is fulfilling to you.I hope this helps!

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: speaker
text: I'm a teenager, and I created a sort of imaginary friend to help me cope with stressful situations or if I'm worried or upset. She "gives me advice" and comforts me and tells me it'll be okay. I've given her a name (Solace) and created a personality for her that's like a comforting motherly figure. I know it's just my own advice and my own thoughts, but it's just that I'm thinking of them through a voice other than my own. I do this because I know I never really listen to my own advice, and I thought it would be better if it was through someone else who knew my thought process in and out, through this imaginary friend. Is this normal? Could it develop into a separate personality with time if I continue a mentality that she is her own person?

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: Hi, I'm Amelia!

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: You know, it does sounds like you have imagined a motherly comfort figure for yourself.

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, when I have a person in my office that is very self-critical, I have him/her speak to his or herself as though he/she were speaking to a loved one.

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: Isn't it sad that we speak to others more lovingly than we do ourselves?If you have not received empathy, nurturing, or comfort from a caregiver, it is hard to internalize empathy, nurture or comfort from the inside.

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: There is a saying that "We have been hurt in relationships and we can heal in relationships."

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: Healing and growth are best provided in the context of healthy relationship.

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: How about going the next step and finding a compassionate therapist or loving mentor that could actually provide you with the comfort that you need.

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: You deserve to be seen, heard, noticed, and valued.

title: Is it weird or dangerous to give myself advice through an imaginary friend?
author: listener
text: I am wishing my very best to you!

title: Why can't I change?
author: speaker
text: I know I'm ruining my life with a lot of the decisions I make. I consistently tell myself I need to make some serious changes in my life, but I just can't seem to even though I really want to. Why can't I force myself to change?

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Hello, and thank you for your question.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Changing unwanted behavior is one of the hardest things a person can do.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: I agree with Sherry that being patient with yourself is important.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Here are a few things I would suggest:1.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Get clear on the behaviors you really want to change, and make sure they are behaviors that CAN be changed.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Sometimes we will set a goal like, "I want to be more confident" but that is hard to measure and prove to yourself that you accomplished it.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Saying you are going to accept a date or go on a job interview is something you can actually do, and something that you may consider to be demonstrating confidence.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Whatever your change of behavior is, make sure it is something you can actually change.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: If you are going to give up a behavior, decide what you are going to do in place of it.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: So, if you are going to stop showing up late for work, then you are deciding to be on time for work and demonstrating your value of being punctual.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: If you are going to make changes, really nail down WHY you want to make them.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: What is it about making these changes that is important to you as a person?

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: For example, if you have the goal of weight loss, the reason this is important to you as a person may be because you value self-care.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Knowing WHY you want to make changes is both your motivation and your compass for getting there.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Once you know WHY you want to make these changes, I strongly suggest setting small goals.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: If you set too high of goals you may not accomplish them and just feel worse.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: So, make the goal small, realistic, and guided by the the things you want to be as a person.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: As Sherry mentioned, finding a counselor is sometimes a good idea if you really feel stuck.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Any counselor who does work with goal-setting and motivation can probably help.
