title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Be well,Robin Landwehr, DBH, LPCC

title: Why can't I change?
author: speaker
text: I know I'm ruining my life with a lot of the decisions I make. I consistently tell myself I need to make some serious changes in my life, but I just can't seem to even though I really want to. Why can't I force myself to change?

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: In general the reason people aren't able to change is because the person feels a sense of fear to change.What the roots are of this fear are usually easiest to identify by talking with someone whom you trust and feel safe to talk about your inner thoughts and emotions.If you haven't got someone like this in your life, which is common, then shop around for a therapist because a therapist is someone who is professionally trained to listen in a way which helps someone know more about who they are.Be patient with yourself too.

title: Why can't I change?
author: listener
text: Change sometimes feels much scarier and is more complex than simple compared with whatever you would like to change.

title: I did something I can't get over
author: speaker
text:
I was with my friends fishing by a pond. I found a frog and stabbed it with my friend's knife. I'm not sure why I did it. My friends saw me do it it and were shocked and got really mad at me.
   Now if someone brings it up I get really upset and panicked. I don't know why I feel like this. Does this mean there is something wrong with me?

title: I did something I can't get over
author: listener
text: The good news is your awareness that being violent to animals feels out of character for you.

title: I did something I can't get over
author: listener
text: I'm glad you have awareness and I'm glad you are not at ease with killing frogs.Fairly likely that you were acting out aggressively toward the frog, feelings of being on the receiving side of similar type of violence.Basically, you did unto the frog what someone has or to you, feels like, has been done to you.Use your surprising finding of how strong your anger and most likely inward pain.

title: I did something I can't get over
author: listener
text: Reflect on your closest relationships and how these people treat you.

title: I did something I can't get over
author: listener
text: It is possible you feel more hurt by someone who is close to you than you ever realized.Stabbing innocent frogs is wrong.

title: I did something I can't get over
author: listener
text: It is understandable as a way to show you how much inner pain you probably have.It is also wrong that someone close to you hurt you.The direction to go is to recognize your pain and then decide how to go about changing what is possible on your side of that or those relationship(s).

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: speaker
text: She was diagnosed a type one diabetic two years ago and had a very tough time dealing with it. She has an attachment issue also; her mother just moved to a much nicer home, and she gets angry and demands to go back to her prior home. We do not understand what is going on, and it is driving us crazy.

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: listener
text: There are many possible answers here.

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: listener
text: It could be that she misses friends, that she felt safe in the other house (emotionally safe and comfortable), or dozens of other things.

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: listener
text: Will she talk about it when she's not mad?

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: listener
text: You mentioned that she has an attachment issue.

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: listener
text: It could also be that she was attached to the house.

title: Why does my granddaughter instantly switch moods?
author: listener
text: It's not the same as being attached to a person, but possessions and safe places certainly mean a lot.

title: Do feelings of depersonalization go away?
author: speaker
text: I've felt this way for two years. I feel so much better now then I did when it started, but it is still there in the back of my mind at all times.

title: Do feelings of depersonalization go away?
author: listener
text: Best answer that I can give to you is that some level of de-personalization is quite normal for everyone, it will come and go throughout life, kind of like being on a roller-coaster, "here it is, then it's gone not to return for quite some time", like many things, the more that you fixate on it, the more stress it will cause you, consider it part of life, accept it, and move on, now if your having many, many ,many of these episodes or have some auditory or visual hallucination or disturbances or emotional unbalancing that accompany it than that is definitely something to look at, but for the most part nothing to worry about.

title: Do feelings of depersonalization go away?
author: listener
text: Hope this helps,C

title: I've been having breakdowns for no reason at all
author: speaker
text: I start to think of an issue that doesn't even matter or something bad that happened years ago. Then, I cry, pull at my hair, plug my ears, hit myself, and throw things. In loud public places, I get on edge and start being sarcastic and moody. I have an awful fear of people leaving me (which normally ends up happening) and I feel like I'm too clingy.

title: I've been having breakdowns for no reason at all
author: listener
text: There is a reason you are having breakdowns.

title: I've been having breakdowns for no reason at all
author: listener
text: I can't agree that they happen for "no reason at all".

title: I've been having breakdowns for no reason at all
author: listener
text: Finding out the reason is going to be your biggest challenge because that may require you to dig deep into your past, uncover hurtful experiences, or recognize something that would be extremely pain.

title: I've been having breakdowns for no reason at all
author: listener
text: However, if you don't find professional help to carefully guide you through whatever you may confront, the symptoms mentioned will continue and may even get worse.

title: I've been having breakdowns for no reason at all
author: listener
text: There is a light at the end of the road but you need some help to find the right road to get on so you can see it.

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: speaker
text:
I have an ex-boyfriend who just lies about everything. He is super lazy. He lies to everyone that he has a good job, builds trust, and then start borrowing money—and large amounts too. It has come to the point where he has gone through several group of friends. He is leaving a trail behind full of friends in debt because he would put on a sob story, borrow money, then disappear. He refuses to work, so he sits at home playing games all day and either lies to his mom for money or lies to his friends. I used to think his lying was due to his drug habit, but now I'm hearing from other ex-friends of his that this started even before the drugs got into his life. He would borrow anywhere from $5,000 to $50,000 from everyone and it would all disappear. He's in debt with bills. He doesn't gamble, but he spends his money on random stuff.
   Although he has this habit of lying compulsively and spending money, he seems to be a good person. He'll always give a homeless person all his change no matter what. My brother has epilepsy and is really antisocial—my ex-boyfriend makes an actual effort to socialize with my brother. He takes him out to the movies and plays video games with him. He drives me to school and work every day and picks me up—just basically the small things that add up to the fact that he's not totally a horrible human being. Is he just simple a pathological liar or is there something that could possibly be deep down in there?

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you have some ambivalent feelings towards your ex-boyfriend that are difficult to sort out.

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: You notice that there are both desirable and undesirable things about him, and this is true of everyone to one degree or another.

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: One question that I would have for you is, are you satisfied with your relationship with him as it currently stands?

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: Are you happy with the boundaries between the two of you, or would you like them to be different?

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: Negotiating through conflict and establishing different boundaries are definitely things you could work on with the help of a therapist.

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: Another question I would have for you is, what would it mean for you to find out what motivates his behavior?

title: Is my ex-boyfriend a pathological liar?
author: listener
text: Discovering the roots of such behavior is something that he would have to work on in his own therapy and not something that you and a therapist could discover without him.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: speaker
text: I was never like this. Recently this year (my first year of high school), I started getting emotional for no reason.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: Hello Vancouver, It's really common for people to become very upset over small things sometimes.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: The small thing is a "trigger", and the emotions aren't so much about that event that's happening in the present; they are more connected to old events that evoked the same feeling.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: You've likely had too much of that feeling in your life and you've developed a sensitivity to it.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: Look at the small events that are triggers for you and ask yourself what same or similar emotion they evoke.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: If there's anger there, look underneath that.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: Is it powerlessness, worthlessness, hurt, shame...?

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: Then ask yourself when in your life you've experienced TOO much of that feeling.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: As a child, maybe, but not necessarily.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: That's the first step, and combined with empathy, compassion and self-esteem, you're starting to build what I call an emotional air conditioner.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: A good therapist can help you with the rest of this process and with learning ways of coping with emotions daily.

title: How can I stop being so emotional all the time over worthless stuff?
author: listener
text: I wish you the best.

title: How do I know if I have bipolar disorder?
author: speaker
text: I feel that I am struggling with undiagnosed bipolar disorder, and it is making my day-to-day life extremely difficult.

title: How do I know if I have bipolar disorder?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you are experiencing a great deal of distress and you're wondering if it may meet a diagnosis of Bipolar disorder.

title: How do I know if I have bipolar disorder?
author: listener
text: There are a few different types of Bipolar diagnoses in the DSM (diagnositc and statistical manual) and the best way to find out if your experiences would meet that diagnosis would be to meet with a mental health professional.

title: How do I know if I have bipolar disorder?
author: listener
text: You can also look up the diagnosis online and see if what you are going through meets the criteria.One question that I would have for you is, what would it mean for you to find out that you meet the criteria for such a diagnosis?

title: How do I know if I have bipolar disorder?
author: listener
text: It sounds like whether or not you do, you are suffering and working with a therapist may help you get into a better place.

title: Is there a lawsuit for counselors and therapists who failed to report a relapse?
author: speaker
text:
I have a relative who is in his twenties. He was in a drug rehabilitation program and got kicked out for using drugs again. No one informed family that he was using drugs again. He subsequently overdosed and was found dead.
 Is their accountability of counselors, therapists or the halfway house for not reporting that he had relapsed? Is there a legal case for failing to report?

title: Is there a lawsuit for counselors and therapists who failed to report a relapse?
author: listener
text: I am so sorry for your loss.

title: Is there a lawsuit for counselors and therapists who failed to report a relapse?
author: listener
text: Generally therapists only have a duty to report self harm to ones self or others if it is expressed to them.

title: Is there a lawsuit for counselors and therapists who failed to report a relapse?
author: listener
text: Often times they will not report relapses due to the fact that proper releases were not signed or patient has specifically asked them not to for fear of shaming or failure again.

title: Is there a lawsuit for counselors and therapists who failed to report a relapse?
author: listener
text: I understand this may not be the answer you were hoping for.

title: Is there a lawsuit for counselors and therapists who failed to report a relapse?
author: listener
text: I would encourage the family to seek therapy themselves for help coping with such a loss.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: speaker
text: What do you do when a therapist and a parent drugs a child and makes up lies in order to stop the other parent's custody visitation?

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: I will admit I am confused about this question.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Are you the other parent in question or a concerned coworker of this therapist?

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Therapists do not prescribe or have access to medication.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Most therapists won't even get involved in a custody battle.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: They know there is a good chance of their records ending up in court and that they themselves will have to testify in court.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Of course, therapists are human and can make mistakes, but I find it highly unlikely that a therapist would knowingly and willingly do something like this that is such a major ethical violation.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Not only are they losing their license to practice by doing this, they are going to face criminal charges and jail time.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: If their clinical judgment is that the other parent is a danger to the child, they don't have to resort to illegal means to try to prove this.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: If you have concrete proof that this has happened then there is a process in which you can file a report against the therapist with their licensure board.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Every therapist is licensed in their state.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: There are different types of licensures so you would need to know this therapist's licensure.Most accusations from the other parent are expected in a custody situation because people do tend to get quite ugly.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Don't accuse the therapist or the parent of anything just to try to make yourself look better and them look bad.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: Have evidence of wrongdoing before accusing them of this.

title: Unethical Therapy Practices
author: listener
text: If this has really happened then of course it needs to be reported, but don't try to ruin someone's career unless you are sure this occurred.

title: Is it ethical for a social worker to ignore a client’s phone calls?
author: speaker
text: I terminated my counseling relationship with a social worker several years ago. I am now realizing that I would like to begin counseling again. The social worker’s voicemail message says that he returns calls in 24 hours, but he hasn't called me back. I called him on the weekend and made it clear that I want him to call me back. Can he just ignore me?

title: Is it ethical for a social worker to ignore a client’s phone calls?
author: listener
text: Yes, your former social worker should return your phone call.It is the professional ethic to do so and plain human decency to do so.If he doesn't, there is nothing you can directly do about the fact of his ignoring you.There are formal complaints you can make, which you can consider doing.What matters most is receiving social work service.Stick with looking for another social worker who is willing to help you.The self-doubts you mention may be worth examining.They do not, however excuse the social worker mishandling himself.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: speaker
text: I think I have depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, and I have anger issues. I told my mom over and over again. She told me she would get me a therapist, but she never did. I just found out that my mom can't afford a therapist for me.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: listener
text: It can be difficult to get counseling if you don't feel supported by family members.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: listener
text: There might be a few options.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: listener
text: If you are in school, I'd recommend talking to a school counselor or school nurse.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: listener
text: They often will be able to help you access free or affordable counseling resources in your community.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: listener
text: In addition, depending on where you live, it's also often possible to call 211 for referrals to free or low cost counseling services in your area.I'd encourage you not to give up.

title: How can I see if a therapist if my mom can't afford it?
author: listener
text: You are on the right track.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There are typically three reasons why therapy is terminated:1) Client has met therapy goals2) Client is not progressing 3) Therapist is not a good fit for clientIn order to properly assess whether therapy is helping and what progress is being made, the therapist needs to have ways of consistently checking in with clients sessions-by-session to determine what is helping, what isn't, and where the client is at in relation to their original therapy goals.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: When a client has met their goals, that is a good time to end counselling sessions unless the client has new goals or simply wants to check-in periodically to make sure that they are still on track (sometimes referred to as relapse prevention).

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: When a client is not progressing, and feedback has been taken and attempts have been made to make the therapy more helpful for the client but to no avail, than it is considered unethical to continue to work with the client.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In these circumstances, referring out to another therapist who may be a better fit is a good idea.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The end of the counselor/client relationship is one of mutual respect and engagement.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Counseling sessions can end for any number of reasons.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Among them are the client's inability to make forward progress in therapy; the clinician's inability to help the client (for a variety of reasons); a mutually agreed upon time frame for a number of sessions to be provided; or the financial challenges of the client who decides that they need to put their resources elsewhere.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In this last case, a counselor should never cancel sessions with a client simply on the basis of the client's inability to pay.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: That is traditionally seen as an unethical practice.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Other arrangements can be made to provide care to the client, which in itself should be paramount.When the client and therapist decide that services are done, it is best if there is at least one or two more sessions to allow a case file review to occur, and to bring an appropriate psychological sense of closure to the client (and vicariously to the clinician as well, those this is perhaps not as important).

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This transition gives both a sense of having reached the end of a journey...rather than some abrupt departure from it.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: (An abrupt ending in therapy can have a varying level of impact both emotionally and psychologically on the client and therapist).

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Sometimes the closure of therapy is the result of a program of therapy being formally completed, in which there is a mutually known (albeit perhaps approximate) date of when that program will be finished.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In this case, the client is likely feeling that impending closure and has time to prepare mentally and emotionally from a place of being the client in therapy, to a place of healing, growth and situational resolution.I have always worked in therapy with the following slogan (if you will), that I learned years ago during graduate school: "Not every therapist is good for every client, and not every client is good for every therapist."

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It is perhaps one of the most important guiding views I hold in working with clients.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The therapeutic relationship is driven by mutuality - the desire of the client to get better at living life, and the therapist's desire to truly see the client heal and grow.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: When there is a block in this process from either side that prevents that synergy from occurring, the relationship that should be established may not be able to form.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Or, if already formed, may at some point be unable to move forward.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In these instances, referring the client to another type of service or clinician is appropriate.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Usually, this can be seen pretty quickly by either party, though sometimes it is not always clear.Ultimately, the client and counselor need to work together to discover if the needs of the client (which is paramount) are being met in the therapeutic engagement with their current counselor, or if other arrangements need to be made to go elsewhere.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If both are observant in this process, they can work together to maintain that sacred space and continue to reach the goals that have been set.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Eventually, therapy will end, but hopefully based on the client's successful journey to the place where they wanted to go, and thus opening the next chapters of their life to a space that is more whole and brighter.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Hopefully both the client and counselor would together decide when to terminate counseling sessions.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It's really helpful for the client to leave counseling with a solid sense of what he or she has accomplished in counseling, so it can be a good idea to spend some time acknowledging that in the last session or sessions.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, however, a client has needs beyond the scope of the counselor's expertise.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: That's a good time for a conversation about those needs and ideas of  how best to meet them, whether by adding in care with an additional mental health professional or transferring care entirely to a new mental health provider.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There are different reasons why a counselor may seek to terminate with a client and these will each have different processes by which the counselor will come to that decision.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Here are a few examples.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The counselor may determine that the client's needs are outside what the counselor is competent to be able to work with.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: A person may have come to the counselor talking about a particular issue but either when they first met or as counseling progressed, it may become clear that the issue is in fact something different or that there is an additional related issue.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If that issue is outside the competence of the counselor, the counselor should look for alternatives, the most common of which would be to terminate and refer.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Beyond clinical issues, this could also come up around particular other related facts, such as the culture of the client or linguistic issues.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This could also be the choice of the counselor if they know someone that they feel would be a better match for the client's issues.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Another reason for discharge (and possible referral) would be if the relationship does not seem to be a good fit.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: No counselor is the right person to work with everyone.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If the right level of connection is not happening, the counselor will often look first at what they are doing, might talk about it with the client and ultimately will admit that things don't seem to be working to allow the desired therapeutic process to work.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: A similar process would be followed if the counselor determined that the client might not yet be ready for counseling as evidenced by lack of engagement such as frequent cancellations, not doing any agreed on work between sessions, showing up late or being really guarded in session.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The easiest situation to decide on is when a person has met their counseling goals and have nothing new that they are working on.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: While this is the easiest one to determine, it is also probably the hardest one for the counselor as they may be like the client in not wanting the relationship to come to an end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: However, counselors know that this is part of the process.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: They will also determine this by regularly reviewing the treatment plan or by sending in the sessions that the work has come to an end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This type of termination maybe final or may be with the intent that the client will return later to address other things that have been identified but for which they are not ready to move into.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: All of these (and other) situations involves the counselor being open to the relationship ending, to monitoring how things are going, then engaging in self reflection, possibly talking with the client and then coming to a conclusion on which the counselor  follows through.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: For most:  When the money/insurance runs out.When best:  When the job is done... and you're feeling much better.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: To be able to identify a clear ending to a counseling relationship, we must have a clear understanding of the goals and limitations of treatment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Usually, during the initial evaluation, I identify my client’s short term and long term therapy goals.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: As therapy progress, we verify goals on a monthly to a quarterly basis, depending on the frequency of the appointments.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Once the therapy goals have been met, there is a closing session, the counseling relationship is ended, and the client can stop attending sessions.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In some cases, the client can also establish new goals and determine if I am a good fit for their therapy needs or if they need a new provider, in which case I provide multiple referrals.The counseling relationship could also end due to other factors like noncompliance= when a client is not committed to the agreed treatment process, or when the client’s or a counselor violates the counseling relationship.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Either the counselor or the client is able to end counseling.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Although, as mental health providers we need to provide a reason for terminating our therapeutic relationship and referral options, as a client no explanation is needed, a closing session is highly recommended.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: ¿Cómo termina la terapia?¿Cómo un consejero decide cuando terminar las sesiones de consejería o terminar de trabajar con un paciente?Para poder determinar el final de la relación del consejero, debemos comprender las metas y parámetros de la terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Usualmente durante la evaluación inicial se identifican metas a corto y largo plazo con el cliente, y se discute con el cliente como esas metas serán alcanzadas.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Durante el proceso de terapia el consejero revisa las metas mensual o trimestralmente dependiendo de la frecuencia de las citas.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Ya que las metas de terapia son alcanzadas, hay una sesión de cierre y el cliente puede terminar la terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: En algunos casos el cliente puede identificar nuevas metas para la terapia y determinar si el mismo consejero u otro consejero le pueden asistir.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: La relación de consejería también puede terminar por no conformar o violentar los parámetros  establecidos para la terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Tanto el consejero como el cliente pueden terminar la relación de terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Como proveedores de salud mental los consejeros estamos obligados a proveer un razón para la conclusión del tratamiento y proveer referidos según aplique, los clientes no necesitan proveer una explicación, aunque es recomendable discutirlo en una sesión de cierre.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It is usually time to end counseling sessions when it is clear to both the client and the counselor that therapeutic goals have been reached and enough improvement has been made that the client can continue without that support.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There are exceptions to this rule, but for the most part this is when counselors begin termination.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: For some clients, this is an easy process that marks the achievements they have made in working through their emotions and difficulties.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: For some other clients, however, this is a difficult process in which they are losing a valuable support and are understandably anxious about what life will be like without the frequent meetings.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Ultimately, termination is different for everyone, and there are many ways that termination can be healthy and helpful.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: As a therapist who believes in client self-determination above most other elements of the process, I want to as much as possible leave it up to the client to determine when they are finished.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In the case of a termination because a client's distress has resolved, I might periodically check in with the client about how therapy has been going, and if we want to re-evaluate where we are.The more unfortunate situation would come about if I felt that I wasn't the best fit for the client.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I would offer that in words, and ideas of therapists (with names) of who I thought might be a better fit and why.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It still is up to the client whether to continue, however should they want to keep seeing me, a part of the work would be about that want (to see someone who professionally doesn't believe they can help as much as someone else.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: )I also find it perplexing when I hear a client (or on a personal level) tell me that their therapist said they "didn't need therapy."

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I don't know that I buy into that scenario all that much, because I do believe that yes, not everyone NEEDS therapy, but that everyone CAN benefit from therapy and I don't believe it is the therapist's job to deter someone from ever seeking out help of any kind.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Ideally, termination should be a mutual process.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It's not that the therapist kicks the client out at some point and says, "Okay, you're done."

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Rather, over time the client will decrease the frequency with which he/she comes to session so that it may start off as weekly, then decrease to biweekly, then perhaps once every three weeks, then once/month and so on.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Throughout this process, the therapist and client should have had regular check ins about progress toward goals.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If the client feels good about where he/she is in life, he/she might decide to suspend therapy for now.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: That being said, the therapist should make it very clear that if the client ever decided to return for "maintenance" therapy or a check in, he/she would always be welcome.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There is no hard and fast rule to ending or a particular time period in which it must end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: What matters most is that the client feels good about it and knows that the therapist will always be there should he/she wish to return.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: For a therapist, deciding to end counseling sessions or terminate working with a client is a thoughtful and intentional decision.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: One that is not entered into lightly.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: While there are many considerations counselors take into account, to help answer this question, I'll offer an example of two areas that counselor's take into consideration when ending counseling sessions:Does the client need different or more specialized care than the current counselor can provide?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This requires the counselor to determine whether referring the client to another therapist or health care provider is needed.And, has the therapeutic relationship reached treatment goal(s)?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: While this question is specific to the counselor, I'd like to also add that a client, at any time, can end counseling.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In general, I usually let the client decide when this should occur, sometimes with some clients it will be a joint agreement, but even in that case it should weigh mostly on what the client feels.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In short, therapy ends when you feel your done.C

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In the best case scenario, it's a mutual discussion and decision.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If not,  I've had the discussion initiated both ways, by me, when I sense the client has gone has far as they want, by lack of interest in accepting or completing homework assignments, missing or cancelling appointments, usually at the last minute, lack of participation during sessions.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Client initiates by asking me pointed questions about why the need for homework assignments,, by forgetting their calendar, or their checkbook :) , by suggesting that we make appointments over longer intervals (once a week to once a month, for example).

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I rarely have had to terminate a working relationship--that's why I don't charge for the first visit, so we know if we are a good fit before we start working together.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Then I periodically ask whether the client feels we are making progress, moving in the right direction, talking about the most relevant issues etc.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Hi there, There are a number of reasons why a therapeutic relationship might end including, but not limited to the client reaching their goals, the client reaching a place of acceptance where they wish to remain or even a breach within the relationship.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The last aspect should likely be taken to supervision in order to be fully processed.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: All of these things could happen, and usually happen organically (again, except for the last example).

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Your question, however, was about the counselor ending treatment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This is a bit more difficult and can be very nerve-wracking.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It may be beneficial to take this with you to supervision, as well.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It's important to understand why you feel the need to end or terminate with the client, as well.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Do you feel that they would be better suited for another therapist, have they achieved their goals or is it something else?In regular, open-ended sessions, I try to make a point of checking in with the clients fairly frequently.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In these check-ins, I use the time to ask the client how they feel about the sessions and if there is anything they wish to focus on more astutely.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I also ask if they have any immediate goals that they would like to prioritize.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In goal-oriented sessions, I check in more frequently to ensure that both the client and I remain focused and, should they wish to shift their focus, that they recognize it is part of my responsibilities to make sure we move back to the desired goal.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Often, especially in longer term therapeutic relationships, we as clinicians can see that the client has reached their goal, however they are apprehensive about ending therapy.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This is actually a great place to go with them; why would they feel unable to handle issues in their external or internal environment without you?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Often, having this open discussion can increase empowerment and mastery.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: That said, it could also highlight other issues which the client may have been apprehensive about going into within therapy and now, as the relationship seems to be ending, feels more confident in bringing these up.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In the case where the relationship is a toxic one, terminating with a client may be the best option for both of you.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It's a difficult conversation, but recall that part of the role of the therapist is to model that these discomforts can be managed.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I hope that this brief response can assist you going forward!

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This is a question that is very specific to each person.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There are definitely some variables, but I can give you some general ideas for when counseling might end:When a client has met all of their goals, at least to a degree when they feel that they no longer need to work on them with the assistance of a counselorSometimes a decision is made that a client is no longer benefiting from counseling at a certain timeSometimes clients have to remain in counseling in order to receive medication.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This depends on agency policy, but sometimes it is a requirement.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If the medication is necessary and cannot be prescribed by a primary care physician, frequency of sessions is usually decreased greatlyI'm not sure why you are asking this question, but it is also something that is often discussed at the beginning of treatment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Oftentimes "discharge goals" change as treatment progresses because more is known about clients, their goals, changes in their goals, and many other things.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Changes are normal, but your counselor probably has discharge goals in mind, at least generally, from the beginning.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I strongly encourage you to ask about it!

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: speaker
text:
My therapist is gay so there are no sexual issues here. However, my therapist for six years has made me believe that he cares about me and that we are friends. I have loaned money to him many times, and he always paid me back.
   I had a medical emergency last weekend and I was heavily medicated. I knew that this therapist came into my home and wrote down my credit card information so he could pay back what he owed me, but this therapist dropped me off and never came again. I don't know what to do.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: I'm sorry to hear that this has happened.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: Counselors are legally and ethically required to make sure that they always put the wellbeing of their clients above their own interests.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: In addition, counselor ethical rules, and the laws in just about every state, make it illegal for counselors to take advantage of a client financially.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: A counselor borrowing money from a client (even if the counselor pays it back) would usually be considered to be taking advantage of the client.There are a few options you have at this point if you can't (or don't want) to continue to try to contact him directly.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: You can file a complaint with your states' regulatory board and let them know what has happened.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: An investigator will then look into the situation for you.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: Another option would be for you to find a different counsleor who can provide you with an independent and netural point of view to help you figure out how you want to handle this situation.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: speaker
text:
My therapist is gay so there are no sexual issues here. However, my therapist for six years has made me believe that he cares about me and that we are friends. I have loaned money to him many times, and he always paid me back.
   I had a medical emergency last weekend and I was heavily medicated. I knew that this therapist came into my home and wrote down my credit card information so he could pay back what he owed me, but this therapist dropped me off and never came again. I don't know what to do.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: Do you want this therapist to have your credit card information?If not, then cancel the credit cards that you believe may now be accessible to this therapist.Therapists are expected to keep very clear boundaries between the therapy work and not have other relationships, such as "friend" or "money lender" with someone who is their patient.Therapists are never "friends" with their patients.Letting you believe that you are the therapist's friend, is a violation of professional ethics and almost definitely, a violation of the Consumer Protection laws in your State.Start by dropping this person as your therapist.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: He has broken too many ethical standards to be worthy of offering therapy.Think over if you'd like remaining friends with this person, whom you describe as lacking integrity and stealing from you.If you need help getting back money from him, then contact the police and talk to a detective about what has happened so far.

title: My therapist betrayed my trust
author: listener
text: The detective will advise according to the laws in your community and State, whether to file a police report, and what steps are necessary to utilize the Court system to get back your funds.If you'd like doing future patients who may be treated to similar ways by this therapist, a favor, go online and file a complaint with the therapist's Licensing Board.Good luck!

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: speaker
text: I am an international student, and it is my first semester in graduate school in the United States. I faced a cultural shock, and I was so depressed when I arrived here. My counselor in the university was my savior. He helped me a great deal. Now I am going back to my country for a vacation. I was thinking to get him something special with my country's name on it, and I remembered that he likes wine. My country is known for that. Is it appropriate to give him wine as a gift after Christmas?

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: listener
text: I don't think it's appropriate to give your counselor a bottle of wine.

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: listener
text: Your counselor helped you and supported you, which is great, But a gift is inappropriate.

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: listener
text: I can understand that you want to show your gratitude.

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: listener
text: There are many other ways to do that.

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: listener
text: You could drop your counselor a note or card, thank him in person, or tell him how much he helped you.

title: Is it appropriate to give my counselor a bottle of wine for Christmas?
author: listener
text: These small gestures can be very meaningful for both of you.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: speaker
text: I have an eating disorder of binging. I've had gastric sleeve surgery. I need help with issues of abuse as a child, addiction, and abusive men. I have been in therapy for five months and get no feedback from my therapist.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: It can be really frustrating to feel like your counselor is not providing you with the help you need.My recommendation in a situation like this would be to let your counselor know how you feel.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Specifically tell Your counselor that you don't seem to be getting the amount of feedback you would like.If this doesn't help, then you might want to look for another counselor who will be a better fit for you.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: speaker
text: I have an eating disorder of binging. I've had gastric sleeve surgery. I need help with issues of abuse as a child, addiction, and abusive men. I have been in therapy for five months and get no feedback from my therapist.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Hi Anaheim,Relationships with therapists have some things in common with other relationships; they work best if there is dialogue about what your hopes, thoughts, emotions and needs are.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Are you letting your therapist know what your goals are?

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: It's okay to say "I'd really like us to focus on this piece", or "I'm looking for specific direction about how to manage this part".

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Your therapist is wise if they ask questions that determine what your needs are, but they can't read your mind.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Not every therapist will be a good fit for you.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: I know I'm not a good fit for everyone I meet.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: We have different styles; some are more  passive and focus on listening.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: This might be the type of therapist you have.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: For some people this is what they want, but maybe it's not for you.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Maybe you want someone who digs at you more, asks more questions, gives you strategies, lets you know what they think... someone more active.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: If this is the case, it doesn't mean s/he's a bad therapist...it's just not what you're looking for.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: Sometimes people think they can't end sessions with their therapist; they might be worried about hurt feelings.

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener
text: But, in the end, you don't owe your therapist anything if you feel it's not working or it's not a good match.

title: Should I get a new therapist?

title: Should I get a new therapist?
author: listener

title: Should I get a new therapist?

title: How do I approach my doctor about seeing a therapist?

text: Having this kind of conversation with a doctor can feel difficult.

title: How do I approach my doctor about seeing a therapist?
author: listener
text: But remember, you are the expert on you.

title: How do I approach my doctor about seeing a therapist?
author: listener
text: Any good medical professional will recognize that.You are absolutely right to think about the importance of being your own health care advocate.

title: How do I approach my doctor about seeing a therapist?

text: Generally, the best approach is simply to be honest.

title: How do I approach my doctor about seeing a therapist?

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: speaker
text: I need help dealing with stress. How can I handle it all and feel less stressed out?

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: In case you feel some relief to know you're feeling the tone of our times.We live with crumbling of our values which then gives rise to insecurity everywhere.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: If someone doesn't know what their values are then its difficult to do anything, and right now everyday we hear uncertainty in what used to be our basic assumptions.You're more normal for noticing and feeling stressed than if you imagine life felt fine the way it is!One road to take is to accept that there are no clear roads forward.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: This means to change long term goals into shorter ones.Also, in general the more focused you can be as to your particular wishes, motivations, interests, and people about whom you care, the greater will be your sense of confidence that your personal world is as secure as it can be for right now.And, it helps too to know that nothing lasts forever, eventually all of what is up in the air will start to land in a much more clear way.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: speaker
text: I need help dealing with stress. How can I handle it all and feel less stressed out?

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: Part of handling stress is making sure that your perception of the stress is accurate.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: Sometimes stress can seem more than it really is.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: One thing that I encourage my clients to do is to ask themselves, "What is this stressor really about?"

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: Simplifying stress is a key to minimizing stress and leads to feeling less stressed out.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: speaker
text: I need help dealing with stress. How can I handle it all and feel less stressed out?

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: There are many causes for feeling stressed out.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: Between a demanding job, family responsibilities, and everything else that can come up, stress becomes more and more part of our everyday life.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: One of the best ways to combat the toxic effects of stress on our bodies, social lives, and overall well being is to engage in self-care.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: But not the self-care that most people think of like vacations or massages.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: The best self-care is the kind that helps you live the life that you already have rather than escape it.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: You see, the reason why vacations and massages don't work long term in reducing stress is that they allow you to escape from what is causing the stress without truly fixing it so you just return to what already stressed you out.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: So, instead you need to find ways to help live with the stressors that you already have.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: They can be things like creating a more manageable schedule, introducing healthy eating or exercising, financial planning, and even learning a few simple relaxation skills.

title: How can I be less stressed?
author: listener
text: The key to combatting stress is to make small but consistent changes to your life so that it becomes more manageable and more enjoyable.

title: How do I relieve stress and find balance?
author: speaker
text: I'm in my late 20s. I have two jobs right now, I'm in school, and I feel like I just have a lot under my belt right now. I get stressed out really easily. I tend to worry and over-think. I'm just worried about money and everything.

title: How do I relieve stress and find balance?
author: listener
text: A good start is to pay attention to some basic issues: sleep, nutrition, exercise and socially supportive relationships.

title: How do I relieve stress and find balance?
author: listener
text: A great car on an empty tank will not get you very far.

title: Is there a reason I have always been attracted to men much older then me?
author: speaker
text: I am a young adult, and I was sexually assaulted by an older man when I was a teenager (which has really intensified the guilt/shame). However, I've been attracted to much older men since I was even younger than that.

title: Is there a reason I have always been attracted to men much older then me?
author: listener
text: Sometimes the reason for being attracted to older men is because of growing up with a father who was distant.If you grew up having enough interaction with your dad to know you'd have liked more and didn't receive this, then maybe your longings of childhood are still active within you.It is ok to like older men.Just be sure you're not idealizing them, or anyone else.Because regardless of age, a relationship is based on who the two people really are, not how we'd like imagining them.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: speaker
text: I have been experiencing a lot of sexual tension with a lot of the guys that I talk to nowadays. I keep imagining having sex with them. I have never had sex before, nor have I had a boyfriend. I feel lonely and empty. I feel like my body is not okay, and I am missing something. I talk to so many boys in school, and I always fantasize about half of them. I want this feeling to stop because it is interfering with my time to study since most of the time, I am busy thinking about sex.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: Hi Montreal, I'm glad you wrote.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: What you're experiencing is normal.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: We're sexual beings.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: We have a built-in desire to connect sexually with others, because it feels good, to keep procreation going, and mostly to "connect" with other people, because connecting with others makes us feel fulfilled and valuable.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: Sexual desire is a healthy part of you.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: Maybe your body is telling you it wants to dive into that water and taste it instead of just staring at it?

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: It sounds like you're beginning to explore yourself sexually, and that's okay.At your young age, you also have another innate burning desire, and that is to know yourself.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: I see both of these desires burning and competing in you.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: It's a bit of a crazy time...you want to connect with others but you're not sure who you are or what you want from them.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: You want to know yourself but you can't learn about yourself in a vacuum.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: It's okay to trust your instincts.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: It's okay to connect sexually with others, as long as you're preventing disease and pregnancy and you know how to protect your boundaries.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: But even as I write this, I think maybe I'm being controlling and overprotective of you; it's your body and you're in charge of what happens to it!

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: (But I do want you to be safe...whatever that means to you).

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: Maybe talk to someone you trust.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: With each encounter you have with other people (sexual or not), you will learn more about yourself and what you want, both sexually and just in relationship or friendship.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: You will develop a sense of who you are.Have you tried to get to know yourself sexually?

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: This is a super place to start, and knowing how your own body works can give you confidence when you eventually connect with others.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: When you explore your own body, what feels good?

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: What brings you to orgasm?

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener
text: I wish you well as you explore both who you are and how it feels to connect with others safely.

title: How do I deal with sexual tension?
author: listener

title: How do I repair my friendship?
author: speaker
text: My best friend and I were pranking her friend, and I told her to tell him that she likes him. She said no, but I forced her. After she told him, he told her that he likes her too. Their friendship is ruined because of me. She won't forgive me, and I feel really guilty. I feel like crying.

title: How do I repair my friendship?
author: listener
text: This takes time.

title: How do I repair my friendship?
author: listener
text: I don't know how long it has been, but perhaps if your friend is willing to discuss other things with you for a little while, you could discuss this at some point in the future.Hopefully the true intentions will become apparent (in the idea that it was a prank).Also, I encourage you to look at how this is affecting you and how you feel about yourself as well.

title: How do I repair my friendship?
author: listener
text: If it was meant to be a joke and it did not work, that is not entirely your fault.I wonder how you could forgive yourself for what happened?Are you able to seek what you meant to do compared to what actually happened?Do you notice that not everything that has happened here is in your control?Do you recognize that even though you would like things to be better, if your friend is not ready or willing, you are trying to do your part to make it right?Maybe everyone who is/was involved in this can talk together all at the same time to set straight what is truth and what was misunderstood.I wonder if you can think of your own positive attributes (for example: honesty, compassion, trustworthiness, friendship, good listener, caring) and look at what truly exists within you rather than just one your friend is able to see right now.This can be really difficult for multiple reasons, not the least of which is that it involves more than just you, so it's important to focus on the idea that you can ask these other people who were involved to discuss it, but that is ultimately up to them.Best wishes for looking at the positive parts of yourself and your friendships.

title: I have an old roommate who might be a psychopath
author: speaker
text: I was “mentored” by this guy for a few years spiritually. It was okay at times, but other times, it was just weird. I try not to think about it too much, but a lot of manipulation and lying happened, yet no one else really believed me when I told them. It's like he's two different people, and no one else really sees that side of him. I was blamed for a lot of our troubles, and now we don't really talk much. I'm worried because he's in a trusted position of leadership and no one suspects anything. They just think I'm attacking his character. How do I know for sure?

title: I have an old roommate who might be a psychopath
author: listener
text: It doesn't really matter what the actual diagnosis is, and whether or not he is an actual psychopath, he has manipulated and lied to you, and that is enough reason for you to stay far away from him.

title: I have an old roommate who might be a psychopath
author: listener
text: Men (and women) with these characteristics can become violent.

title: I have an old roommate who might be a psychopath

title: Why do I always get ignored by people?

title: Why do I always get ignored by people?
author: listener
text: I understand the feeling of not being liked due to not having any responses on the sites you list.More than likely the non-response has less to do with liking you than w liking the way you write your messages.Have you tried asking a question in your posts?

title: Why do I always get ignored by people?

title: How do I stop a bully who adults wouldn't recognize as bullying without speaking to the bully?
author: speaker
text: She mostly targets me on social media. The bullying used to be much worse, but it is still going on. The comments are so vague, but I know that they are meant for me. Even when I confront her, she messages me short phrases to try to get in my head. If I try to fight back, she will ruin me.

title: How do I stop a bully who adults wouldn't recognize as bullying without speaking to the bully?
author: listener
text: Sorry to hear of your problem situation.

title: How do I stop a bully who adults wouldn't recognize as bullying without speaking to the bully?
author: listener
text: Feeling intimidated by another person is very unsettling.Stop having contact with the person.Bullies only interact with others either by intimidating someone or by themselves feeling intimidated by someone.Bullies do not have the same dynamics as everyone else.No one can convince or persuade or talk a bully out of their behavior.The best protection for yourself, assuming you are not being physically threatened by the person, is to close contact with them.This does not take away any of the disappointment or sadness of wishing for a better relationship with the person.Until the bully wants to interact differently with others, only harm can result from contact with them.Step one is to stop the bleeding, then to assess and learn to live with not having the person in your life.

title: The child I nanny hates me!
author: speaker
text:
I nanny a three year old. When he wakes up in the morning he calls out for someone to come get him. If I am the one to go get him out of bed he gets really upset and refuses to let me near him. He screams that he wants his mom or dad (they work from home).    The rest of the day he loves me. But not in the mornings.
   What can I do?

title: The child I nanny hates me!
author: listener
text: Be lighthearted, this toddler may not be a morning person!

title: The child I nanny hates me!
author: listener
text: He is most likely wanting to connect with either parent when he arises in the morning.

title: The child I nanny hates me!
author: listener
text: It could be helpful to talk with his parents and establish a routine that he would be comfortable with.

title: The child I nanny hates me!
author: speaker
text:
I nanny a three year old. When he wakes up in the morning he calls out for someone to come get him. If I am the one to go get him out of bed he gets really upset and refuses to let me near him. He screams that he wants his mom or dad (they work from home).    The rest of the day he loves me. But not in the mornings.
   What can I do?

title: The child I nanny hates me!
author: listener
text: It is very likely the child is upset by the fact that the parents have left, more than that he hates you in particular.The fact that by afternoon he is happy with you shows more likelihood that he reacts to the parents departure more than who you are.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
author: listener
text: A failed suicide attempt is commonly thought of as a “cry for help,” however it can also be a serious attempt to find a permanent solution to depression, hopelessness or other feelings a person feels are unbearable.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
author: listener
text: It’s wonderful that you want to support your husband, but If your husband is feeling depressed and hopeless, you can best help him by getting him to a mental health professional.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
author: listener
text: Feelings of hopelessness and depression, and previous attempts at suicide are all risk factors for future suicide attempts.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?
author: listener
text: With a mental health professional, or in the emergency room of a hospital, your husband should be evaluated for suicidal thoughts, intent and plan, and if he is a danger to himself he should probably be hospitalized again until he is stable.

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?

title: How can I help my husband after a suicide attempt?

author: listener

author: listener
text: Even if you decide against immediately telling him how you're feeling, knowing this about yourself will guide how and the topics you bring up with him.Is your husband talking easily with you?Do you have some ideas as to what is creating his feeling of hopelessness?The ideal approach would be if the two of you are able to discuss what bothers him and what bothers you.Depending on how far away you each are from such a position, you may benefit from speaking with a licensed professional therapist who can guide you and or you and your husband on opening up for discussion what feels stressful enough to merit taking one's own life.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

author: listener
text: Being able to manage your thoughts and choose what to think about yourself is something you would learn in  counseling.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text:

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?
author: listener
text: A lot of times the thoughts we have about ourselves are messages we have received from other people and later internalized them.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: So in that sense, these thoughts are yours and belong to you, but you have received these messages from somebody else.

text: Even though we all receive messages like this at times, it pays to be careful not to ignore other messages we are receiving, such as a loved one appreciating your help or attention, a friend responding to encouragement, or a colleague showing interest in you.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?
author: listener
text: I hope this helps.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text:

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: Many people have thoughts like those you describe, and often it feels like someone else is saying it because they are things that may have been said to you when you were very young.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: When young children hear negative things about themselves they tend to internalize these negative ideas and to form negative core beliefs.

text: The good news is we can learn to stop these thoughts and to replace them with healthier thoughts.

text: The first step is to catch yourself when you are thinking these thoughts, and to stay "stop!

text: "; then replace it with another thought.

author: listener
text: So for instance, maybe you fail a test or get rejected by a romantic interest.

text: You catch yourself saying "you aren't worth anything".

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: Stop this thought, and replace it with "You didn't do as well on that test as you would have liked.

text: Let's figure out how you can do better next time."

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: So the idea is to develop a voice of a "friend", who can tell you the kind of things you would say to your own best friend.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?
author: listener
text: As a general information, in short, I can say that our thoughts are greatly influenced by our early life experiences.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?
author: listener
text: Our thoughts are processed through schemes, these are mental images or templates by which we make meaning of the world around us.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?
author: listener
text: While our upbringing has a great influence on the way we see and interact with the world around us as adults, However, we are not condemned to abide by them for life, in psychotherapy, you learn to change negative schemas with positive ones.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?
author: listener
text: Yeah, if you had less than optimal childhood you would have some sort of negative schemas that unconsciously lead to self-sabotage your efforts for success and happiness.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: The research in the field of interpersonal neurobiology suggests that without conscious awareness and reflective practices we tend to interact with the world by repeating old habits of mind.

title: Why can't I stop these thoughts?

text: On the other hand, in psychotherapy you can learn helpful strategies to increase your conscious abilities to stay in control of your mind in the present moment and reduce intrusions of negative mind habits.
