title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: speaker
text: I'm currently struggling with diagnosed depression, anxiety, and Misophonia. Also, I am 99% sure I have Borderline Personality Disorder and Avoidant Personality Disorder. I read the DSM-IV, taken college psychology, etc. I know it in my heart I have them. Is self-diagnosing okay with the right research?

title: Is self-diagnosing okay?
author: listener
text: Any diagnosis is limited in its usefulness.Knowing the name of some typical ways you may feel, think and behave, doesn't help you or anyone to understand why the person is the way they are and how to change any of these characteristics.Both self-diagnosing and being diagnosed are equally unhelpful to know why you are the way you are and what to do about it.Consider yourself a person who wants to find a better way to be who you are, and this will get you further with better results than to read a list of descriptions which all are very indicting and negative sounding.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: speaker
text:
She has trouble falling and staying asleep and she's always either extremely hungry or not hungry at all. She also gets angry and feels like crying really easily for no reason. She says she is always "kind of down."
   Is this depression? What can I do to help her?

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Sounds like signs of someone who is depressed.Since the person in question is your friend, offer your friendship to listen to any situations or feelings she has about herself and the way her life is going.Depressed people are often lonely people and feel as though no one around them cares or notices them.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Your willingness to be available to her may lift her spirits.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Feeling loved goes a long way to dissolving depressed feelings.Also, if in the beginning when you offer to talk, there is a high chance she'll be defensive and turn down your offer.Try again on another day and then another day.When people feel depressed they usually shut down.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: So you may need a few or several tries before your friend accepts your offer to show her you care about how she is doing.Also, watch for signs within yourself that your friends' depression is not sinking your emotions.

title: I think my friend might have depression
author: listener
text: Depressed people are draining to be around because they often see and talk about only the negatives and drawbacks of situations.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: speaker
text:

   I believe I have an actually case of something called hyper empathy disorder. But since it's such a new disorder I can't find any information about it. Could this be what is going on with me?

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Sometimes it's helps to have a name for a problem - it can make you feel less alone as in, "oh there's a name for this and other people have this experience too."

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: On the other hand naming the problem can also make it stick around longer as in "now I have a special problem that has a special name, and that's an important part of who I am.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: "Bottom line, whether it's a disorder or not, you would like life to be easier and not have to be pulled so much by other people's energy and feelings.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: You might want to try imagining that you have a volume dial on your empathy (just like the volume dial or button on the tv) that you can gently turn down to the point where you still feel what's going on but it's not so "loud".

title: I think I empathize too much
author: speaker
text:
I empathize so much, even with characters on tv or in video games, that I actually feel physical pain. This has made life difficult to say the least.
   I believe I have an actually case of something called hyper empathy disorder. But since it's such a new disorder I can't find any information about it. Could this be what is going on with me?

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: It sounds like this would be difficult at times, particularly if you feel misunderstood.You may or may not know that we all have chemicals in our brain.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: We also have different sections of our brain that become active when different things happen.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: There is a part of our brain where a lot of our emotions originate that is also designed to protect us when we are going through things that have been physically or emotionally painful in the past, and when that part of the brain is sometimes overactive (perceiving threat when there is no actual threat at the time), sometimes anxiety can develop.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: This doesn't necessarily mean that everyone has an anxiety disorder, but often if we are afraid of something that is not actually a legitimate concern (for example, most insects are not going to hurt me, but I still do not like them very much), we have anxiety about it.The first thing I thought of when I read your question is that perhaps some part of your brain are overactive.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: I did find an article that may be helpful to you, but I just want to caution you.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Not everything listed here applies to you.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Also, the article uses the term "brain anomalies."

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: This does not mean that there is something majorly wrong with your brain.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: While I cannot tell you exactly what is happening, I'm asking you not to panic over the term and to just consider that perhaps some of the chemical reactions in your brain may be a little overactive, which may be able to be corrected with medication or something similar.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: I can't tell for certain from what you posted whether or not this is what is happening, but I would recommend that you either talk to your primary care physician or a therapist or psychiatrist.Here is the article: http://blogs.psychcentral.com/addiction-recovery/2012/09/too-much-empathy/When you meet with your doctor or a therapist, please try to convey how much this is affecting your life.Thank you so much for posting here and I wish you the best.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: speaker
text:
I empathize so much, even with characters on tv or in video games, that I actually feel physical pain. This has made life difficult to say the least.
   I believe I have an actually case of something called hyper empathy disorder. But since it's such a new disorder I can't find any information about it. Could this be what is going on with me?

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: The world needs more people lately who have such a high degree of empathy which you describe in yourself!If it feels a little burdensome, then look to balance what is too much with its opposite.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Since you're giving a lot of empathy, maybe you'd like receiving a lot of empathy.In the situation you describe, when you start empathizing with others, real or cartoon, ask yourself whether you've felt empathy coming in your direction lately.Often people give to others what they feel within themselves is missing.The emotional brain reasons that if I give you my support, say, then at least I will feel half of what being supported is like.Obviously the wish to receive more empathy cannot be fulfilled by you directly.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Empathy is delivered by someone who is willing to offer it.Reflect on whether you are allowing those who are in your world, to know when you would like to receive their empathy.Is it possible you keep your feelings to yourself and present as though you are able to handle a great deal more than you'd like to handle without anyone's kindness to support you?Being open to others about your own inner thoughts and feelings is much more difficult than it sounds.It sounds easy to just tell someone how you feel.Sometimes the first step is the most difficult, of accessing how you feel.Start with knowing the amount of empathy you'd like from others and what stops you from asking.Also, about your diagnosis and the lack of  studies and lists and formulas.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Each person is unique, the instructions and guidelines don't necessarily mean very much.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Often having a diagnosis makes a person feel weak, stigmatized, incompetent.

title: I think I empathize too much
author: listener
text: Forget the diagnosis and concentrate on what you need to do differently in order to feel better.The answers are inside you, not inside a book or website.

text: Good question!The client's job is to concentrate on stating the details of their problem and to thoughtfully engage in a dialogue about these areas with the therapist.The most difficult job for a client is willingness to self-examine, hold oneself accountable for relationship and life situations, and honestly feel the difficult, often painful feelings and insecurities which troubling situations create.The client doesn't train the therapist.If you feel you are with a therapist who requires you to train them, then politely decline continuing to pay for their services.Then find yourself a different therapist who feels secure and knowledgeable enough in their skills to not require training by their client.

text: There is no such thing as having too many problems for therapy.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Therapy is great because it will help you process all that you are going through, heal from past and present pain, and gain clarity.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: speaker
text:
I have so many issues to address. I have a history of sexual abuse, I’m a breast cancer survivor and I am a lifetime insomniac.    I have a long history of depression and I’m beginning to have anxiety. I have low self esteem but I’ve been happily married for almost 35 years.
   I’ve never had counseling about any of this. Do I have too many issues to address in counseling?

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: It could be said that you might be the perfect candidate for counseling!

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: No one is beyond hope, and someone brave enough to be honest regarding their struggles, with the intention of reaching out for help is certainly a person a qualified counselor would be happy to assist.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: You may want to do some research on therapists in your local area who specialize in mind-body connection, or one of the struggles you have acknowledged in your post, in order to find a therapist that is best suited to meet your needs.

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener
text: Good luck on your search, and remember that the world is a better place with you in it.

text:

the most concerning issues first.

text: Participating in counseling with a licensed professional offers a safe place and therapeutic relationship where healing can occur.

author: listener

title: Do I have too many issues for counseling?
author: listener

title: What are the skills needed by a counselor?
author: speaker
text: What are the basic skills a good counselor needs to have?

title: What are the skills needed by a counselor?
author: listener
text: 1) An awareness of their own incompetence and inexperience with events in your life;2) An awareness of how the body, mind, emotions, spirit, and others all intertwine and activate one another;3) How to work to use these connections to have you improve your experience...Oh yeah, and there's some listening in there, as well :)

title: What are the skills needed by a counselor?
author: speaker
text: What are the basic skills a good counselor needs to have?

title: What are the skills needed by a counselor?
author: listener
text: To be non-judgemental, know who they themselves are, be able to step forward and ask questions with ease and grace into painful emotional areas.Also to respect human difference in accomplishing basic life tasks and everyday living.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There are different reasons why a counselor may seek to terminate with a client and these will each have different processes by which the counselor will come to that decision.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Here are a few examples.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The counselor may determine that the client's needs are outside what the counselor is competent to be able to work with.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: A person may have come to the counselor talking about a particular issue but either when they first met or as counseling progressed, it may become clear that the issue is in fact something different or that there is an additional related issue.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If that issue is outside the competence of the counselor, the counselor should look for alternatives, the most common of which would be to terminate and refer.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Beyond clinical issues, this could also come up around particular other related facts, such as the culture of the client or linguistic issues.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This could also be the choice of the counselor if they know someone that they feel would be a better match for the client's issues.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Another reason for discharge (and possible referral) would be if the relationship does not seem to be a good fit.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: No counselor is the right person to work with everyone.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If the right level of connection is not happening, the counselor will often look first at what they are doing, might talk about it with the client and ultimately will admit that things don't seem to be working to allow the desired therapeutic process to work.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: A similar process would be followed if the counselor determined that the client might not yet be ready for counseling as evidenced by lack of engagement such as frequent cancellations, not doing any agreed on work between sessions, showing up late or being really guarded in session.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: The easiest situation to decide on is when a person has met their counseling goals and have nothing new that they are working on.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: While this is the easiest one to determine, it is also probably the hardest one for the counselor as they may be like the client in not wanting the relationship to come to an end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: However, counselors know that this is part of the process.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: They will also determine this by regularly reviewing the treatment plan or by sending in the sessions that the work has come to an end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This type of termination maybe final or may be with the intent that the client will return later to address other things that have been identified but for which they are not ready to move into.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: All of these (and other) situations involves the counselor being open to the relationship ending, to monitoring how things are going, then engaging in self reflection, possibly talking with the client and then coming to a conclusion on which the counselor  follows through.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: From the very beginning of counseling sessions I emphasize that the work will and must end at some point.In counseling there is an arc to the process.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: A beginning, middle and end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I am always digging, searching and exploring.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There comes a point where things come to there natural ending.I always leave an opening for continuing counseling in the future.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: At least as a check in.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: For most:  When the money/insurance runs out.When best:  When the job is done... and you're feeling much better.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: To be able to identify a clear ending to a counseling relationship, we must have a clear understanding of the goals and limitations of treatment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Usually, during the initial evaluation, I identify my client’s short term and long term therapy goals.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: As therapy progress, we verify goals on a monthly to a quarterly basis, depending on the frequency of the appointments.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Once the therapy goals have been met, there is a closing session, the counseling relationship is ended, and the client can stop attending sessions.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In some cases, the client can also establish new goals and determine if I am a good fit for their therapy needs or if they need a new provider, in which case I provide multiple referrals.The counseling relationship could also end due to other factors like noncompliance= when a client is not committed to the agreed treatment process, or when the client’s or a counselor violates the counseling relationship.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Either the counselor or the client is able to end counseling.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Although, as mental health providers we need to provide a reason for terminating our therapeutic relationship and referral options, as a client no explanation is needed, a closing session is highly recommended.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: ¿Cómo termina la terapia?¿Cómo un consejero decide cuando terminar las sesiones de consejería o terminar de trabajar con un paciente?Para poder determinar el final de la relación del consejero, debemos comprender las metas y parámetros de la terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Usualmente durante la evaluación inicial se identifican metas a corto y largo plazo con el cliente, y se discute con el cliente como esas metas serán alcanzadas.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Durante el proceso de terapia el consejero revisa las metas mensual o trimestralmente dependiendo de la frecuencia de las citas.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Ya que las metas de terapia son alcanzadas, hay una sesión de cierre y el cliente puede terminar la terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: En algunos casos el cliente puede identificar nuevas metas para la terapia y determinar si el mismo consejero u otro consejero le pueden asistir.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: La relación de consejería también puede terminar por no conformar o violentar los parámetros  establecidos para la terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Tanto el consejero como el cliente pueden terminar la relación de terapia.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Como proveedores de salud mental los consejeros estamos obligados a proveer un razón para la conclusión del tratamiento y proveer referidos según aplique, los clientes no necesitan proveer una explicación, aunque es recomendable discutirlo en una sesión de cierre.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: As a therapist who believes in client self-determination above most other elements of the process, I want to as much as possible leave it up to the client to determine when they are finished.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In the case of a termination because a client's distress has resolved, I might periodically check in with the client about how therapy has been going, and if we want to re-evaluate where we are.The more unfortunate situation would come about if I felt that I wasn't the best fit for the client.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I would offer that in words, and ideas of therapists (with names) of who I thought might be a better fit and why.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It still is up to the client whether to continue, however should they want to keep seeing me, a part of the work would be about that want (to see someone who professionally doesn't believe they can help as much as someone else.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: )I also find it perplexing when I hear a client (or on a personal level) tell me that their therapist said they "didn't need therapy."

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I don't know that I buy into that scenario all that much, because I do believe that yes, not everyone NEEDS therapy, but that everyone CAN benefit from therapy and I don't believe it is the therapist's job to deter someone from ever seeking out help of any kind.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Ideally, termination should be a mutual process.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It's not that the therapist kicks the client out at some point and says, "Okay, you're done."

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Rather, over time the client will decrease the frequency with which he/she comes to session so that it may start off as weekly, then decrease to biweekly, then perhaps once every three weeks, then once/month and so on.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Throughout this process, the therapist and client should have had regular check ins about progress toward goals.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If the client feels good about where he/she is in life, he/she might decide to suspend therapy for now.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: That being said, the therapist should make it very clear that if the client ever decided to return for "maintenance" therapy or a check in, he/she would always be welcome.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There is no hard and fast rule to ending or a particular time period in which it must end.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: What matters most is that the client feels good about it and knows that the therapist will always be there should he/she wish to return.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: For a therapist, deciding to end counseling sessions or terminate working with a client is a thoughtful and intentional decision.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: One that is not entered into lightly.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: While there are many considerations counselors take into account, to help answer this question, I'll offer an example of two areas that counselor's take into consideration when ending counseling sessions:Does the client need different or more specialized care than the current counselor can provide?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This requires the counselor to determine whether referring the client to another therapist or health care provider is needed.And, has the therapeutic relationship reached treatment goal(s)?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: While this question is specific to the counselor, I'd like to also add that a client, at any time, can end counseling.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In general, I usually let the client decide when this should occur, sometimes with some clients it will be a joint agreement, but even in that case it should weigh mostly on what the client feels.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: In short, therapy ends when you feel your done.C

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I will work with clients and continually review progress with them and determine if counseling is helping.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If a client appears to have less to talk about in sessions, appears more stable for a period of time and has reached therapeutic goals I will talk about termination.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Some clients however I may continue with on a monthly or bi monthly process to allow for check-ins to see how they are doing and if they need more help at that time.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Counseling ends when the client has received the maximum benefit from the therapist.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Even if the therapist believes the client is not making progress, the client may feel they are improving and receiving a benefit.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: And the therapist may see a benefit and the client does not.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It is best to have ongoing dialogue with the client to determine when termination is appropriate.

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Goodbyes can be hard.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Chances are most of the goodbyes you have experienced in your life have been
difficult.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Saying goodbye to a therapist can be different.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
It can be an
opportunity to create a healthy ending in a positive relationship in your life.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
If you work with a therapist who is skilled, then saying goodbye can be just as
transformative as the therapy itself.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Ending therapy is also known
as “termination.” I know, “termination” doesn’t have a great ring to it!

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: However, it is what it is.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It is an ending of the relationship as it existed.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: It is reality cold and stark.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Of course, when I talk to clients I don’t use the
word “termination,” I usually say “our goodbye.”  Under what circumstances does therapy usually
end?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Therapy should end when a client does not need further assistance, is not
receiving any benefit from therapy, or might be harmed by continuing to work
with a particular therapist.In the best case scenario
the decision to move on from therapy and “say our goodbyes” happens when both
the therapist and the client feel like the client is ready to move on and move
up!

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Ending the therapeutic relationship
should actually be worked on from the very first session.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
What I mean by that
is, there should be an understanding that the work we do together will have an
ending and that is a good thing because it means the client has gained the
skills to continue working on themselves independently.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
So the first session I
have with clients usually outlines a plan where the end goal is discussed and
we both have an understanding of the skills the client wants to learn or what
they hope to achieve.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Now sometimes there are
situations where the therapist ends the relationship and the client may take
that personally, it is hard when any relationship ends and it might bring up
feelings of sadness, and fear or abandonment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Any good therapist will end the
relationship based on what is right for the client.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
What are some situations
where a therapist might end the relationship?If the situation the client
is dealing with is out of the therapist's scope of practice, the therapist may
end the relationship and refer the client to someone else.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
This is in the
client’s best interest.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Another reason a therapist might end the relationship
is that the therapist is in a place in her life which prevents her from being
objective and helpful.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
A therapist who
is going through a painful divorce may have difficulty working with a couple
that considering divorce.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
A good therapist may see that their judgement may be
clouded and want to refer the client to see someone else.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
This is good practice
and helps the client.If a client is actively
suicidal or actively using substances then the therapist may end the
relationship and refer out for a higher level of care.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
The client may need to
be hospitalized or may need an inpatient substance abuse treatment program.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Therapy may be terminated while they are being treated and may continue after
the intensive program is completed.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
Ending therapy should be a
time for connection and bringing together accomplishments, or reviewing the
next important step the client needs to take.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
It should not be an experience of
abandonment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
A skilled therapist will help a client gain a new perspective on
closure.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text:
For some clients, it may be the one time in their lives when they get
a clean ending in a healthy relationship and they get to feel a sense of
control on creating that ending.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Good luck to you!

title: How does counseling end?
author: speaker
text: How does a counselor decide when to end counseling sessions or to terminate working with a client?

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This is a question that is very specific to each person.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: There are definitely some variables, but I can give you some general ideas for when counseling might end:When a client has met all of their goals, at least to a degree when they feel that they no longer need to work on them with the assistance of a counselorSometimes a decision is made that a client is no longer benefiting from counseling at a certain timeSometimes clients have to remain in counseling in order to receive medication.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: This depends on agency policy, but sometimes it is a requirement.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: If the medication is necessary and cannot be prescribed by a primary care physician, frequency of sessions is usually decreased greatlyI'm not sure why you are asking this question, but it is also something that is often discussed at the beginning of treatment.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Oftentimes "discharge goals" change as treatment progresses because more is known about clients, their goals, changes in their goals, and many other things.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: Changes are normal, but your counselor probably has discharge goals in mind, at least generally, from the beginning.

title: How does counseling end?
author: listener
text: I strongly encourage you to ask about it!

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: speaker
text: What are some difficulties that a counselor can encounter when dealing with a client?

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: Yes, just like some relationships outside of our work are more difficult than others.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: But, I would not say that the "client is more difficult," rather the dynamic between myself and the client, which constitutes a relationship, might feel more difficult.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: And that's okay (sometimes things that feel like the most challenging end up with profound shifts and outcomes.)

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: It is often helpful to understand difficulties that exist, because they can illuminate for a therapist something with which a client might be struggling, and when it takes place in the therapy space, it can be experienced and then worked through.It's hard to necessarily say what some difficulties are that a counselor might encounter, but I would say that not showing up, like in any relationship, is one of the hardest things for me.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: And not just physically not showing up (though that is certainly frustrating), but not being open to the work is a form of not showing up.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: While not every client is as "motivated to change," it's helpful to my therapist-client relationships that the client try.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: It might be hard for them, but the effort even to say "this is tough for me" can go a long way in these kinds of relationships.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: speaker
text: What are some difficulties that a counselor can encounter when dealing with a client?

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: Each counselor will have their own list of "difficulties" in doing therapy work with a client.

title: Are some clients more difficult than others?
author: listener
text: Even if clinically trained similarly, since counselors are human then their response to your question will reflect their unique differences as humans.On my list is when the emotional pain I feel for someone describing some type of injustice or unfair treatment by another, feels very deep.Sometimes I feel like avoiding the pain I feel by asking questions which will steer the conversation away from the painful areas the client talks about.What in fact is necessary to clear out their pain, is to step further into so as to realize their emotional pain isn't greater than who they are.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: speaker
text: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Hi!

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Great question.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: I believe counseling does help people!

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Of course, I am a therapist, so I would think that!

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: :)  Seriously - I think therapy and counseling allow us to understand ourselves, our motivations and the things that bring us happiness and discontent.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Therapy can create opportunities to try new skills and enhance positive attributes that are already present in someone.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: I like to think of therapy as an unbiased "aerial view" of our lives.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Someone outside can often help us notice things we might otherwise miss.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Hope this helps!

title: How does counseling help people?
author: speaker
text: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Yes, counseling helps a lot of people, especially when there is a good rapport between the counselor and their client.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Knowing your counselor is someone who is really on your side and wants to see you grow past your difficulties into a healthy, happy, successful life is more important than what kind of counseling method they use.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: If you are looking for a counselor, take your time and be sure you feel heard and respected as well as challenged to grow.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: speaker
text: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: A counselor can do a few things that can be helpful:1) Give you a space where you can explore what's in your head without worrying about being judged or punished.2) Help you better understand yourself, your choices, your motivations.3) Give you tools and information you can use to help create change in your life.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Ultimately, though, it's up to the client to take action, because action is what creates change.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: So, a counselor can't create change ... but they can facilitate and support it.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: speaker
text: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: No, not really;And it's impossible for it to, anyway;And, this is isn't some sort of "you did it all yourself" kind of blather;Because:1) In most outcomes, if a man or woman simply does nothing and waits, most of the time, they get better... (there are reasons to that);2) In most therapy sessions, approximately 92% (give or take, per study) of all outcomes--be they positive or negative--occur due to factors SOLELY WITHIN the man or woman seeking therapy to begin with;3) The word "THERAPY" does not imply cure, but implies treatment (suppression);4) Truly, a proper "therapist" will be able to spot the problem quickly, recommended proper protocols quickly, and coach to completion.5) Even if we PRESUME generosity, the "therapist" really doesn't matter much (maybe 8%); it really all is in you...Be well, man...

title: How does counseling help people?
author: speaker
text: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: You are asking a room full of counselors, and so I am going to guess that we may be a bit biased :).

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: My answer is this: sometimes.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Many people benefit from counseling and when counseling works those benefits can show up through positive improvements in your moods, making more choices that align with your values, working through stuff, and a general improved sense of self.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, for a variety of reasons, a counselor, the approach they are using and the person do not match up and when that happens sometimes counseling does not help.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: It is very important to find the right counselor for you.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Ideally this should be someone you feel a level of trust and connection with who is also using a style that you feel confident in.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Research has shown that these aspects (what is called the 'therapeutic alliance') along with shared goals between the client and counselor give counseling the best chance at being effective

title: How does counseling help people?
author: speaker
text: Does counseling really do anything that can help people?

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
I believe that counseling (and finding a GOOD therapist)
will be of significant help when the individual seeking therapy desires change,
improvement, and overall growth.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Most counseling involves homework and a level
of commitment outside of session that also contributes to resolution of
problems and an ability to cope with stresses in a productive way.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Here are
some of the key ways that therapy can help.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Helps to define the problem and gain a clearer
understanding of where it originates.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Many people seek counseling because of symptoms they are
experiencing.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
These can include feeling sad, increased sleeping, substance use,
panic attacks, self-harm, isolating one’s self, academic decline, etc.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Often
times, people are not aware of what is causing these symptoms.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Having a
therapist to help guide and explore why the symptoms are occurring and where
they come from will give individuals increased insight and awareness into their
problems.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Allows for a safe outlet to vent.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Not everyone likes to share their problems with close
friends or family members.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Maybe they don’t want others to know of their flaws.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Maybe they don’t want to burden others with their problems.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Or maybe they just
are not comfortable talking about themselves.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
And in some situations people do
not have the option of talking with someone they know because they have no
friends or family.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
While talking with those we know can help bring some relief
it is also nice to talk with someone like a therapist who is objective and
emotionally removed from given situations.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Counseling gives a safe outlet in
which one can express their personal feelings and thoughts without feeling
judged.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text: Counselors can offer various problem solving solutions.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
A good therapist usually will not directly point their
client in the direction they need to go.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Counseling is about growth and
teaching the client to identify triggers and use effective coping strategies
that will bring about emotional and psychological relief.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Counselors will help
clients to explore the various options available in given situation, based on
the client’s needs, wants, and values and will help them to choose the option
that best fits with their desired outcome.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Gives one the tools needed to cope with current and future
problems.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Many individuals that seek therapy have never learned
good coping strategies.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Perhaps they did not have parents or caretakers to
model productive ways to cope or maybe the symptoms they are suffering from are
overbearing and take away the energy needed to cope.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
Different diagnoses
require different tools; however some are beneficial for any problem and any
individual.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
These include but are not limited to relaxation techniques,
breathing exercises, development of healthy routines, using mindfulness,
improving communication skills, and recognizing and changing maladaptive
thought patterns.

title: How does counseling help people?
author: listener
text:
A good counselor will teach clients how to use these tools,
will often practice them during session, and will assign homework for further
practice and mastery of the skills.

title: Is it normal to go into therapy feeling nervous?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?

text: Studies show that the most important element in effective therapy is that you feel a connection with your counselor.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Hello.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Counseling often begins way before the client ever actually calls the local therapist.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: There is often a tipping point in the internal struggle that the client experiences, where they can no longer deal with the issues on their own and thus giving the motivation to seek external help.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: That said, clients usually go seeking therapists based on what their insurance will cover, or what is likely to be more and more the case in the near future...what they are able to pay for out of pocket.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: That first phone call to a prospective counselor can often feel like torture, but it doesn't have to stay that way.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Counselors are well trained to acknowledge the inherent goodness of all clients, and should be able to see and hear the sense of fear in the client of being judged or put down in some way.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: The counselor you select should be compassionate, caring, able to join with you on your journey to resolving your issues or concerns, and to do so without negative judgment of you as a person of worth.Once you have found a counselor you want to work with, you would then schedule an appointment to meet.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: That first session is often very low key.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: There might be some forms for you to complete, which will help the counselor address your concerns and learn a bit more about you.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: The counselor will typically provide you with what we generally call in the profession a professional disclosure or practice statement.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: This document (which may be several pages long) usually outlines the counselor's credentials; practice rules; forms of payment; office hours; emergency contact details; and confidentiality guidelines under state and federal law, among other details.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: All of this benefits you as the client, so that you are well informed and can focus your attention on why you are meeting with the counselor.In the first session, it is absolutely okay to be nervous.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Here's a really big secret (which is important to keep in mind as counseling begins): Counselors are often as nervous (if not more) to meet a new client, as the client is to meet their new counselor.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: It's true.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: We as professionals are trying to put our best foot forward to impress you with our awesome counseling skills.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: While simultaneously hiding all the troubling unwanted issues that we ourselves have in our life too, and being worried that we might not know if we can help the client sitting in front of us.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: What makes it even more challenging, is that counselors are often put on a giant pedestal of perfection by clients (all while we as counselors tend to look at it like we're standing on a three legged stool).

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: This is normal for us when seen from the eyes of the client.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Counselors and clients are both human, and we both make mistakes.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Coming from that place of understanding, might bring a sense of ease to both the client and the therapist as they seek to work together.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Part of this perception of perfection held by clients toward counselors, is that the skills of the counselor might look like they have all the answers.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: We honestly do not, plain and simple.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Counselors come from life experiences (where they might be farther down on life's road than you); they hold completion of various forms of training; and have advanced education.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Yet we are in the end, imperfect beings struggling to help imperfect people.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: This makes it easier to be compassionate to new clients walking through our door with the hope that we will receive that same compassion in return.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Very often, we can find ourselves reflected in our clients' lives with their struggles and can become more effective at helping if we have resolved similar issues in our own life.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: So as you begin to seek out a therapist, try looking for one who is aware of their own life issues and is actively working on them too.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Someone who can meet you where you are at emotionally and can understand your sense of your struggle that you are facing at the present moment.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: That counselor may be a good example for you as you enter into therapy and build your own strength, and thus begin dealing with the issues more effectively you bring up in therapy.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Usually people call me by phone, they introduce themselves, we chat for a bit, then we schedule a time for their appointment

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: I have found that if you go to my website and fill out the form, I can usually get back to you within 24 hours.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: In my most efficient instances, I've been able to set-up a consultation within a couple of days, which is just 15 minutes by phone, to chat a little about what you might want to work on, how I may or may not be a good fit, etc.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Then from there, if you want to meet in person we can set up an initial session.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: I will usually be able to let you know what kinds of ongoing times for counseling that I have available over the phone.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Scheduling is a big barrier to finding a therapist, especially in New York, when schedules seem pretty busy all around.I've heard a lot of statistics about how prospective clients in therapy will often wait for months before reaching out, which is why I think that email is great.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Cold-calling can cause an unnecessary amount of anxiety (also, who will hear me on the phone?)

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: whereas email is relatively easy to begin a conversation, from what I've found.I tend to recommend clients give a new therapist a couple of sessions to get a feel for fit.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: But, if it's horrible after one session, and you feel awful when you leave, that's another story.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: I might want to explore with you what felt so awful, but if you don't want to come back, that is well within your right.Also, keep in mind that we want to help.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: So, please don't feel like we are judging you for seeking out help!

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: You are strong for doing so.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Far too often I hear about it as a weakness, and that's just BS:)

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: A great place to start is at www.psychologytoday.com.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: You can search by location and identify therapists who have expertise in your area of concern.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Once you find a few people that fit your criteria, read about them on Psychology today as well as check out their website if they have one.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Next, either call or email them to set up a time to talk for a few minutes.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: When you speak with them, you want to know a few things: do they have a decent amount of experience in your area of concern?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Are their fees, insurance coverage and scheduling availability a good fit for you?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Most importantly, see if you feel comfortable when you speak to them on the phone!

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: If this person is a good match in these areas, schedule an initial consultation so that you can see if you are also a good match in person.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: First, identify the areas that you need help with.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: What are the issues that are most troubling you?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Are these situations creating an impact on your daily routine?Second, do some research as to the type of counselling service you are looking and that would best suit your needs.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Are you looking for individual sesssions, couples/family sessions, etc.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: And research potential therapists in your area that focus their counselling approach on your therapeutic needs.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Third, contact the therapist (most don't answer the phones, so leave a message or send an email).

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Don't be affraid to ask questions.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: You want to make sure that this professional is a good "match" for you and will work with you at working toward your therapeutic goals (the things you want to address/work on during the sessions).Fourth, have the expectation that, depending on the issues, you will need multiple sessions/appointments with the therapist to really address the issues and work toward your therapeutic goals.It takes strength and courage to reach out for help, but I know you can reach your goals.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: It takes time, patience, and practice do really address your needs.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Good luck!

title: How does someone approach a counselor?

text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: I always suggest that you find the right fit.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: You have every right to interview the therapist and ask as many questions as you need.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: It is our job as a therapist to explain our approach and philosophy.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: This gives you a good overview of the therapist.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Just call and say that you would like to talk to the therapist.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Say your interested in the services but unclear about how the process works.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: From there a seasoned therapist should be proficient in helping to guide you through the process with ease and comfort.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Starting the counseling process can be daunting but here are some ways that hopefully help make the process a little less overwhelming.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: First,I'd start with finding a therapist through a therapist directory and searching for a therapist specifically in your area and with the expertise you're looking for.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: There are many reputable therapist directories online that offer specific information and links to therapist websites to learn more about how they can help.Next, I'd pick two or three of interest to contact directly.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Have a list of questions that are important to you that you can ask to determine whether a particular therapist is a good fit.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Many therapists offer a free phone consultation to allow you both to determine whether it is a good fit.Then, after you schedule, the next step is to see what it's like being in session to determine if the fit is still a match.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: The easiest way to start the counseling process is to do a little research online.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: A quick search for the type of counseling you are looking for can be helpful.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: There are lots of Counselors out there to choose from, so many times you will have to take it a few steps further than that.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Check out their website, social media, and any reviews (but remember, people are not always very nice).

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: If you plan on using insurance to pay for at least part of the services, look for one that is in your network.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: You can find out if someone is in your network by looking for providers on your insurance's website.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: If your coverage isn't that great and you know you're going to be paying for it all anyway (because you're an all-star and verified your coverage already with the insurance company), then you can really pick any Counselor you want, but working with one that is at least out of network will give you the benefit of having it applied to your deductible.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: If you have any questions about that process or just want some help in getting your benefits from the insurance company once you've started counseling, Better is a good option.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Once you've found a Counselor you think is a good fit for you, normally the best step to take here is to call and schedule your very first appointment.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: With many Counselors you can now send an email, but a phone call can normally tell you quite a bit about someone and their clinic.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Once you're all scheduled, they will either get you to do some paperwork before you come in, or many times they just let you fill it out once you get there.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: From there, all you have to do is show up!

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: speaker
text: How does a person start the counseling process?

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: The first thing to do is to reflect on what you want to seek counseling.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: Search online and then set up a phone consultation.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: A person can find out a lot about a counselor and the services that they offer over the phone.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: After a consultation then set up an intake questions.

title: How does someone approach a counselor?
author: listener
text: The overall goal is to make sure that you are comfortable with the counselor and the services they can offer.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: People do cry in therapy sometimes, but it's not at all necessary to cry in order for most kinds of therapy to be helpful.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: When you start counseling you don't yet know your counselor very well, so it's normal to keep your feelings in check until you feel comfortable and a bit more relaxed with your counselor and with the situation.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Sometimes, though, there are emotions that have been waiting and waiting to finally find someone who will listen with a kind ear.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: If you feel safe right away in the situation with your counselor, you might just cry in spite of your fears about it.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Your therapist is used to people expressing how they feel and will keep strict confidentiality, so even though it's embarrassing, finally experiencing someone truly listening with empathy and kindness may just be worth it.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's okay too to let your counselor know right at the beginning that you're kind of freaked out about getting too emotional in front of another person.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It is is absolutely normal to cry in therapy.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: I can understand wanting to keep everything together and put your best foot forward with everyone you come into contact with, but it can be such a powerful experience to cry with somebody that can hear you and accept you.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's so brave of you to go and share yourself with your counselor!

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: I hope you will keep being brave as you begin healing.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Lots of people do cry in session, but your therapist won't be uneasy with this.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Crying is a natural response and it also releases toxins, so some might say it's necessary!

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Remember that you can be in charge of what you talk about in your session and if there's something that feels too uncomfortable, just say, "I'm not ready to talk about that."

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Your counselor wants  you to feel at ease and will probably not push you right away to a very uncomfortable place.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: As you get to know your therapist, you will feel more relaxed and even not worry so much about how you appear to them.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's normal to be anxious going into a new situation especially when you might not feel in control of uncomfortable emotions.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Don't give up, go and put your best effort in!

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Hope that helps, Allison

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Many people cry during their therapy sessions.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Actually most people cry in their therapist's office.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: I tell my clients that it's safe to cry in my office and crying isn't a sign of weakness.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: It's a normal human response to pain.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: People actually do more harm to themselves by trying not to cry than by crying.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Crying is very cleansing and an important part of the healing process for many people.

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: speaker
text: I start counseling/therapy in a few days (I'm freaking out) but my main fear is that I'll cry and embarrass myself, is it something to worry about?

title: Is it normal to cry during therapy?
author: listener
text: Please feel free to cry during therapy if you suddenly feel painful emotions arising when you describe some of your unsatisfying and unfulfilling relationships and situations.Crying when realizing the emotional hurt and unfairness between you and someone, clears you for new ways of handling interactions.As a therapist, I always have a box of tissues on the table next to the couch where people who utilize my therapy, sit.I hope you will soon discover that once your tears unlock your awareness of harmful relationships in your life, you will quickly see the freedom to establish new and happier patterns of relating.Have a good therapy!

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: speaker
text: After first meeting the client, what is the process that a counselor facilitates?

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: For me, I want a client to feel like I understand what brings them to seek help from me.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: So I might explore both their present circumstances, as well as their history, and try to start making some connections between the two, but so that the both of us can understand what is taking place.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: Not every therapist goes into history in the same way, either.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: The way the therapist practices will often inform the ways in which they collect and look at data.However, above all, my goal, especially in the beginning of therapy, is to work on developing a working rapport with any client.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: Most research states that the quality of the relationship, rather than modality of therapy, indicates success rates.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: One of the most essential components of rapport is that someone feels heard, attuned to, and understood.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: speaker
text: After first meeting the client, what is the process that a counselor facilitates?

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: Hi.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: This is an excellent question !

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: I think that the answer probably varies depending upon the particular therapist .

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: In my work with people , once we have met and I have gotten an idea of the person'a concerns and the issues they want help with , I spend the next few sessions gathering as much history and as much information about the client's current concerns in order to formulate some ideas about what may be causing distress .

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: I would then share my thoughts with the client to see if they feel I am understanding them and on the right track.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: We would then discuss the best plan to address the client's concerns .

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: Usually I will suggest strategies that I think may be helpful and ask the client for feedback about whether or not they think my suggestions feel helpful .

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: I always encourage clients to be really honest with me about this.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: I tell them that I would hate for them to agree to try things that they know they won't try just to avoid "hurting my feelings" or "offending me."

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: I want to be helpful and while I have the expertise as far as typically helpful  strategies, I really like to work collaboratively and have clients tell me what they do and don't like / agree with or not agree with when I share my thoughts about a treatment plan .

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: We the   work together to come up with a plan that will be helpful , but also realistic and then revise it and try new things if necessary as we go along.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: If things aren't improving , I am very happy and willing to try something new !

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: I hope this is helpful for you !

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: speaker
text: After first meeting the client, what is the process that a counselor facilitates?

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: There are probably no two therapists alike because first and foremost we are human beings!And...our personalities may somewhat guide how we go about getting to know you, identifying what you would like to be different in your life and developing a plan to get where you would like to be.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: The very most important thing that will determine a successful outcome is the healthy therapeutic relationship between you and your therapist.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: If you don't feel safe, comfortable and ready to work together, then it is likely not a good fit.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: And that's OK...speak up and the therapist should assist you in finding someone you can readily work with.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: speaker
text: After first meeting the client, what is the process that a counselor facilitates?

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: Great question which I imagine many other people have as well.The therapist will want to know your main source of life discomfort.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: In what areas are the problem interactions which you hope will disappear?The therapist is trained to listen for your emotions to your story.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: And to open these up to you in a kind and safe way so that you'll start to see your circumstance in a new light in which you feel more of your own authority to handle the troubling conditions.The therapist and you will refine your thinking and theories.

title: What happens in a counseling session?
author: listener
text: The therapist will ask questions to help you prepare for any stumbling blocks along your way of creating your own new answers to the problem you brought to counseling.I hope you'll enjoy learning and creating new thinking and interacting patterns!
